Context

Homotopy theory

homotopy theory, (‚àû,1)-category theory, homotopy type theory

flavors: stable, equivariant, rational, p-adic, proper, geometric, cohesive, directed‚Ä¶

models: topological, simplicial, localic, ‚Ä¶

see also algebraic topology

Basic notions of homotopy theory

Traditionally, mathematics and physics have been founded on set theory, whose concept of sets is that of ‚Äúbags of distinguishable points‚Äù.

But fundamental physics is governed by the gauge principle. This says that given any two ‚Äúthings‚Äù, such as two field histories xx and yy, it is in general wrong to ask whether they are equal or not, instead one has to ask where there is a gauge transformation

x‚ü∂Œ≥y x \stackrel{\gamma}{\longrightarrow} y

between them. In mathematics this is called a homotopy.

This principle applies also to gauge transformations/homotopies themselves, and thus leads to gauge-of-gauge transformations or homotopies of homotopies

and so on to ever higher gauge transformations or higher homotopies:

This shows that what xx an yy here are elements of is not really a set in the sense of set theory. Instead, such a collection of elements with higher gauge transformations/higher homotopies between them is called a homotopy type.

Hence the theory of homotopy types ‚Äì homotopy theory ‚Äì is much like set theory, but with the concept of gauge transformation/homotopy built right into its foundations. Homotopy theory is gauged mathematics.

A classical model for homotopy types are simply topological spaces: Their points represent the elements, the continuous paths between points represent the gauge transformations, and continuous deformations of paths represent higher gauge transformations. A central result of homotopy theory is the proof of the homotopy hypothesis, which says that under this identification homotopy types are equivalent to topological spaces viewed, in turn, up to ‚Äúweak homotopy equivalence‚Äù.

In the special case of a homotopy type with a single element xx, the gauge transformations necessarily go from xx to itself and hence form a group of symmetries of xx.

This way homotopy theory subsumes group theory.

If there are higher order gauge-of-gauge transformations/homotopies of homotopies between these symmetry group-elements, then one speaks of 2-groups, 3-groups, ‚Ä¶ n-groups, and eventually of ‚àû-groups. When homotopy types are represented by topological spaces, then ‚àû-groups are represented by topological groups.

This way homotopy theory subsumes parts of topological group theory.

Since, generally, there is more than one element in a homotopy type, these are like ‚Äúgroups with several elements‚Äù, and as such they are called groupoids (Def. 77).

If there are higher order gauge-of-gauge transformations/homotopies of homotopies between the transformations in such a groupoid, one speaks of 2-groupoids, 3-groupoids, ‚Ä¶ n-groupoids, and eventually of ‚àû-groupoids. The plain sets are recovered as the special case of 0-groupoids.

Due to the higher orders nn appearing here, mathematical structures based not on sets but on homotopy types are also called higher structures.

Hence homotopy types are equivalently ‚àû-groupoids. This perspective makes explicit that homotopy types are the unification of plain sets with the concept of gauge-symmetry groups.

An efficient way of handling ‚àû-groupoids is in their explicit guise as Kan complexes (Def. 74 below); these are the non-abelian generalization of the chain complexes used in homological algebra. Indeed, chain homotopy is a special case of the general concept of homotopy, and hence homological algebra forms but a special abelian corner within homotopy theory. Conversely, homotopy theory may be understood as the non-abelian generalization of homological algebra.

Hence, in a self-reflective manner, there are many different but equivalent incarnations of homotopy theory. Below we discuss in turn:

  • Topological homotopy theory

    ‚àû-groupoids modeled by topological spaces. This is the classical model of homotopy theory familiar from traditional point-set topology, such as covering space-theory.

  • Simplicial homotopy theory.

    ‚àû-groupoids modeled on simplicial sets, whose fibrant objects are the Kan complexes. This simplicial homotopy theory is Quillen equivalent to topological homotopy theory (the ‚Äúhomotopy hypothesis‚Äù), which makes explicit that homotopy theory is not really about topological spaces, but about the ‚àû-groupoids that these represent.

\,

Ideally, abstract homotopy theory would simply be a complete replacement of set theory, obtained by removing the assumption of strict equality, relaxing it to gauge equivalence/homotopy. As such, abstract homotopy theory would be part and parcel of the foundations of mathematics themselves, not requiring any further discussion. This ideal perspective is the promise of homotopy type theory and may become full practical reality in the next decades.

Until then, abstract homotopy theory has to be formulated on top of the traditional foundations of mathematics provided by set theory, much like one may have to run a Linux emulator on a Windows machine, if one does happen to be stuck with the latter.

A very convenient and powerful such emulator for homotopy theory within set theory is model category theory, originally due to Quillen 67 and highly developed since. This we introduce here.

The idea is to consider ordinary categories (Def. \ref{Categories}) but with the understanding that some of their morphisms

X‚ü∂fY X \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y

should be homotopy equivalences (Def. 31), namely similar to isomorphisms (Def. \ref{Isomorphism}), but not necessarily satisfying the two equations defining an actual isomorphism

f ‚àí1‚àòf=id XAAAAf‚àòf ‚àí1=id Y f^{-1} \circ f \;=\; id_{X} \phantom{AAAA} f \circ f^{-1} \;=\; id_Y

but intended to satisfy this only with equality relaxed to gauge transformation/homotopy:

(1)f ‚àí1‚àòf‚áígaugeid XAAAAf‚àòf ‚àí1‚áígaugeid Y. f^{-1} \circ f \;\overset{gauge}{\Rightarrow}\; id_{X} \phantom{AAAA} f \circ f^{-1} \;\overset{gauge}{\Rightarrow}\; id_Y \,.

Such would-be homotopy equivalences are called weak equivalences (Def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences} below).

In principle, this information already defines a homotopy theory by a construction called simplicial localization, which turns weak equivalences into actual homotopy equivalences in a suitable way (Remark \ref{SimplicialLocalizationOutlook} below).

However, without further tools this construction is very unwieldy. The extra structure of a model category (Def. 1 below) on top of a category with weak equivalences provides a set of tools.

The idea here is to abstract (in Def. 8 below) from the evident concepts in topological homotopy theory of left homotopy (Def. 29) and right homotopy (Def. 34) between continuous functions: These are provided by continuous functions out of a cylinder space Cyl(X)=X√ó[0,1]Cyl(X) = X \times [0,1] or into a path space Path(X)=X [0,1]Path(X) = X^{[0,1]}, respectively, where in both cases the interval space [0,1][0,1] serves to parameterize the relevant gauge transformation/homotopy.

Now a little reflection shows (this was the seminal insight of Quillen 67) that what really matters in this construction of homotopies is that the path space factors the diagonal morphism from a space XX to its Cartesian product as

diag X:X‚ü∂weak equiv. cofibration Path(X)‚ü∂ fibration X√óX diag_X \;\colon\; X \underoverset{\text{weak equiv.}}{\text{ cofibration }}{\longrightarrow} Path(X) \overset{\text{ fibration }}{\longrightarrow} X \times X

while the cylinder serves to factor the codiagonal morphism as

codiag X:X‚äîX‚ü∂cofibrationCyl(X)‚ü∂weak equivfibrationX codiag_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \overset{ \text{cofibration} }{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \underoverset{ \text{weak equiv} }{ \text{fibration} }{\longrightarrow} X

where in both cases ‚Äúfibration‚Äù means something like well behaved surjection, while ‚Äúcofibration‚Äù means something like satisfying the lifting property (Def. 2 below) against fibrations that are also weak equivalences.

Such factorizations subject to lifting properties is what the definition of model category axiomatizes, in some generality. That this indeed provides a good toolbox for handling homotopy equivalences is shown by the Whitehead theorem in model categories (Lemma 5 below), which exhibits all weak equivalences as actual homotopy equivalences after passage to ‚Äúgood representatives‚Äù of objects (fibrant/cofibrant resolutions, Def. 10 below). Accordingly, the first theorem of model category theory (Quillen 67, I.1 theorem 1, reproduced as Theorem 1 below), provides a tractable expression for the hom-sets modulo homotopy equivalence of the underlying category with weak equivalences in terms of actual morphisms out of cofibrant resolutions into fibrant resolutions (Lemma 7 below).

This is then generally how model category-theory serves as a model for homotopy theory: All homotopy-theoretic constructions, such as that of long homotopy fiber sequences (Prop. 25 below), are reflected via constructions of ordinary category theory but applied to suitably resolved objects.

\,

Literature (Dwyer-Spalinski 95)

\,

Definition

(model category)

A model category is

  1. a category ùíû\mathcal{C} (Def. \ref{Categories}) with all limits and colimits (Def. \ref{Limits});

  2. three sub-classes W,Fib,Cof‚äÇMor(ùíû)W, Fib, Cof \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) of its class of morphisms;

such that

  1. the class WW makes ùíû\mathcal{C} into a category with weak equivalences, def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences};

  2. The pairs (W‚à©Cof,Fib)(W \cap Cof\;,\; Fib) and (Cap,W‚à©Fib)(Cap\;,\; W\cap Fib) are both weak factorization systems, def. 3.

One says:

  • elements in WW are weak equivalences,

  • elements in CofCof are cofibrations,

  • elements in FibFib are fibrations,

  • elements in W‚à©CofW\cap Cof are acyclic cofibrations,

  • elements in W‚à©FibW \cap Fib are acyclic fibrations.

The form of def. 1 is due to (Joyal, def. E.1.2). It implies various other conditions that (Quillen 67) demands explicitly, see prop. 1 and prop. 3 below.

We now dicuss the concept of weak factorization systems (Def. 3 below) appearing in def. 1.

Factorization systems

Definition

(lift and extension)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be any category. Given a diagram in ùíû\mathcal{C} of the form

X ‚ü∂f Y p‚Üì B \array{ X &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{p}}\downarrow \\ B }

then an extension of the morphism ff along the morphism pp is a completion to a commuting diagram of the form

X ‚ü∂f Y p‚Üì ‚Üó fÀú B. \array{ X &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{p}}\downarrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\tilde f}} \\ B } \,.

Dually, given a diagram of the form

A ‚Üì p X ‚ü∂f Y \array{ && A \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ X &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

then a lift of ff through pp is a completion to a commuting diagram of the form

A fÀú‚Üó ‚Üì p X ‚ü∂f Y. \array{ && A \\ &{}^{\mathllap{\tilde f}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ X &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Combining these cases: given a commuting square

X 1 ‚ü∂f 1 Y 1 p l‚Üì ‚Üì p r X 2 ‚ü∂f 1 Y 2 \array{ X_1 &\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y_1 \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_l}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_r}} \\ X_2 &\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y_2 }

then a lifting in the diagram is a completion to a commuting diagram of the form

X 1 ‚ü∂f 1 Y 1 p l‚Üì ‚Üó ‚Üì p r X 2 ‚ü∂f 1 Y 2. \array{ X_1 &\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y_1 \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_l}}\downarrow &\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_r}} \\ X_2 &\stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y_2 } \,.

Given a sub-class of morphisms K‚äÇMor(ùíû)K \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}), then

  • a morphism p rp_r as above is said to have the right lifting property against KK or to be a KK-injective morphism if in all square diagrams with p rp_r on the right and any p l‚ààKp_l \in K on the left a lift exists.

dually:

  • a morphism p lp_l is said to have the left lifting property against KK or to be a KK-projective morphism if in all square diagrams with p lp_l on the left and any p r‚ààKp_r \in K on the left a lift exists.
Definition

(weak factorization systems)

A weak factorization system (WFS) on a category ùíû\mathcal{C} is a pair (Proj,Inj)(Proj,Inj) of classes of morphisms of ùíû\mathcal{C} such that

  1. Every morphism f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X\to Y of ùíû\mathcal{C} may be factored as the composition of a morphism in ProjProj followed by one in InjInj

    f:X‚ü∂‚ààProjZ‚ü∂‚ààInjY. f\;\colon\; X \overset{\in Proj}{\longrightarrow} Z \overset{\in Inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

  2. The classes are closed under having the lifting property, def. 2, against each other:

    1. ProjProj is precisely the class of morphisms having the left lifting property against every morphisms in InjInj;

    2. InjInj is precisely the class of morphisms having the right lifting property against every morphisms in ProjProj.

Definition

(functorial factorization)** For $\mathcal{C}$ a [[category?, afunctorial factorization** of the morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C} is a functor

fact:ùíû Œî[1]‚ü∂ùíû Œî[2] fact \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\Delta[2]}

which is a section of the composition functor d 1:ùíû Œî[2]‚Üíùíû Œî[1]d_1 \;\colon \;\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[2]}\to \mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]}.

Remark

In def. 4 we are using the following standard notation, see at simplex category and at nerve of a category:

Write [1]={0‚Üí1}[1] = \{0 \to 1\} and [2]={0‚Üí1‚Üí2}[2] = \{0 \to 1 \to 2\} for the ordinal numbers, regarded as posets and hence as categories. The arrow category Arr(ùíû)Arr(\mathcal{C}) is equivalently the functor category ùíû Œî[1]‚âîFunct(Œî[1],ùíû)\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]} \coloneqq Funct(\Delta[1], \mathcal{C}), while ùíû Œî[2]‚âîFunct(Œî[2],ùíû)\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[2]}\coloneqq Funct(\Delta[2], \mathcal{C}) has as objects pairs of composable morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C}. There are three injective functors Œ¥ i:[1]‚Üí[2]\delta_i \colon [1] \rightarrow [2], where Œ¥ i\delta_i omits the index ii in its image. By precomposition, this induces functors d i:ùíû Œî[2]‚ü∂ùíû Œî[1]d_i \colon \mathcal{C}^{\Delta[2]} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]}. Here

  • d 1d_1 sends a pair of composable morphisms to their composition;

  • d 2d_2 sends a pair of composable morphisms to the first morphisms;

  • d 0d_0 sends a pair of composable morphisms to the second morphisms.

Definition

A weak factorization system, def. 3, is called a functorial weak factorization system if the factorization of morphisms may be chosen to be a functorial factorization factfact, def. 4, i.e. such that d 2‚àòfactd_2 \circ fact lands in ProjProj and d 0‚àòfactd_0\circ fact in InjInj.

Remark

Not all weak factorization systems are functorial, def. 5, although most (including those produced by the small object argument (prop. 4 below), with due care) are.

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a category and let K‚äÇMor(ùíû)K\subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) be a class of morphisms. Write KProjK Proj and KInjK Inj, respectively, for the sub-classes of KK-projective morphisms and of KK-injective morphisms, def. 2. Then:

  1. Both classes contain the class of isomorphism of ùíû\mathcal{C}.

  2. Both classes are closed under composition in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

    KProjK Proj is also closed under transfinite composition.

  3. Both classes are closed under forming retracts in the arrow category ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]} (see remark 3).

  4. KProjK Proj is closed under forming pushouts of morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C} (‚Äúcobase change‚Äù).

    KInjK Inj is closed under forming pullback of morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C} (‚Äúbase change‚Äù).

  5. KProjK Proj is closed under forming coproducts in ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]}.

    KInjK Inj is closed under forming products in ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]}.

Proof

We go through each item in turn.

containing isomorphisms

Given a commuting square

A ‚Üíf X ‚ààIso i‚Üì ‚Üì p B ‚ü∂g Y \array{ A &\overset{f}{\rightarrow}& X \\ {}_{\mathllap{\in Iso}}^{\mathllap{i}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ B &\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

with the left morphism an isomorphism, then a lift is given by using the inverse of this isomorphism f‚àòi ‚àí1‚Üó{}^{{f \circ i^{-1}}}\nearrow. Hence in particular there is a lift when p‚ààKp \in K and so i‚ààKProji \in K Proj. The other case is formally dual.

closure under composition

Given a commuting square of the form

A ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààKInj p 1 ‚ààK i‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààKInj p 2 B ‚ü∂ Y \array{ A &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Inj}} \\ {}^{\mathllap{i}}_{\mathllap{\in K}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_2}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Inj}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& Y }

consider its pasting decomposition as

A ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üò ‚Üì ‚ààKInj p 1 ‚ààK i‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààKInj p 2 B ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Inj}} \\ {}^{\mathllap{i}}_{\mathllap{\in K}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_2}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Inj}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

Now the bottom commuting square has a lift, by assumption. This yields another pasting decomposition

A ‚ü∂ X ‚ààK i‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààKInj p 1 ‚Üì ‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààKInj p 2 B ‚ü∂ Y \array{ A &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i}}_{\mathllap{\in K}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Inj}} \\ \downarrow &\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_2}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Inj}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& Y }

and now the top commuting square has a lift by assumption. This is now equivalently a lift in the total diagram, showing that p 1‚àòp 1p_1\circ p_1 has the right lifting property against KK and is hence in KInjK Inj. The case of composing two morphisms in KProjK Proj is formally dual. From this the closure of KProjK Proj under transfinite composition follows since the latter is given by colimits of sequential composition and successive lifts against the underlying sequence as above constitutes a cocone, whence the extension of the lift to the colimit follows by its universal property.

closure under retracts

Let jj be the retract of an i‚ààKProji \in K Proj, i.e. let there be a commuting diagram of the form.

id A: A ‚ü∂ C ‚ü∂ A ‚Üì j ‚Üì ‚ààKProj i ‚Üì j id B: B ‚ü∂ D ‚ü∂ B. \array{ id_A \colon & A &\longrightarrow& C &\longrightarrow& A \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{j}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Proj}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{j}} \\ id_B \colon & B &\longrightarrow& D &\longrightarrow& B } \,.

Then for

A ‚ü∂ X j‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààK f B ‚ü∂ Y \array{ A &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{j}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& Y }

a commuting square, it is equivalent to its pasting composite with that retract diagram

A ‚ü∂ C ‚ü∂ A ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì j ‚Üì ‚ààKProj i ‚Üì j ‚Üì ‚ààK f B ‚ü∂ D ‚ü∂ B ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& C &\longrightarrow& A &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{j}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i}}_{\mathrlap{\in K Proj}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{j}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& D &\longrightarrow& B &\longrightarrow & Y } \,.

Here the pasting composite of the two squares on the right has a lift, by assumption:

A ‚ü∂ C ‚ü∂ A ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì j ‚Üì i ‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààK f B ‚ü∂ D ‚ü∂ B ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& C &\longrightarrow& A &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{j}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i}}_{} && \nearrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& D &\longrightarrow& B &\longrightarrow & Y } \,.

By composition, this is also a lift in the total outer rectangle, hence in the original square. Hence jj has the left lifting property against all p‚ààKp \in K and hence is in KProjK Proj. The other case is formally dual.

closure under pushout and pullback

Let p‚ààKInjp \in K Inj and and let

Z√ó fX ‚ü∂ X f *p‚Üì ‚Üì p Z ‚ü∂f Y \array{ Z \times_f X &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{{f^* p}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ Z &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow} & Y }

be a pullback diagram in ùíû\mathcal{C}. We need to show that f *pf^* p has the right lifting property with respect to all i‚ààKi \in K. So let

A ‚ü∂ Z√ó fX ‚ààK i‚Üì ‚Üì f *p B ‚ü∂g Z \array{ A &\longrightarrow& Z \times_f X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i}}_{\mathllap{\in K}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\mathrlap{f^* p}}} \\ B &\stackrel{g}{\longrightarrow}& Z }

be a commuting square. We need to construct a diagonal lift of that square. To that end, first consider the pasting composite with the pullback square from above to obtain the commuting diagram

A ‚ü∂ Z√ó fX ‚ü∂ X i‚Üì ‚Üì f *p ‚Üì p B ‚ü∂g Z ‚ü∂f Y. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& Z \times_f X &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f^* p}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ B &\stackrel{g}{\longrightarrow}& Z &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

By the right lifting property of pp, there is a diagonal lift of the total outer diagram

A ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì i (fg)^‚Üó ‚Üì p B ‚ü∂fg Y. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i}} &{}^{\hat {(f g)}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ B &\stackrel{f g}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

By the universal property of the pullback this gives rise to the lift g^\hat g in

Z√ó fX ‚ü∂ X g^‚Üó ‚Üì f *p ‚Üì p B ‚ü∂g Z ‚ü∂f Y. \array{ && Z \times_f X &\longrightarrow& X \\ &{}^{\hat g} \nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f^* p}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ B &\stackrel{g}{\longrightarrow}& Z &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

In order for g^\hat g to qualify as the intended lift of the total diagram, it remains to show that

A ‚ü∂ Z√ó fX ‚Üì i g^‚Üó B \array{ A &\longrightarrow& Z \times_f X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i}} & {}^{\hat g}\nearrow \\ B }

commutes. To do so we notice that we obtain two cones with tip AA:

  • one is given by the morphisms

    1. A‚ÜíZ√ó fX‚ÜíXA \to Z \times_f X \to X
    2. A‚ÜíiB‚ÜígZA \stackrel{i}{\to} B \stackrel{g}{\to} Z

    with universal morphism into the pullback being

    • A‚ÜíZ√ó fXA \to Z \times_f X

  • the other by

    1. A‚ÜíiB‚Üíg^Z√ó fX‚ÜíXA \stackrel{i}{\to} B \stackrel{\hat g}{\to} Z \times_f X \to X
    2. A‚ÜíiB‚ÜígZA \stackrel{i}{\to} B \stackrel{g}{\to} Z.

    with universal morphism into the pullback being

    • A‚ÜíiB‚Üíg^Z√ó fXA \stackrel{i}{\to} B \stackrel{\hat g}{\to} Z \times_f X.

The commutativity of the diagrams that we have established so far shows that the first and second morphisms here equal each other, respectively. By the fact that the universal morphism into a pullback diagram is unique this implies the required identity of morphisms.

The other case is formally dual.

closure under (co-)products

Let {(A s‚Üíi sB s)‚ààKProj} s‚ààS\{(A_s \overset{i_s}{\to} B_s) \in K Proj\}_{s \in S} be a set of elements of KProjK Proj. Since colimits in the presheaf category ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]} are computed componentwise, their coproduct in this arrow category is the universal morphism out of the coproduct of objects ‚àês‚ààSA s\underset{s \in S}{\coprod} A_s induced via its universal property by the set of morphisms i si_s:

‚äîs‚ààSA s‚ü∂(i s) s‚ààS‚äîs‚ààSB s. \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} A_s \overset{(i_s)_{s\in S}}{\longrightarrow} \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} B_s \,.

Now let

‚äîs‚ààSA s ‚ü∂ X (i s) s‚ààS‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààK f ‚äîs‚ààSB s ‚ü∂ Y \array{ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(i_s)_{s\in S}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} B_s &\longrightarrow& Y }

be a commuting square. This is in particular a cocone under the coproduct of objects, hence by the universal property of the coproduct, this is equivalent to a set of commuting diagrams

{A s ‚ü∂ X ‚ààKProj i s‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààK f B s ‚ü∂ Y} s‚ààS. \left\{ \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_s}}_{\mathllap{\in K Proj}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ B_s &\longrightarrow& Y } \;\;\;\; \right\}_{s\in S} \,.

By assumption, each of these has a lift ‚Ñì s\ell_s. The collection of these lifts

{A s ‚ü∂ X ‚ààProj i s‚Üì ‚Ñì s‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààK f B s ‚ü∂ Y} s‚ààS \left\{ \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_s}}_{\mathllap{\in Proj}}\downarrow &{}^{\ell_s}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ B_s &\longrightarrow& Y } \;\;\;\; \right\}_{s\in S}

is now itself a compatible cocone, and so once more by the universal property of the coproduct, this is equivalent to a lift (‚Ñì s) s‚ààS(\ell_s)_{s\in S} in the original square

‚äîs‚ààSA s ‚ü∂ X (i s) s‚ààS‚Üì (‚Ñì s) s‚ààS‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààK f ‚äîs‚ààSB s ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} A_s &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(i_s)_{s\in S}}}\downarrow &{}^{(\ell_s)_{s\in S}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in K}} \\ \underset{s \in S}{\sqcup} B_s &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

This shows that the coproduct of the i si_s has the left lifting property against all f‚ààKf\in K and is hence in KProjK Proj. The other case is formally dual.

An immediate consequence of prop. 1 is this:

Corollary

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a category with all small colimits, and let K‚äÇMor(ùíû)K\subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) be a sub-class of its morphisms. Then every KK-injective morphism, def. 2, has the right lifting property, def. 2, against all KK-relative cell complexes, def. 37 and their retracts, remark 3.

Remark

By a retract of a morphism X‚ü∂fYX \stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow} Y in some category ùíû\mathcal{C} we mean a retract of ff as an object in the arrow category ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]}, hence a morphism A‚ü∂gBA \stackrel{g}{\longrightarrow} B such that in ùíû Œî[1]\mathcal{C}^{\Delta[1]} there is a factorization of the identity on gg through ff

id g:g‚ü∂f‚ü∂g. id_g \;\colon\; g \longrightarrow f \longrightarrow g \,.

This means equivalently that in ùíû\mathcal{C} there is a commuting diagram of the form

id A: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂ A ‚Üì g ‚Üì f ‚Üì g id B: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂ B. \array{ id_A \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\longrightarrow& A \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ id_B \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\longrightarrow& B } \,.
Lemma

In every category CC the class of isomorphisms is preserved under retracts in the sense of remark 3.

Proof

For

id A: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂ A ‚Üì g ‚Üì f ‚Üì g id B: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂ B. \array{ id_A \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\longrightarrow& A \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ id_B \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\longrightarrow& B } \,.

a retract diagram and X‚ÜífYX \overset{f}{\to} Y an isomorphism, the inverse to A‚ÜígBA \overset{g}{\to} B is given by the composite

X ‚ü∂ A ‚Üë f ‚àí1 B ‚ü∂ Y . \array{ & & & X & \longrightarrow & A \\ & && \uparrow^{\mathrlap{f^{-1}}} && \\ & B & \longrightarrow& Y&& } \,.

More generally:

Proposition

Given a model category in the sense of def. 1, then its class of weak equivalences is closed under forming retracts (in the arrow category, see remark 3).

(Joyal, prop. E.1.3)

Proof

Let

id: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂ A f‚Üì ‚Üì w ‚Üì f id: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂ B \array{ id \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\longrightarrow& A \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}} \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{w}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ id \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\longrightarrow& B }

be a commuting diagram in the given model category, with w‚ààWw \in W a weak equivalence. We need to show that then also f‚ààWf \in W.

First consider the case that f‚ààFibf \in Fib.

In this case, factor ww as a cofibration followed by an acyclic fibration. Since w‚ààWw \in W and by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) this is even a factorization through an acyclic cofibration followed by an acyclic fibration. Hence we obtain a commuting diagram of the following form:

id: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂AAAA A id‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Cof ‚Üì id id: A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂s X‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂AAtAA A‚Ä≤ ‚ààFib f‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib ‚Üì ‚ààFib f id: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂AAAA B, \array{ id \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ & {}^{\mathllap{id}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Cof}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ id \colon & A' &\overset{s}{\longrightarrow}& X' &\overset{\phantom{AA}t\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}& A' \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}_{\mathllap{\in Fib}} \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ id \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& B } \,,

where ss is uniquely defined and where tt is any lift of the top middle vertical acyclic cofibration against ff. This now exhibits ff as a retract of an acyclic fibration. These are closed under retract by prop. 1.

Now consider the general case. Factor ff as an acyclic cofibration followed by a fibration and form the pushout in the top left square of the following diagram

id: A ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂AAAA A ‚ààW‚à©Cof‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Cof ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Cof id: A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂ X‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂AAAA A‚Ä≤ ‚ààFib‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW ‚Üì ‚ààFib id: B ‚ü∂ Y ‚ü∂AAAA B, \array{ id \colon & A &\longrightarrow& X &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\in W \cap Cof}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Cof}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Cof}} \\ id \colon & A' &\overset{}{\longrightarrow}& X' &\overset{\phantom{AA}\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}& A' \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\in Fib}} \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W }} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ id \colon & B &\longrightarrow& Y &\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}& B } \,,

where the other three squares are induced by the universal property of the pushout, as is the identification of the middle horizontal composite as the identity on A‚Ä≤A'. Since acyclic cofibrations are closed under forming pushouts by prop. 1, the top middle vertical morphism is now an acyclic fibration, and hence by assumption and by two-out-of-three so is the middle bottom vertical morphism.

Thus the previous case now gives that the bottom left vertical morphism is a weak equivalence, and hence the total left vertical composite is.

Lemma

(retract argument)

Consider a composite morphism

f:X‚ü∂iA‚ü∂pY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{i}{\longrightarrow} A \stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

  1. If ff has the left lifting property against pp, then ff is a retract of ii.

  2. If ff has the right lifting property against ii, then ff is a retract of pp.

Proof

We discuss the first statement, the second is formally dual.

Write the factorization of ff as a commuting square of the form

X ‚ü∂i A f‚Üì ‚Üì p Y = Y. \array{ X &\stackrel{i}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ Y &= & Y } \,.

By the assumed lifting property of ff against pp there exists a diagonal filler gg making a commuting diagram of the form

X ‚ü∂i A f‚Üì g‚Üó ‚Üì p Y = Y. \array{ X &\stackrel{i}{\longrightarrow}& A \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow &{}^{\mathllap{g}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ Y &= & Y } \,.

By rearranging this diagram a little, it is equivalent to

X = X f‚Üì i‚Üì id Y: Y ‚ü∂g A ‚ü∂p Y. \array{ & X &=& X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{i}}\downarrow \\ id_Y \colon & Y &\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}& A &\underset{p}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Completing this to the right, this yields a diagram exhibiting the required retract according to remark 3:

id X: X = X = X f‚Üì i‚Üì f‚Üì id Y: Y ‚ü∂g A ‚ü∂p Y. \array{ id_X \colon & X &=& X &=& X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{i}}\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow \\ id_Y \colon & Y &\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}& A &\underset{p}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Small object argument

Given a set C‚äÇMor(ùíû)C \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) of morphisms in some category ùíû\mathcal{C}, a natural question is how to factor any given morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y through a relative CC-cell complex, def. 37, followed by a CC-injective morphism, def. 39

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCcellX^‚ü∂‚ààCinjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in C cell}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in C inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

A first approximation to such a factorization turns out to be given simply by forming X^=X 1\hat X = X_1 by attaching all possible CC-cells to XX. Namely let

(C/f)‚âî{dom(c) ‚ü∂ X c‚ààC‚Üì ‚Üì f cod(c) ‚ü∂ Y} (C/f) \coloneqq \left\{ \array{ dom(c) &\stackrel{}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{c\in C}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ cod(c) &\longrightarrow& Y } \right\}

be the set of all ways to find a CC-cell attachment in ff, and consider the pushout X^\hat X of the coproduct of morphisms in CC over all these:

‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) ‚ü∂ X ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)c‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)cod(c) ‚ü∂ X 1. \array{ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} c}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} cod(c) &\longrightarrow& X_1 } \,.

This gets already close to producing the intended factorization:

First of all the resulting map X‚ÜíX 1X \to X_1 is a CC-relative cell complex, by construction.

Second, by the fact that the coproduct is over all commuting squres to ff, the morphism ff itself makes a commuting diagram

‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) ‚ü∂ X ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)c‚Üì ‚Üì f ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)cod(c) ‚ü∂ Y \array{ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} c}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} cod(c) &\longrightarrow& Y }

and hence the universal property of the colimit means that ff is indeed factored through that CC-cell complex X 1X_1; we may suggestively arrange that factorizing diagram like so:

‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) ‚ü∂ X id‚Üì ‚Üì ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)dom(c) X 1 ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)c‚Üì ‚Üó ‚Üì ‚àêc‚àà(C/f)cod(c) ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{id}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} dom(c) && X_1 \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} c}}\downarrow &\nearrow& \downarrow \\ \underset{c\in(C/f)}{\coprod} cod(c) &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

This shows that, finally, the colimiting co-cone map ‚Äì the one that now appears diagonally ‚Äì almost exhibits the desired right lifting of X 1‚ÜíYX_1 \to Y against the c‚ààCc\in C. The failure of that to hold on the nose is only the fact that a horizontal map in the middle of the above diagram is missing: the diagonal map obtained above lifts not all commuting diagrams of c‚ààCc\in C into ff, but only those where the top morphism dom(c)‚ÜíX 1dom(c) \to X_1 factors through X‚ÜíX 1X \to X_1.

The idea of the small object argument now is to fix this only remaining problem by iterating the construction: next factor X 1‚ÜíYX_1 \to Y in the same way into

X 1‚ü∂X 2‚ü∂Y X_1 \longrightarrow X_2 \longrightarrow Y

and so forth. Since relative CC-cell complexes are closed under composition, at stage nn the resulting X‚ü∂X nX \longrightarrow X_n is still a CC-cell complex, getting bigger and bigger. But accordingly, the failure of the accompanying X n‚ü∂YX_n \longrightarrow Y to be a CC-injective morphism becomes smaller and smaller, for it now lifts against all diagrams where dom(c)‚ü∂X ndom(c) \longrightarrow X_n factors through X n‚àí1‚ü∂X nX_{n-1}\longrightarrow X_n, which intuitively is less and less of a condition as the X n‚àí1X_{n-1} grow larger and larger.

The concept of small object is just what makes this intuition precise and finishes the small object argument. For the present purpose we just need the following simple version:

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a category and C‚äÇMor(ùíû)C \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) a sub-set of its morphisms, say that these have small domains if there is an ordinal Œ±\alpha (def. 25) such that for every c‚ààCc\in C and for every CC-relative cell complex given by a transfinite composition (def. 26)

f:X‚ÜíX 1‚ÜíX 2‚Üí‚ãØ‚ÜíX Œ≤‚Üí‚ãØ‚ü∂X^ f \;\colon\; X \to X_1 \to X_2 \to \cdots \to X_\beta \to \cdots \longrightarrow \hat X

every morphism dom(c)‚ü∂X^dom(c)\longrightarrow \hat X factors through a stage X Œ≤‚ÜíX^X_\beta \to \hat X of order Œ≤<Œ±\beta \lt \alpha:

X Œ≤ ‚Üó ‚Üì dom(c) ‚ü∂ X^. \array{ && X_\beta \\ & \nearrow & \downarrow \\ dom(c) &\longrightarrow& \hat X } \,.

The above discussion proves the following:

Proposition

(small object argument)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a locally small category with all small colimits. If a set C‚äÇMor(ùíû)C\subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) of morphisms has all small domains in the sense of def. 6, then every morphism f:X‚ü∂f\colon X\longrightarrow in ùíû\mathcal{C} factors through a CC-relative cell complex, def. 37, followed by a CC-injective morphism, def. 39

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCcellX^‚ü∂‚ààCinjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in C cell}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in C inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

(Quillen 67, II.3 lemma)

Homotopy

We discuss how the concept of homotopy is abstractly realized in model categories, def. 1.

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category, def. 1, and X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} an object.

  • A path space object Path(X)Path(X) for XX is a factorization of the diagonal Œî X:X‚ÜíX√óX\Delta_X \;\colon\; X \to X \times X as
Œî X:X‚ü∂‚ààWiPath(X)‚ü∂‚ààFib(p 0,p 1)X√óX. \Delta_X \;\colon\; X \underoverset{\in W}{i}{\longrightarrow} Path(X) \underoverset{\in Fib}{(p_0,p_1)}{\longrightarrow} X \times X \,.

where X‚ÜíPath(X)X\to Path(X) is a weak equivalence and Path(X)‚ÜíX√óXPath(X) \to X \times X is a fibration.

  • A cylinder object Cyl(X)Cyl(X) for XX is a factorization of the codiagonal (or ‚Äúfold map‚Äù) ‚àá X:X‚äîX‚ÜíX\nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \to X as
‚àá X:X‚äîX‚ü∂‚ààCof(i 0,i 1)Cyl(X)‚ü∂‚ààWpX. \nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \underoverset{\in Cof}{(i_0,i_1)}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \underoverset{\in W}{p}{\longrightarrow} X \,.

where Cyl(X)‚ÜíXCyl(X) \to X is a weak equivalence. and X‚äîX‚ÜíCyl(X)X \sqcup X \to Cyl(X) is a cofibration.

Remark

For every object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} in a model category, a cylinder object and a path space object according to def. 7 exist: the factorization axioms guarantee that there exists

  1. a factorization of the codiagonal as

    ‚àá X:X‚äîX‚ü∂‚ààCofCyl(X)‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©FibX \nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \overset{\in Cof}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow} X

  2. a factorization of the diagonal as

    Œî X:X‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©CofPath(X)‚ü∂‚ààFibX√óX. \Delta_X \;\colon\; X \overset{\in W \cap Cof}{\longrightarrow} Path(X) \overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} X \times X \,.

The cylinder and path space objects obtained this way are actually better than required by def. 7: in addition to Cyl(X)‚ÜíXCyl(X)\to X being just a weak equivalence, for these this is actually an acyclic fibration, and dually in addition to X‚ÜíPath(X)X\to Path(X) being a weak equivalence, for these it is actually an acyclic cofibrations.

Some authors call cylinder/path-space objects with this extra property ‚Äúvery good‚Äù cylinder/path-space objects, respectively.

One may also consider dropping a condition in def. 7: what mainly matters is the weak equivalence, hence some authors take cylinder/path-space objects to be defined as in def. 7 but without the condition that X‚äîX‚ÜíCyl(X)X \sqcup X\to Cyl(X) is a cofibration and without the condition that Path(X)‚ÜíXPath(X) \to X is a fibration. Such authors would then refer to the concept in def. 7 as ‚Äúgood‚Äù cylinder/path-space objects.

The terminology in def. 7 follows the original (Quillen 67, I.1 def. 4). With the induced concept of left/right homotopy below in def. 8, this admits a quick derivation of the key facts in the following, as we spell out below.

Lemma

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category. If X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} is cofibrant, then for every cylinder object Cyl(X)Cyl(X) of XX, def. 7, not only is (i 0,i 1):X‚äîX‚ÜíX(i_0,i_1) \colon X \sqcup X \to X a cofibration, but each

i 0,i 1:X‚ü∂Cyl(X) i_0, i_1 \colon X \longrightarrow Cyl(X)

is an acyclic cofibration separately.

Dually, if X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} is fibrant, then for every path space object Path(X)Path(X) of XX, def. 7, not only is (p 0,p 1):Path(X)‚ÜíX√óX(p_0,p_1) \colon Path(X)\to X \times X a cofibration, but each

p 0,p 1:Path(X)‚ü∂X p_0, p_1 \colon Path(X) \longrightarrow X

is an acyclic fibration separately.

Proof

We discuss the case of the path space object. The other case is formally dual.

First, that the component maps are weak equivalences follows generally: by definition they have a right inverse Path(X)‚ÜíXPath(X) \to X and so this follows by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

But if XX is fibrant, then also the two projection maps out of the product X√óX‚ÜíXX \times X \to X are fibrations, because they are both pullbacks of the fibration X‚Üí*X \to \ast

X√óX ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì X ‚ü∂ *. \array{ X\times X &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow \\ X &\longrightarrow& \ast } \,.

hence p i:Path(X)‚ÜíX√óX‚ÜíXp_i \colon Path(X)\to X \times X \to X is the composite of two fibrations, and hence itself a fibration, by prop. 1.

Path space objects are very non-unique as objects up to isomorphism:

Example

If X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} is a fibrant object in a model category, def. 1, and for Path 1(X)Path_1(X) and Path 2(X)Path_2(X) two path space objects for XX, def. 7, then the fiber product Path 1(X)√ó XPath 2(X)Path_1(X) \times_X Path_2(X) is another path space object for XX: the pullback square

X ‚ü∂Œî X X√óX ‚Üì ‚Üì Path 1(X)√óXPath 2(X) ‚ü∂ Path 1(X)√óPath 2(X) ‚ààFib‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààFib X√óX√óX ‚ü∂(id,Œî X,id) X√óX√óX√óX ‚Üì ‚ààFib (pr 1,pr 3) ‚Üì (p 1,p 4) X√óX = X√óX \array{ X &\overset{\Delta_X}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ Path_1(X) \underset{X}{\times} Path_2(X) &\longrightarrow& Path_1(X)\times Path_2(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ X \times X \times X &\overset{(id,\Delta_X,id)}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X\times X \times X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(pr_1,pr_3)}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p_1, p_4)}} \\ X\times X &=& X \times X }

gives that the induced projection is again a fibration. Moreover, using lemma 3 and two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) gives that X‚ÜíPath 1(X)√ó XPath 2(X)X \to Path_1(X) \times_X Path_2(X) is a weak equivalence.

For the case of the canonical topological path space objects of def 33, with Path 1(X)=Path 2(X)=X I=X [0,1]Path_1(X) = Path_2(X) = X^I = X^{[0,1]} then this new path space object is X I‚à®I=X [0,2]X^{I \vee I} = X^{[0,2]}, the mapping space out of the standard interval of length 2 instead of length 1.

Definition

(abstract left homotopy and abstract right homotopy

Let f,g:X‚ü∂Yf,g \colon X \longrightarrow Y be two parallel morphisms in a model category.

  • A left homotopy Œ∑:f‚áí Lg\eta \colon f \Rightarrow_L g is a morphism Œ∑:Cyl(X)‚ü∂Y\eta \colon Cyl(X) \longrightarrow Y from a cylinder object of XX, def. 7, such that it makes this diagram commute:
X ‚ü∂ Cyl(X) ‚üµ X f‚Üò ‚Üì Œ∑ ‚Üô g Y. \array{ X &\longrightarrow& Cyl(X) &\longleftarrow& X \\ & {}_{\mathllap{f}}\searrow &\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}}& \swarrow_{\mathrlap{g}} \\ && Y } \,.
  • A right homotopy Œ∑:f‚áí Rg\eta \colon f \Rightarrow_R g is a morphism Œ∑:X‚ÜíPath(Y)\eta \colon X \to Path(Y) to some path space object of XX, def. 7, such that this diagram commutes:
X f‚Üô ‚Üì Œ∑ ‚Üò g Y ‚üµ Path(Y) ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ && X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\swarrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}} & \searrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ Y &\longleftarrow& Path(Y) &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.
Lemma

Let f,g:X‚ÜíYf,g \colon X \to Y be two parallel morphisms in a model category.

  1. Let XX be cofibrant. If there is a left homotopy f‚áí Lgf \Rightarrow_L g then there is also a right homotopy f‚áí Rgf \Rightarrow_R g (def. 8) with respect to any chosen path space object.

  2. Let XX be fibrant. If there is a right homotopy f‚áí Rgf \Rightarrow_R g then there is also a left homotopy f‚áí Lgf \Rightarrow_L g with respect to any chosen cylinder object.

In particular if XX is cofibrant and YY is fibrant, then by going back and forth it follows that every left homotopy is exhibited by every cylinder object, and every right homotopy is exhibited by every path space object.

Proof

We discuss the first case, the second is formally dual. Let Œ∑:Cyl(X)‚ü∂Y\eta \colon Cyl(X) \longrightarrow Y be the given left homotopy. Lemma 3 implies that we have a lift hh in the following commuting diagram

X ‚ü∂i‚àòf Path(Y) ‚ààW‚à©Cof i 0‚Üì h‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààFib p 0,p 1 Cyl(X) ‚ü∂(f‚àòp,Œ∑) Y√óY, \array{ X &\overset{i \circ f}{\longrightarrow}& Path(Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}_{\mathllap{\in W \cap Cof}}\downarrow &{}^{\mathllap{h}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0,p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ Cyl(X) &\underset{(f \circ p,\eta)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,,

where on the right we have the chosen path space object. Now the composite Œ∑Àú‚âîh‚àòi 1\tilde \eta \coloneqq h \circ i_1 is a right homotopy as required:

Path(Y) h‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààFib p 0,p 1 X ‚ü∂i 1 Cyl(X) ‚ü∂(f‚àòp,Œ∑) Y√óY. \array{ && && Path(Y) \\ && &{}^{\mathllap{h}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0,p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ X &\overset{i_1}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(X) &\underset{(f \circ p,\eta)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,.
Proposition

For XX a cofibrant object in a model category and YY a fibrant object, then the relations of left homotopy f‚áí Lgf \Rightarrow_L g and of right homotopy f‚áí Rgf \Rightarrow_R g (def. 8) on the hom set Hom(X,Y)Hom(X,Y) coincide and are both equivalence relations.

Proof

That both relations coincide under the (co-)fibrancy assumption follows directly from lemma 4.

The symmetry and reflexivity of the relation is obvious.

That right homotopy (hence also left homotopy) with domain XX is a transitive relation follows from using example 1 to compose path space objects.

The homotopy category

We discuss the construction that takes a model category, def. 1, and then universally forces all its weak equivalences into actual isomorphisms.

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category, def. 1. Write Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) for the category whose

  • objects are those objects of ùíû\mathcal{C} which are both fibrant and cofibrant;

  • morphisms are the homotopy classes of morphisms of ùíû\mathcal{C}, hence the equivalence classes of morphism under the equivalence relation of prop. 5;

and whose composition operation is given on representatives by composition in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

This is, up to equivalence of categories, the homotopy category of the model category ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Proposition

Def. 9 is well defined, in that composition of morphisms between fibrant-cofibrant objects in ùíû\mathcal{C} indeed passes to homotopy classes.

Proof

Fix any morphism X‚ÜífYX \overset{f}{\to} Y between fibrant-cofibrant objects. Then for precomposition

(‚àí)‚àò[f]:Hom Ho(ùíû)(Y,Z)‚ÜíHom Ho(ùíû(X,Z)) (-) \circ [f] \;\colon\; Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(Y,Z) \to Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C}(X,Z))}

to be well defined, we need that with (g‚àºh):Y‚ÜíZ(g\sim h)\;\colon\; Y \to Z also (fg‚àºfh):X‚ÜíZ(f g \sim f h)\;\colon\; X \to Z. But by prop 5 we may take the homotopy ‚àº\sim to be exhibited by a right homotopy Œ∑:Y‚ÜíPath(Z)\eta \colon Y \to Path(Z), for which case the statement is evident from this diagram:

Z g‚Üó ‚Üë p 1 X ‚ü∂f Y ‚ü∂Œ∑ Path(Z) h‚Üò ‚Üì p 0 Z. \array{ && && Z \\ && & {}^{\mathllap{g}}\nearrow & \uparrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}} \\ X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow} & Y &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Path(Z) \\ && & {}_{\mathllap{h}}\searrow & \downarrow_{\mathrlap{p_0}} \\ && && Z } \,.

For postcomposition we may choose to exhibit homotopy by left homotopy and argue dually.

We now spell out that def. 9 indeed satisfies the universal property that defines the localization of a category with weak equivalences at its weak equivalences.

Lemma

(Whitehead theorem in model categories)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category. A weak equivalence between two objects which are both fibrant and cofibrant is a homotopy equivalence (1).

Proof

By the factorization axioms in the model category ùíû\mathcal{C} and by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}), every weak equivalence f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y factors through an object ZZ as an acyclic cofibration followed by an acyclic fibration. In particular it follows that with XX and YY both fibrant and cofibrant, so is ZZ, and hence it is sufficient to prove that acyclic (co-)fibrations between such objects are homotopy equivalences.

So let f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y be an acyclic fibration between fibrant-cofibrant objects, the case of acyclic cofibrations is formally dual. Then in fact it has a genuine right inverse given by a lift f ‚àí1f^{-1} in the diagram

‚àÖ ‚Üí X ‚ààcof‚Üì f ‚àí1‚Üó ‚Üì ‚ààFib‚à©W f X = X. \array{ \emptyset &\rightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in cof}}\downarrow &{}^{{f^{-1}}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib \cap W}} \\ X &=& X } \,.

To see that f ‚àí1f^{-1} is also a left inverse up to left homotopy, let Cyl(X)Cyl(X) be any cylinder object on XX (def. 7), hence a factorization of the codiagonal on XX as a cofibration followed by a an acyclic fibration

X‚äîX‚ü∂Œπ XCyl(X)‚ü∂pX X \sqcup X \stackrel{\iota_X}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow} X

and consider the commuting square

X‚äîX ‚ü∂(f ‚àí1‚àòf,id) X Œπ X ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib f Cyl(X) ‚ü∂f‚àòp Y, \array{ X \sqcup X &\stackrel{(f^{-1}\circ f, id)}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_X}}{}_{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ Cyl(X) &\underset{f\circ p}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,,

which commutes due to f ‚àí1f^{-1} being a genuine right inverse of ff. By construction, this commuting square now admits a lift Œ∑\eta, and that constitutes a left homotopy Œ∑:f ‚àí1‚àòf‚áí Lid\eta \colon f^{-1}\circ f \Rightarrow_L id.

Definition

(fibrant resolution and cofibrant resolution)

Given a model category ùíû\mathcal{C}, consider a choice for each object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} of

  1. a factorization ‚àÖ‚ü∂‚ààCofi XQX‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fibp XX\emptyset \underoverset{\in Cof}{i_X}{\longrightarrow} Q X \underoverset{\in W \cap Fib}{p_X}{\longrightarrow} X of the initial morphism, such that when XX is already cofibrant then p X=id Xp_X = id_X;

  2. a factorization X‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Cofj XPX‚ü∂‚ààFibq X*X \underoverset{\in W \cap Cof}{j_X}{\longrightarrow} P X \underoverset{\in Fib}{q_X}{\longrightarrow} \ast of the terminal morphism, such that when XX is already fibrant then j X=id Xj_X = id_X.

Write then

Œ≥ P,Q:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû) \gamma_{P,Q} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C})

for the functor to the homotopy category, def. 9, which sends an object XX to the object PQXP Q X and sends a morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y to the homotopy class of the result of first lifting in

‚àÖ ‚ü∂ QY i X‚Üì Qf‚Üó ‚Üì p Y QX ‚ü∂f‚àòp X Y \array{ \emptyset &\longrightarrow& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_X}}\downarrow &{}^{Q f}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_Y}} \\ Q X &\underset{f\circ p_X}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

and then lifting (here: extending) in

QX ‚ü∂j QY‚àòQf PQY j QX‚Üì PQf‚Üó ‚Üì q QY PQX ‚ü∂ *. \array{ Q X &\overset{j_{Q Y} \circ Q f}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{j_{Q X}}}\downarrow &{}^{P Q f}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{q_{Q Y}}} \\ P Q X &\longrightarrow& \ast } \,.
Lemma

The construction in def. 10 is indeed well defined.

Proof

First of all, the object PQXP Q X is indeed both fibrant and cofibrant (as well as related by a zig-zag of weak equivalences to XX):

‚àÖ ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üò ‚ààCof QX ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Cof PQX ‚ü∂‚ààFib * ‚ààW‚Üì X. \array{ \emptyset \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{\in Cof}} \\ Q X &\underset{\in W \cap Cof}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X &\underset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& \ast \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow \\ X } \,.

Now to see that the image on morphisms is well defined. First observe that any two choices (Qf) i(Q f)_{i} of the first lift in the definition are left homotopic to each other, exhibited by lifting in

QX‚äîQX ‚ü∂((Qf) 1,(Qf) 2) QY ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib p Y Cyl(QX) ‚ü∂f‚àòp X‚àòœÉ QX Y. \array{ Q X \sqcup Q X &\stackrel{((Q f)_1, (Q f)_2 )}{\longrightarrow}& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_{Y}}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ Cyl(Q X) &\underset{f \circ p_{X} \circ \sigma_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Hence also the composites j QY‚àò(Q f) ij_{Q Y}\circ (Q_f)_i are left homotopic to each other, and since their domain is cofibrant, then by lemma 4 they are also right homotopic by a right homotopy Œ∫\kappa. This implies finally, by lifting in

QX ‚ü∂Œ∫ Path(PQY) ‚ààW‚à©Cof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààFib PQX ‚ü∂(R(Qf) 1,P(Qf) 2) PQY√óPQY \array{ Q X &\overset{\kappa}{\longrightarrow}& Path(P Q Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W \cap Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ P Q X &\underset{(R (Q f)_1, P (Q f)_2)}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y \times P Q Y }

that also P(Qf) 1P (Q f)_1 and P(Qf) 2P (Q f)_2 are right homotopic, hence that indeed PQfP Q f represents a well-defined homotopy class.

Finally to see that the assignment is indeed functorial, observe that the commutativity of the lifting diagrams for QfQ f and PQfP Q f imply that also the following diagram commutes

X ‚üµp X QX ‚ü∂j QX PQX f‚Üì ‚Üì Qf ‚Üì PQf Y ‚üµp y QY ‚ü∂j QY PQY. \array{ X &\overset{p_X}{\longleftarrow}& Q X &\overset{j_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q f}} \\ Y &\underset{p_y}{\longleftarrow}& Q Y &\underset{j_{Q Y}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y } \,.

Now from the pasting composite

X ‚üµp X QX ‚ü∂j QX PQX f‚Üì ‚Üì Qf ‚Üì PQf Y ‚üµp Y QY ‚ü∂j QY PQY g‚Üì ‚Üì Qg ‚Üì PQg Z ‚üµp Z QZ ‚ü∂j QZ PQZ \array{ X &\overset{p_X}{\longleftarrow}& Q X &\overset{j_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q f}} \\ Y &\underset{p_Y}{\longleftarrow}& Q Y &\underset{j_{Q Y}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{g}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q g}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q g}} \\ Z &\underset{p_Z}{\longleftarrow}& Q Z &\underset{j_{Q Z}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Z }

one sees that (PQg)‚àò(PQf)(P Q g)\circ (P Q f) is a lift of g‚àòfg \circ f and hence the same argument as above gives that it is homotopic to the chosen PQ(g‚àòf)P Q(g \circ f).

For the following, recall the concept of natural isomorphism between functors: for F,G:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF, G \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} two functors, then a natural transformation Œ∑:F‚áíG\eta \colon F \Rightarrow G is for each object c‚ààObj(ùíû)c \in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a morphism Œ∑ c:F(c)‚ü∂G(c)\eta_c \colon F(c) \longrightarrow G(c) in ùíü\mathcal{D}, such that for each morphism f:c 1‚Üíc 2f \colon c_1 \to c_2 in ùíû\mathcal{C} the following is a commuting square:

F(c 1) ‚ü∂Œ∑ c 1 G(c 1) F(f)‚Üì ‚Üì G(f) F(c 2) ‚ü∂Œ∑ c 2 G(c 2). \array{ F(c_1) &\overset{\eta_{c_1}}{\longrightarrow}& G(c_1) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{G(f)}} \\ F(c_2) &\underset{\eta_{c_2}}{\longrightarrow}& G(c_2) } \,.

Such Œ∑\eta is called a natural isomorphism if its Œ∑ c\eta_c are isomorphisms for all objects cc.

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a category with weak equivalences, its localization at the weak equivalences is, if it exists,

  1. a category denoted ùíû[W ‚àí1]\mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]

  2. a functor

    Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂ùíû[W ‚àí1] \gamma \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]

such that

  1. Œ≥\gamma sends weak equivalences to isomorphisms;

  2. Œ≥\gamma is universal with this property, in that:

    for F:ùíû‚ü∂DF \colon \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow D any functor out of ùíû\mathcal{C} into any category DD, such that FF takes weak equivalences to isomorphisms, it factors through Œ≥\gamma up to a natural isomorphism œÅ\rho

    ùíû ‚ü∂F D Œ≥‚Üò ‚áì œÅ ‚Üó FÀú Ho(ùíû) \array{ \mathcal{C} && \overset{F}{\longrightarrow} && D \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\gamma}}\searrow &\Downarrow^{\rho}& \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\tilde F}} \\ && Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

    and this factorization is unique up to unique isomorphism, in that for (FÀú 1,œÅ 1)(\tilde F_1, \rho_1) and (FÀú 2,œÅ 2)(\tilde F_2, \rho_2) two such factorizations, then there is a unique natural isomorphism Œ∫:FÀú 1‚áíFÀú 2\kappa \colon \tilde F_1 \Rightarrow \tilde F_2 making the evident diagram of natural isomorphisms commute.

Theorem

(convenient localization of model categories)

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a model category, the functor Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} in def. 10 (for any choice of PP and QQ) exhibits Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) as indeed being the localization of the underlying category with weak equivalences at its weak equivalences, in the sense of def. 11:

ùíû = ùíû Œ≥ P,Q‚Üì ‚Üì Œ≥ Ho(ùíû) ‚âÉ ùíû[W ‚àí1]. \array{ \mathcal{C} &=& \mathcal{C} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{P,Q}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\simeq& \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}] } \,.

(Quillen 67, I.1 theorem 1)

Proof

First, to see that that Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} indeed takes weak equivalences to isomorphisms: By two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) applied to the commuting diagrams shown in the proof of lemma 6, the morphism PQfP Q f is a weak equivalence if ff is:

X ‚üµ‚âÉp X QX ‚ü∂‚âÉj QX PQX f‚Üì ‚Üì Qf ‚Üì PQf Y ‚üµp y‚âÉ QY ‚ü∂j QY‚âÉ PQY \array{ X &\underoverset{\simeq}{p_X}{\longleftarrow}& Q X &\underoverset{\simeq}{j_{Q X}}{\longrightarrow}& P Q X \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Q f}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{P Q f}} \\ Y &\underoverset{p_y}{\simeq}{\longleftarrow}& Q Y &\underoverset{j_{Q Y}}{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& P Q Y }

With this the ‚ÄúWhitehead theorem for model categories‚Äù, lemma 5, implies that PQfP Q f represents an isomorphism in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}).

Now let F:ùíû‚ü∂DF \colon \mathcal{C}\longrightarrow D be any functor that sends weak equivalences to isomorphisms. We need to show that it factors as

ùíû ‚ü∂F D Œ≥‚Üò ‚áì œÅ ‚Üó FÀú Ho(ùíû) \array{ \mathcal{C} && \overset{F}{\longrightarrow} && D \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\gamma}}\searrow &\Downarrow^{\rho}& \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\tilde F}} \\ && Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

uniquely up to unique natural isomorphism. Now by construction of PP and QQ in def. 10, Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} is the identity on the full subcategory of fibrant-cofibrant objects. It follows that if FÀú\tilde F exists at all, it must satisfy for all X‚ÜífYX \stackrel{f}{\to} Y with XX and YY both fibrant and cofibrant that

FÀú([f])‚âÉF(f), \tilde F([f]) \simeq F(f) \,,

(hence in particular FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(f))=F(PQf)\tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(f)) = F(P Q f)).

But by def. 9 that already fixes FÀú\tilde F on all of Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}), up to unique natural isomorphism. Hence it only remains to check that with this definition of FÀú\tilde F there exists any natural isomorphism œÅ\rho filling the diagram above.

To that end, apply FF to the above commuting diagram to obtain

F(X) ‚üµisoF(p X) F(QX) ‚ü∂isoF(j QX) F(PQX) F(f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(Qf) ‚Üì F(PQf) F(Y) ‚üµF(p y)iso F(QY) ‚ü∂F(j QY)iso F(PQY). \array{ F(X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(p_X)}{\longleftarrow}& F(Q X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(j_{Q X})}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(Q f)}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(P Q f)}} \\ F(Y) &\underoverset{F(p_y)}{iso}{\longleftarrow}& F(Q Y) &\underoverset{F(j_{Q Y})}{iso}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q Y) } \,.

Here now all horizontal morphisms are isomorphisms, by assumption on FF. It follows that defining œÅ X‚âîF(j QX)‚àòF(p X) ‚àí1\rho_X \coloneqq F(j_{Q X}) \circ F(p_X)^{-1} makes the required natural isomorphism:

œÅ X: F(X) ‚ü∂isoF(p X) ‚àí1 F(QX) ‚ü∂isoF(j QX) F(PQX) = FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(X)) F(f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(PQf) ‚Üì FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(f)) œÅ Y: F(Y) ‚ü∂F(p y) ‚àí1iso F(QY) ‚ü∂F(j QY)iso F(PQY) = FÀú(Œ≥ P,Q(X)). \array{ \rho_X \colon & F(X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(p_X)^{-1}}{\longrightarrow}& F(Q X) &\underoverset{iso}{F(j_{Q X})}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q X) &=& \tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(X)) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(P Q f)}} && \downarrow^{\tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(f))} \\ \rho_Y\colon& F(Y) &\underoverset{F(p_y)^{-1}}{iso}{\longrightarrow}& F(Q Y) &\underoverset{F(j_{Q Y})}{iso}{\longrightarrow}& F(P Q Y) &=& \tilde F(\gamma_{P,Q}(X)) } \,.
Remark

Due to theorem 1 we may suppress the choices of cofibrant QQ and fibrant replacement PP in def. 10 and just speak of the localization functor

Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû) \gamma \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C})

up to natural isomorphism.

In general, the localization ùíû[W ‚àí1]\mathcal{C}[W^{-1}] of a category with weak equivalences (ùíû,W)(\mathcal{C},W) (def. 11) may invert more morphisms than just those in WW. However, if the category admits the structure of a model category (ùíû,W,Cof,Fib)(\mathcal{C},W,Cof,Fib), then its localization precisely only inverts the weak equivalences.

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category (def. 1) and let Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû)\gamma \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}) be its localization functor (def. 10, theorem 1). Then a morphism ff in ùíû\mathcal{C} is a weak equivalence precisely if Œ≥(f)\gamma(f) is an isomorphism in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}).

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 96, II, prop 1.14)

While the construction of the homotopy category in def. 9 combines the restriction to good (fibrant/cofibrant) objects with the passage to homotopy classes of morphisms, it is often useful to consider intermediate stages:

Definition

Given a model category ùíû\mathcal{C}, write

ùíû fc ‚Üô ‚Üò ùíû c ùíû f ‚Üò ‚Üô ùíû \array{ && \mathcal{C}_{f c} \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ \mathcal{C}_c && && \mathcal{C}_f \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && \mathcal{C} }

for the system of full subcategory inclusions of:

  1. the category of fibrant objects ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f

  2. the category of cofibrant objects ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c,

  3. the category of fibrant-cofibrant objects ùíû fc\mathcal{C}_{fc},

all regarded a categories with weak equivalences (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}), via the weak equivalences inherited from ùíû\mathcal{C}, which we write (ùíû f,W f)(\mathcal{C}_f, W_f), (ùíû c,W c)(\mathcal{C}_c, W_c) and (ùíû fc,W fc)(\mathcal{C}_{f c}, W_{f c}).

Remark

(categories of fibrant objects and cofibration categories)

Of course the subcategories in def. 12 inherit more structure than just that of categories with weak equivalences from ùíû\mathcal{C}. ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f and ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c each inherit ‚Äúhalf‚Äù of the factorization axioms. One says that ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f has the structure of a ‚Äúfibration category‚Äù called a ‚ÄúBrown-category of fibrant objects‚Äù, while ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c has the structure of a ‚Äúcofibration category‚Äù.

We discuss properties of these categories of (co-)fibrant objects below in Homotopy fiber sequences.

The proof of theorem 1 immediately implies the following:

Corollary

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a model category, the restriction of the localization functor Œ≥:ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû)\gamma\;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}) from def. 10 (using remark 5) to any of the sub-categories with weak equivalences of def. 12

ùíû fc ‚Üô ‚Üò ùíû c ùíû f ‚Üò ‚Üô ùíû ‚Üì Œ≥ Ho(ùíû) \array{ && \mathcal{C}_{f c} \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ \mathcal{C}_c && && \mathcal{C}_f \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && \mathcal{C} \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma}} \\ && Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

exhibits Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) equivalently as the localization also of these subcategories with weak equivalences, at their weak equivalences. In particular there are equivalences of categories

Ho(ùíû)‚âÉùíû[W ‚àí1]‚âÉùíû f[W f ‚àí1]‚âÉùíû c[W c ‚àí1]‚âÉùíû fc[W fc ‚àí1]. Ho(\mathcal{C}) \simeq \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}] \simeq \mathcal{C}_f[W_f^{-1}] \simeq \mathcal{C}_c[W_c^{-1}] \simeq \mathcal{C}_{f c}[W_{f c}^{-1}] \,.

The following says that for computing the hom-sets in the homotopy category, even a mixed variant of the above will do; it is sufficient that the domain is cofibrant and the codomain is fibrant:

Lemma

(hom-sets of homotopy category via mapping cofibrant resolutions into fibrant resolutions)

For X,Y‚ààùíûX, Y \in \mathcal{C} with XX cofibrant and YY fibrant, and for P,QP, Q fibrant/cofibrant replacement functors as in def. 10, then the morphism

Hom Ho(ùíû)(PX,QY)=Hom ùíû(PX,QY)/ ‚àº‚ü∂Hom ùíû(j X,p Y)Hom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(P X,Q Y) = Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Q Y)/_{\sim} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(j_X, p_Y)}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_{\sim}

(on homotopy classes of morphisms, well defined by prop. 5) is a natural bijection.

(Quillen 67, I.1 lemma 7)

Proof

We may factor the morphism in question as the composite

Hom ùíû(PX,QY)/ ‚àº‚ü∂Hom ùíû(id PX,p Y)/ ‚àºHom ùíû(PX,Y)/ ‚àº‚ü∂Hom ùíû(j X,id Y)/ ‚àºHom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Q Y)/_{\sim} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_{P X}, p_Y)/_\sim }{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Y)/_{\sim} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(j_X, id_Y)/_\sim}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_{\sim} \,.

This shows that it is sufficient to see that for XX cofibrant and YY fibrant, then

Hom ùíû(id X,p Y)/ ‚àº:Hom ùíû(X,QY)/ ‚àº‚ÜíHom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_X, p_Y)/_\sim \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X, Q Y)/_\sim \to Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_\sim

is an isomorphism, and dually that

Hom ùíû(j X,id Y)/ ‚àº:Hom ùíû(PX,Y)/ ‚àº‚ÜíHom ùíû(X,Y)/ ‚àº Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(j_X, id_Y)/_\sim \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(P X, Y)/_\sim \to Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)/_\sim

is an isomorphism. We discuss this for the former; the second is formally dual:

First, that Hom ùíû(id X,p Y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_X, p_Y) is surjective is the lifting property in

‚àÖ ‚ü∂ QY ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib p Y X ‚ü∂f Y, \array{ \emptyset &\longrightarrow& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_Y}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,,

which says that any morphism f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y comes from a morphism f^:X‚ÜíQY\hat f \colon X \to Q Y under postcomposition with QY‚Üíp YYQ Y \overset{p_Y}{\to} Y.

Second, that Hom ùíû(id X,p Y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id_X, p_Y) is injective is the lifting property in

X‚äîX ‚ü∂(f,g) QY ‚ààCof‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib p Y Cyl(X) ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y, \array{ X \sqcup X &\overset{(f,g)}{\longrightarrow}& Q Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Cof}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_Y}}_{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ Cyl(X) &\underset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,,

which says that if two morphisms f,g:X‚ÜíQYf, g \colon X \to Q Y become homotopic after postcomposition with p Y:QX‚ÜíYp_Y \colon Q X \to Y, then they were already homotopic before.

We record the following fact which will be used in part 1.1 (here):

Lemma

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category (def. 1). Then every commuting square in its homotopy category Ho(C)Ho(C) (def. 9) is, up to isomorphism of squares, in the image of the localization functor ùíû‚ü∂Ho(ùíû)\mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}) of a commuting square in ùíû\mathcal{C} (i.e.: not just commuting up to homotopy).

Proof

Let

A ‚ü∂f B a‚Üì ‚Üì b A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂f‚Ä≤ B‚Ä≤‚ààHo(ùíû) \array{ A &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{a}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{b}} \\ A' &\underset{f'}{\longrightarrow}& B' } \;\;\;\;\; \in Ho(\mathcal{C})

be a commuting square in the homotopy category. Writing the same symbols for fibrant-cofibrant objects in ùíû\mathcal{C} and for morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C} representing these, then this means that in ùíû\mathcal{C} there is a left homotopy of the form

A ‚ü∂f B i 1‚Üì ‚Üì b Cyl(A) ‚ü∂Œ∑ B‚Ä≤ i 0‚Üë ‚Üë f‚Ä≤ A ‚ü∂a A‚Ä≤. \array{ A &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{b}} \\ Cyl(A) &\underset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& B' \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}\uparrow && \uparrow^{\mathrlap{f'}} \\ A &\underset{a}{\longrightarrow}& A' } \,.

Consider the factorization of the top square here through the mapping cylinder of ff

A ‚ü∂f B i 1‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚ààW Cyl(A) ‚ü∂ Cyl(f) i 0‚Üë Œ∑‚Üò ‚Üì A B‚Ä≤ a‚Üò ‚Üë f‚Ä≤ A‚Ä≤ \array{ A &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ Cyl(A) &\underset{}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(f) \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}\uparrow &{}_{\mathllap{\eta}}\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ A && B' \\ & {}_{\mathllap{a}}\searrow & \uparrow_{\mathrlap{f'}} \\ && A' }

This exhibits the composite A‚Üíi 0Cyl(A)‚ÜíCyl(f)A \overset{i_0}{\to} Cyl(A) \to Cyl(f) as an alternative representative of ff in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}), and Cyl(f)‚ÜíB‚Ä≤Cyl(f) \to B' as an alternative representative for bb, and the commuting square

A ‚ü∂ Cyl(f) a‚Üì ‚Üì A‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂f‚Ä≤ B‚Ä≤ \array{ A &\overset{}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(f) \\ {}^{\mathllap{a}}\downarrow && \downarrow \\ A' &\underset{f'}{\longrightarrow}& B' }

as an alternative representative of the given commuting square in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}).

Derived functors

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} and ùíü\mathcal{D} two categories with weak equivalences, def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}, then a functor F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C}\longrightarrow \mathcal{D} is called a homotopical functor if it sends weak equivalences to weak equivalences.

Definition

Given a homotopical functor F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} (def. 13) between categories with weak equivalences whose homotopy categories Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}) and Ho(ùíü)Ho(\mathcal{D}) exist (def. 11), then its (‚Äútotal‚Äù) derived functor is the functor Ho(F)Ho(F) between these homotopy categories which is induced uniquely, up to unique isomorphism, by their universal property (def. 11):

ùíû ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂‚àÉHo(F) Ho(ùíü). \array{ \mathcal{C} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\exists \; Ho(F)}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,.
Remark

While many functors of interest between model categories are not homotopical in the sense of def. 13, many become homotopical after restriction to the full subcategories ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f of fibrant objects or ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c of cofibrant objects, def. 12. By corollary 1 this is just as good for the purpose of homotopy theory.

Therefore one considers the following generalization of def. 14:

Definition

(derived functors)

Consider a functor F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} out of a model category ùíû\mathcal{C} (def. 1) into a category with weak equivalences ùíü\mathcal{D} (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

  1. If the restriction of FF to the full subcategory ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f of fibrant object becomes a homotopical functor (def. 13), then the derived functor of that restriction, according to def. 14, is called the right derived functor of FF and denoted by ‚ÑùF\mathbb{R}F:

    ùíû f ‚Ü™ ùíû ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû f‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü ‚ÑùF: ùíû f[W ‚àí1] ‚âÉ Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂Ho(F) Ho(ùíü), \array{ & \mathcal{C}_f &\hookrightarrow& \mathcal{C} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\gamma}_{\mathcal{C}_f}} \downarrow && \swArrow_{\simeq} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ \mathbb{R} F \colon & \mathcal{C}_f[W^{-1}] &\simeq& Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{Ho(F)}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,,

    where we use corollary 1.

  2. If the restriction of FF to the full subcategory ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c of cofibrant object becomes a homotopical functor (def. 13), then the derived functor of that restriction, according to def. 14, is called the left derived functor of FF and denoted by ùïÉF\mathbb{L}F:

    ùíû c ‚Ü™ ùíû ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû f‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü ùïÉF: ùíû c[W ‚àí1] ‚âÉ Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂Ho(F) Ho(ùíü), \array{ & \mathcal{C}_c &\hookrightarrow& \mathcal{C} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\gamma}_{\mathcal{C}_f}}\downarrow && \swArrow_{\simeq} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ \mathbb{L} F \colon & \mathcal{C}_c[W^{-1}] &\simeq& Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{Ho(F)}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,,

    where again we use corollary 1.

The key fact that makes def. 15 practically relevant is the following:

Proposition

(Ken Brown's lemma)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category with full subcategories ùíû f,ùíû c\mathcal{C}_f, \mathcal{C}_c of fibrant objects and of cofibrant objects respectively (def. 12). Let ùíü\mathcal{D} be a category with weak equivalences.

  1. A functor out of the category of fibrant objects

    F:ùíû f‚ü∂ùíü F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}_f \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

    is a homotopical functor, def. 13, already if it sends acylic fibrations to weak equivalences.

  2. A functor out of the category of cofibrant objects

    F:ùíû c‚ü∂ùíü F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}_c \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

    is a homotopical functor, def. 13, already if it sends acylic cofibrations to weak equivalences.

The following proof refers to the factorization lemma, whose full statement and proof we postpone to further below (lemma 10).

Proof

We discuss the case of a functor on a category of fibrant objects ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f, def. 12. The other case is formally dual.

Let f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y be a weak equivalence in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f. Choose a path space object Path(X)Path(X) (def. 7) and consider the diagram

Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib X ‚ààW p 1 *f‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààW f Path(Y) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fibp 1 Y ‚ààW‚à©Fib p 0‚Üì Y, \array{ Path(f) &\underset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_1^\ast f}}_{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ Path(Y) &\overset{p_1}{\underset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_0}}_{\mathllap{\in W \cap Fib}}\downarrow \\ Y } \,,

where the square is a pullback and Path(f)Path(f) on the top left is our notation for the universal cone object. (Below we discuss this in more detail, it is the mapping cocone of ff, def. 18).

Here:

  1. p ip_i are both acyclic fibrations, by lemma 3;

  2. Path(f)‚ÜíXPath(f) \to X is an acyclic fibration because it is the pullback of p 1p_1.

  3. p 1 *fp_1^\ast f is a weak equivalence, because the factorization lemma 10 states that the composite vertical morphism factors ff through a weak equivalence, hence if ff is a weak equivalence, then p 1 *fp_1^\ast f is by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

Now apply the functor FF to this diagram and use the assumption that it sends acyclic fibrations to weak equivalences to obtain

F(Path(f)) ‚ü∂‚ààW F(X) F(p 1 *f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(f) F(Path(Y)) ‚ü∂‚ààWF(p 1) F(Y) ‚ààW F(p 0)‚Üì Y. \array{ F(Path(f)) &\underset{\in W }{\longrightarrow}& F(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(p_1^\ast f)}}_{\mathllap{}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(f)}} \\ F(Path(Y)) &\overset{F(p_1)}{\underset{\in W }{\longrightarrow}}& F(Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(p_0)}}_{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow \\ Y } \,.

But the factorization lemma 10, in addition says that the vertical composite p 0‚àòp 1 *fp_0 \circ p_1^\ast f is a fibration, hence an acyclic fibration by the above. Therefore also F(p 0‚àòp 1 *f)F(p_0 \circ p_1^\ast f) is a weak equivalence. Now the claim that also F(f)F(f) is a weak equivalence follows with applying two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) twice.

Corollary

Let ùíû,ùíü\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be model categories and consider F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \colon \mathcal{C}\longrightarrow \mathcal{D} a functor. Then:

  1. If FF preserves cofibrant objects and acyclic cofibrations between these, then its left derived functor (def. 15) ùïÉF\mathbb{L}F exists, fitting into a diagram

    ùíû c ‚ü∂F ùíü c Œ≥ ùíû‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂ùïÉF Ho(ùíü) \array{ \mathcal{C}_{c} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D}_{c} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\overset{\mathbb{L}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) }

  2. If FF preserves fibrant objects and acyclic fibrants between these, then its right derived functor (def. 15) ‚ÑùF\mathbb{R}F exists, fitting into a diagram

    ùíû f ‚ü∂F ùíü f Œ≥ ùíû‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂‚ÑùF Ho(ùíü). \array{ \mathcal{C}_{f} &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D}_{f} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\mathbb{R}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) } \,.
Proposition

Let F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíüF \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} be a functor between two model categories (def. 1).

  1. If FF preserves fibrant objects and weak equivalences between fibrant objects, then the total right derived functor ‚ÑùF‚âî‚Ñù(Œ≥ ùíü‚àòF)\mathbb{R}F \coloneqq \mathbb{R}(\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}\circ F) (def. 15) in

    ùíû f ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû f‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂‚ÑùF Ho(ùíü) \array{ \mathcal{C}_f &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}_f}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\mathbb{R}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) }

    is given, up to isomorphism, on any object X‚ààùíû‚ü∂Œ≥ ùíûHo(ùíû) X\in \mathcal{C} \overset{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{C}) by appying FF to a fibrant replacement PXP X of XX and then forming a cofibrant replacement Q(F(PX))Q(F(P X)) of the result:

‚ÑùF(X)‚âÉQ(F(PX)). \mathbb{R}F(X) \simeq Q(F(P X)) \,.

  1. If FF preserves cofibrant objects and weak equivalences between cofibrant objects, then the total left derived functor ùïÉF‚âîùïÉ(Œ≥ ùíü‚àòF)\mathbb{L}F \coloneqq \mathbb{L}(\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}\circ F) (def. 15) in

    ùíû c ‚ü∂F ùíü Œ≥ ùíû c‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ ùíü Ho(ùíû) ‚ü∂ùïÉF Ho(ùíü) \array{ \mathcal{C}_c &\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{D} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}_c}}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}) &\underset{\mathbb{L}F}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{D}) }

    is given, up to isomorphism, on any object X‚ààùíû‚ü∂Œ≥ ùíûHo(ùíû) X\in \mathcal{C} \overset{\gamma_{\mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{C}) by appying FF to a cofibrant replacement QXQ X of XX and then forming a fibrant replacement P(F(QX))P(F(Q X)) of the result:

ùïÉF(X)‚âÉP(F(QX)). \mathbb{L}F(X) \simeq P(F(Q X)) \,.
Proof

We discuss the first case, the second is formally dual. By the proof of theorem 1 we have

‚ÑùF(X) ‚âÉŒ≥ ùíü(F(Œ≥ ùíû)) ‚âÉŒ≥ ùíüF(Q(P(X))). \begin{aligned} \mathbb{R}F(X) & \simeq \gamma_{\mathcal{D}}(F(\gamma_{\mathcal{C}})) \\ & \simeq \gamma_{\mathcal{D}}F(Q(P(X)) ) \end{aligned} \,.

But since FF is a homotopical functor on fibrant objects, the cofibrant replacement morphism F(Q(P(X)))‚ÜíF(P(X))F(Q(P(X)))\to F(P(X)) is a weak equivalence in ùíü\mathcal{D}, hence becomes an isomorphism under Œ≥ ùíü\gamma_{\mathcal{D}}. Therefore

‚ÑùF(X)‚âÉŒ≥ ùíü(F(P(X))). \mathbb{R}F(X) \simeq \gamma_{\mathcal{D}}(F(P(X))) \,.
