Now since FF is assumed to preserve fibrant objects, F(P(X))F(P(X)) is fibrant in ùíü\mathcal{D}, and hence Œ≥ ùíü\gamma_{\mathcal{D}} acts on it (only) by cofibrant replacement.

Quillen adjunctions

In practice it turns out to be useful to arrange for the assumptions in corollary 2 to be satisfied by pairs of adjoint functors (this Def.). Recall that this is a pair of functors LL and RR going back and forth between two categories

ùíû‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {} \mathcal{D}

such that there is a natural bijection between hom-sets with LL on the left and those with RR on the right:

œï d,c:Hom ùíû(L(d),c)‚ü∂‚âÉHom ùíü(d,R(c)) \phi_{d,c} \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L(d),c) \underoverset{\simeq}{}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(d, R(c))

for all objects d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D} and c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}. This being natural means that œï:Hom ùíü(L(‚àí),‚àí)‚áíHom ùíû(‚àí,R(‚àí))\phi \colon Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),-) \Rightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-, R(-)) is a natural transformation, hence that for all morphisms g:d 2‚Üíd 1g \colon d_2 \to d_1 and f:c 1‚Üíc 2f \colon c_1 \to c_2 the following is a commuting square:

Hom ùíû(L(d 1),c 1) ‚ü∂‚âÉœï d 1,c 1 Hom ùíü(d 1,R(c 1)) L(f)‚àò(‚àí)‚àòg‚Üì ‚Üì g‚àò(‚àí)‚àòR(g) Hom ùíû(L(d 2),c 2) ‚ü∂œï d 2,c 2‚âÉ Hom ùíü(d 2,R(c 2)). \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L(d_1), c_1) & \underoverset{\simeq}{\phi_{d_1,c_1}}{\longrightarrow} & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(d_1, R(c_1)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{L(f) \circ (-)\circ g}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g\circ (-)\circ R(g)}} \\ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L(d_2), c_2) & \underoverset{\phi_{d_2, c_2}}{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(d_2, R(c_2)) } \,.

We write (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) to indicate such an adjunction and call LL the left adjoint and RR the right adjoint of the adjoint pair.

The archetypical example of a pair of adjoint functors is that consisting of forming Cartesian products Y√ó(‚àí)Y \times (-) and forming mapping spaces (‚àí) Y(-)^Y, as in the category of compactly generated topological spaces of def. 88.

If f:L(d)‚Üícf \colon L(d) \to c is any morphism, then the image œï d,c(f):d‚ÜíR(c)\phi_{d,c}(f) \colon d \to R(c) is called its adjunct, and conversely. The fact that adjuncts are in bijection is also expressed by the notation

L(c)‚ü∂fdc‚ü∂fÀúR(d). \frac{ L(c) \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} d }{ c \overset{\tilde f}{\longrightarrow} R(d) } \,.

For an object d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D}, the adjunct of the identity on LdL d is called the adjunction unit Œ∑ d:d‚ü∂RLd\eta_d \;\colon\; d \longrightarrow R L d.

For an object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, the adjunct of the identity on RcR c is called the adjunction counit œµ c:LRc‚ü∂c\epsilon_c \;\colon\; L R c \longrightarrow c.

Adjunction units and counits turn out to encode the adjuncts of all other morphisms by the formulas

  • (Ld‚Üífc)Àú=(d‚ÜíŒ∑RLd‚ÜíRfRc)\widetilde{(L d\overset{f}{\to}c)} = (d\overset{\eta}{\to} R L d \overset{R f}{\to} R c)

  • (d‚ÜígRc)Àú=(Ld‚ÜíLgLRc‚Üíœµc)\widetilde{(d\overset{g}{\to} R c)} = (L d \overset{L g}{\to} L R c \overset{\epsilon}{\to} c).

Definition

(Quillen adjunction)

Let ùíû,ùíü\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be model categories. A pair of adjoint functors (Def. \ref{AdjointFunctorsInTermsOfNaturalBijectionOfHomSets}) between them

(L‚ä£R):ùíû‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü (L \dashv R) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {} \mathcal{D}

is called a Quillen adjunction (and LL,RR are called left/right Quillen functors, respectively) if the following equivalent conditions are satisfied

  1. LL preserves cofibrations and RR preserves fibrations;

  2. LL preserves acyclic cofibrations and RR preserves acyclic fibrations;

  3. LL preserves cofibrations and acylic cofibrations;

  4. RR preserves fibrations and acyclic fibrations.

Proposition

The conditions in def. 16 are indeed all equivalent.

(Quillen 67, I.4, theorem 3)

Proof

First observe that

  • (i) A left adjoint LL between model categories preserves acyclic cofibrations precisely if its right adjoint RR preserves fibrations.

  • (ii) A left adjoint LL between model categories preserves cofibrations precisely if its right adjoint RR preserves acyclic fibrations.

We discuss statement (i), statement (ii) is formally dual. So let f:A‚ÜíBf\colon A \to B be an acyclic cofibration in ùíü\mathcal{D} and g:X‚ÜíYg \colon X \to Y a fibration in ùíû\mathcal{C}. Then for every commuting diagram as on the left of the following, its (L‚ä£R)(L\dashv R)-adjunct is a commuting diagram as on the right here:

A ‚ü∂ R(X) f‚Üì ‚Üì R(g) B ‚ü∂ R(Y),L(A) ‚ü∂ X L(f)‚Üì ‚Üì g L(B) ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& R(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R(g)}} \\ B &\longrightarrow& R(Y) } \;\;\;\;\;\; \,, \;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ L(A) &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{L(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ L(B) &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

If LL preserves acyclic cofibrations, then the diagram on the right has a lift, and so the (L‚ä£R)(L\dashv R)-adjunct of that lift is a lift of the left diagram. This shows that R(g)R(g) has the right lifting property against all acylic cofibrations and hence is a fibration. Conversely, if RR preserves fibrations, the same argument run from right to left gives that LL preserves acyclic fibrations.

Now by repeatedly applying (i) and (ii), all four conditions in question are seen to be equivalent.

Lemma

Let ùíû‚ü∂R‚ä•‚üµLùíü\mathcal{C} \stackrel{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{\underoverset{R}{\bot}{\longrightarrow}} \mathcal{D} be a Quillen adjunction, def. 16.

  1. For X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} a fibrant object and Path(X)Path(X) a path space object (def. 7), then R(Path(X))R(Path(X)) is a path space object for R(X)R(X).

  2. For X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} a cofibrant object and Cyl(X)Cyl(X) a cylinder object (def. 7), then L(Cyl(X))L(Cyl(X)) is a path space object for L(X)L(X).

Proof

Consider the second case, the first is formally dual.

First Observe that L(Y‚äîY)‚âÉLY‚äîLYL(Y \sqcup Y) \simeq L Y \sqcup L Y because LL is left adjoint and hence preserves colimits, hence in particular coproducts.

Hence

L(X‚äîX‚Üí‚ààCofCyl(X))=(L(X)‚äîL(X)‚Üí‚ààCofL(Cyl(X))) L(\X \sqcup X \overset{\in Cof}{\to} Cyl(X)) = (L(X) \sqcup L(X) \overset{\in Cof}{\to } L (Cyl(X)))

is a cofibration.

Second, with YY cofibrant then also Y‚äîCyl(Y)Y \sqcup Cyl(Y) is a cofibrantion, since Y‚ÜíY‚äîYY \to Y \sqcup Y is a cofibration (lemma 3). Therefore by Ken Brown's lemma (prop. 8) LL preserves the weak equivalence Cyl(Y)‚ü∂‚ààWYCyl(Y) \overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow} Y.

Proposition

(Quillen adjunction descends to homotopy categories)

For ùíû‚ü∂R‚ä•‚üµLùíü\mathcal{C} \underoverset{\underoverset{R}{\bot}{\longrightarrow}}{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{} \mathcal{D} a Quillen adjunction, def. 16, then also the corresponding left and right derived functors, def. 15, via cor. 2, form a pair of adjoint functors

Ho(ùíû)‚ä•‚ü∂‚ÑùR‚üµùïÉLHo(ùíü). Ho(\mathcal{C}) \underoverset {\underset{\mathbb{R}R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\mathbb{L}L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} Ho(\mathcal{D}) \,.

(Quillen 67, I.4 theorem 3)

Proof

By def. 15 and lemma 7 it is sufficient to see that for X,Y‚ààùíûX, Y \in \mathcal{C} with XX cofibrant and YY fibrant, then there is a natural bijection

Hom ùíû(LX,Y)/ ‚àº‚âÉHom ùíû(X,RY)/ ‚àº. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L X , Y)/_\sim \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X, R Y)/_\sim \,.

Since by the adjunction isomorphism for (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) such a natural bijection exists before passing to homotopy classes (‚àí)/ ‚àº(-)/_\sim, it is sufficient to see that this respects homotopy classes. To that end, use from lemma 9 that with Cyl(Y)Cyl(Y) a cylinder object for YY, def. 7, then L(Cyl(Y))L(Cyl(Y)) is a cylinder object for L(Y)L(Y). This implies that left homotopies

(f‚áí Lg):LX‚ü∂Y (f \Rightarrow_L g) \;\colon\; L X \longrightarrow Y

given by

Œ∑:Cyl(LX)=LCyl(X)‚ü∂Y \eta \;\colon\; Cyl(L X) = L Cyl(X) \longrightarrow Y

are in bijection to left homotopies

(fÀú‚áí LgÀú):X‚ü∂RY (\tilde f \Rightarrow_L \tilde g) \;\colon\; X \longrightarrow R Y

given by

Œ∑Àú:Cyl(X)‚ü∂RX. \tilde \eta \;\colon\; Cyl(X) \longrightarrow R X \,.

The following is the analog of adjoint equivalence of categories (Def. \ref{AdjointEquivalenceOfCategories}) for model categories:

Definition

(Quillen equivalence)

For ùíû,ùíü\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} two model categories (Def. 1), a Quillen adjunction (def. 16)

(L‚ä£R):ùíû‚ä•‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü (L \dashv R) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

is called a Quillen equivalence, to be denoted

ùíû Q‚âÉ Q‚ü∂R‚üµLùíü, \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\phantom{{}_{Q}} \simeq_{\mathrlap{Q}}} \mathcal{D} \,,

if the following equivalent conditions hold:

  1. The right derived functor of RR (via prop. 9, corollary 2) is an equivalence of categories

    ‚ÑùR:Ho(ùíû)‚ü∂‚âÉHo(ùíü). \mathbb{R}R \colon Ho(\mathcal{C}) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{D}) \,.

  2. The left derived functor of LL (via prop. 9, corollary 2) is an equivalence of categories

    ùïÉL:Ho(ùíü)‚ü∂‚âÉHo(ùíû). \mathbb{L}L \colon Ho(\mathcal{D}) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} Ho(\mathcal{C}) \,.

  3. For every cofibrant object d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D}, the ‚Äúderived adjunction unit‚Äù, hence the composite

    d‚ü∂Œ∑R(L(d))‚ü∂R(j L(d))R(P(L(d))) d \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R(L(d)) \overset{R(j_{L(d)})}{\longrightarrow} R(P(L(d)))

    (of the adjunction unit with any fibrant replacement PP as in def. 10) is a weak equivalence;

    and for every fibrant object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, the ‚Äúderived adjunction counit‚Äù, hence the composite

    L(Q(R(c)))‚ü∂L(p R(c))L(R(c))‚ü∂œµc L(Q(R(c))) \overset{L(p_{R(c)})}{\longrightarrow} L(R(c)) \overset{\epsilon}{\longrightarrow} c

    (of the adjunction counit with any cofibrant replacement as in def. 10) is a weak equivalence in DD.

  4. For every cofibrant object d‚ààùíüd \in \mathcal{D} and every fibrant object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, a morphism d‚ü∂R(c)d \longrightarrow R(c) is a weak equivalence precisely if its adjunct morphism L(c)‚ÜídL(c) \to d is:

    d‚ü∂‚ààW ùíüR(c)L(d)‚ü∂‚ààW ùíûc. \frac{ d \overset{\in W_{\mathcal{D}}}{\longrightarrow} R(c) }{ L(d) \overset{\in W_{\mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} c } \,.
Poposition

The conditions in def. 17 are indeed all equivalent.

(Quillen 67, I.4, theorem 3)

Proof

That 1)‚áî2)1) \Leftrightarrow 2) follows from prop. 10 (if in an adjoint pair one is an equivalence, then so is the other).

To see the equivalence 1),2)‚áî3)1),2) \Leftrightarrow 3), notice (prop.) that a pair of adjoint functors is an equivalence of categories precisely if both the adjunction unit and the adjunction counit are natural isomorphisms. Hence it is sufficient to show that the morphisms called ‚Äúderived adjunction (co-)units‚Äù above indeed represent the adjunction (co-)unit of (ùïÉL‚ä£‚ÑùR)(\mathbb{L}L \dashv \mathbb{R}R) in the homotopy category. We show this now for the adjunction unit, the case of the adjunction counit is formally dual.

To that end, first observe that for d‚ààùíü cd \in \mathcal{D}_c, then the defining commuting square for the left derived functor from def. 15

ùíü c ‚ü∂L ùíû Œ≥ P‚Üì ‚áô ‚âÉ ‚Üì Œ≥ P,Q Ho(ùíü) ‚ü∂ùïÉL Ho(ùíû) \array{ \mathcal{D}_c &\overset{L}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{C} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\gamma_P}}\downarrow &\swArrow_{\simeq}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_{P,Q}}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{D}) &\underset{\mathbb{L}L}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(\mathcal{C}) }

(using fibrant and fibrant/cofibrant replacement functors Œ≥ P\gamma_P, Œ≥ P,Q\gamma_{P,Q} from def. 10 with their universal property from theorem 1, corollary 1) gives that

(ùïÉL)d‚âÉPLPd‚âÉPLd‚ààHo(ùíû), (\mathbb{L} L ) d \simeq P L P d \simeq P L d \;\;\;\; \in Ho(\mathcal{C}) \,,

where the second isomorphism holds because the left Quillen functor LL sends the acyclic cofibration j d:d‚ÜíPdj_d \colon d \to P d to a weak equivalence.

The adjunction unit of (ùïÉL‚ä£‚ÑùR)(\mathbb{L}L \dashv \mathbb{R}R) on Pd‚ààHo(ùíû)P d \in Ho(\mathcal{C}) is the image of the identity under

Hom Ho(ùíû)((ùïÉL)Pd,(ùïÉL)Pd)‚Üí‚âÉHom Ho(ùíû)(Pd,(‚ÑùR)(ùïÉL)Pd). Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}((\mathbb{L}L) P d, (\mathbb{L} L) P d) \overset{\simeq}{\to} Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(P d, (\mathbb{R}R)(\mathbb{L}L) P d) \,.

By the above and the proof of prop. 10, that adjunction isomorphism is equivalently that of (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) under the isomorphism

Hom Ho(ùíû)(PLd,PLd)‚ü∂Hom(j Ld,id)Hom ùíû(Ld,PLd)/ ‚àº Hom_{Ho(\mathcal{C})}(P L d , P L d) \overset{Hom(j_{L d}, id)}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L d, P L d)/_\sim

of lemma 7. Hence the derived adjunction unit is the (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R)-adjunct of

Ld‚ü∂j LdPLd‚ÜíidPLd, L d \overset{j_{L d}}{\longrightarrow} P L d \overset{id}{\to} P L d \,,

which indeed (by the formula for adjuncts) is

X‚ü∂Œ∑RLd‚ü∂R(j Ld)RPLd. X \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R L d \overset{R (j_{L d})}{\longrightarrow} R P L d \,.

To see that 4)‚áí3)4) \Rightarrow 3):

Consider the weak equivalence LX‚ü∂j LXPLXL X \overset{j_{L X}}{\longrightarrow} P L X. Its (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R)-adjunct is

X‚ü∂Œ∑RLX‚ü∂Rj LXRPLX X \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R L X \overset{R j_{L X}}{\longrightarrow} R P L X

by assumption 4) this is again a weak equivalence, which is the requirement for the derived unit in 3). Dually for derived counit.

To see 3)‚áí4)3) \Rightarrow 4):

Consider any f:Ld‚Üícf \colon L d \to c a weak equivalence for cofibrant dd, firbant cc. Its adjunct fÀú\tilde f sits in a commuting diagram

fÀú: d ‚ü∂Œ∑ RLd ‚ü∂Rf Rc =‚Üì ‚Üì Rj Ld ‚Üì Rj c d ‚ü∂‚ààW RPLd ‚ü∂RPf RPc, \array{ \tilde f \colon & d &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& R L d &\overset{R f}{\longrightarrow}& R c \\ & {}^{\mathllap{=}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R j_{L d}}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R j_c}} \\ & d &\underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& R P L d &\overset{R P f}{\longrightarrow}& R P c } \,,

where PfP f is any lift constructed as in def. 10.

This exhibits the bottom left morphism as the derived adjunction unit, hence a weak equivalence by assumption. But since ff was a weak equivalence, so is PfP f (by two-out-of-three). Thereby also RPfR P f and Rj YR j_Y, are weak equivalences by Ken Brown's lemma 8 and the assumed fibrancy of cc. Therefore by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) also the adjunct fÀú\tilde f is a weak equivalence.

In certain situations the conditions on a Quillen equivalence simplify. For instance:

Proposition

If in a Quillen adjunction ùíû ‚ä•‚ÜíR‚ÜêL ùíü \array{\mathcal{C} &\underoverset{\underset{R}{\to}}{\overset{L}{\leftarrow}}{\bot}& \mathcal{D}} (def. 16) the right adjoint RR ‚Äúcreates weak equivalences‚Äù (in that a morphism ff in ùíû\mathcal{C} is a weak equivalence precisly if U(f)U(f) is) then (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) is a Quillen equivalence (def. 17) precisely already if for all cofibrant objects d‚ààùíüd \in \mathcal{D} the plain adjunction unit

d‚ü∂Œ∑R(L(d)) d \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R (L (d))

is a weak equivalence.

Proof

By prop. 11, generally, (L‚ä£R)(L \dashv R) is a Quillen equivalence precisely if

  1. for every cofibrant object d‚ààùíüd\in \mathcal{D}, the ‚Äúderived adjunction unit‚Äù

    d‚ü∂Œ∑R(L(d))‚ü∂R(j L(d))R(P(L(d))) d \overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow} R(L(d)) \overset{R(j_{L(d)})}{\longrightarrow} R(P(L(d)))

    is a weak equivalence;

  2. for every fibrant object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, the ‚Äúderived adjunction counit‚Äù

    L(Q(R(c)))‚ü∂L(p R(c))L(R(c))‚ü∂œµc L(Q(R(c))) \overset{L(p_{R(c)})}{\longrightarrow} L(R(c)) \overset{\epsilon}{\longrightarrow} c

    is a weak equivalence.

Consider the first condition: Since RR preserves the weak equivalence j L(d)j_{L(d)}, then by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) the composite in the first item is a weak equivalence precisely if Œ∑\eta is.

Hence it is now sufficient to show that in this case the second condition above is automatic.

Since RR also reflects weak equivalences, the composite in item two is a weak equivalence precisely if its image

R(L(Q(R(c))))‚ü∂R(L(p R(c)))R(L(R(c)))‚ü∂R(œµ)R(c) R(L(Q(R(c)))) \overset{R(L(p_{R(c))})}{\longrightarrow} R(L(R(c))) \overset{R(\epsilon)}{\longrightarrow} R(c)

under RR is.

Moreover, assuming, by the above, that Œ∑ Q(R(c))\eta_{Q(R(c))} on the cofibrant object Q(R(c))Q(R(c)) is a weak equivalence, then by two-out-of-three this composite is a weak equivalence precisely if the further composite with Œ∑\eta is

Q(R(c))‚ü∂Œ∑ Q(R(c))R(L(Q(R(c))))‚ü∂R(L(p R(c)))R(L(R(c)))‚ü∂R(œµ)R(c). Q(R(c)) \overset{\eta_{Q(R(c))}}{\longrightarrow} R(L(Q(R(c)))) \overset{R(L(p_{R(c))})}{\longrightarrow} R(L(R(c))) \overset{R(\epsilon)}{\longrightarrow} R(c) \,.

By the formula for adjuncts, this composite is the (L‚ä£R)(L\dashv R)-adjunct of the original composite, which is just p R(c)p_{R(c)}

L(Q(R(c)))‚ü∂L(p R(c))L(R(c))‚ü∂œµcQ(R(C))‚ü∂p R(c)R(c). \frac{ L(Q(R(c))) \overset{L(p_{R(c)})}{\longrightarrow} L(R(c)) \overset{\epsilon}{\longrightarrow} c }{ Q(R(C)) \overset{p_{R(c)}}{\longrightarrow} R(c) } \,.

But p R(c)p_{R(c)} is a weak equivalence by definition of cofibrant replacement.

\,

Mapping cones

In the context of homotopy theory, a pullback diagram, such as in the definition of the fiber in example 33

fib(f) ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üì f * ‚ü∂ Y \array{ fib(f) &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y }

ought to commute only up to a (left/right) homotopy (def. 8) between the outer composite morphisms. Moreover, it should satisfy its universal property up to such homotopies.

Instead of going through the full theory of what this means, we observe that this is plausibly modeled by the following construction, and then we check (below) that this indeed has the relevant abstract homotopy theoretic properties.

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category, def. 1 with ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} its model structure on pointed objects, prop. 36. For f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y a morphism between cofibrant objects (hence a morphism in (ùíû */) c‚Ü™ùíû */(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})_c\hookrightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\ast/}, def. 12), its reduced mapping cone is the object

Cone(f)‚âî*‚äîXCyl(X)‚äîXY Cone(f) \coloneqq \ast \underset{X}{\sqcup} Cyl(X) \underset{X}{\sqcup} Y

in the colimiting diagram

X ‚ü∂f Y ‚Üì i 1 ‚Üì i X ‚ü∂i 0 Cyl(X) ‚Üì ‚Üò Œ∑ ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ ‚ü∂ Cone(f), \array{ && X &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i_1}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i}} \\ X &\stackrel{i_0}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(X) \\ \downarrow && & \searrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}} & \downarrow \\ {*} &\longrightarrow& &\longrightarrow& Cone(f) } \,,

where Cyl(X)Cyl(X) is a cylinder object for XX, def. 7.

Dually, for f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y a morphism between fibrant objects (hence a morphism in (ùíû *) f‚Ü™ùíû */(\mathcal{C}^{\ast})_f\hookrightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\ast/}, def. 12), its mapping cocone is the object

Path *(f)‚âî*√óYPath(Y)√óYY Path_\ast(f) \coloneqq \ast \underset{Y}{\times} Path(Y)\underset{Y}{\times} Y

in the following limit diagram

Path *(f) ‚ü∂ ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üò Œ∑ ‚Üì f Path(Y) ‚ü∂p 1 Y ‚Üì ‚Üì p 0 * ‚ü∂ Y, \array{ Path_\ast(f) &\longrightarrow& &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &\searrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}}& && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ && Path(Y) &\underset{p_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y } \,,

where Path(Y)Path(Y) is a path space object for YY, def. 7.

Remark

When we write homotopies (def. 8) as double arrows between morphisms, then the limit diagram in def. 18 looks just like the square in the definition of fibers in example 33, except that it is filled by the right homotopy given by the component map denoted Œ∑\eta:

Path *(f) ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚áô Œ∑ ‚Üì f * ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ Path_\ast(f) &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &\swArrow_{\eta}& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

Dually, the colimiting diagram for the mapping cone turns to look just like the square for the cofiber, except that it is filled with a left homotopy

X ‚ü∂f Y ‚Üì ‚áô Œ∑ ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ Cone(f) \array{ X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ \downarrow &\swArrow_{\eta}& \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Cone(f) }
Proposition

The colimit appearing in the definition of the reduced mapping cone in def. 18 is equivalent to three consecutive pushouts:

X ‚ü∂f Y ‚Üì i 1 (po) ‚Üì i X ‚ü∂i 0 Cyl(X) ‚ü∂ Cyl(f) ‚Üì (po) ‚Üì (po) ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ Cone(X) ‚ü∂ Cone(f). \array{ && X &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i_1}} &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i}} \\ X &\stackrel{i_0}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(X) &\longrightarrow& Cyl(f) \\ \downarrow &(po)& \downarrow & (po) & \downarrow \\ {*} &\longrightarrow& Cone(X) &\longrightarrow& Cone(f) } \,.

The two intermediate objects appearing here are called

  • the plain reduced cone Cone(X)‚âî*‚äîXCyl(X)Cone(X) \coloneqq \ast \underset{X}{\sqcup} Cyl(X);

  • the reduced mapping cylinder Cyl(f)‚âîCyl(X)‚äîXYCyl(f) \coloneqq Cyl(X) \underset{X}{\sqcup} Y.

Dually, the limit appearing in the definition of the mapping cocone in def. 18 is equivalent to three consecutive pullbacks:

Path *(f) ‚ü∂ Path(f) ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì f Path *(Y) ‚ü∂ Path(Y) ‚ü∂p 1 Y ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì p 0 * ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ Path_\ast(f) &\longrightarrow& Path(f) &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ Path_\ast(Y) &\longrightarrow& Path(Y) &\underset{p_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

The two intermediate objects appearing here are called

  • the based path space object Path *(Y)‚âî*‚àèYPath(Y)Path_\ast(Y) \coloneqq \ast \underset{Y}{\prod} Path(Y);

  • the mapping path space or mapping co-cylinder Path(f)‚âîX√óYPath(X)Path(f) \coloneqq X \underset{Y}{\times} Path(X).

Definition

Let X‚ààùíû */X \in \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} be any pointed object.

  1. The mapping cone, def. 13, of X‚Üí*X \to \ast is called the reduced suspension of XX, denoted

    Œ£X=Cone(X‚Üí*). \Sigma X = Cone(X\to\ast)\,.

    Via prop. 13 this is equivalently the coproduct of two copies of the cone on XX over their base:

    X ‚ü∂ * ‚Üì i 1 (po) ‚Üì X ‚ü∂i 0 Cyl(X) ‚ü∂ Cone(X) ‚Üì (po) ‚Üì (po) ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ Cone(X) ‚ü∂ Œ£X. \array{ && X &\stackrel{}{\longrightarrow}& \ast \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{i_1}} &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ X &\stackrel{i_0}{\longrightarrow}& Cyl(X) &\longrightarrow& Cone(X) \\ \downarrow &(po)& \downarrow & (po) & \downarrow \\ {*} &\longrightarrow& Cone(X) &\longrightarrow& \Sigma X } \,.

    This is also equivalently the cofiber, example 33 of (i 0,i 1)(i_0,i_1), hence (example 28) of the wedge sum inclusion:

    X‚à®X=X‚äîX‚ü∂(i 0,i 1)Cyl(X)‚ü∂cofib(i 0,i 1)Œ£X. X \vee X = X \sqcup X \overset{(i_0,i_1)}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \overset{cofib(i_0,i_1)}{\longrightarrow} \Sigma X \,.

  2. The mapping cocone, def. 13, of *‚ÜíX\ast \to X is called the loop space object of XX, denoted

    Œ©X=Path *(*‚ÜíX). \Omega X = Path_\ast(\ast \to X) \,.

    Via prop. 13 this is equivalently

    Œ©X ‚ü∂ Path *(X) ‚ü∂ * ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì Path *(X) ‚ü∂ Path(X) ‚ü∂p 1 X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì p 0 * ‚ü∂ X. \array{ \Omega X &\longrightarrow& Path_\ast(X) &\longrightarrow& \ast \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{} \\ Path_\ast(X) &\longrightarrow& Path(X) &\underset{p_1}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& X } \,.

    This is also equivalently the fiber, example 33 of (p 0,p 1)(p_0,p_1):

    Œ©X‚ü∂fib(p 0,p 1)Path(X)‚ü∂(p 0,p 1)X√óX. \Omega X \overset{fib(p_0,p_1)}{\longrightarrow} Path(X) \overset{(p_0,p_1)}{\longrightarrow} X \times X \,.
Proposition

In pointed topological spaces Top */Top^{\ast/},

  • the reduced suspension objects (def. 19) induced from the standard reduced cylinder (‚àí)‚àß(I +)(-)\wedge (I_+) of example 31 are isomorphic to the smash product (def. 46) with the 1-sphere, for later purposes we choose to smash on the left and write

    cofib(X‚à®X‚ÜíX‚àß(I +))‚âÉS 1‚àßX, cofib(X \vee X \to X \wedge (I_+)) \simeq S^1 \wedge X \,,

Dually:

  • the loop space objects (def. 19) induced from the standard pointed path space object Maps(I +,‚àí) *Maps(I_+,-)_\ast are isomorphic to the pointed mapping space (example 32) with the 1-sphere

    fib(Maps(I +,X) *‚ÜíX√óX)‚âÉMaps(S 1,X) *. fib(Maps(I_+,X)_\ast \to X \times X) \simeq Maps(S^1, X)_\ast \,.
Proof

By immediate inspection: For instance the fiber of Maps(I +,X) *‚ü∂X√óXMaps(I_+,X)_\ast \longrightarrow X\times X is clearly the subspace of the unpointed mapping space X IX^I on elements that take the endpoints of II to the basepoint of XX.

Example

For ùíû=\mathcal{C} = Top with Cyl(X)=X√óICyl(X) = X\times I the standard cyclinder object, def. 28, then by example 19, the mapping cone, def. 18, of a continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y is obtained by

  1. forming the cylinder over XX;

  2. attaching to one end of that cylinder the space YY as specified by the map ff.

  3. shrinking the other end of the cylinder to the point.

Accordingly the suspension of a topological space is the result of shrinking both ends of the cylinder on the object two the point. This is homeomoprhic to attaching two copies of the cone on the space at the base of the cone.

(graphics taken from Muro 10)

Below in example 5 we find the homotopy-theoretic interpretation of this standard topological mapping cone as a model for the homotopy cofiber.

Remark

The formula for the mapping cone in prop. 13 (as opposed to that of the mapping co-cone) does not require the presence of the basepoint: for f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y a morphism in ùíû\mathcal{C} (as opposed to in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) we may still define

Cone‚Ä≤(f)‚âîY‚äîXCone‚Ä≤(X), Cone'(f) \coloneqq Y \underset{X}{\sqcup} Cone'(X) \,,

where the prime denotes the unreduced cone, formed from a cylinder object in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Proposition

For f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y a morphism in Top, then its unreduced mapping cone, remark 9, with respect to the standard cylinder object X√óIX \times I def. 28, is isomorphic to the reduced mapping cone, def. 18, of the morphism f +:X +‚ÜíY +f_+ \colon X_+ \to Y_+ (with a basepoint adjoined, def. 45) with respect to the standard reduced cylinder (example 31):

Cone‚Ä≤(f)‚âÉCone(f +). Cone'(f) \simeq Cone(f_+) \,.
Proof

By prop. 35 and example 30, Cone(f +)Cone(f_+) is given by the colimit in TopTop over the following diagram:

* ‚ü∂ X‚äî* ‚ü∂(f,id) Y‚äî* ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì X‚äî* ‚ü∂ (X√óI)‚äî* ‚Üì ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ ‚ü∂ Cone(f +). \array{ \ast &\longrightarrow& X \sqcup \ast &\overset{(f,id)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \sqcup \ast \\ \downarrow && \downarrow && \downarrow \\ X \sqcup\ast &\longrightarrow& (X \times I) \sqcup \ast \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& &\longrightarrow& Cone(f_+) } \,.

We may factor the vertical maps to give

* ‚ü∂ X‚äî* ‚ü∂(f,id) Y‚äî* ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì X‚äî* ‚ü∂ (X√óI)‚äî* ‚Üì ‚Üì *‚äî* ‚ü∂ ‚ü∂ Cone‚Ä≤(f) + ‚Üì ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ ‚ü∂ Cone‚Ä≤(f). \array{ \ast &\longrightarrow& X \sqcup \ast &\overset{(f,id)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \sqcup \ast \\ \downarrow && \downarrow && \downarrow \\ X \sqcup\ast &\longrightarrow& (X \times I) \sqcup \ast \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow \\ \ast \sqcup \ast &\longrightarrow& &\longrightarrow& Cone'(f)_+ \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& &\longrightarrow& Cone'(f) } \,.

This way the top part of the diagram (using the pasting law to compute the colimit in two stages) is manifestly a cocone under the result of applying (‚àí) +(-)_+ to the diagram for the unreduced cone. Since (‚àí) +(-)_+ is itself given by a colimit, it preserves colimits, and hence gives the partial colimit Cone‚Ä≤(f) +Cone'(f)_+ as shown. The remaining pushout then contracts the remaining copy of the point away.

Example 3 makes it clear that every cycle S n‚ÜíYS^n \to Y in YY that happens to be in the image of XX can be continuously translated in the cylinder-direction, keeping it constant in YY, to the other end of the cylinder, where it shrinks away to the point. This means that every homotopy group of YY, def. 30, in the image of ff vanishes in the mapping cone. Hence in the mapping cone the image of XX under ff in YY is removed up to homotopy. This makes it intuitively clear how Cone(f)Cone(f) is a homotopy-version of the cokernel of ff. We now discuss this formally.

Lemma

(factorization lemma)

Let ùíû c\mathcal{C}_c be a category of cofibrant objects, def. 12. Then for every morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y the mapping cylinder-construction in def. 13 provides a cofibration resolution of ff, in that

  1. the composite morphism X‚ü∂i 0Cyl(X)‚ü∂(i 1) *fCyl(f)X \overset{i_0}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(X) \overset{(i_1)_\ast f}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(f) is a cofibration;

  2. ff factors through this morphism by a weak equivalence left inverse to an acyclic cofibration

    f:X‚ü∂‚ààCof(i 1) *f‚àòi 0Cyl(f)‚ü∂‚ààWY, f \;\colon\; X \underoverset{\in Cof}{(i_1)_\ast f\circ i_0}{\longrightarrow} Cyl(f) \underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow} Y \,,

Dually:

Let ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f be a category of fibrant objects, def. 12. Then for every morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y the mapping cocylinder-construction in def. 13 provides a fibration resolution of ff, in that

  1. the composite morphism Path(f)‚ü∂p 1 *fPath(Y)‚ü∂p 0YPath(f) \overset{p_1^\ast f}{\longrightarrow} Path(Y) \overset{p_0}{\longrightarrow} Y is a fibration;

  2. ff factors through this morphism by a weak equivalence right inverse to an acyclic fibration:

    f:X‚ü∂‚ààWPath(f)‚ü∂‚ààFibp 0‚àòp 1 *fY, f \;\colon\; X \underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow} Path(f) \underoverset{\in Fib}{p_0 \circ p_1^\ast f}{\longrightarrow} Y \,,
Proof

We discuss the second case. The first case is formally dual.

So consider the mapping cocylinder-construction from prop. 13

Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib X p 1 *f‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì f Path(Y) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fibp 1 Y ‚ààW‚à©Fib‚Üì p 0 Y. \array{ Path(f) &\overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_1^\ast f}}\downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ Path(Y) &\underoverset{\in W \cap Fib}{p_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W \cap Fib}}\downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0}} \\ Y } \,.

To see that the vertical composite is indeed a fibration, notice that, by the pasting law, the above pullback diagram may be decomposed as a pasting of two pullback diagram as follows

Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààFib(f,id) *(p 1,p 0) X√óY ‚Üípr 1 X ‚Üì ‚Üì (f,Id) ‚Üì f Path(Y) ‚ü∂(p 1,p 0)‚ààFib Y√óY ‚ü∂pr 1 Y p 0‚Üì ‚Üô pr 2‚ààFib Y. \array{ Path(f) &\underoverset{\in Fib}{(f,id)^\ast(p_1,p_0)}{\longrightarrow}& X \times Y &\stackrel{pr_1}{\to}& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(f, Id)}} && \downarrow^\mathrlap{f} \\ Path(Y) &\overset{(p_1,p_0) \in Fib }{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y &\stackrel{pr_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{p_0}}\downarrow & \swarrow_{\mathrlap{pr_2 \atop {\in Fib}}} \\ Y } \,.

Both squares are pullback squares. Since pullbacks of fibrations are fibrations by prop. 1, the morphism Path(f)‚ÜíX√óYPath(f) \to X \times Y is a fibration. Similarly, since XX is fibrant, also the projection map X√óY‚ÜíYX \times Y \to Y is a fibration (being the pullback of X‚Üí*X \to \ast along Y‚Üí*Y \to \ast).

Since the vertical composite is thereby exhibited as the composite of two fibrations

Path(f)‚ü∂(f,id) *(p 1,p 0)X√óY‚ü∂pr 2‚àò(f,Id)=pr 2Y, Path(f) \overset{(f,id)^\ast(p_1,p_0)}{\longrightarrow} X \times Y \stackrel{pr_2 \circ (f ,Id) = pr_2}{\longrightarrow} Y \,,

it is itself a fibration.

Then to see that there is a weak equivalence as claimed:

The universal property of the pullback Path(f)Path(f) induces a right inverse of Path(f)‚ÜíXPath(f) \to X fitting into this diagram

id X: X ‚ü∂‚ààW‚àÉ Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib X f‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì f id Y: Y ‚ü∂‚ààWi Path(Y) ‚Üíp 1 Y Id‚Üò ‚Üì p 0 Y, \array{ id_X \colon & X &\underoverset{\in W}{\exists}{\longrightarrow} & Path(f) & \overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ & {}^{\mathrlap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ id_Y\colon& Y &\underoverset{\in W}{i}{\longrightarrow}& Path(Y) &\stackrel{p_1}{\to}& Y \\ & & {}_{\mathllap{Id}}\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_0}} \\ & && Y } \,,

which is a weak equivalence, as indicated, by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

This establishes the claim.

Categories of fibrant objects

Below we discuss the homotopy-theoretic properties of the mapping cone- and mapping cocone-constructions from above. Before we do so, we here establish a collection of general facts that hold in categories of fibrant objects and dually in categories of cofibrant objects, def. 12.

Literature (Brown 73, section 4).

Lemma

Let f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y be a morphism in a category of fibrant objects, def. 12. Then given any choice of path space objects Path(X)Path(X) and Path(Y)Path(Y), def. 7, there is a replacement of Path(X)Path(X) by a path space object Path(X)Àú\widetilde{Path(X)} along an acylic fibration, such that Path(X)Àú\widetilde{Path(X)} has a morphism œï\phi to Path(Y)Path(Y) which is compatible with the structure maps, in that the following diagram commutes

X ‚ü∂f Y ‚Üô ‚Üì ‚Üì Path(X) ‚üµ‚ààW‚à©Fib Path(X)Àú ‚ü∂œï Path(Y) (p 0 X,p 1 X)‚Üò ‚Üì (p 0 Y,p 1 Y) ‚Üì (pÀú 0 X,pÀú 1 X) X√óX ‚ü∂(f,f) Y√óY. \array{ && X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ &\swarrow& \downarrow && \downarrow \\ Path(X) &\underset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longleftarrow}& \widetilde{Path(X)} &\overset{\phi}{\longrightarrow}& Path(Y) \\ &{}_{\mathllap{(p^X_0,p^X_1)}}\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p^Y_0,p^Y_1)}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(\tilde p^X_0,\tilde p^X_1)}} \\ && X \times X &\overset{(f,f)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,.

(Brown 73, section 2, lemma 2)

Proof

Consider the commuting square

X ‚ü∂f Y ‚ü∂ Path(Y) ‚Üì ‚Üì (p 0 Y,p 1 Y) Path(X) ‚ü∂(p 0 X,p 1 X) X√óX ‚ü∂(f,f) Y√óY. \array{ X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y &\longrightarrow& Path(Y) \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p_0^Y, p_1^Y)}} \\ Path(X) &\overset{(p^X_0,p^X_1)}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X &\overset{(f,f)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,.

Then consider its factorization through the pullback of the right morphism along the bottom morphism,

X ‚ü∂ (f‚àòp 0 X,f‚àòp 1 X) *Path(Y) ‚ü∂ Path(Y) ‚ààW‚Üò ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib ‚Üì ‚ààFib (p 0 Y,p 1 Y) Path(X) ‚ü∂(f‚àòp 0 X,f‚àòp 1 X) Y√óY. \array{ X &\longrightarrow& (f \circ p_0^X, f\circ p_1^X)^\ast Path(Y) &\longrightarrow& Path(Y) \\ &{}_{\mathllap{\in W}}\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p_0^Y, p_1^Y)}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ && Path(X) &\overset{(f \circ p_0^X, f\circ p_1^X)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,.

Finally use the factorization lemma 10 to factor the morphism X‚Üí(f‚àòp 0 X,f‚àòp 1 X) *Path(Y)X \to (f \circ p_0^X, f\circ p_1^X)^\ast Path(Y) through a weak equivalence followed by a fibration, the object this factors through serves as the desired path space resolution

X ‚ü∂‚ààW Path(X)Àú ‚ü∂ Path(Y) ‚ààW‚Üò ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib ‚Üì (p 0 Y,p 1 Y) Path(X) ‚ü∂(f‚àòp 0 X,f‚àòp 1 X) Y√óY. \array{ X &\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& \widetilde{Path(X)} &\longrightarrow& Path(Y) \\ &{}_{\mathllap{\in W}}\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p_0^Y, p_1^Y)}} \\ && Path(X) &\overset{(f \circ p_0^X, f\circ p_1^X)}{\longrightarrow}& Y \times Y } \,.
Lemma

In a category of fibrant objects ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f, def. 12, let

A 1 ‚ü∂f A 2 ‚ààFib‚Üò ‚Üô ‚ààFib B \array{ A_1 &&\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}&& A_2 \\ & {}_{\in Fib}\searrow && \swarrow_{\in Fib} \\ && B }

be a morphism over some object BB in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f and let u:B‚Ä≤‚ÜíBu \colon B' \to B be any morphism in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f. Let

u *A 1 ‚ü∂u *f u *A 2 ‚ààFib‚Üò ‚Üô ‚ààFib B‚Ä≤ \array{ u^*A_1 &&\stackrel{u^* f}{\longrightarrow}&& u^* A_2 \\ & {}_{\in Fib}\searrow && \swarrow_{\in Fib} \\ && B' }

be the corresponding morphism pulled back along uu.

Then

  • if ff is a fibration then also u *fu^* f is a fibration;

  • if ff is a weak equivalence then also u *fu^* f is a weak equivalence.

(Brown 73, section 4, lemma 1)

Proof

For f‚ààFibf \in Fib the statement follows from the pasting law which says that if in

B‚Ä≤√ó BA 1 ‚ü∂ A 1 ‚Üì u *f‚ààFib ‚Üì f‚ààFib B‚Ä≤√ó BA 2 ‚ü∂ A 2 ‚Üì ‚ààFib ‚Üì ‚ààFib B‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂u B \array{ B' \times_B A_1 &\longrightarrow& A_1 \\ \;\;\downarrow^{\mathrlap{u^* f \in Fib}} && \;\;\downarrow^{\mathrlap{f \in Fib}} \\ B' \times_B A_2 &\longrightarrow& A_2 \\ \;\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} && \;\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ B' &\stackrel{u}{\longrightarrow}& B }

the bottom and the total square are pullback squares, then so is the top square. The same reasoning applies for f‚ààW‚à©Fibf \in W \cap Fib.

Now to see the case that f‚ààWf\in W:

Consider the full subcategory (ùíû /B) f(\mathcal{C}_{/B})_f of the slice category ùíû /B\mathcal{C}_{/B} (def. 43) on its fibrant objects, i.e. the full subcategory of the slice category on the fibrations

X ‚Üì ‚ààFib p B \array{ X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ B }

into BB. By factorizing for every such fibration the diagonal morphisms into the fiber product X√óBXX \underset{B}{\times} X through a weak equivalence followed by a fibration, we obtain path space objects Path B(X)Path_B(X) relative to BB:

(Œî X)/B: X ‚ü∂‚ààW Path B(X) ‚ü∂‚ààFib X√óBX ‚ààFib‚Üò ‚Üì ‚Üô ‚ààFib B. \array{ (\Delta_X)/B \;\colon & X &\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& Path_B(X) &\overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \underset{B}{\times} X \\ & & {}_{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\searrow & \downarrow & \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ & && B } \,.

With these, the factorization lemma (lemma 10) applies in (ùíû /B) f(\mathcal{C}_{/B})_f.

(Notice that for this we do need the restriction of ùíû /B\mathcal{C}_{/B} to the fibrations, because this ensures that the projections p i:X 1√ó BX 2‚ÜíX ip_i \colon X_1 \times_B X_2 \to X_i are still fibrations, which is used in the proof of the factorization lemma (here).)

So now given any

X ‚ü∂‚ààWf Y ‚ààFib‚Üò ‚Üô ‚ààFib B \array{ X && \underoverset{\in W}{f}{\longrightarrow} && Y \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ && B }

apply the factorization lemma in (ùíû /B) f(\mathcal{C}_{/B})_f to factor it as

X ‚ü∂i‚ààW Path B(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib Y ‚ààFib‚Üò ‚Üì ‚Üô ‚ààFib B. \array{ X &\overset{i \in W}{\longrightarrow}& Path_B(f) &\overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\searrow &\downarrow& \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ && B } \,.

By the previous discussion it is sufficient now to show that the base change of ii to B‚Ä≤B' is still a weak equivalence. But by the factorization lemma in (ùíû /B) f(\mathcal{C}_{/B})_f, the morphism ii is right inverse to another acyclic fibration over BB:

id X: X ‚ü∂i‚ààW Path B(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib X ‚ààFib‚Üò ‚Üì ‚Üô ‚ààFib B. \array{ id_X \;\colon & X &\overset{i \in W}{\longrightarrow}& Path_B(f) &\overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ & & {}_{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\searrow &\downarrow& \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ & && B } \,.

(Notice that if we had applied the factorization lemma of Œî X\Delta_X in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f instead of (Œî X)/B(\Delta_X)/B in (ùíû /B)(\mathcal{C}_{/B}) then the corresponding triangle on the right here would not commute.)

Now we may reason as before: the base change of the top morphism here is exhibited by the following pasting composite of pullbacks:

B‚Ä≤√óBX ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì B‚Ä≤√óBPath B(f) ‚ü∂ Path B(f) ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib B‚Ä≤√óBX ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì B‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂ B. \array{ B' \underset{B}{\times} X &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow \\ B' \underset{B}{\times} Path_B(f) &\longrightarrow& Path_B(f) \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ B' \underset{B}{\times}X &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow \\ B' &\longrightarrow& B } \,.

The acyclic fibration Path B(f)Path_B(f) is preserved by this pullback, as is the identity id X:X‚ÜíPath B(X)‚ÜíXid_X \colon X \to Path_B(X)\to X. Hence the weak equivalence X‚ÜíPath B(X)X \to Path_B(X) is preserved by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

Lemma

In a category of fibrant objects, def. 12, the pullback of a weak equivalence along a fibration is again a weak equivalence.

(Brown 73, section 4, lemma 2)

Proof

Let u:B‚Ä≤‚ÜíBu \colon B' \to B be a weak equivalence and p:E‚ÜíB p \colon E \to B be a fibration. We want to show that the left vertical morphism in the pullback

E√ó BB‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂ B‚Ä≤ ‚Üì ‚áí‚ààW ‚Üì ‚ààW E ‚ü∂‚ààFib B \array{ E \times_B B' &\longrightarrow& B' \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\Rightarrow \in W} } && \;\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ E &\stackrel{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& B }

is a weak equivalence.

First of all, using the factorization lemma 10 we may factor B‚Ä≤‚ÜíBB' \to B as

B‚Ä≤‚ü∂‚ààWPath(u)‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©FB B' \stackrel{\in W}{\longrightarrow} Path(u) \stackrel{\in W \cap F}{\longrightarrow} B

with the first morphism a weak equivalence that is a right inverse to an acyclic fibration and the right one an acyclic fibration.

Then the pullback diagram in question may be decomposed into two consecutive pullback diagrams

E√ó BB‚Ä≤ ‚Üí B‚Ä≤ ‚Üì ‚Üì Q ‚Üí‚ààFib Path(u) ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib ‚Üì ‚ààW‚à©Fib E ‚ü∂‚ààFib B, \array{ E \times_B B' &\to& B' \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ Q &\stackrel{\in Fib}{\to}& Path(u) \\ \;\;\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} && \;\;\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W \cap Fib}} \\ E &\stackrel{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& B } \,,

where the morphisms are indicated as fibrations and acyclic fibrations using the stability of these under arbitrary pullback.

This means that the proof reduces to proving that weak equivalences u:B‚Ä≤‚Üí‚ààWBu : B' \stackrel{\in W}{\to} B that are right inverse to some acyclic fibration v:B‚Üí‚ààW‚à©FB‚Ä≤v : B \stackrel{\in W \cap F}{\to} B' map to a weak equivalence under pullback along a fibration.

Given such uu with right inverse vv, consider the pullback diagram

E (p,id)‚ààW‚Üì ‚Üò id E 1‚âî B√ó B‚Ä≤E ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib E ‚Üì ‚ààFib ‚Üì p‚ààFib (pb) B ‚Üì ‚Üì v‚ààW‚à©Fib B ‚ü∂v‚ààFib‚à©W B‚Ä≤. \array{ & E \\ & {}^{\mathllap{{(p,id)}\atop \in W}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ E_1 \coloneqq & B \times_{B'} E & \stackrel{\in W \cap Fib }{\longrightarrow} & E \\ & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p \in Fib }} \\ & &(pb)& B \\ & \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{v \in W \cap Fib}} \\ & B &\overset{v \in Fib \cap W}{\longrightarrow}& B' } \,.

Notice that the indicated universal morphism p√óId:E‚Üí‚ààWE 1p \times Id \colon E \stackrel{\in W}{\to} E_1 into the pullback is a weak equivalence by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

The previous lemma 12 says that weak equivalences between fibrations over BB are themselves preserved by base extension along u:B‚Ä≤‚ÜíBu \colon B' \to B. In total this yields the following diagram

u *E=B‚Ä≤√ó BE ‚ü∂ E u *(p√óId)‚ààW‚Üì p√óId‚ààW‚Üì ‚Üò id u *E 1 ‚ü∂ E 1 ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib E ‚Üì ‚ààFib ‚Üì ‚ààFib ‚Üì p‚ààFib B ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì v‚ààW‚à©Fib B‚Ä≤ ‚ü∂u B ‚ü∂v‚ààW‚à©Fib B‚Ä≤ \array{ && u^* E = B' \times_B E &\longrightarrow & E \\ && {}^{\mathllap{ {u^*(p \times Id)} \atop {\in W} }}\downarrow && {}^{\mathllap{ {p \times Id} \atop {\in W} }}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ && u^* E_1 &\longrightarrow& E_1 &\stackrel{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& E \\ &&\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}}&&\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p \in Fib}} \\ &&&&&& B \\ &&\downarrow&&\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{v \in W \cap Fib}} \\ && B' &\stackrel{u}{\longrightarrow}& B &\stackrel{v \in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& B' }

so that with p√óId:E‚ÜíE 1p \times Id : E \to E_1 a weak equivalence also u *(p√óId)u^* (p \times Id) is a weak equivalence, as indicated.

Notice that u *E=B‚Ä≤√ó BE‚ÜíEu^* E = B' \times_B E \to E is the morphism that we want to show is a weak equivalence. By two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) for that it is now sufficient to show that u *E 1‚ÜíE 1u^* E_1 \to E_1 is a weak equivalence.

That finally follows now since, by assumption, the total bottom horizontal morphism is the identity. Hence so is the top horizontal morphism. Therefore u *E 1‚ÜíE 1u^\ast E_1 \to E_1 is right inverse to a weak equivalence, hence is a weak equivalence.

Lemma

Let (ùíû */) f(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})_f be a category of fibrant objects, def. 12 in a model structure on pointed objects (prop. 36). Given any commuting diagram in ùíû \mathcal{C}^{} of the form

X‚Ä≤ 1 ‚ü∂t‚ààW X 1 ‚ü∂g‚ü∂f X 2 ‚Üì ‚ààFib p 1 ‚Üì ‚ààFib p 2 B ‚ü∂u C \array{ X'_1 &\underoverset{t}{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& X_1 &\stackrel{\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}}& X_2 \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_2}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ && B &\overset{u}{\longrightarrow}& C }

(meaning: both squares commute and tt equalizes ff with gg) then the localization functor Œ≥:(ùíû */) f‚ÜíHo(ùíû */)\gamma \colon (\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})_f \to Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) (def. 10, cor 1) takes the morphisms fib(p 1)‚ü∂‚ü∂fib(p 2)fib(p_1) \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow} fib(p_2) induced by ff and gg on fibers (example 33) to the same morphism, in the homotopy category.

(Brown 73, section 4, lemma 4)

Proof

First consider the pullback of p 2p_2 along uu: this forms the same kind of diagram but with the bottom morphism an identity. Hence it is sufficient to consider this special case.

Consider the full subcategory (ùíû /B */) f(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_{/B})_f of the slice category ùíû /B */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_{/B} (def. 43) on its fibrant objects, i.e. the full subcategory of the slice category on the fibrations

X ‚Üì ‚ààFib p B \array{ X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ B }

into BB. By factorizing for every such fibration the diagonal morphisms into the fiber product X√óBXX \underset{B}{\times} X through a weak equivalence followed by a fibration, we obtain path space objects Path B(X)Path_B(X) relative to BB:

(Œî X)/B: X ‚ü∂‚ààW Path B(X) ‚ü∂‚ààFib X√óBX ‚ààFib‚Üò ‚Üì ‚Üô ‚ààFib B. \array{ (\Delta_X)/B \;\colon & X &\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& Path_B(X) &\overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \underset{B}{\times} X \\ & & {}_{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\searrow & \downarrow & \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ & && B } \,.

With these, the factorization lemma (lemma 10) applies in (ùíû /B */) f(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_{/B})_f.

Let then X‚ÜísPath B(X 2)‚Üí(p 0,p 1)X 2√ó BX 2X\overset{s}{\to}Path_B(X_2)\overset{(p_0,p_1)}{\to} X_2 \times_B X_2 be a path space object for X 2X_2 in the slice over BB and consider the following commuting square

X‚Ä≤ 1 ‚ü∂sft Path B(X 2) ‚ààW t‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààFib (p 0,p 1) X 1 ‚ü∂(f,g) X 2√óBX 2. \array{ X'_1 &\overset{s f t}{\longrightarrow}& Path_B(X_2) \\ {}^{\mathllap{t}}_{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p_0,p_1)}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ X_1 &\overset{(f,g)}{\longrightarrow}& X_2\underset{B}{\times} X_2 } \,.

By factoring this through the pullback (f,g) *(p 0,p 1)(f,g)^\ast(p_0,p_1) and then applying the factorization lemma 10 and then two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) to the factoring morphisms, this may be replaced by a commuting square of the same form, where however the left morphism is an acyclic fibration

X‚Ä≥ 1 ‚ü∂ Path B(X 2) ‚ààW‚à©Fib t‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààFib (p 0,p 1) X 1 ‚ü∂(f,g) X 2√óBX 2. \array{ X''_1 &\overset{}{\longrightarrow}& Path_B(X_2) \\ {}^{\mathllap{t}}_{\mathllap{\in W\cap Fib}} \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p_0,p_1)}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ X_1 &\overset{(f,g)}{\longrightarrow}& X_2\underset{B}{\times} X_2 } \,.

This makes also the morphism X‚Ä≥ 1‚ÜíBX''_1 \to B be a fibration, so that the whole diagram may now be regarded as a diagram in the category of fibrant objects (ùíû /B) f(\mathcal{C}_{/B})_f of the slice category over BB.

As such, the top horizontal morphism now exhibits a right homotopy which under localization Œ≥ B:(ùíû /B) f‚ü∂Ho(ùíû /B)\gamma_B \;\colon\; (\mathcal{C}_{/B})_f \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}_{/B}) (def. 10) of the slice model structure (prop. 36) we have

Œ≥ B(f)=Œ≥ B(g). \gamma_B(f) = \gamma_B(g) \,.

The result then follows by observing that we have a commuting square of functors

(ùíû /B */) f ‚ü∂fib ùíû */ ‚Üì Œ≥ B ‚áô ‚Üì Œ≥ Ho(ùíû /B */) ‚ü∂ Ho(ùíû */), \array{ (\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_{/B})_f &\overset{fib}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma_B}} &\swArrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\gamma}} \\ Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_{/B}) &\longrightarrow& Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) } \,,

because, by lemma 12, the top and right composite sends weak equivalences to isomorphisms, and hence the bottom filler exists by theorem 1. This implies the claim.

Homotopy fibers

We now discuss the homotopy-theoretic properties of the mapping cone- and mapping cocone-constructions from above.

Literature (Brown 73, section 4).

Remark

The factorization lemma 10 with prop. 13 says that the mapping cocone of a morphism ff, def. 18, is equivalently the plain fiber, example 33, of a fibrant resolution fÀú\tilde f of ff:

Path *(f) ‚ü∂ Path(f) ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì fÀú * ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ Path_\ast(f) &\longrightarrow& Path(f) \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\tilde f}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

The following prop. 16 says that, up to equivalence, this situation is independent of the specific fibration resolution fÀú\tilde f provided by the factorization lemma (hence by the prescription for the mapping cocone), but only depends on it being some fibration resolution.

Proposition

In the category of fibrant objects (ùíû */) f(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})_f, def. 12, of a model structure on pointed objects (prop. 36) consider a morphism of fiber-diagrams, hence a commuting diagram of the form

fib(p 1) ‚ü∂ X 1 ‚ü∂‚ààFibp 1 Y 1 ‚Üì h ‚Üì g ‚Üì f fib(p 2) ‚ü∂ X 2 ‚ü∂‚ààFibp 2 Y 2. \array{ fib(p_1) &\longrightarrow& X_1 &\underoverset{\in Fib}{p_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y_1 \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{h}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ fib(p_2) &\longrightarrow& X_2 &\underoverset{\in Fib}{p_2}{\longrightarrow}& Y_2 } \,.

If ff and gg weak equivalences, then so is hh.

Proof

Factor the diagram in question through the pullback of p 2p_2 along ff

fib(p 1) ‚ü∂ X 1 ‚Üì h ‚ààW‚Üì ‚Üò p 1 fib(f *p 2) ‚ü∂ f *X 2 ‚ü∂‚ààFibf *p 2 Y 1 ‚Üì ‚âÉ ‚Üì ‚ààW ‚Üì ‚ààW f fib(p 2) ‚ü∂ X 2 ‚ü∂‚ààFibp 2 Y 2 \array{ fib(p_1) &\longrightarrow& X_1 \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{h}} && {}^{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}} & \\ fib(f^\ast p_2) &\longrightarrow& f^\ast X_2 &\underoverset{\in Fib}{f^\ast p_2}{\longrightarrow}& Y_1 \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}}_{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ fib(p_2) &\longrightarrow& X_2 &\underoverset{\in Fib}{p_2}{\longrightarrow}& Y_2 }

and observe that

  1. fib(f *p 2)=pt *f *p 2=pt *p 2=fib(p 2)fib(f^\ast p_2) = pt^\ast f^\ast p_2 = pt^\ast p_2 = fib(p_2);

  2. f *X 2‚ÜíX 2f^\ast X_2 \to X_2 is a weak equivalence by lemma 13;

  3. X 1‚Üíf *X 2X_1 \to f^\ast X_2 is a weak equivalence by assumption and by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences});

Moreover, this diagram exhibits h:fib(p 1)‚Üífib(f *p 2)=fib(p 2)h \colon fib(p_1)\to fib(f^\ast p_2) = fib(p_2) as the base change, along *‚ÜíY 1\ast \to Y_1, of X 1‚Üíf *X 2X_1 \to f^\ast X_2. Therefore the claim now follows with lemma 12.

Hence we say:

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category and ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} its model category of pointed objects, prop. 36. For f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y any morphism in its category of fibrant objects (ùíû */) f(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})_f, def. 12, then its homotopy fiber

hofib(f)‚ü∂X hofib(f)\longrightarrow X

is the morphism in the homotopy category Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}), def. 9, which is represented by the fiber, example 33, of any fibration resolution fÀú\tilde f of ff (hence any fibration fÀú\tilde f such that ff factors through a weak equivalence followed by fÀú\tilde f).

Dually:

For f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y any morphism in its category of cofibrant objects (ùíû */) c(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})_c, def. 12, then its homotopy cofiber

Y‚ü∂hocofib(f) Y \longrightarrow hocofib(f)

is the morphism in the homotopy category Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}), def. 9, which is represented by the cofiber, example 33, of any cofibration resolution of ff (hence any cofibration fÀú\tilde f such that ff factors as fÀú\tilde f followed by a weak equivalence).

Proposition

The homotopy fiber in def. 20 is indeed well defined, in that for f 1f_1 and f 2f_2 two fibration replacements of any morphisms ff in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f, then their fibers are isomorphic in Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}).

Proof

It is sufficient to exhibit an isomorphism in Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) from the fiber of the fibration replacement given by the factorization lemma 10 (for any choice of path space object) to the fiber of any other fibration resolution.

Hence given a morphism f:Y‚ü∂Xf \colon Y \longrightarrow X and a factorization

f:X‚ü∂‚ààWX^‚ü∂f 1‚ààFibY f \;\colon\; X \underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \underoverset{f_1}{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} Y

consider, for any choice Path(Y)Path(Y) of path space object (def. 7), the diagram

Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib X ‚ààW‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààW Path(f 1) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fib X^ ‚ààFib‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì f 1‚ààFib Path(Y) ‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©Fibp 1 Y p 0‚ààW‚à©Fib‚Üì Y \array{ Path(f) &\overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ Path(f_1) &\overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow}& \hat X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in Fib}}\downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{ {f_1} \atop {\in Fib}}} \\ Path(Y) &\underoverset{\in W \cap Fib}{p_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{ {p_0} \atop \in W \cap Fib}}\downarrow \\ Y }

as in the proof of lemma 10. Now by repeatedly using prop. 16:

  1. the bottom square gives a weak equivalence from the fiber of Path(f 1)‚ÜíPath(Y)Path(f_1) \to Path(Y) to the fiber of f 1f_1;

  2. The square

    Path(f 1) ‚ü∂id Path(f 1) ‚Üì ‚Üì Path(Y) ‚ü∂p 0 Y \array{ Path(f_1) &\overset{id}{\longrightarrow}& Path(f_1) \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ Path(Y) &\underset{p_0}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

    gives a weak equivalence from the fiber of Path(f 1)‚ÜíPath(Y)Path(f_1) \to Path(Y) to the fiber of Path(f 1)‚ÜíYPath(f_1)\to Y.

  3. Similarly the total vertical composite gives a weak equivalence via

    Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààW Path(f 1) ‚Üì ‚Üì Y ‚ü∂id Y \array{ Path(f) &\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& Path(f_1) \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ Y &\underset{id}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

from the fiber of Path(f)‚ÜíYPath(f) \to Y to the fiber of Path(f 1)‚ÜíYPath(f_1)\to Y.

Together this is a zig-zag of weak equivalences of the form

fib(f 1)‚üµ‚ààWfib(Path(f 1)‚ÜíPath(Y))‚ü∂‚ààWfib(Path(f 1)‚ÜíY)‚üµ‚ààWfib(Path(f)‚ÜíY) fib(f_1) \;\overset{\in W}{\longleftarrow}\; fib(Path(f_1)\to Path(Y)) \;\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}\; fib(Path(f_1)\to Y) \;\overset{\in W}{\longleftarrow}\; fib(Path(f) \to Y)

between the fiber of Path(f)‚ÜíYPath(f) \to Y and the fiber of f 1f_1. This gives an isomorphism in the homotopy category.

Example

(fibers of Serre fibrations)

In showing that Serre fibrations are abstract fibrations in the sense of model category theory, theorem 2 implies that the fiber FF (example 33) of a Serre fibration, def. 76

F ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì p B \array{ F &\longrightarrow& X \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ && B }

over any point is actually a homotopy fiber in the sense of def. 20. With prop. 16 this implies that the weak homotopy type of the fiber only depends on the Serre fibration up to weak homotopy equivalence in that if p‚Ä≤:X‚Ä≤‚ÜíB‚Ä≤p' \colon X' \to B' is another Serre fibration fitting into a commuting diagram of the form

X ‚ü∂‚ààW cl X‚Ä≤ ‚Üì p ‚Üì p‚Ä≤ B ‚ü∂‚ààW cl B‚Ä≤ \array{ X &\overset{\in W_{cl}}{\longrightarrow}& X' \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p'}} \\ B &\overset{\in W_{cl}}{\longrightarrow}& B' }

then F‚ü∂‚ààW clF‚Ä≤F \overset{\in W_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} F'.

In particular this gives that the weak homotopy type of the fiber of a Serre fibration p:X‚ÜíBp \colon X \to B does not change as the basepoint is moved in the same connected component. For let Œ≥:I‚ü∂B\gamma \colon I \longrightarrow B be a path between two points

b 0,1:*‚ü∂‚ààW cli 0,1I‚ü∂Œ≥B. b_{0,1} \;\colon\; \ast \underoverset{\in W_{cl}}{i_{0,1}}{\longrightarrow} I \overset{\gamma}{\longrightarrow} B \,.

Then since all objects in (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} are fibrant, and since the endpoint inclusions i 0,1i_{0,1} are weak equivalences, lemma 13 gives the zig-zag of top horizontal weak equivalences in the following diagram:

F b 0= b 0 *p ‚ü∂‚ààW cl Œ≥ *p ‚üµ‚ààW cl b 1 *p =F b 1 ‚Üì (pb) ‚ÜìŒ≥ *f‚ààFib (pb) ‚Üì * ‚ü∂i 0‚ààW cl I ‚üµi 1‚ààW cl * \array{ F_{b_0} = & b_0^\ast p &\overset{\in W_{cl}}{\longrightarrow}& \gamma^{\ast}p &\overset{\in W_{cl}}{\longleftarrow}& b_1^\ast p & = F_{b_1} \\ & \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow{\mathrlap{{\gamma^\ast f} \atop {\in \atop {Fib}}}} &\;\;(pb)& \downarrow \\ & \ast &\underoverset{i_0}{\in W_{cl}}{\longrightarrow}& I &\underoverset{i_1}{\in W_{cl}}{\longleftarrow}& \ast }

and hence an isomorphism F b 0‚âÉF b 1F_{b_0} \simeq F_{b_1} in the classical homotopy category (def. 42).

The same kind of argument applied to maps from the square I 2I^2 gives that if Œ≥ 1,Œ≥ 2:I‚ÜíB\gamma_1, \gamma_2\colon I \to B are two homotopic paths with coinciding endpoints, then the isomorphisms between fibers over endpoints which they induce are equal. (But in general the isomorphism between the fibers does depend on the choice of homotopy class of paths connecting the basepoints!)

The same kind of argument also shows that if BB has the structure of a cell complex (def. 36) then the restriction of the Serre fibration to one cell D nD^n may be identified in the homotopy category with D n√óFD^n \times F, and may be canonically identified so if the fundamental group of XX is trivial. This is used when deriving the Serre-Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence for pp (prop.).

Example

For every continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y between CW-complexes, def. 36, then the standard topological mapping cone is the attaching space (example 19)

Y‚à™ fCone(X)‚ààTop Y \cup_f Cone(X) \;\; \in Top

of YY with the standard cone Cone(X)Cone(X) given by collapsing one end of the standard topological cyclinder X√óIX \times I (def. 28) as shown in example 3.

Equipped with the canonical continuous function

Y‚ü∂Y‚à™ fCone(X) Y \longrightarrow Y \cup_f Cone(X)

this represents the homotopy cofiber, def. 20, of ff with respect to the classical model structure on topological spaces ùíû=Top Quillen\mathcal{C}= Top_{Quillen} from theorem 2.

Proof

By prop. 33, for XX a CW-complex then the standard topological cylinder object X√óIX\times I is indeed a cyclinder object in Top QuillenTop_{Quillen}. Therefore by prop. 13 and the factorization lemma 10, the mapping cone construction indeed produces first a cofibrant replacement of ff and then the ordinary cofiber of that, hence a model for the homotopy cofiber.

Example

The homotopy fiber of the inclusion of classifying spaces BO(n)‚Ü™BO(n+1)B O(n) \hookrightarrow B O(n+1) is the n-sphere S nS^n. See this prop. at Classifying spaces and G-structure.

Example

Suppose a morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y already happens to be a fibration between fibrant objects. The factorization lemma 10 replaces it by a fibration out of the mapping cocylinder Path(f)Path(f), but such that the comparison morphism is a weak equivalence:

fib(f) ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂‚ààFibf Y ‚Üì ‚ààW ‚Üì ‚ààW ‚Üì id fib(fÀú) ‚ü∂ Path(f) ‚ü∂‚ààFibfÀú Y. \array{ fib(f) &\longrightarrow& X &\underoverset{\in Fib}{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ fib(\tilde f) &\longrightarrow& Path(f) &\underoverset{\in Fib}{\tilde f}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Hence by prop. 16 in this case the ordinary fiber of ff is weakly equivalent to the mapping cocone, def. 18.

We may now state the abstract version of the statement of prop. 30:

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category. For f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y any morphism of pointed objects, and for AA a pointed object, def. 44, then the sequence

[A,hofib(f)] *‚ü∂i *[A,X] *‚ü∂f *[A,Y] * [A,hofib(f)]_\ast \overset{i_\ast}{\longrightarrow} [A,X]_\ast \overset{f_\ast}{\longrightarrow} [A,Y]_{\ast}

is exact as a sequence of pointed sets.

(Where the sequence here is the image of the homotopy fiber sequence of def. 20 under the hom-functor [A,‚àí] *:Ho(ùíû */)‚ü∂Set */[A,-]_\ast \;\colon\; Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \longrightarrow Set^{\ast/} from example 34.)

Proof

Let AA, XX and YY denote fibrant-cofibrant objects in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} representing the given objects of the same name in Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}). Moreover, let ff be a fibration in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} representing the given morphism of the same name in Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}).

Then by def. 20 and prop. 17 there is a representative hofib(f)‚ààùíûhofib(f) \in \mathcal{C} of the homotopy fiber which fits into a pullback diagram of the form

hofib(f) ‚ü∂i X ‚Üì ‚Üì f * ‚ü∂ Y \array{ hofib(f) &\overset{i}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y }

With this the hom-sets in question are represented by genuine morphisms in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}, modulo homotopy. From this it follows immediately that im(i *)im(i_\ast) includes into ker(f *)ker(f_\ast). Hence it remains to show the converse: that every element in ker(f *)ker(f_\ast) indeed comes from im(i *)im(i_\ast).

But an element in ker(f *)ker(f_\ast) is represented by a morphism Œ±:A‚ÜíX\alpha \colon A \to X such that there is a left homotopy as in the following diagram

A ‚ü∂Œ± X i 0‚Üì Œ∑Àú‚Üó ‚Üì f A ‚ü∂i 1 Cyl(A) ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y ‚Üì ‚Üì = * ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ && A &\overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ && {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}\downarrow &{}^{\tilde \eta}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ A &\overset{i_1}{\longrightarrow} & Cyl(A) &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{=}} \\ \ast && \longrightarrow && Y } \,.

Now by lemma 3 the square here has a lift Œ∑Àú\tilde \eta, as shown. This means that i 1‚àòŒ∑Àúi_1 \circ\tilde \eta is left homotopic to Œ±\alpha. But by the universal property of the fiber, i 1‚àòŒ∑Àúi_1 \circ \tilde \eta factors through i:hofib(f)‚ÜíXi \colon hofib(f) \to X.

With prop. 16 it also follows notably that the loop space construction becomes well-defined on the homotopy category:

Remark

Given an object X‚ààùíû f */X \in \mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_f, and picking any path space object Path(X)Path(X), def. 7 with induced loop space object Œ©X\Omega X, def. 19, write Path 2(X)=Path(X)√óXPath(X)Path_2(X) = Path(X) \underset{X}{\times} Path(X) for the path space object given by the fiber product of Path(X)Path(X) with itself, via example 1. From the pullback diagram there, the fiber inclusion Œ©X‚ÜíPath(X)\Omega X \to Path(X) induces a morphism

Œ©X√óŒ©X‚ü∂(Œ©X) 2. \Omega X \times \Omega X \longrightarrow (\Omega X)_2 \,.

In the case where ùíû */=Top */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} = Top^{\ast/} and Œ©\Omega is induced, via def. 19, from the standard path space object (def. 33), i.e. in the case that

Œ©X=fib(Maps(I +,X) *‚ü∂X√óX), \Omega X = fib(Maps(I_+,X)_\ast \longrightarrow X \times X) \,,

then this is the operation of concatenating two loops parameterized by I=[0,1]I = [0,1] to a single loop parameterized by [0,2][0,2].

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category, def. 1. Then the construction of forming loop space objects X‚Ü¶Œ©XX\mapsto \Omega X, def. 19 (which on ùíû f */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_f depends on a choice of path space objects, def. 7) becomes unique up to isomorphism in the homotopy category (def. 9) of the model structure on pointed objects (prop. 36) and extends to a functor:

Œ©:Ho(ùíû */)‚ü∂Ho(ùíû */). \Omega \;\colon\; Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \,.

Dually, the reduced suspension operation, def. 19, which on ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} depends on a choice of cylinder object, becomes a functor on the homotopy category

Œ£:Ho(ùíû */)‚ü∂Ho(ùíû */). \Sigma \;\colon\; Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \,.

Moreover, the pairing operation induced on the objects in the image of this functor via remark 11 (concatenation of loops) gives the objects in the image of Œ©\Omega group object structure, and makes this functor lift as

Œ©:Ho(ùíû */)‚ü∂Grp(Ho(ùíû */)). \Omega \;\colon\; Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \longrightarrow Grp(Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})) \,.

(Brown 73, section 4, theorem 3)

Proof

Given an object X‚ààùíû */X \in \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} and given two choices of path space objects Path(X)Path(X) and Path(X)Àú\widetilde{Path(X)}, we need to produce an isomorphism in Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) between Œ©X\Omega X and Œ©ÀúX\tilde \Omega X.

To that end, first lemma 11 implies that any two choices of path space objects are connected via a third path space by a span of morphisms compatible with the structure maps. By two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) every morphism of path space objects compatible with the inclusion of the base object is a weak equivalence. With this, lemma 12 implies that these morphisms induce weak equivalences on the corresponding loop space objects. This shows that all choices of loop space objects become isomorphic in the homotopy category.

Moreover, all the isomorphisms produced this way are actually equal: this follows from lemma 14 applied to

X ‚ü∂s Path(X) ‚ü∂‚ü∂ Path(X)Àú ‚Üì ‚Üì X√óX ‚ü∂id X√óX. \array{ X &\overset{s}{\longrightarrow}& Path(X) &\stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow}& \widetilde{Path(X)} \\ && \downarrow && \downarrow \\ && X\times X &\overset{id}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X } \,.

This way we obtain a functor

Œ©:ùíû f */‚ü∂Ho(ùíû */). \Omega \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{\ast/}_f \longrightarrow Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \,.

By prop. 16 (and using that Cartesian product preserves weak equivalences) this functor sends weak equivalences to isomorphisms. Therefore the functor on homotopy categories now follows with theorem 1.

It is immediate to see that the operation of loop concatenation from remark 11 gives the objects Œ©X‚ààHo(ùíû */)\Omega X \in Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) the structure of monoids. It is now sufficient to see that these are in fact groups:

We claim that the inverse-assigning operation is given by the left map in the following pasting composite

Œ©‚Ä≤X ‚ü∂ Path‚Ä≤(X) ‚ü∂ X√óX ‚Üì ‚âÉ ‚Üì ‚âÉ (pb) ‚Üì swap Œ©X ‚ü∂ Path(X) ‚ü∂(p 0,p 1) X√óX, \array{ \Omega' X &\longrightarrow& Path'(X) &\overset{}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}} &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{swap}} \\ \Omega X &\longrightarrow& Path(X) &\underset{(p_0,p_1)}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X } \,,

(where Path‚Ä≤(X)Path'(X), thus defined, is the path space object obtained from Path(X)Path(X) by ‚Äúreversing the notion of source and target of a path‚Äù).

To see that this is indeed an inverse, it is sufficient to see that the two morphisms

Œ©X‚ü∂‚ü∂(Œ©X) 2 \Omega X \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow} (\Omega X)_2

induced from

Path(X)‚ü∂(s‚àòp 0,s‚àòp 0)‚ü∂ŒîPath(X)√ó XPath‚Ä≤(X) \array{ Path(X) \stackrel{\overset{\Delta}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{(s\circ p_0,s \circ p_0)}{\longrightarrow}} Path(X) \times_X Path'(X) }

coincide in the homotopy category. This follows with lemma 14 applied to the following commuting diagram:

X ‚ü∂i Path(X) ‚ü∂(s‚àòp 0,s‚àòp 0)‚ü∂Œî Path(X)√ó XPath‚Ä≤(X) (p 0,p 1)‚Üì ‚Üì X√óX ‚ü∂Œî‚àòpr 1 X√óX. \array{ X &\overset{i}{\longrightarrow}& Path(X) &\stackrel{\overset{\Delta}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{(s\circ p_0,s \circ p_0)}{\longrightarrow}}& Path(X)\times_X Path'(X) \\ && {}^{\mathllap{(p_0,p_1)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ && X\times X &\overset{\Delta \circ pr_1}{\longrightarrow}& X \times X } \,.

Homotopy pullbacks

The concept of homotopy fibers of def. 20 is a special case of the more general concept of homotopy pullbacks.

Definition

(proper model category)

A model category ùíû\mathcal{C} (def. 1) is called

  • a right proper model category if pullback along fibrations preserves weak equivalences;

  • a left proper model category if pushout along cofibrations preserves weak equivalences;

  • a proper model category if it is both left and right proper.

Example

By lemma 13, a model category ùíû\mathcal{C} (def. 1) in which all objects are fibrant is a right proper model category (def. 21).

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a right proper model category (def. 21). Then a commuting square

A ‚ü∂ B ‚Üì ‚Üì g C ‚ü∂f D \array{ A &\longrightarrow& B \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} \\ C &\underset{f}{\longrightarrow}& D }

in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f is called a homotopy pullback (of ff along gg and equivalently of gg along ff) if the following equivalent conditions hold:

  1. for some factorization of the form

    g:B‚ü∂‚ààWB^‚ü∂‚ààFibD g \colon B \overset{\in W }{\longrightarrow} \hat B \overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} D

    the universally induced morphism from AA into the pullback of B^\hat B along ff is a weak equivalence:

    A ‚ü∂ B ‚ààW‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW C√óDB^ ‚ü∂ B^ ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààFib C ‚ü∂ D. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ C \underset{D}{\times} \hat B &\longrightarrow& \hat B \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ C &\longrightarrow& D } \,.

  2. for some factorization of the form

    f:C‚ü∂‚ààWC^‚ü∂‚ààFibD f \colon C \overset{\in W }{\longrightarrow} \hat C \overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} D

    the universally induced morphism from AA into the pullback of D^\hat D along gg is a weak equivalence:

    A‚ü∂‚ààWC^√óDB. A \overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow} \hat C \underset{D}{\times} B \,.

  3. the above two conditions hold for every such factorization.

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 96, II (8.14))

Proposition

The conditions in def. 22 are indeed equivalent.

Proof

First assume that the first condition holds, in that

A ‚ü∂ B ‚ààW‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW C√óDB^ ‚ü∂ B^ ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààFib C ‚ü∂ D. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ C \underset{D}{\times} \hat B &\longrightarrow& \hat B \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ C &\longrightarrow& D } \,.

Then let

f:C‚ü∂‚ààWC^‚ü∂‚ààFibD f \colon C \overset{\in W }{\longrightarrow} \hat C \overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} D

be any factorization of ff and consider the pasting diagram (using the pasting law for pullbacks)

A ‚ü∂ C^√óDB ‚ü∂ B ‚ààW‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààW C√óDB^ ‚ü∂‚ààW C^√óDD^ ‚ü∂‚ààFib B^ ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààFib (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààFib C ‚ü∂‚ààW C^ ‚ü∂‚ààFib D, \array{ A &\overset{}{\longrightarrow}& \hat C \underset{D}{\times} B &\longrightarrow& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{\in W}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ C\underset{D}{\times} \hat B &\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& \hat C \underset{D}{\times} \hat D &\overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& \hat B \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in \atop Fib}} &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ C &\underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& \hat C &\underset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow}& D } \,,

where the inner morphisms are fibrations and weak equivalences, as shown, by the pullback stability of fibrations (prop. 1) and then since pullback along fibrations preserves weak equivalences by assumption of right properness (def. 21). Hence it follows by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}) that also the comparison morphism A‚ÜíC^√óDBA \to \hat C \underset{D}{\times} B is a weak equivalence.

In conclusion, if the homotopy pullback condition is satisfied for one factorization of gg, then it is satisfied for all factorizations of ff. Since the argument is symmetric in ff and gg, this proves the claim.

Remark

In particular, an ordinary pullback square of fibrant objects, one of whose edges is a fibration, is a homotopy pullback square according to def. 22.

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a right proper model category (def. 21). Given a diagram in ùíû\mathcal{C} of the form

A ‚ü∂ B ‚üµ‚ààFib C ‚Üì ‚ààW ‚Üì ‚ààW ‚Üì ‚ààW D ‚ü∂ E ‚üµ‚ààFib F \array{ A &\longrightarrow& B &\overset{\in Fib}{\longleftarrow}& C \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ D &\longrightarrow& E &\underset{\in Fib}{\longleftarrow}& F }

then the induced morphism on pullbacks is a weak equivalence

A√óBC‚ü∂‚ààWD√óEF. A \underset{B}{\times} C \overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow} D \underset{E}{\times} F \,.
Proof

(The reader should draw the 3-dimensional cube diagram which we describe in words now.)

First consider the universal morphism C‚ÜíE√óFCC \to E \underset{F}{\times} C and observe that it is a weak equivalence by right properness (def. 21) and two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

Then consider the universal morphism A√óBC‚ÜíA√óB(E√óFC)A \underset{B}{\times}C \to A \underset{B}{\times}(E \underset{F}{\times}C) and observe that this is also a weak equivalence, since A√óBCA \underset{B}{\times} C is the limiting cone of a homotopy pullback square by remark 12, and since the morphism is the comparison morphism to the pullback of the factorization constructed in the first step.

Now by using the pasting law, then the commutativity of the ‚Äúleft‚Äù face of the cube, then the pasting law again, one finds that A√óB(E√óFC)‚âÉA√óD(DFE√ó)A \underset{B}{\times} (E \underset{F}{\times} C) \simeq A \underset{D}{\times} (D \underset{E} F{\times}). Again by right properness this implies that A√óB(E√óFC)‚ÜíD√óEFA \underset{B}{\times} (E \underset{F}{\times} C)\to D \underset{E}{\times} F is a weak equivalence.

With this the claim follows by two-out-of-three.

Homotopy pullbacks satisfy the usual abstract properties of pullbacks:

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a right proper model category (def. 21). If in a commuting square in ùíû\mathcal{C} one edge is a weak equivalence, then the square is a homotopy pullback square precisely if the opposite edge is a weak equivalence, too.

Proof

Consider a commuting square of the form

A ‚ü∂ B ‚Üì ‚Üì C ‚ü∂‚ààW D. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& B \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ C &\underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& D } \,.

To detect whether this is a homotopy pullback, by def. 22 and prop. 20, we are to choose any factorization of the right vertical morphism to obtain the pasting composite

A ‚ü∂ B ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚ààW C√óDB^ ‚ü∂‚ààW B^ ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì ‚ààFib C ‚ü∂‚ààW D. \array{ A &\longrightarrow& B \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in W}} \\ C \underset{D}{\times} \hat B &\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& \hat B \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ C &\underset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& D } \,.

Here the morphism in the middle is a weak equivalence by right properness (def. 21). Hence it follows by two-out-of-three that the top left comparison morphism is a weak equivalence (and so the original square is a homotopy pullback) precisely if the top morphism is a weak equivalence.

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a right proper model category (def. 21).

  1. (pasting law) If in a commuting diagram

    A ‚ü∂ B ‚ü∂ C ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì D ‚ü∂ E ‚ü∂ F \array{ A &\longrightarrow& B &\longrightarrow& C \\ \downarrow && \downarrow && \downarrow \\ D &\longrightarrow& E &\underset{}{\longrightarrow}& F }

    the square on the right is a homotoy pullback (def. 22) then the left square is, too, precisely if the total rectangle is;

  2. in the presence of functorial factorization (def. 4) through weak equivalences followed by fibrations:

    every retract of a homotopy pullback square (in the category ùíû f ‚ñ°\mathcal{C}_f^{\Box} of commuting squares in ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f) is itself a homotopy pullback square.

Proof

For the first statement: choose a factorization of C‚Üí‚ààWF^‚Üí‚ààFibFC \overset{\in W}{\to} \hat F \overset{\in Fib}{\to} F, pull it back to a factorization B‚ÜíB^‚Üí‚ààFibEB \to \hat B \overset{\in Fib}{\to} E and assume that B‚ÜíB^B \to \hat B is a weak equivalence, i.e. that the right square is a homotopy pullback. Now use the ordinary pasting law to conclude.

For the second statement: functorially choose a factorization of the two right vertical morphisms of the squares and factor the squares through the pullbacks of the corresponding fibrations along the bottom morphisms, respectively. Now the statement that the squares are homotopy pullbacks is equivalent to their top left vertical morphisms being weak equivalences. Factor these top left morphisms functorially as cofibrations followed by acyclic fibrations. Then the statement that the squares are homotopy pullbacks is equivalent to those top left cofibrations being acyclic. Now the claim follows using that the retract of an acyclic cofibration is an acyclic cofibration (prop. 1).

\,

Long fiber sequences

The ordinary fiber, example 33, of a morphism has the property that taking it twice is always trivial:

*‚âÉfib(fib(f))‚ü∂fib(f)‚ü∂X‚ü∂fY. \ast \simeq fib(fib(f)) \longrightarrow fib(f) \longrightarrow X \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

This is crucially different for the homotopy fiber, def. 20. Here we discuss how this comes about and what the consequences are.

Proposition

Let ùíû f\mathcal{C}_f be a category of fibrant objects of a model category, def. 12 and let f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y be a morphism in its category of pointed objects, def. 44. Then the homotopy fiber of its homotopy fiber, def. 20, is isomorphic, in Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}), to the loop space object Œ©Y\Omega Y of YY (def. 19, prop. 19):

hofib(hofib(X‚ÜífY))‚âÉŒ©Y. hofib(hofib(X \overset{f}{\to}Y)) \simeq \Omega Y \,.
Proof

Assume without restriction that f:X‚ü∂Yf \;\colon\; X \longrightarrow Y is already a fibration between fibrant objects in ùíû\mathcal{C} (otherwise replace and rename). Then its homotopy fiber is its ordinary fiber, sitting in a pullback square

hofib(f)‚âÉ F ‚ü∂i X ‚Üì ‚Üì f * ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ hofib(f) \simeq & F &\overset{i}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ & \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ & \ast &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

In order to compute hofib(hofib(f))hofib(hofib(f)), i.e. hofib(i)hofib(i), we need to replace the fiber inclusion ii by a fibration. Using the factorization lemma 10 for this purpose yields, after a choice of path space object Path(X)Path(X) (def. 7), a replacement of the form

F ‚ü∂‚ààW F√ó XPath(X) i‚Üò ‚Üì ‚ààFib iÀú X. \array{ F &\overset{\in W}{\longrightarrow}& F \times_X Path(X) \\ &{}_{\mathllap{i}}\searrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\tilde i}}_{\mathrlap{\in Fib}} \\ && X } \,.

Hence hofib(i)hofib(i) is the ordinary fiber of this map:

hofib(hofib(f))‚âÉF√ó XPath(X)√ó X*‚ààHo(ùíû */). hofib(hofib(f)) \simeq F \times_X Path(X) \times_X \ast \;\;\;\; \in Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \,.

Notice that

F√ó XPath(X)‚âÉ*√ó YPath(X) F \times_X Path(X) \; \simeq \; \ast \times_Y Path(X)

because of the pasting law:
