F√ó XPath(X) ‚ü∂ Path(X) ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì F ‚ü∂i X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì f * ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ F \times_X Path(X) &\longrightarrow& Path(X) \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow \\ F &\overset{i}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.

Hence

hofib(hofib(f))‚âÉ*√ó YPath(X)√ó X*. hofib(hofib(f)) \;\simeq\; \ast \times_Y Path(X) \times_X \ast \,.

Now we claim that there is a choice of path space objects Path(X)Path(X) and Path(Y)Path(Y) such that this model for the homotopy fiber (as an object in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) sits in a pullback diagram of the following form:

*√ó YPath(X)√ó X* ‚ü∂ Path(X) ‚Üì ‚Üì‚ààW‚à©F Œ©Y ‚ü∂ Path(Y)√ó YX ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ Y√óX. \array{ \ast \times_Y Path(X) \times_X \ast &\longrightarrow& Path(X) \\ \downarrow && \downarrow\mathrlap{\in W \cap F} \\ \Omega Y &\longrightarrow& Path(Y)\times_Y X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y \times X } \,.

By the pasting law and the pullback stability of acyclic fibrations, this will prove the claim.

To see that the bottom square here is indeed a pullback, check the universal property: A morphism out of any AA into *√óY√óXPath(Y)√ó YX\ast \underset{Y \times X}{\times} Path(Y) \times_Y X is a morphism a:A‚ÜíPath(Y)a \colon A \to Path(Y) and a morphism b:A‚ÜíXb \colon A \to X such that p 0(a)=*p_0(a) = \ast, p 1(a)=f(b)p_1(a) = f(b) and b=*b = \ast. Hence it is equivalently just a morphism a:A‚ÜíPath(Y)a \colon A \to Path(Y) such that p 0(a)=*p_0(a) = \ast and p 1(a)=*p_1(a) = \ast. This is the defining universal property of Œ©Y‚âî*√óYPath(Y)√óY*\Omega Y \coloneqq \ast \underset{Y}{\times} Path(Y) \underset{Y}{\times} \ast.

Now to construct the right vertical morphism in the top square (Quillen 67, page 3.1): Let Path(Y)Path(Y) be any path space object for YY and let Path(X)Path(X) be given by a factorization

(id X,i‚àòf,id X):X‚Üí‚ààWPath(X)‚ü∂‚ààFibX√ó YPath(Y)√ó YX (id_X, \; i \circ f, \; id_X) \;\colon\; X \overset{\in W}{\to} Path(X) \overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} X \times_Y Path(Y) \times_Y X

and regarded as a path space object of XX by further comoposing with

(pr 1,pr 3):X√ó YPath(Y)√ó YX‚ü∂‚ààFibX√óX. (pr_1,pr_3)\colon X \times_Y Path(Y) \times_Y X \overset{\in Fib}{\longrightarrow} X \times X \,.

We need to show that Path(X)‚ÜíPath(Y)√ó YXPath(X)\to Path(Y) \times_Y X is an acyclic fibration.

It is a fibration because X√ó YPath(Y)√ó YX‚ÜíPath(Y)√ó YXX\times_Y Path(Y) \times_Y X \to Path(Y)\times_Y X is a fibration, this being the pullback of the fibration X‚ÜífYX \overset{f}{\to} Y.

To see that it is also a weak equivalence, first observe that Path(Y)√ó YX‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©FibX Path(Y)\times_Y X \overset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow} X, this being the pullback of the acyclic fibration of lemma 3. Hence we have a factorization of the identity as

id X:X‚ü∂‚ààWiPath(X)‚ü∂Path(Y)√ó YX‚ü∂‚ààW‚à©FibX id_X \;\colon\; X \underoverset{\in W}{i}{\longrightarrow} Path(X) \overset{}{\longrightarrow} Path(Y)\times_Y X \underset{\in W \cap Fib}{\longrightarrow} X

and so finally the claim follows by two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

Remark

There is a conceptual way to understand prop. 24 as follows: If we draw double arrows to indicate homotopies, then a homotopy fiber (def. 20) is depicted by the following filled square:

hofib(f) ‚ü∂ * ‚Üì ‚áô ‚Üì X ‚ü∂f Y \array{ hofib(f) &\longrightarrow& \ast \\ \downarrow &\swArrow& \downarrow \\ X &\underset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

just like the ordinary fiber (example 33) is given by a plain square

fib(f) ‚ü∂ * ‚Üì ‚Üì X ‚ü∂f Y. \array{ fib(f) &\longrightarrow& \ast \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ X &\underset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

One may show that just like the fiber is the universal solution to making such a commuting square (a pullback limit cone def. 23), so the homotopy fiber is the universal solution up to homotopy to make such a commuting square up to homotopy ‚Äì a homotopy pullback homotopy limit cone.

Now just like ordinary pullbacks satisfy the pasting law saying that attaching two pullback squares gives a pullback rectangle, the analogue is true for homotopy pullbacks. This implies that if we take the homotopy fiber of a homotopy fiber, thereby producing this double homotopy pullback square

hofib(g) ‚ü∂ hofib(f) ‚ü∂ * ‚Üì ‚áô ‚Üì g ‚áô ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ X ‚ü∂f Y \array{ hofib(g) &\longrightarrow& hofib(f) &\longrightarrow& \ast \\ \downarrow &\swArrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g}} &\swArrow& \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& X &\underset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

then the total outer rectangle here is itself a homotopy pullback. But the outer rectangle exhibits the homotopy fiber of the point inclusion, which, via def. 19 and lemma 10, is the loop space object:

Œ©Y ‚ü∂ * ‚Üì ‚áô ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ \Omega Y &\longrightarrow& \ast \\ \downarrow &\swArrow& \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.
Proposition

(long homotopy fiber sequences)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category and let f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y be morphism in the pointed homotopy category Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) (prop. 36). Then:

  1. There is a long sequence to the left in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} of the form

    ‚ãØ‚ü∂Œ©X‚ü∂Œ©¬ØfŒ©Y‚ü∂hofib(f)‚ü∂X‚ü∂fY, \cdots \longrightarrow \Omega X \overset{\overline{\Omega} f}{\longrightarrow} \Omega Y \longrightarrow hofib(f) \longrightarrow X \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y \,,

    where each morphism is the homotopy fiber (def. 20) of the following one: the homotopy fiber sequence of ff. Here Œ©¬Øf\overline{\Omega}f denotes Œ©f\Omega f followed by forming inverses with respect to the group structure on Œ©(‚àí)\Omega(-) from prop. 19.

    Moreover, for A‚ààùíû */A\in \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} any object, then there is a long exact sequence

    ‚ãØ‚Üí[A,Œ© 2Y] *‚ü∂[A,Œ©hofib(f)] *‚ü∂[A,Œ©X] *‚ü∂[A,Œ©Y]‚ü∂[A,hofib(f)] *‚ü∂[A,X] *‚ü∂[A,Y] * \cdots \to [A,\Omega^2 Y]_\ast \longrightarrow [A,\Omega hofib(f)]_\ast \longrightarrow [A, \Omega X]_\ast \longrightarrow [A,\Omega Y] \longrightarrow [A,hofib(f)]_\ast \longrightarrow [A,X]_\ast \longrightarrow [A,Y]_\ast

    of pointed sets, where [‚àí,‚àí] *[-,-]_\ast denotes the pointed set valued hom-functor of example 34.

  2. Dually, there is a long sequence to the right in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} of the form

    X‚ü∂fY‚ü∂hocofib(f)‚ü∂Œ£X‚ü∂Œ£¬ØfŒ£Y‚Üí‚ãØ, X \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y \overset{}{\longrightarrow} hocofib(f) \longrightarrow \Sigma X \overset{\overline{\Sigma} f}{\longrightarrow} \Sigma Y \to \cdots \,,

    where each morphism is the homotopy cofiber (def. 20) of the previous one: the homotopy cofiber sequence of ff. Moreover, for A‚ààùíû */A\in \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} any object, then there is a long exact sequence

    ‚ãØ‚Üí[Œ£ 2X,A] *‚ü∂[Œ£hocofib(f),A] *‚ü∂[Œ£Y,A] *‚ü∂[Œ£X,A]‚ü∂[hocofib(f),A] *‚ü∂[Y,A] *‚ü∂[X,A] * \cdots \to [\Sigma^2 X, A]_\ast \longrightarrow [\Sigma hocofib(f), A]_\ast \longrightarrow [\Sigma Y, A]_\ast \longrightarrow [\Sigma X, A] \longrightarrow [hocofib(f),A]_\ast \longrightarrow [Y,A]_\ast \longrightarrow [X,A]_\ast

    of pointed sets, where [‚àí,‚àí] *[-,-]_\ast denotes the pointed set valued hom-functor of example 34.

(Quillen 67, I.3, prop. 4)

Proof

That there are long sequences of this form is the result of combining prop. 24 and prop. 18.

It only remains to see that it is indeed the morphisms Œ©¬Øf\overline{\Omega} f that appear, as indicated.

In order to see this, it is convenient to adopt the following notation: for f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y a morphism, then we denote the collection of generalized element of its homotopy fiber as

hofib(f)={(x,f(x)‚áùŒ≥ 1*)} hofib(f) = \left\{ (x, f(x) \overset{\gamma_1}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast) \right\}

indicating that these elements are pairs consisting of an element xx of XX and a ‚Äúpath‚Äù (an element of the given path space object) from f(x)f(x) to the basepoint.

This way the canonical map hofib(f)‚ÜíXhofib(f) \to X is (x,f(x)‚áù*)‚Ü¶x(x, f(x) \rightsquigarrow \ast) \mapsto x. Hence in this notation the homotopy fiber of the homotopy fiber reads

hofib(hofib(f))={((x,f(x)‚áùŒ≥ 1*),x‚áùŒ≥ 2*)}. hofib(hofib(f)) = \left\{ ( (x, f(x) \overset{\gamma_1}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast), x \overset{\gamma_2}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast ) \right\} \,.

This identifies with Œ©Y\Omega Y by forming the loops

Œ≥ 1‚ãÖf(Œ≥ 2¬Ø), \gamma_1 \cdot f(\overline{\gamma_2}) \,,

where the overline denotes reversal and the dot denotes concatenation.

Then consider the next homotopy fiber

hofib(hofib(hofib(f)))={(((x,f(x)‚áùŒ≥ 1*),x‚áùŒ≥ 2*),(x ‚áùŒ≥ 3 * f(x) ‚áùf(Œ≥ 3) * Œ≥ 1‚Üò ‚áí ‚Üô *))}, hofib(hofib(hofib(f))) = \left\{ \left( ( (x, f(x) \overset{\gamma_1}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast), x \overset{\gamma_2}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast ), \left( \array{ x && \overset{\gamma_3}{\rightsquigarrow} && \ast \\ f(x) &&\overset{f(\gamma_3)}{\rightsquigarrow}&& \ast \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\gamma_1}}\searrow & \Rightarrow & \swarrow_{\mathllap{}} \\ && \ast } \right) \right) \right\} \,,

where on the right we have a path in hofib(f)hofib(f) from (x,f(x)‚áùŒ≥ 1*)(x, f(x)\overset{\gamma_1}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast) to the basepoint element. This is a path Œ≥ 3\gamma_3 together with a path-of-paths which connects f 1f_1 to f(Œ≥ 3)f(\gamma_3).

By the above convention this is identified with the loop in XX which is

Œ≥ 2‚ãÖ(Œ≥¬Ø 3). \gamma_2 \cdot (\overline{\gamma}_3) \,.

But the map to hofib(hofib(f))hofib(hofib(f)) sends this data to ((x,f(x)‚áùŒ≥ 1*),x‚áùŒ≥ 2*)( (x, f(x) \overset{\gamma_1}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast), x \overset{\gamma_2}{\rightsquigarrow} \ast ), hence to the loop

Œ≥ 1‚ãÖf(Œ≥ 2¬Ø) ‚âÉf(Œ≥ 3)‚ãÖf(Œ≥ 2¬Ø) =f(Œ≥ 3‚ãÖŒ≥ 2¬Ø) =f(Œ≥ 2‚ãÖŒ≥¬Ø 3¬Ø) =f(Œ≥ 2‚ãÖŒ≥¬Ø 3)¬Ø, \begin{aligned} \gamma_1 \cdot f( \overline{\gamma_2} ) & \simeq f(\gamma_3) \cdot f(\overline{\gamma_2}) \\ & = f( \gamma_3 \cdot \overline{\gamma_2} ) \\ & = f ( \overline{\gamma_2 \cdot \overline{\gamma}_3} ) \\ & = \overline{f(\gamma_2 \cdot \overline{\gamma}_3) } \end{aligned} \,,

hence to the reveral of the image under ff of the loop in XX.

Remark

In (Quillen 67, I.3, prop. 3, prop. 4) more is shown than stated in prop. 25: there the connecting homomorphism Œ©Y‚Üíhofib(f)\Omega Y \to hofib(f) is not just shown to exist, but is described in detail via an action of Œ©Y\Omega Y on hofib(f)hofib(f) in Ho(ùíû)Ho(\mathcal{C}). This takes a good bit more work. For our purposes here, however, it is sufficient to know that such a morphism exists at all, hence that Œ©Y‚âÉhofib(hofib(f))\Omega Y \simeq hofib(hofib(f)).

Example

Let ùíû=(Top cg) Quillen\mathcal{C} = (Top_{cg})_{Quillen} be the classical model structure on topological spaces (compactly generated) from theorem 2, theorem 4. Then using the standard pointed topological path space objects Maps(I +,X)Maps(I_+,X) from def. 33 and example 32 as the abstract path space objects in def. 7, via prop. 34, this gives that

[*,Œ© nX]‚âÉœÄ n(X) [\ast, \Omega^n X] \simeq \pi_n(X)

is the nnth homotopy group, def. 30, of XX at its basepoint.

Hence using A=*A = \ast in the first item of prop. 25, the long exact sequence this gives is of the form

‚ãØ‚ÜíœÄ 3(X)‚ü∂f *œÄ 3(Y)‚ü∂œÄ 2(hofib(f))‚ü∂œÄ 2(X)‚ü∂‚àíf *œÄ 2(Y)‚ü∂œÄ 1(hofib(f))‚ü∂œÄ 1(X)‚ü∂f *œÄ 1(Y)‚ü∂*. \cdots \to \pi_3(X) \overset{f_\ast}{\longrightarrow} \pi_3(Y) \longrightarrow \pi_2(hofib(f)) \overset{}{\longrightarrow} \pi_2(X) \overset{-f_\ast}{\longrightarrow} \pi_2(Y) \longrightarrow \pi_1(hofib(f)) \overset{}{\longrightarrow} \pi_1(X) \overset{f_\ast}{\longrightarrow} \pi_1(Y) \overset{}{\longrightarrow} \ast \,.

This is called the long exact sequence of homotopy groups induced by ff.

Remark

As we pass to stable homotopy theory (in Part 1)), the long exact sequences in example 9 become long not just to the left, but also to the right. Given then a tower of fibrations, there is an induced sequence of such long exact sequences of homotopy groups, which organizes into an exact couple. For more on this see at Interlude -- Spectral sequences (this remark).

Example

Let again ùíû=(Top cg) Quillen\mathcal{C} = (Top_{cg})_{Quillen} be the classical model structure on topological spaces (compactly generated) from theorem 2, theorem 4, as in example 9. For E‚ààTop cg */E \in Top_{cg}^{\ast/} any pointed topological space and i:A‚Ü™Xi \colon A \hookrightarrow X an inclusion of pointed topological spaces, the exactness of the sequence in the second item of prop. 25

‚ãØ‚Üí[hocofib(i),E]‚ü∂[X,E] *‚ü∂[A,E] *‚Üí‚ãØ \cdots \to [hocofib(i), E] \longrightarrow [X,E]_\ast \longrightarrow [A,E]_\ast \to \cdots

gives that the functor

[‚àí,E] *:(Top CW */) op‚ü∂Set */ [-,E]_\ast \;\colon\; (Top^{\ast/}_{CW})^{op} \longrightarrow Set^{\ast/}

behaves like one degree in an additive reduced cohomology theory (def.). The Brown representability theorem (thm.) implies that all additive reduced cohomology theories are degreewise representable this way (prop.).

\,

‚àû\infty-Groupoids I): Topological homotopy theory

This section first recalls relevant concepts from actual topology (‚Äúpoint-set topology‚Äù) and highlights facts that motivate the axiomatics of model categories below. We prove two technical lemmas (lemma 15 and lemma 19) that serve to establish the abstract homotopy theory of topological spaces further below.

Then we discuss how the category Top of topological spaces satisfies the axioms of abstract homotopy theory (model category) theory, def. 1.

Literature (Hirschhorn 15)

\,

Throughout, let Top denote the category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions between them. Its isomorphisms are the homeomorphisms.

(Further below we restrict attention to the full subcategory of compactly generated topological spaces.)

Universal constructions

To begin with, we recall some basics on universal constructions in Top: limits and colimits of diagrams of topological spaces; exponential objects.

Generally, recall:

Definition

A diagram in a category ùíû\mathcal{C} is a small category II and a functor

X ‚Ä¢:I‚ü∂ùíû X_\bullet \;\colon\; I \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}
(i‚ü∂œïj)‚Ü¶(X i‚ü∂X(œï)X j). (i \overset{\phi}{\longrightarrow} j) \; \mapsto ( X_i \overset{X(\phi)}{\longrightarrow} X_j) \,.

A cone over this diagram is an object QQ equipped with morphisms p i:Q‚ü∂X ip_i \colon Q \longrightarrow X_i for all i‚ààIi \in I, such that all these triangles commute:

Q p i‚Üô ‚Üò p j X i ‚ü∂X(œï) X j. \array{ && Q \\ & {}^{\mathllap{p_i}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{p_j}} \\ X_i && \underset{X(\phi)}{\longrightarrow} && X_j } \,.

Dually, a co-cone under the diagram is QQ equipped with morphisms q i:X i‚ü∂Qq_i \colon X_i \longrightarrow Q such that all these triangles commute

X i ‚ü∂X(œï) X j q i‚Üò ‚Üô q j Q. \array{ X_i && \overset{X(\phi)}{\longrightarrow} && X_j \\ & {}_{\mathllap{q_i}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{q_j}} \\ && Q } \,.

A limit over the diagram is a universal cone, denoted lim‚üµ i‚ààIX i\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} X_i, that is: a cone such that every other cone uniquely factors through it Q‚ü∂lim‚üµ i‚ààIX iQ \longrightarrow \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} X_i, making all the resulting triangles commute.

Dually, a colimit over the diagram is a universal co-cone, denoted lim‚ü∂ i‚ààIX i\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} X_i.

We now discuss limits and colimits in ùíû=\mathcal{C}= Top. The key for understanding these is the fact that there are initial and final topologies:

Definition

Let {X i=(S i,œÑ i)‚ààTop} i‚ààI\{X_i = (S_i,\tau_i) \in Top\}_{i \in I} be a set of topological spaces, and let S‚ààSetS \in Set be a bare set. Then

  1. For {S‚Üíf iS i} i‚ààI\{S \stackrel{f_i}{\to} S_i \}_{i \in I} a set of functions out of SS, the initial topology œÑ initial({f i} i‚ààI)\tau_{initial}(\{f_i\}_{i \in I}) is the topology on SS with the minimum collection of open subsets such that all f i:(S,œÑ initial({f i} i‚ààI))‚ÜíX if_i \colon (S,\tau_{initial}(\{f_i\}_{i \in I}))\to X_i are continuous.

  2. For {S i‚Üíf iS} i‚ààI\{S_i \stackrel{f_i}{\to} S\}_{i \in I} a set of functions into SS, the final topology œÑ final({f i} i‚ààI)\tau_{final}(\{f_i\}_{i \in I}) is the topology on SS with the maximum collection of open subsets such that all f i:X i‚Üí(S,œÑ final({f i} i‚ààI))f_i \colon X_i \to (S,\tau_{final}(\{f_i\}_{i \in I})) are continuous.

Example

For XX a single topological space, and Œπ S:S‚Ü™U(X)\iota_S \colon S \hookrightarrow U(X) a subset of its underlying set, then the initial topology œÑ intial(Œπ S)\tau_{intial}(\iota_S), def. 24, is the subspace topology, making

Œπ S:(S,œÑ initial(Œπ S))‚Ü™X \iota_S \;\colon\; (S, \tau_{initial}(\iota_S)) \hookrightarrow X

a topological subspace inclusion.

Example

Conversely, for p S:U(X)‚ü∂Sp_S \colon U(X) \longrightarrow S an epimorphism, then the final topology œÑ final(p S)\tau_{final}(p_S) on SS is the quotient topology.

Proposition

Let II be a small category and let X ‚Ä¢:I‚ü∂TopX_\bullet \colon I \longrightarrow Top be an II-diagram in Top (a functor from II to TopTop), with components denoted X i=(S i,œÑ i)X_i = (S_i, \tau_i), where S i‚ààSetS_i \in Set and œÑ i\tau_i a topology on S iS_i. Then:

  1. The limit of X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet exists and is given by the topological space whose underlying set is the limit in Set of the underlying sets in the diagram, and whose topology is the initial topology, def. 24, for the functions p ip_i which are the limiting cone components:

    lim‚üµ i‚ààIS i p i‚Üô ‚Üò p j S i ‚ü∂ S j. \array{ && \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} S_i \\ & {}^{\mathllap{p_i}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{p_j}} \\ S_i && \underset{}{\longrightarrow} && S_j } \,.

    Hence

    lim‚üµ i‚ààIX i‚âÉ(lim‚üµ i‚ààIS i,œÑ initial({p i} i‚ààI)) \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} X_i \simeq \left(\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} S_i,\; \tau_{initial}(\{p_i\}_{i \in I})\right)

  2. The colimit of X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet exists and is the topological space whose underlying set is the colimit in Set of the underlying diagram of sets, and whose topology is the final topology, def. 24 for the component maps Œπ i\iota_i of the colimiting cocone

    S i ‚ü∂ S j Œπ i‚Üò ‚Üô Œπ j lim‚ü∂ i‚ààIS i. \array{ S_i && \longrightarrow && S_j \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\iota_i}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\iota_j}} \\ && \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} S_i } \,.

    Hence

    lim‚ü∂ i‚ààIX i‚âÉ(lim‚ü∂ i‚ààIS i,œÑ final({Œπ i} i‚ààI)) \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} X_i \simeq \left(\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} S_i,\; \tau_{final}(\{\iota_i\}_{i \in I})\right)

(e.g. Bourbaki 71, section I.4)

Proof

The required universal property of (lim‚üµ i‚ààIS i,œÑ initial({p i} i‚ààI))\left(\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} S_i,\; \tau_{initial}(\{p_i\}_{i \in I})\right) (def. 23) is immediate: for

(S,œÑ) f i‚Üô ‚Üò f j X i ‚ü∂ X j \array{ && (S,\tau) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f_i}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{f_j}} \\ X_i && \underset{}{\longrightarrow} && X_j }

any cone over the diagram, then by construction there is a unique function of underlying sets S‚ü∂lim‚üµ i‚ààIS iS \longrightarrow \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i \in I} S_i making the required diagrams commute, and so all that is required is that this unique function is always continuous. But this is precisely what the initial topology ensures.

The case of the colimit is formally dual.

Example

The limit over the empty diagram in TopTop is the point *\ast with its unique topology.

Example

For {X i} i‚ààI\{X_i\}_{i \in I} a set of topological spaces, their coproduct ‚äîi‚ààIX i‚ààTop\underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} X_i \in Top is their disjoint union.

In particular:

Example

For S‚ààSetS \in Set, the SS-indexed coproduct of the point, ‚àês‚ààS*\underset{s \in S}{\coprod}\ast is the set SS itself equipped with the final topology, hence is the discrete topological space on SS.

Example

For {X i} i‚ààI\{X_i\}_{i \in I} a set of topological spaces, their product ‚àèi‚ààIX i‚ààTop\underset{i \in I}{\prod} X_i \in Top is the Cartesian product of the underlying sets equipped with the product topology, also called the Tychonoff product.

In the case that SS is a finite set, such as for binary product spaces X√óYX \times Y, then a sub-basis for the product topology is given by the Cartesian products of the open subsets of (a basis for) each factor space.

Example

The equalizer of two continuous functions f,g:X‚ü∂‚ü∂Yf, g \colon X \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow} Y in TopTop is the equalizer of the underlying functions of sets

eq(f,g)‚Ü™S X‚ü∂g‚ü∂fS Y eq(f,g) \hookrightarrow S_X \stackrel{\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}} S_Y

(hence the largets subset of S XS_X on which both functions coincide) and equipped with the subspace topology, example 11.

Example

The coequalizer of two continuous functions f,g:X‚ü∂‚ü∂Yf, g \colon X \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow} Y in TopTop is the coequalizer of the underlying functions of sets

S X‚ü∂g‚ü∂fS Y‚ü∂coeq(f,g) S_X \stackrel{\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{g}{\longrightarrow}} S_Y \longrightarrow coeq(f,g)

(hence the quotient set by the equivalence relation generated by f(x)‚àºg(x)f(x) \sim g(x) for all x‚ààXx \in X) and equipped with the quotient topology, example 12.

Example

For

A ‚ü∂g Y f‚Üì X \array{ A &\overset{g}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow \\ X }

two continuous functions out of the same domain, then the colimit under this diagram is also called the pushout, denoted

A ‚ü∂g Y f‚Üì ‚Üì g *f X ‚ü∂ X‚äî AY.. \array{ A &\overset{g}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{g_\ast f}} \\ X &\longrightarrow& X \sqcup_A Y \,. } \,.

(Here g *fg_\ast f is also called the pushout of ff, or the cobase change of ff along gg.)

This is equivalently the coequalizer of the two morphisms from AA to the coproduct of XX with YY (example 14):

A‚ü∂‚ü∂X‚äîY‚ü∂X‚äî AY. A \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow} X \sqcup Y \longrightarrow X \sqcup_A Y \,.

If gg is an inclusion, one also writes X‚à™ fYX \cup_f Y and calls this the attaching space.

By example 18 the pushout/attaching space is the quotient topological space

X‚äî AY‚âÉ(X‚äîY)/‚àº X \sqcup_A Y \simeq (X\sqcup Y)/\sim

of the disjoint union of XX and YY subject to the equivalence relation which identifies a point in XX with a point in YY if they have the same pre-image in AA.

(graphics from Aguilar-Gitler-Prieto 02)

Notice that the defining universal property of this colimit means that completing the span

A ‚ü∂ Y ‚Üì X \array{ A &\longrightarrow& Y \\ \downarrow \\ X }

to a commuting square

A ‚ü∂ Y ‚Üì ‚Üì X ‚ü∂ Z \array{ A &\longrightarrow& Y \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ X &\longrightarrow& Z }

is equivalent to finding a morphism

X‚äîAY‚ü∂Z. X \underset{A}{\sqcup} Y \longrightarrow Z \,.
Example

For A‚Ü™XA\hookrightarrow X a topological subspace inclusion, example 11, then the pushout

A ‚Ü™ X ‚Üì (po) ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ X/A \array{ A &\hookrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& X/A }

is the quotient space or cofiber, denoted X/AX/A.

Example

An important special case of example 19:

For n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} write

  • D n‚âî{x‚Üí‚àà‚Ñù n||x‚Üí|‚â§1}‚Ü™‚Ñù nD^n \coloneqq \{ \vec x\in \mathbb{R}^n | \; {\vert \vec x \vert \leq 1}\} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^n for the standard topological n-disk (equipped with its subspace topology as a subset of Cartesian space);

  • S n‚àí1=‚àÇD n‚âî{x‚Üí‚àà‚Ñù n||x‚Üí|=1}‚Ü™‚Ñù nS^{n-1} = \partial D^n \coloneqq \{ \vec x\in \mathbb{R}^n | \; {\vert \vec x \vert = 1}\} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^n for its boundary, the standard topological n-sphere.

Notice that S ‚àí1=‚àÖS^{-1} = \emptyset and that S 0=*‚äî*S^0 = \ast \sqcup \ast.

Let

i n:S n‚àí1‚ü∂D n i_n \colon S^{n-1}\longrightarrow D^n

be the canonical inclusion of the standard (n-1)-sphere as the boundary of the standard n-disk (both regarded as topological spaces with their subspace topology as subspaces of the Cartesian space ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n).

Then the colimit in Top under the diagram

D n‚üµi nS n‚àí1‚ü∂i nD n, D^n \overset{i_n}{\longleftarrow} S^{n-1} \overset{i_n}{\longrightarrow} D^n \,,

i.e. the pushout of i ni_n along itself, is the n-sphere S nS^n:

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂i n D n i n‚Üì (po) ‚Üì D n ‚ü∂ S n. \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{i_n}{\longrightarrow}& D^n \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_n}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ D^n &\longrightarrow& S^n } \,.

(graphics from Ueno-Shiga-Morita 95)

Another kind of colimit that will play a role for certain technical constructions is transfinite composition. First recall

Definition

A partial order is a set SS equipped with a relation ‚â§\leq such that for all elements a,b,c‚ààSa,b,c \in S

1) (reflexivity) a‚â§aa \leq a;

2) (transitivity) if a‚â§ba \leq b and b‚â§cb \leq c then a‚â§ca \leq c;

3) (antisymmetry) if a‚â§ba\leq b and b‚â§a\b \leq a then a=ba = b.

This we may and will equivalently think of as a category with objects the elements of SS and a unique morphism a‚Üíba \to b precisely if a‚â§ba\leq b. In particular an order-preserving function between partially ordered sets is equivalently a functor between their corresponding categories.

A bottom element ‚ä•\bot in a partial order is one such that ‚ä•‚â§a\bot \leq a for all a. A top element ‚ä§\top is one for wich a‚â§‚ä§a \leq \top.

A partial order is a total order if in addition

4) (totality) either a‚â§ba\leq b or b‚â§ab \leq a.

A total order is a well order if in addition

5) (well-foundedness) every non-empty subset has a least element.

An ordinal is the equivalence class of a well-order.

The successor of an ordinal is the class of the well-order with a top element freely adjoined.

A limit ordinal is one that is not a successor.

Example

The finite ordinals are labeled by n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, corresponding to the well-orders {0‚â§1‚â§2‚ãØ‚â§n‚àí1}\{0 \leq 1 \leq 2 \cdots \leq n-1\}. Here (n+1)(n+1) is the successor of nn. The first non-empty limit ordinal is œâ=[(‚Ñï,‚â§)]\omega = [(\mathbb{N}, \leq)].

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a category, and let I‚äÇMor(ùíû)I \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) be a class of its morphisms.

For Œ±\alpha an ordinal (regarded as a category), an Œ±\alpha-indexed transfinite sequence of elements in II is a diagram

X ‚Ä¢:Œ±‚ü∂ùíû X_\bullet \;\colon\; \alpha \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}

such that

  1. X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet takes all successor morphisms Œ≤‚Üí‚â§Œ≤+1\beta \stackrel{\leq}{\to} \beta + 1 in Œ±\alpha to elements in II

    X Œ≤,Œ≤+1‚ààI X_{\beta,\beta + 1} \in I

  2. X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet is continuous in that for every nonzero limit ordinal Œ≤<Œ±\beta \lt \alpha, X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet restricted to the full-subdiagram {Œ≥|Œ≥‚â§Œ≤}\{\gamma \;|\; \gamma \leq \beta\} is a colimiting cocone in ùíû\mathcal{C} for X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet restricted to {Œ≥|Œ≥<Œ≤}\{\gamma \;|\; \gamma \lt \beta\}.

The corresponding transfinite composition is the induced morphism

X 0‚ü∂X Œ±‚âîlim‚ü∂X ‚Ä¢ X_0 \longrightarrow X_\alpha \coloneqq \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}X_\bullet

into the colimit of the diagram, schematically:

X 0 ‚ÜíX 0,1 X 1 ‚ÜíX 1,2 X 2 ‚Üí ‚ãØ ‚Üò ‚Üì ‚Üô ‚ãØ X Œ±. \array{ X_0 &\stackrel{X_{0,1}}{\to}& X_1 &\stackrel{X_{1,2}}{\to}& X_2 &\to& \cdots \\ & \searrow & \downarrow & \swarrow & \cdots \\ && X_\alpha } \,.

We now turn to the discussion of mapping spaces/exponential objects.

Definition

For XX a topological space and YY a locally compact topological space (in that for every point, every neighbourhood contains a compact neighbourhood), the mapping space

X Y‚ààTop X^Y \in Top

is the topological space

  • whose underlying set is the set Hom Top(Y,X)Hom_{Top}(Y,X) of continuous functions Y‚ÜíXY \to X,

  • whose open subsets are unions of finitary intersections of the following subbase elements of standard open subsets:

    the standard open subset U K‚äÇHom Top(Y,X)U^K \subset Hom_{Top}(Y,X) for

    • K‚Ü™YK \hookrightarrow Y a compact topological space subset

    • U‚Ü™XU \hookrightarrow X an open subset

    is the subset of all those continuous functions ff that fit into a commuting diagram of the form

    K ‚Ü™ Y ‚Üì ‚Üì f U ‚Ü™ X. \array{ K &\hookrightarrow& Y \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ U &\hookrightarrow& X } \,.

Accordingly this is called the compact-open topology on the set of functions.

The construction extends to a functor

(‚àí) (‚àí):Top lc op√óTop‚ü∂Top. (-)^{(-)} \;\colon\; Top_{lc}^{op} \times Top \longrightarrow Top \,.
Proposition

For XX a topological space and YY a locally compact topological space (in that for each point, each open neighbourhood contains a compact neighbourhood), the topological mapping space X YX^Y from def. 27 is an exponential object, i.e. the functor (‚àí) Y(-)^Y is right adjoint to the product functor Y√ó(‚àí)Y \times (-): there is a natural bijection

Hom Top(Z√óY,X)‚âÉHom Top(Z,X Y) Hom_{Top}(Z \times Y, X) \simeq Hom_{Top}(Z, X^Y)

between continuous functions out of any product topological space of YY with any Z‚ààTopZ \in Top and continuous functions from ZZ into the mapping space.

A proof is spelled out here (or see e.g. Aguilar-Gitler-Prieto 02, prop. 1.3.1).

Remark

In the context of prop. 27 it is often assumed that YY is also a Hausdorff topological space. But this is not necessary. What assuming Hausdorffness only achieves is that all alternative definitions of ‚Äúlocally compact‚Äù become equivalent to the one that is needed for the proposition: for every point, every open neighbourhood contains a compact neighbourhood.

Remark

Proposition 27 fails in general if YY is not locally compact. Therefore the plain category Top of all topological spaces is not a Cartesian closed category.

This is no problem for the construction of the homotopy theory of topological spaces as such, but it becomes a technical nuisance for various constructions that one would like to perform within that homotopy theory. For instance on general pointed topological spaces the smash product is in general not associative.

On the other hand, without changing any of the following discussion one may just pass to a more convenient category of topological spaces such as notably the full subcategory of compactly generated topological spaces Top cg‚Ü™TopTop_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top (def. 88) which is Cartesian closed. This we turn to below.

Homotopy

The fundamental concept of homotopy theory is clearly that of homotopy. In the context of topological spaces this is about contiunous deformations of continuous functions parameterized by the standard interval:

Definition

Write

I‚âî[0,1]‚Ü™‚Ñù I \coloneqq [0,1] \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}

for the standard topological interval, a compact connected topological subspace of the real line.

Equipped with the canonical inclusion of its two endpoints

*‚äî*‚ü∂(Œ¥ 0,Œ¥ 1)I‚ü∂‚àÉ!* \ast \sqcup \ast \stackrel{(\delta_0,\delta_1)}{\longrightarrow} I \stackrel{\exists !}{\longrightarrow} \ast

this is the standard interval object in Top.

For X‚ààTopX \in Top, the product topological space X√óIX\times I, example 16, is called the standard cylinder object over XX. The endpoint inclusions of the interval make it factor the codiagonal on XX

‚àá X:X‚äîX‚ü∂((id,Œ¥ 0),(id,Œ¥ 1))X√óI‚ü∂X. \nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \stackrel{((id,\delta_0),(id,\delta_1))}{\longrightarrow} X \times I \longrightarrow X \,.
Definition

(left homotopy)

For f,g:X‚ü∂Yf,g\colon X \longrightarrow Y two continuous functions between topological spaces X,YX,Y, then a left homotopy

Œ∑:f‚áí Lg \eta \colon f \,\Rightarrow_L\, g

is a continuous function

Œ∑:X√óI‚ü∂Y \eta \;\colon\; X \times I \longrightarrow Y

out of the standard cylinder object over XX, def. 28, such that this fits into a commuting diagram of the form

X (id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üò f X√óI ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y (id,Œ¥ 1)‚Üë ‚Üó g X. \array{ X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ X \times I &\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_1)}}\uparrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{g}} \\ X } \,.

(graphics grabbed from J. Tauber here)

Example

Let XX be a topological space and let x,y‚ààXx,y \in X be two of its points, regarded as functions x,y:*‚ü∂Xx,y \colon \ast \longrightarrow X from the point to XX. Then a left homotopy, def. 29, between these two functions is a commuting diagram of the form

* Œ¥ 0‚Üì ‚Üò x I ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y Œ¥ 1‚Üë ‚Üó y *. \array{ \ast \\ {}^{\mathllap{\delta_0}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{x}} \\ I &\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{\delta_1}}\uparrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{y}} \\ \ast } \,.

This is simply a continuous path in XX whose endpoints are xx and yy.

For instance:

Example

Let

const 0:I‚ü∂*‚ü∂Œ¥ 0I const_0 \;\colon\; I \longrightarrow \ast \overset{\delta_0}{\longrightarrow} I

be the continuous function from the standard interval I=[0,1]I = [0,1] to itself that is constant on the value 0. Then there is a left homotopy, def. 29, from the identity function

Œ∑:id I‚áíconst 0 \eta \;\colon\; id_I \Rightarrow const_0

given by

Œ∑(x,t)‚âîx(1‚àít). \eta(x,t) \coloneqq x(1-t) \,.

A key application of the concept of left homotopy is to the definition of homotopy groups:

Definition

For XX a topological space, then its set œÄ 0(X)\pi_0(X) of connected components, also called the 0-th homotopy set, is the set of left homotopy-equivalence classes (def. 29) of points x:*‚ÜíXx \colon \ast \to X, hence the set of path-connected components of XX (example 23). By composition this extends to a functor

œÄ 0:Top‚ü∂Set. \pi_0 \colon Top \longrightarrow Set \,.

For n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, n‚â•1n \geq 1 and for x:*‚ÜíXx \colon \ast \to X any point, then the nnth homotopy group œÄ n(X,x)\pi_n(X,x) of XX at xx is the group

  • whose underlying set is the set of left homotopy-equivalence classes of maps I n‚ü∂XI^n \longrightarrow X that take the boundary of I nI^n to xx and where the left homotopies Œ∑\eta are constrained to be constant on the boundary;

  • whose group product operation takes [Œ±:I n‚ÜíX][\alpha \colon I^n \to X] and [Œ≤:I n‚ÜíX][\beta \colon I^n \to X] to [Œ±‚ãÖŒ≤][\alpha \cdot \beta] with

Œ±‚ãÖŒ≤:I n‚ü∂‚âÉI n‚äîI n‚àí1I n‚ü∂(Œ±,Œ≤)X, \alpha \cdot \beta \;\colon\; I^n \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} I^n \underset{I^{n-1}}{\sqcup} I^n \stackrel{(\alpha,\beta)}{\longrightarrow} X \,,

where the first map is a homeomorphism from the unit nn-cube to the nn-cube with one side twice the unit length (e.g. (x 1,x 2,x 3,‚ãØ)‚Ü¶(2x 1,x 2,x 3,‚ãØ)(x_1, x_2, x_3, \cdots) \mapsto (2 x_1, x_2, x_3, \cdots)).

By composition, this construction extends to a functor

œÄ ‚Ä¢‚â•1:Top */‚ü∂Grp ‚Ñï ‚â•1 \pi_{\bullet \geq 1} \;\colon\; Top^{\ast/} \longrightarrow Grp^{\mathbb{N}_{\geq 1}}

from pointed topological spaces to graded groups.

Notice that often one writes the value of this functor on a morphism ff as f *=œÄ ‚Ä¢(f)f_\ast = \pi_\bullet(f).

Remark

At this point we don‚Äôt go further into the abstract reason why def. 30 yields group structure above degree 0, which is that positive dimension spheres are H-cogroup objects. But this is important, for instance in the proof of the Brown representability theorem. See the section Brown representability theorem in Part S.

Definition

(homotopy equivalence)

A continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \;\colon\; X \longrightarrow Y is called a homotopy equivalence if there exists a continuous function the other way around, g:Y‚ü∂Xg \;\colon\; Y \longrightarrow X, and left homotopies, def. 29, from the two composites to the identity:

Œ∑ 1:f‚àòg‚áí Lid Y \eta_1 \;\colon\; f\circ g \Rightarrow_L id_Y

and

Œ∑ 2:g‚àòf‚áí Lid X. \eta_2 \;\colon\; g\circ f \Rightarrow_L id_X \,.

If here Œ∑ 2\eta_2 is constant along II, ff is said to exhibit XX as a deformation retract of YY.

Example

For XX a topological space and X√óIX \times I its standard cylinder object of def. 28, then the projection p:X√óI‚ü∂Xp \colon X \times I \longrightarrow X and the inclusion (id,Œ¥ 0):X‚ü∂X√óI(id, \delta_0) \colon X \longrightarrow X\times I are homotopy equivalences, def. 31, and in fact are homotopy inverses to each other:

The composition

X‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0)X√óI‚ü∂pX X \overset{(id,\delta_0)}{\longrightarrow} X\times I \overset{p}{\longrightarrow} X

is immediately the identity on XX (i.e. homotopic to the identity by a trivial homotopy), while the composite

X√óI‚ü∂pX‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0)X√óI X \times I \overset{p}{\longrightarrow} X \overset{(id, \delta_0)}{\longrightarrow} X\times I

is homotopic to the identity on X√óIX \times I by a homotopy that is pointwise in XX that of example 24.

Definition

A continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y is called a weak homotopy equivalence if its image under all the homotopy group functors of def. 30 is an isomorphism, hence if

œÄ 0(f):œÄ 0(X)‚ü∂‚âÉœÄ 0(X) \pi_0(f) \;\colon\; \pi_0(X) \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \pi_0(X)

and for all x‚ààXx \in X and all n‚â•1n \geq 1

œÄ n(f):œÄ n(X,x)‚ü∂‚âÉœÄ n(Y,f(y)). \pi_n(f) \;\colon\; \pi_n(X,x) \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \pi_n(Y,f(y)) \,.
Proposition

Every homotopy equivalence, def. 31, is a weak homotopy equivalence, def. 32.

In particular a deformation retraction, def. 31, is a weak homotopy equivalence.

Proof

First observe that for all X‚ààX\in Top the inclusion maps

X‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0)X√óI X \overset{(id,\delta_0)}{\longrightarrow} X \times I

into the standard cylinder object, def. 28, are weak homotopy equivalences: by postcomposition with the contracting homotopy of the interval from example 24 all homotopy groups of X√óIX \times I have representatives that factor through this inclusion.

Then given a general homotopy equivalence, apply the homotopy groups functor to the corresponding homotopy diagrams (where for the moment we notationally suppress the choice of basepoint for readability) to get two commuting diagrams

œÄ ‚Ä¢(X) œÄ ‚Ä¢(id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üò œÄ ‚Ä¢(f)‚àòœÄ ‚Ä¢(g) œÄ ‚Ä¢(X√óI) ‚ü∂œÄ ‚Ä¢(Œ∑) œÄ ‚Ä¢(Y) œÄ ‚Ä¢(id,Œ¥ 1)‚Üë ‚Üó œÄ ‚Ä¢(id) œÄ ‚Ä¢(X),œÄ ‚Ä¢(Y) œÄ ‚Ä¢(id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üò œÄ ‚Ä¢(g)‚àòœÄ ‚Ä¢(f) œÄ ‚Ä¢(Y√óI) ‚ü∂œÄ ‚Ä¢(Œ∑) œÄ ‚Ä¢(X) œÄ ‚Ä¢(id,Œ¥ 1)‚Üë ‚Üó œÄ ‚Ä¢(id) œÄ ‚Ä¢(Y). \array{ \pi_\bullet(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\pi_\bullet(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{\pi_\bullet(f)\circ \pi_\bullet(g)}} \\ \pi_\bullet(X \times I) &\stackrel{\pi_\bullet(\eta)}{\longrightarrow}& \pi_\bullet(Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\pi_\bullet(id,\delta_1)}}\uparrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\pi_\bullet(id)}} \\ \pi_\bullet(X) } \;\;\;\;\;\;\; \,, \;\;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ \pi_\bullet(Y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\pi_\bullet(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathrlap{\pi_\bullet(g)\circ \pi_\bullet(f)}} \\ \pi_\bullet(Y \times I) &\stackrel{\pi_\bullet(\eta)}{\longrightarrow}& \pi_\bullet(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\pi_\bullet(id,\delta_1)}}\uparrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\pi_\bullet(id)}} \\ \pi_\bullet(Y) } \,.

By the previous observation, the vertical morphisms here are isomorphisms, and hence these diagrams exhibit œÄ ‚Ä¢(f)\pi_\bullet(f) as the inverse of œÄ ‚Ä¢(g)\pi_\bullet(g), hence both as isomorphisms.

Remark

The converse of prop. 28 is not true generally: not every weak homotopy equivalence between topological spaces is a homotopy equivalence. (For an example with full details spelled out see for instance Fritsch, Piccinini: ‚ÄúCellular Structures in Topology‚Äù, p. 289-290).

However, as we will discuss below, it turns out that

  1. every weak homotopy equivalence between CW-complexes is a homotopy equivalence (Whitehead's theorem, cor. 3);

  2. every topological space is connected by a weak homotopy equivalence to a CW-complex (CW approximation, remark 23).

Example

For X‚ààTopX\in Top, the projection X√óI‚ü∂XX\times I \longrightarrow X from the cylinder object of XX, def. 28, is a weak homotopy equivalence, def. 32. This means that the factorization

‚àá X:X‚äîX‚Ü™X√óI‚ü∂‚âÉX \nabla_X \;\colon\; X \sqcup X \stackrel{}{\hookrightarrow} X\times I \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} X

of the codiagonal ‚àá X\nabla_X in def. 28, which in general is far from being a monomorphism, may be thought of as factoring it through a monomorphism after replacing XX, up to weak homotopy equivalence, by X√óIX\times I.

In fact, further below (prop. 24) we see that X‚äîX‚ÜíX√óIX \sqcup X \to X \times I has better properties than the generic monomorphism has, in particular better homotopy invariant properties: it has the left lifting property against all Serre fibrations E‚ü∂pB E \stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow} B that are also weak homotopy equivalences.

Of course the concept of left homotopy in def. 29 is accompanied by a concept of right homotopy. This we turn to now.

Definition

(path space)

For XX a topological space, its standard topological path space object is the topological path space, hence the mapping space X IX^I, prop. 27, out of the standard interval II of def. 28.

Example

The endpoint inclusion into the standard interval, def. 28, makes the path space X IX^I of def. 33 factor the diagonal on XX through the inclusion of constant paths and the endpoint evaluation of paths:

Œî X:X‚ü∂X I‚Üí*X I‚ü∂X *‚äî*‚ÜíIX√óX. \Delta_X \;\colon\; X \stackrel{X^{I \to \ast}}{\longrightarrow} X^I \stackrel{X^{\ast \sqcup \ast \to I}}{\longrightarrow} X \times X \,.

This is the formal dual to example 28. As in that example, below we will see (prop. 34) that this factorization has good properties, in that

  1. X I‚Üí*X^{I \to \ast} is a weak homotopy equivalence;

  2. X *‚äî*‚ÜíIX^{\ast \sqcup \ast \to I} is a Serre fibration.

So while in general the diagonal Œî X\Delta_X is far from being an epimorphism or even just a Serre fibration, the factorization through the path space object may be thought of as replacing XX, up to weak homotopy equivalence, by its path space, such as to turn its diagonal into a Serre fibration after all.

Definition

(right homotopy)

For f,g:X‚ü∂Yf,g\colon X \longrightarrow Y two continuous functions between topological spaces X,YX,Y, then a right homotopy f‚áí Rgf \Rightarrow_R g is a continuous function

Œ∑:X‚ü∂Y I \eta \;\colon\; X \longrightarrow Y^I

into the path space object of XX, def. 33, such that this fits into a commuting diagram of the form

Y f‚Üó ‚Üë X Œ¥ 0 X ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y I g‚Üò ‚Üì Y Œ¥ 1 Y. \array{ && Y \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\nearrow & \uparrow^{\mathrlap{X^{\delta_0}}} \\ X &\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y^I \\ & {}_{\mathllap{g}}\searrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Y^{\delta_1}}} \\ && Y } \,.

Cell complexes

We consider topological spaces that are built consecutively by attaching basic cells.

Definition

Write

I Top‚âî{S n‚àí1‚Ü™Œπ nD n} n‚àà‚Ñï‚äÇMor(Top) I_{Top} \coloneqq \left\{ S^{n-1} \stackrel{\iota_n}{\hookrightarrow} D^{n} \right\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \; \subset Mor(Top)

for the set of canonical boundary inclusion maps of the standard n-disks, example 21. This going to be called the set of standard topological generating cofibrations.

Definition

For X‚ààTopX \in Top and for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, an nn-cell attachment to XX is the pushout (‚Äúattaching space‚Äù, example 19) of a generating cofibration, def. 35

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂œï X Œπ n‚Üì (po) ‚Üì D n ‚ü∂ X‚äîS n‚àí1D n =X‚à™ œïD n \array{ S^{n-1} &\stackrel{\phi}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ D^n &\longrightarrow& X \underset{S^{n-1}}{\sqcup} D^n & = X \cup_\phi D^n }

along some continuous function œï\phi.

A continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y is called a topological relative cell complex if it is exhibited by a (possibly infinite) sequence of cell attachments to XX, in that it is a transfinite composition (def. 26) of pushouts (example 19)

‚àêiS n i‚àí1 ‚ü∂ X k ‚àêiŒπ n i‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚àêiD n i ‚ü∂ X k+1 \array{ \underset{i}{\coprod} S^{n_i - 1} &\longrightarrow& X_{k} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{i}{\coprod}\iota_{n_i}}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ \underset{i}{\coprod} D^{n_i} &\longrightarrow& X_{k+1} }

of coproducts (example 14) of generating cofibrations (def. 35).

A topological space XX is a cell complex if ‚àÖ‚ü∂X\emptyset \longrightarrow X is a relative cell complex.

A relative cell complex is called a finite relative cell complex if it is obtained from a finite number of cell attachments.

A (relative) cell complex is called a (relative) CW-complex if the above transfinite composition is countable

X=X 0 ‚ü∂ X 1 ‚ü∂ X 2 ‚ü∂ ‚ãØ f‚Üò ‚Üì ‚Üô ‚ãØ Y=lim‚ü∂X ‚Ä¢ \array{ X = X_0 &\longrightarrow& X_1 &\longrightarrow& X_2 &\longrightarrow& \cdots \\ & {}_{\mathllap{f}}\searrow & \downarrow & \swarrow && \cdots \\ && Y = \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim} X_\bullet }

and if X kX_k is obtained from X k‚àí1X_{k-1} by attaching cells precisely only of dimension kk.

Remark

Strictly speaking a relative cell complex, def. 36, is a function f:X‚ÜíYf\colon X \to Y, together with its cell structure, hence together with the information of the pushout diagrams and the transfinite composition of the pushout maps that exhibit it.

In many applications, however, all that matters is that there is some (relative) cell decomosition, and then one tends to speak loosely and mean by a (relative) cell complex only a (relative) topological space that admits some cell decomposition.

The following lemma 15, together with lemma 19 below are the only two statements of the entire development here that involve the concrete particular nature of topological spaces (‚Äúpoint-set topology‚Äù), everything beyond that is general abstract homotopy theory.

Lemma

Assuming the axiom of choice and the law of excluded middle, every compact subspace of a topological cell complex, def. 36, intersects the interior of a finite number of cells.

(e.g. Hirschhorn 15, section 3.1)

Proof

So let YY be a topological cell complex and C‚Ü™YC \hookrightarrow Y a compact subspace. Define a subset

P‚äÇY P \subset Y

by choosing one point in the interior of the intersection with CC of each cell of YY that intersects CC.

It is now sufficient to show that PP has no accumulation point. Because, by the compactness of XX, every non-finite subset of CC does have an accumulation point, and hence the lack of such shows that PP is a finite set and hence that CC intersects the interior of finitely many cells of YY.

To that end, let c‚ààCc\in C be any point. If cc is a 0-cell in YY, write U c‚âî{c}U_c \coloneqq \{c\}. Otherwise write e ce_c for the unique cell of YY that contains cc in its interior. By construction, there is exactly one point of PP in the interior of e ce_c. Hence there is an open neighbourhood c‚ààU c‚äÇe cc \in U_c \subset e_c containing no further points of PP beyond possibly cc itself, if cc happens to be that single point of PP in e ce_c.

It is now sufficient to show that U cU_c may be enlarged to an open subset UÀú c\tilde U_c of YY containing no point of PP, except for possibly cc itself, for that means that cc is not an accumulation point of PP.

To that end, let Œ± c\alpha_c be the ordinal that labels the stage Y Œ± cY_{\alpha_c} of the transfinite composition in the cell complex-presentation of YY at which the cell e ce_c above appears. Let Œ≥\gamma be the ordinal of the full cell complex. Then define the set

T‚âî{(Œ≤,U)|Œ± c‚â§Œ≤‚â§Œ≥,U‚äÇopenY Œ≤,U‚à©Y Œ±=U c,U‚à©P‚àà{‚àÖ,{c}}}, T \coloneqq \left\{ \; (\beta, U) \;|\; \alpha_c \leq \beta \leq \gamma \;\,,\; U \underset{open}{\subset} Y_\beta \;\,,\; U \cap Y_\alpha = U_c \;\,,\; U \cap P \in \{ \emptyset, \{c\} \} \; \right\} \,,

and regard this as a partially ordered set by declaring a partial ordering via

(Œ≤ 1,U 1)<(Œ≤ 2,U 2)‚áîŒ≤ 1<Œ≤ 2,U 2‚à©Y Œ≤ 1=U 1. (\beta_1, U_1) \lt (\beta_2, U_2) \;\;\;\; \Leftrightarrow \;\;\;\; \beta_1 \lt \beta_2 \;\,,\; U_2 \cap Y_{\beta_1} = U_1 \,.

This is set up such that every element (Œ≤,U)(\beta, U) of TT with Œ≤\beta the maximum value Œ≤=Œ≥\beta = \gamma is an extension UÀú c\tilde U_c that we are after.

Observe then that for (Œ≤ s,U s) s‚ààS(\beta_s, U_s)_{s\in S} a chain in (T,<)(T,\lt) (a subset on which the relation <\lt restricts to a total order), it has an upper bound in TT given by the union (‚à™ sŒ≤ s,‚à™ sU s)({\cup}_s \beta_s ,\cup_s U_s). Therefore Zorn's lemma applies, saying that (T,<)(T,\lt) contains a maximal element (Œ≤ max,U max)(\beta_{max}, U_{max}).

Hence it is now sufficient to show that Œ≤ max=Œ≥\beta_{max} = \gamma. We argue this by showing that assuming Œ≤ max<Œ≥\beta_{\max}\lt \gamma leads to a contradiction.

So assume Œ≤ max<Œ≥\beta_{max}\lt \gamma. Then to construct an element of TT that is larger than (Œ≤ max,U max)(\beta_{max},U_{max}), consider for each cell dd at stage Y Œ≤ max+1Y_{\beta_{max}+1} its attaching map h d:S n‚àí1‚ÜíY Œ≤ maxh_d \colon S^{n-1} \to Y_{\beta_{max}} and the corresponding preimage open set h d ‚àí1(U max)‚äÇS n‚àí1h_d^{-1}(U_{max})\subset S^{n-1}. Enlarging all these preimages to open subsets of D nD^n (such that their image back in X Œ≤ max+1X_{\beta_{max}+1} does not contain cc), then (Œ≤ max,U max)<(Œ≤ max+1,‚à™ dU d)(\beta_{max}, U_{max}) \lt (\beta_{max}+1, \cup_d U_d ). This is a contradiction. Hence Œ≤ max=Œ≥\beta_{max} = \gamma, and we are done.

It is immediate and useful to generalize the concept of topological cell complexes as follows.

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} any category and for K‚äÇMor(ùíû)K \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) any sub-class of its morphisms, a relative KK-cell complexes is a morphism in ùíû\mathcal{C} which is a transfinite composition (def. 26) of pushouts of coproducts of morphsims in KK.

Definition

Write

J Top‚âî{D n‚Ü™(id,Œ¥ 0)D n√óI} n‚àà‚Ñï‚äÇMor(Top) J_{Top} \coloneqq \left\{ D^n \stackrel{(id,\delta_0)}{\hookrightarrow} D^n \times I \right\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \; \subset Mor(Top)

for the set of inclusions of the topological n-disks, def. 35, into their cylinder objects, def. 28, along (for definiteness) the left endpoint inclusion.

These inclusions are similar to the standard topological generating cofibrations I TopI_{Top} of def. 35, but in contrast to these they are ‚Äúacyclic‚Äù (meaning: trivial on homotopy classes of maps from ‚Äúcycles‚Äù given by n-spheres) in that they are weak homotopy equivalences (by prop. 28).

Accordingly, J TopJ_{Top} is to be called the set of standard topological generating acyclic cofibrations.

Lemma

For XX a CW-complex (def. 36), then its inclusion X‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0)X√óIX \overset{(id, \delta_0)}{\longrightarrow} X\times I into its standard cylinder (def. 28) is a J TopJ_{Top}-relative cell complex (def. 37, def. 38).

Proof

First erect a cylinder over all 0-cells

‚àêx‚ààX 0D 0 ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚àêx‚ààX 0D 1 ‚ü∂ Y 1. \array{ \underset{x \in X_0}{\coprod} D^0 &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ \underset{x\in X_0}{\coprod} D^1 &\longrightarrow& Y_1 } \,.

Assume then that the cylinder over all nn-cells of XX has been erected using attachment from J TopJ_{Top}. Then the union of any (n+1)(n+1)-cell œÉ\sigma of XX with the cylinder over its boundary is homeomorphic to D n+1D^{n+1} and is like the cylinder over the cell ‚Äúwith end and interior removed‚Äù. Hence via attaching along D n+1‚ÜíD n+1√óID^{n+1} \to D^{n+1}\times I the cylinder over œÉ\sigma is erected.

Lemma

The maps D n‚Ü™D n√óID^n \hookrightarrow D^n \times I in def. 38 are finite relative cell complexes, def. 36. In other words, the elements of J TopJ_{Top} are I TopI_{Top}-relative cell complexes.

Proof

There is a homeomorphism

D n = D n (id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üì D n√óI ‚âÉ D n+1 \array{ D^n & = & D^n \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow && \downarrow \\ D^n \times I &\simeq& D^{n+1} }

such that the map on the right is the inclusion of one hemisphere into the boundary n-sphere of D n+1D^{n+1}. This inclusion is the result of attaching two cells:

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œπ n D n Œπ n‚Üì (po) ‚Üì D n ‚ü∂ S n ‚Üì = S n ‚ü∂id S n Œπ n+1‚Üì (po) ‚Üì D n+1 ‚ü∂id D n+1. \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{\iota_n}{\longrightarrow}& D^n \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ D^n &\longrightarrow& S^{n} \\ && \downarrow^{=} \\ S^n &\overset{id}{\longrightarrow}& S^n \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_{n+1}}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ D^{n+1} &\underset{id}{\longrightarrow}& D^{n+1} } \,.

here the top pushout is the one from example 21.

Lemma

Every J TopJ_{Top}-relative cell complex (def. 38, def. 37) is a weak homotopy equivalence, def. 32.

Proof

Let X‚ü∂X^=lim‚üµ Œ≤‚â§Œ±X Œ≤X \longrightarrow \hat X = \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{\beta \leq \alpha} X_\beta be a J TopJ_{Top}-relative cell complex.

First observe that with the elements D n‚Ü™D n√óID^n \hookrightarrow D^n \times I of J TopJ_{Top} being homotopy equivalences for all n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} (by example 25), each of the stages X Œ≤‚ü∂X Œ≤+1X_{\beta} \longrightarrow X_{\beta + 1} in the relative cell complex is also a homotopy equivalence. We make this fully explicit:

By definition, such a stage is a pushout of the form

‚äîi‚ààID n i ‚ü∂ X Œ≤ ‚äîi‚ààI(id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì (po) ‚Üì ‚äîi‚ààID n i√óI ‚ü∂ X Œ≤+1. \array{ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} &\longrightarrow& X_\beta \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} (id, \delta_0)} }\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} \times I &\longrightarrow& X_{\beta + 1} } \,.

Then the fact that the projections p n i:D n i√óI‚ÜíD n ip_{n_i} \colon D^{n_i} \times I \to D^{n_i} are strict left inverses to the inclusions (id,Œ¥ 0)(id, \delta_0) gives a commuting square of the form

‚äîi‚ààID n i ‚ü∂ X Œ≤ ‚äîi‚ààI(id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üì id ‚äîi‚ààID n i√óI ‚äîi‚ààIp n i‚Üì ‚Üì ‚äîi‚ààID n i ‚ü∂ X Œ≤ \array{ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} &\longrightarrow& X_\beta \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} (id, \delta_0)} }\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} \times I \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} p_{n_i} }}\downarrow && \downarrow \\ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} &\longrightarrow& X_\beta }

and so the universal property of the colimit (pushout) X Œ≤+1X_{\beta + 1} gives a factorization of the identity morphism on the right through X Œ≤+1X_{\beta + 1}

‚äîi‚ààID n i ‚ü∂ X Œ≤ ‚äîi‚ààI(id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üì ‚äîi‚ààID n i√óI ‚ü∂ X Œ≤+1 ‚äîi‚ààIp n i‚Üì ‚Üì ‚äîi‚ààID n i ‚ü∂ X Œ≤ \array{ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} &\longrightarrow& X_\beta \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} (id, \delta_0)} }\downarrow && \downarrow^{} \\ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} \times I &\longrightarrow& X_{\beta + 1} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} p_{n_i} }}\downarrow && \downarrow \\ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} &\longrightarrow& X_\beta }

which exhibits X Œ≤+1‚ÜíX Œ≤X_{\beta + 1} \to X_\beta as a strict left inverse to X Œ≤‚ÜíX Œ≤+1X_{\beta} \to X_{\beta + 1}. Hence it is now sufficient to show that this is also a homotopy right inverse.

To that end, let

Œ∑ n i:D n i√óI‚ü∂D n i√óI \eta_{n_i} \colon D^{n_i}\times I \longrightarrow D^{n_i} \times I

be the left homotopy that exhibits p n ip_{n_i} as a homotopy right inverse to p n ip_{n_i} by example 25. For each t‚àà[0,1]t \in [0,1] consider the commuting square

‚äîi‚ààID n i ‚ü∂ X Œ≤ ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚äîi‚ààID n i√óI X Œ≤+1 Œ∑ n i(‚àí,t)‚Üì ‚Üì id ‚äîi‚ààID n i√óI ‚ü∂ X Œ≤+1. \array{ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} &\longrightarrow& X_\beta \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} \times I && X_{\beta + 1} \\ {}^{\mathllap{\eta_{n_i}(-,t)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ \underset{i \in I}{\sqcup} D^{n_i} \times I &\longrightarrow& X_{\beta + 1} } \,.

Regarded as a cocone under the span in the top left, the universal property of the colimit (pushout) X Œ≤+1X_{\beta + 1} gives a continuous function

Œ∑(‚àí,t):X Œ≤+1‚ü∂X Œ≤+1 \eta(-,t) \;\colon\; X_{\beta + 1} \longrightarrow X_{\beta + 1}

for each t‚àà[0,1]t \in [0,1]. For t=0t = 0 this construction reduces to the provious one in that Œ∑(‚àí,0):X Œ≤+1‚ÜíX Œ≤‚ÜíX Œ≤+1\eta(-,0) \colon X_{\beta +1 } \to X_{\beta} \to X_{\beta + 1} is the composite which we need to homotope to the identity; while Œ∑(‚àí,1)\eta(-,1) is the identity. Since Œ∑(‚àí,t)\eta(-,t) is clearly also continuous in tt it constitutes a continuous function

Œ∑:X Œ≤+1√óI‚ü∂X Œ≤+1 \eta \;\colon\; X_{\beta + 1}\times I \longrightarrow X_{\beta + 1}

which exhibits the required left homotopy.

So far this shows that each stage X Œ≤‚ÜíX Œ≤+1X_{\beta} \to X_{\beta+1} in the transfinite composition defining X^\hat X is a homotopy equivalence, hence, by prop. 28, a weak homotopy equivalence.

This means that all morphisms in the following diagram (notationally suppressing basepoints and showing only the finite stages)

œÄ n(X) ‚ü∂‚âÉ œÄ n(X 1) ‚ü∂‚âÉ œÄ n(X 2) ‚ü∂‚âÉ œÄ n(X 3) ‚ü∂‚âÉ ‚ãØ ‚âÉ‚Üò ‚Üì ‚âÉ ‚Üô ‚âÉ ‚ãØ lim‚üµ Œ±œÄ n(X Œ±) \array{ \pi_n(X) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& \pi_n(X_1) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& \pi_n(X_2) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& \pi_n(X_3) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& \cdots \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\simeq}}\searrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}} & \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\simeq}} & \cdots \\ && \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_\alpha \pi_n(X_\alpha) }

are isomorphisms.

Moreover, lemma 15 gives that every representative and every null homotopy of elements in œÄ n(X^)\pi_n(\hat X) already exists at some finite stage X kX_k. This means that also the universally induced morphism

lim‚üµ Œ±œÄ n(X Œ±)‚ü∂‚âÉœÄ n(X^) \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_\alpha \pi_n(X_\alpha) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \pi_n(\hat X)

is an isomorphism. Hence the composite œÄ n(X)‚ü∂‚âÉœÄ n(X^)\pi_n(X) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \pi_n(\hat X) is an isomorphism.

Fibrations

Given a relative CC-cell complex Œπ:X‚ÜíY\iota \colon X \to Y, def. 37, it is typically interesting to study the extension problem along ff, i.e. to ask which topological spaces EE are such that every continuous function f:X‚ü∂Ef\colon X \longrightarrow E has an extension fÀú\tilde f along Œπ\iota

X ‚ü∂f E Œπ‚Üì ‚Üó ‚àÉfÀú Y. \array{ X &\stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow}& E \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota}}\downarrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\exists \tilde f}} \\ Y } \,.

If such extensions exists, it means that EE is sufficiently ‚Äúspread out‚Äù with respect to the maps in CC. More generally one considers this extension problem fiberwise, i.e. with both EE and YY (hence also XX) equipped with a map to some base space BB:

Definition

Given a category ùíû\mathcal{C} and a sub-class C‚äÇMor(ùíû)C \subset Mor(\mathcal{C}) of its morphisms, then a morphism p:E‚ü∂Bp \colon E \longrightarrow B in ùíû\mathcal{C} is said to have the right lifting property against the morphisms in CC if every commuting diagram in ùíû\mathcal{C} of the form

X ‚ü∂ E c‚Üì ‚Üì p Y ‚ü∂ B, \array{ X &\longrightarrow& E \\ {}^{\mathllap{c}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ Y &\longrightarrow& B } \,,

with c‚ààCc \in C, has a lift hh, in that it may be completed to a commuting diagram of the form

X ‚ü∂ E c‚Üì h‚Üó ‚Üì p Y ‚ü∂ B. \array{ X &\longrightarrow& E \\ {}^{\mathllap{c}}\downarrow &{}^{\mathllap{h}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ Y &\longrightarrow& B } \,.

We will also say that ff is a CC-injective morphism if it satisfies the right lifting property against CC.

Definition

A continuous function p:E‚ü∂Bp \colon E \longrightarrow B is called a Serre fibration if it is a J TopJ_{Top}-injective morphism; i.e. if it has the right lifting property, def. 39, against all topological generating acylic cofibrations, def. 38; hence if for every commuting diagram of continuous functions of the form

D n ‚ü∂ E (id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üì p D n√óI ‚ü∂ B, \array{ D^n &\longrightarrow& E \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ D^n\times I &\longrightarrow& B } \,,

has a lift hh, in that it may be completed to a commuting diagram of the form

D n ‚ü∂ E (id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì h‚Üó ‚Üì p D n√óI ‚ü∂ B. \array{ D^n &\longrightarrow& E \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow &{}^{\mathllap{h}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ D^n\times I &\longrightarrow& B } \,.
Remark

Def. 76 says, in view of the definition of left homotopy, that a Serre fibration pp is a map with the property that given a left homotopy, def. 29, between two functions into its codomain, and given a lift of one the two functions through pp, then also the homotopy between the two lifts. Therefore the condition on a Serre fibration is also called the homotopy lifting property for maps whose domain is an n-disk.

More generally one may ask functions pp to have such homotopy lifting property for functions with arbitrary domain. These are called Hurewicz fibrations.

Remark

The precise shape of D nD^n and D n√óID^n \times I in def. 76 turns out not to actually matter much for the nature of Serre fibrations. We will eventually find below (prop. 22) that what actually matters here is only that the inclusions D n‚Ü™D n√óID^n \hookrightarrow D^n \times I are relative cell complexes (lemma 17) and weak homotopy equivalences (prop. 28) and that all of these may be generated from them in a suitable way.

But for simple special cases this is readily seen directly, too. Notably we could replace the n-disks in def. 76 with any homeomorphic topological space. A choice important in the comparison to the classical model structure on simplicial sets (below) is to instead take the topological n-simplices Œî n\Delta^n. Hence a Serre fibration is equivalently characterized as having lifts in all diagrams of the form

Œî n ‚ü∂ E (id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üì p Œî n√óI ‚ü∂ B. \array{ \Delta^n &\longrightarrow& E \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ \Delta^n\times I &\longrightarrow& B } \,.

Other deformations of the nn-disks are useful in computations, too. For instance there is a homeomorphism from the nn-disk to its ‚Äúcylinder with interior and end removed‚Äù, formally:

(D n√ó{0})‚à™(‚àÇD n√óI) ‚âÉ D n ‚Üì ‚Üì D n√óI ‚âÉ D n√óI \array{ (D^n \times \{0\})\cup (\partial D^n \times I) &\simeq& D^n \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ D^n \times I &\simeq& D^n\times I }

and hence ff is a Serre fibration equivalently also if it admits lifts in all diagrams of the form

(D n√ó{0})‚à™(‚àÇD n√óI) ‚ü∂ E (id,Œ¥ 0)‚Üì ‚Üì p D n√óI ‚ü∂ B. \array{ (D^n \times \{0\})\cup (\partial D^n \times I) &\longrightarrow& E \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_0)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ D^n\times I &\longrightarrow& B } \,.

The following is a general fact about closure of morphisms defined by lifting properties which we prove in generality below as prop. 1.

Proposition

A Serre fibration, def. 76 has the right lifting property against all retracts (see remark 3) of J TopJ_{Top}-relative cell complexes (def. 38, def. 36).

The following statement is foreshadowing the long exact sequences of homotopy groups (below) induced by any fiber sequence, the full version of which we come to below (example 9) after having developed more of the abstract homotopy theory.

Proposition

Let f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y be a Serre fibration, def. 76, let y:*‚ÜíYy \colon \ast \to Y be any point and write

F y‚Ü™ŒπX‚ü∂fY F_y \overset{\iota}{\hookrightarrow} X \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y

for the fiber inclusion over that point. Then for every choice x:*‚ÜíXx \colon \ast \to X of lift of the point yy through ff, the induced sequence of homotopy groups

œÄ ‚Ä¢(F y,x)‚ü∂Œπ *œÄ ‚Ä¢(X,x)‚ü∂f *œÄ ‚Ä¢(Y) \pi_{\bullet}(F_y, x) \overset{\iota_\ast}{\longrightarrow} \pi_\bullet(X, x) \overset{f_\ast}{\longrightarrow} \pi_\bullet(Y)

is exact, in that the kernel of f *f_\ast is canonically identified with the image of Œπ *\iota_\ast:

ker(f *)‚âÉim(Œπ *). ker(f_\ast) \simeq im(\iota_\ast) \,.
Proof

It is clear that the image of Œπ *\iota_\ast is in the kernel of f *f_\ast (every sphere in F y‚Ü™XF_y\hookrightarrow X becomes constant on yy, hence contractible, when sent forward to YY).

For the converse, let [Œ±]‚ààœÄ ‚Ä¢(X,x)[\alpha]\in \pi_{\bullet}(X,x) be represented by some Œ±:S n‚àí1‚ÜíX\alpha \colon S^{n-1} \to X. Assume that [Œ±][\alpha] is in the kernel of f *f_\ast. This means equivalently that Œ±\alpha fits into a commuting diagram of the form

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œ± X ‚Üì ‚Üì f D n ‚ü∂Œ∫ Y, \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ D^n &\overset{\kappa}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,,

where Œ∫\kappa is the contracting homotopy witnessing that f *[Œ±]=0f_\ast[\alpha] = 0.

Now since xx is a lift of yy, there exists a left homotopy

Œ∑:Œ∫‚áíconst y \eta \;\colon\; \kappa \Rightarrow const_y

as follows:

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œ± X Œπ n‚Üì ‚Üì f D n ‚ü∂Œ∫ Y ‚Üì (id,Œ¥ 1) ‚Üì id D n ‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0) D n√óI ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y ‚Üì ‚Üì * ‚ü∂y Y \array{ && S^{n-1} &\overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ && {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ && D^n &\overset{\kappa}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(id,\delta_1)}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{id}} \\ D^n &\overset{(id,\delta_0)}{\longrightarrow}& D^n \times I &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow \\ \ast && \overset{y}{\longrightarrow} && Y }

(for instance: regard D nD^n as embedded in ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n such that 0‚àà‚Ñù n0 \in \mathbb{R}^n is identified with the basepoint on the boundary of D nD^n and set Œ∑(v‚Üí,t)‚âîŒ∫(tv‚Üí)\eta(\vec v,t) \coloneqq \kappa(t \vec v)).

The pasting of the top two squares that have appeared this way is equivalent to the following commuting square

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂ ‚ü∂Œ± X (id,Œ¥ 1)‚Üì ‚Üì f S n‚àí1√óI ‚ü∂(Œπ n,id) D n√óI ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y. \array{ S^{n-1} &\longrightarrow& &\overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,\delta_1)}}\downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ S^{n-1} \times I &\overset{(\iota_n, id)}{\longrightarrow}& D^n \times I &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Because ff is a Serre fibration and by lemma 16 and prop. 29, this has a lift

Œ∑Àú:S n‚àí1√óI‚ü∂X. \tilde \eta \;\colon\; S^{n-1} \times I \longrightarrow X \,.

Notice that Œ∑Àú\tilde \eta is a basepoint preserving left homotopy from Œ±=Œ∑Àú| 1\alpha = \tilde \eta|_1 to some Œ±‚Ä≤‚âîŒ∑Àú| 0\alpha' \coloneqq \tilde \eta|_0. Being homotopic, they represent the same element of œÄ n‚àí1(X,x)\pi_{n-1}(X,x):

[Œ±‚Ä≤]=[Œ±]. [\alpha'] = [\alpha] \,.

But the new representative Œ±‚Ä≤\alpha' has the special property that its image in YY is not just trivializable, but trivialized: combining Œ∑Àú\tilde \eta with the previous diagram shows that it sits in the following commuting diagram

Œ±‚Ä≤: S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0) S n‚àí1√óI ‚ü∂Œ∑Àú X ‚Üì Œπ n ‚Üì (Œπ n,id) ‚Üì f D n ‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0) D n√óI ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y ‚Üì ‚Üì * ‚ü∂y Y. \array{ \alpha' \colon & S^{n-1} &\overset{(id,\delta_0)}{\longrightarrow}& S^{n-1}\times I &\overset{\tilde \eta}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ & \downarrow^{\iota_n} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(\iota_n,id)}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ & D^n &\overset{(id,\delta_0)}{\longrightarrow}& D^n \times I &\overset{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ & \downarrow && && \downarrow \\ & \ast && \overset{y}{\longrightarrow} && Y } \,.

The commutativity of the outer square says that f *Œ±‚Ä≤f_\ast \alpha' is constant, hence that Œ±‚Ä≤\alpha' is entirely contained in the fiber F yF_y. Said more abstractly, the universal property of fibers gives that Œ±‚Ä≤\alpha' factors through F y‚Ü™ŒπXF_y\overset{\iota}{\hookrightarrow} X, hence that [Œ±‚Ä≤]=[Œ±][\alpha'] = [\alpha] is in the image of Œπ *\iota_\ast.

The following lemma 19, together with lemma 15 above, are the only two statements of the entire development here that crucially involve the concrete particular nature of topological spaces (‚Äúpoint-set topology‚Äù), everything beyond that is general abstract homotopy theory.

Lemma

The continuous functions with the right lifting property, def. 39 against the set I Top={S n‚àí1‚Ü™D n}I_{Top} = \{S^{n-1}\hookrightarrow D^n\} of topological generating cofibrations, def. 35, are precisely those which are both weak homotopy equivalences, def. 32 as well as Serre fibrations, def. 76.

Proof

We break this up into three sub-statements:

A) I TopI_{Top}-injective morphisms are in particular weak homotopy equivalences

Let p:X^‚ÜíXp \colon \hat X \to X have the right lifting property against I TopI_{Top}

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂ X^ Œπ n‚Üì ‚àÉ‚Üó ‚Üì p D n ‚ü∂ X \array{ S^{n-1} &\longrightarrow & \hat X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow &{}^{\mathllap{\exists}}\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ D^n &\longrightarrow& X }

We check that the lifts in these diagrams exhibit œÄ ‚Ä¢(f)\pi_\bullet(f) as being an isomorphism on all homotopy groups, def. 30:

For n=0n = 0 the existence of these lifts says that every point of XX is in the image of pp, hence that œÄ 0(X^)‚ÜíœÄ 0(X)\pi_0(\hat X) \to \pi_0(X) is surjective. Let then S 0=*‚àê*‚ü∂X^S^0 = \ast \coprod \ast \longrightarrow \hat X be a map that hits two connected components, then the existence of the lift says that if they have the same image in œÄ 0(X)\pi_0(X) then they were already the same connected component in X^\hat X. Hence œÄ 0(X^)‚ÜíœÄ 0(X)\pi_0(\hat X)\to \pi_0(X) is also injective and hence is a bijection.

Similarly, for n‚â•1n \geq 1, if S n‚ÜíX^S^n \to \hat X represents an element in œÄ n(X^)\pi_n(\hat X) that becomes trivial in œÄ n(X)\pi_n(X), then the existence of the lift says that it already represented the trivial element itself. Hence œÄ n(X^)‚ÜíœÄ n(X)\pi_n(\hat X) \to \pi_n(X) has trivial kernel and so is injective.

Finally, to see that œÄ n(X^)‚ÜíœÄ n(X)\pi_n(\hat X) \to \pi_n(X) is also surjective, hence bijective, observe that every elements in œÄ n(X)\pi_n(X) is equivalently represented by a commuting diagram of the form

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂ * ‚ü∂ X^ ‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì D n ‚ü∂ X = X \array{ S^{n-1} &\longrightarrow& \ast &\longrightarrow& \hat X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow && \downarrow \\ D^n &\longrightarrow& X &=& X }

and so here the lift gives a representative of a preimage in œÄ n(X^)\pi_{n}(\hat X).

B) I TopI_{Top}-injective morphisms are in particular Serre fibrations

By an immediate closure property of lifting problems (we spell this out in generality as prop. 1, cor. 2 below) an I TopI_{Top}-injective morphism has the right lifting property against all relative cell complexes, and hence, by lemma 17, it is also a J TopJ_{Top}-injective morphism, hence a Serre fibration.

C) Acyclic Serre fibrations are in particular I TopI_{Top}-injective morphisms

(Hirschhorn 15, section 6).

Let f:X‚ÜíYf\colon X \to Y be a Serre fibration that induces isomorphisms on homotopy groups. In degree 0 this means that ff is an isomorphism on connected components, and this means that there is a lift in every commuting square of the form

S ‚àí1=‚àÖ ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üì f D 0=* ‚ü∂ Y \array{ S^{-1} = \emptyset &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ D^0 = \ast &\longrightarrow& Y }

(this is œÄ 0(f)\pi_0(f) being surjective) and in every commuting square of the form

S 0 ‚ü∂ X Œπ 0‚Üì ‚Üì f D 1=* ‚ü∂ Y \array{ S^0 &\longrightarrow& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_0}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ D^1 = \ast &\longrightarrow& Y }

(this is œÄ 0(f)\pi_0(f) being injective). Hence we are reduced to showing that for n‚â•2n \geq 2 every diagram of the form

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œ± X Œπ n‚Üì ‚Üì f D n ‚ü∂Œ∫ Y \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ D^n &\overset{\kappa}{\longrightarrow}& Y }

has a lift.

To that end, pick a basepoint on S n‚àí1S^{n-1} and write xx and yy for its images in XX and YY, respectively

Then the diagram above expresses that f *[Œ±]=0‚ààœÄ n‚àí1(Y,y)f_\ast[\alpha] = 0 \in \pi_{n-1}(Y,y) and hence by assumption on ff it follows that [Œ±]=0‚ààœÄ n‚àí1(X,x)[\alpha] = 0 \in \pi_{n-1}(X,x), which in turn mean that there is Œ∫‚Ä≤\kappa' making the upper triangle of our lifting problem commute:

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œ± X Œπ n‚Üì ‚Üó Œ∫‚Ä≤ D n. \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\kappa'}} \\ D^n } \,.

It is now sufficient to show that any such Œ∫‚Ä≤\kappa' may be deformed to a œÅ‚Ä≤\rho' which keeps making this upper triangle commute but also makes the remaining lower triangle commute.

To that end, notice that by the commutativity of the original square, we already have at least this commuting square:

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œπ n D n Œπ n‚Üì ‚Üì f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤ D n ‚ü∂Œ∫ Y. \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{\iota_n}{\longrightarrow}& D^n \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f \circ \kappa'}} \\ D^n &\underset{\kappa}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

This induces the universal map (Œ∫,f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤)(\kappa,f \circ \kappa') from the pushout of its cospan in the top left, which is the n-sphere (see this example):

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œπ n D n Œπ n‚Üì (po) ‚Üì f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤ D n ‚ü∂Œ∫ S n ‚Üò (Œ∫,f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤) Y. \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{\iota_n}{\longrightarrow}& D^n \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f \circ \kappa'}} \\ D^n &\underset{\kappa}{\longrightarrow}& S^n \\ && & \searrow^{(\kappa,f \circ \kappa')} \\ && && Y } \,.

This universal morphism represents an element of the nnth homotopy group:

[(Œ∫,f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤)]‚ààœÄ n(Y,y). [(\kappa,f \circ \kappa')] \in \pi_n(Y,y) \,.

By assumption that ff is a weak homotopy equivalence, there is a [œÅ]‚ààœÄ n(X,x)[\rho] \in \pi_{n}(X,x) with

f *[œÅ]=[(Œ∫,f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤)] f_\ast [\rho] = [(\kappa,f \circ \kappa')]

hence on representatives there is a lift up to homotopy

X œÅ‚Üó ‚áì ‚Üì f S n ‚ü∂(Œ∫,f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤) Y. \array{ && X \\ &{}^{\mathllap{\rho}}\nearrow_{\mathrlap{\Downarrow}} & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ S^n &\underset{(\kappa,f\circ \kappa')}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

Morever, we may always find œÅ\rho of the form (œÅ‚Ä≤,Œ∫‚Ä≤)(\rho', \kappa') for some œÅ‚Ä≤:D n‚ÜíX\rho' \colon D^n \to X. (‚ÄúPaste Œ∫‚Ä≤\kappa' to the reverse of œÅ\rho.‚Äù)

Consider then the map

S n‚ü∂(f‚àòœÅ‚Ä≤,Œ∫)Y S^n \overset{(f\circ \rho', \kappa)}{\longrightarrow} Y

and observe that this represents the trivial class:

[(f‚àòœÅ‚Ä≤,Œ∫)] =[(f‚àòœÅ‚Ä≤,f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤)]+[(f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤,Œ∫)] =f *[(œÅ‚Ä≤,Œ∫‚Ä≤)]‚èü=[œÅ]+[(f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤,Œ∫)] =[(Œ∫,f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤)]+[(f‚àòŒ∫‚Ä≤,Œ∫)] =0. \begin{aligned} [(f \circ \rho', \kappa)] & = [(f\circ \rho', f\circ \kappa')] + [(f\circ \kappa', \kappa)] \\ & = f_\ast \underset{= [\rho]}{\underbrace{[(\rho',\kappa')]}} + [(f\circ \kappa', \kappa)] \\ & = [(\kappa,f \circ \kappa')] + [(f\circ \kappa', \kappa)] \\ & = 0 \end{aligned} \,.

This means equivalently that there is a homotopy

œï:f‚àòœÅ‚Ä≤‚áíŒ∫ \phi \; \colon \; f\circ \rho' \Rightarrow \kappa

fixing the boundary of the nn-disk.

Hence if we denote homotopy by double arrows, then we have now achieved the following situation

S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂Œ± X Œπ n‚Üì œÅ‚Ä≤‚Üó ‚áì œï ‚Üì f D n ‚ü∂ Y \array{ S^{n-1} &\overset{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{\iota_n}}\downarrow & {}^{\rho'}\nearrow_{\Downarrow^{\phi}} & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ D^n &\longrightarrow& Y }

and it now suffices to show that œï\phi may be lifted to a homotopy of just œÅ‚Ä≤\rho', fixing the boundary, for then the resulting homotopic œÅ‚Ä≥\rho'' is the desired lift.

To that end, notice that the condition that œï:D n√óI‚ÜíY\phi \colon D^n \times I \to Y fixes the boundary of the nn-disk means equivalently that it extends to a morphism

S n‚àí1‚äîS n‚àí1√óID n√óI‚ü∂(f‚àòŒ±,œï)Y S^{n-1} \underset{S^{n-1}\times I}{\sqcup} D^n \times I \overset{(f\circ \alpha,\phi)}{\longrightarrow} Y

out of the pushout that identifies in the cylinder over D nD^n all points lying over the boundary. Hence we are reduced to finding a lift in

D n ‚ü∂œÅ‚Ä≤ X ‚Üì ‚Üì f S n‚àí1‚äîS n‚àí1√óID n√óI ‚ü∂(f‚àòŒ±,œï) Y. \array{ D^n &\overset{\rho'}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ S^{n-1}\underset{S^{n-1}\times I}{\sqcup} D^n \times I &\overset{(f\circ \alpha,\phi)}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \,.

But inspection of the left map reveals that it is homeomorphic again to D n‚ÜíD n√óID^n \to D^n \times I, and hence the lift does indeed exist.

The classical model structure on topological spaces

Definition

Say that a continuous function, hence a morphism in Top, is

  • a classical weak equivalence if it is a weak homotopy equivalence, def. 32;

  • a classical fibration if it is a Serre fibration, def. 76;

  • a classical cofibration if it is a retract (rem. 3) of a relative cell complex, def. 36.

and hence

  • a acyclic classical cofibration if it is a classical cofibration as well as a classical weak equivalence;

  • a acyclic classical fibration if it is a classical fibration as well as a classical weak equivalence.

Write

W cl,Fib cl,Cof cl‚äÇMor(Top) W_{cl},\;Fib_{cl},\;Cof_{cl} \subset Mor(Top)

for the classes of these morphisms, respectively.

We first prove now that the classes of morphisms in def. 41 satisfy the conditions for a model category structure, def. 1 (after some lemmas, this is theorem 2 below). Then we discuss the resulting classical homotopy category (below) and then a few variant model structures whose proof follows immediately along the line of the proof of Top QuillenTop_{Quillen}:

  • The model structure on pointed topological spaces Top Quillen */Top^{\ast/}_{Quillen};

  • The model structure on compactly generated topological spaces (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} and (Top cg */) Quillen(Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen};

  • The model structure on topologically enriched functors [ùíû,(Top cg) Quillen] proj[\mathcal{C}, (Top_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj} and [ùíû,(Top cg *) Quillen] proj[\mathcal{C},(Top^{\ast}_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj}.

\,

Proposition

The classical weak equivalences, def. 41, satify two-out-of-three (def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}).

Proof

Since isomorphisms (of homotopy groups) satisfy 2-out-of-3, this property is directly inherited via the very definition of weak homotopy equivalence, def. 32.

Lemma

Every morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y in Top factors as a classical cofibration followed by an acyclic classical fibration, def. 41:

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCof clX^‚ü∂‚ààW cl‚à©Fib clY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in Cof_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.
Proof

By lemma 15 the set I Top={S n‚àí1‚Ü™D n}I_{Top} = \{S^{n-1}\hookrightarrow D^n\} of topological generating cofibrations, def. 35, has small domains, in the sense of def. 6 (the n-spheres are compact). Hence by the small object argument, prop. 4, ff factors as an I TopI_{Top}-relative cell complex, def. 37, hence just a plain relative cell complex, def. 36, followed by an I TopI_{Top}-injective morphisms, def. 39:

f:X‚ü∂‚ààCof clX^‚ü∂‚ààI TopInjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in Cof_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in I_{Top} Inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

By lemma 19 the map X^‚ÜíY\hat X \to Y is both a weak homotopy equivalence as well as a Serre fibration.

Lemma

Every morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf\colon X \longrightarrow Y in Top factors as an acyclic classical cofibration followed by a fibration, def. 41:

f:X‚ü∂‚ààW cl‚à©Cof clX^‚ü∂‚ààFib clY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in W_{cl} \cap Cof_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in Fib_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.
Proof

By lemma 15 the set J Top={D n‚Ü™D n√óI}J_{Top} = \{D^n \hookrightarrow D^n\times I\} of topological generating acyclic cofibrations, def. 38, has small domains, in the sense of def. 6 (the n-disks are compact). Hence by the small object argument, prop. 4, ff factors as an J TopJ_{Top}-relative cell complex, def. 37, followed by a J topJ_{top}-injective morphisms, def. 39:

f:X‚ü∂‚ààJ TopCellX^‚ü∂‚ààJ TopInjY. f \;\colon\; X \stackrel{\in J_{Top} Cell}{\longrightarrow} \hat X \stackrel{\in J_{Top} Inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

By definition this makes X^‚ÜíY\hat X \to Y a Serre fibration, hence a fibration.

By lemma 17 a relative J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex is in particular a relative I TopI_{Top}-cell complex. Hence X‚ÜíX^X \to \hat X is a classical cofibration. By lemma 18 it is also a weak homotopy equivalence, hence a clasical weak equivalence.

Lemma
