Every commuting square in Top with the left morphism a classical cofibration and the right morphism a fibration, def. 41

‚ü∂ g‚ààCof cl‚Üì ‚Üì f‚ààFib cl ‚ü∂ \array{ &\longrightarrow& \\ {}^{\mathllap{{g \in} \atop {Cof_{cl}}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{{f \in }\atop Fib_{cl}}} \\ &\longrightarrow& }

admits a lift as soon as one of the two is also a classical weak equivalence.

Proof

A) If the fibration ff is also a weak equivalence, then lemma 19 says that it has the right lifting property against the generating cofibrations I TopI_{Top}, and cor. 2 implies the claim.

B) If the cofibration gg on the left is also a weak equivalence, consider any factorization into a relative J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex, def. 38, def. 37, followed by a fibration,

g:‚ü∂‚ààJ TopCell‚ü∂‚ààFib cl, g \;\colon\; \stackrel{\in J_{Top} Cell}{\longrightarrow} \stackrel{\in Fib_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \,,

as in the proof of lemma 21. By lemma 18 the morphism ‚ü∂‚ààJ TopCell\overset{\in J_{Top} Cell}{\longrightarrow} is a weak homotopy equivalence, and so by two-out-of-three (prop. 31) the factorizing fibration is actually an acyclic fibration. By case A), this acyclic fibration has the right lifting property against the cofibration gg itself, and so the retract argument, lemma 2 gives that gg is a retract of a relative J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex. With this, finally cor. 2 implies that ff has the right lifting property against gg.

Finally:

Proposition

The systems (Cof cl,W cl‚à©Fib cl)(Cof_{cl} , W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl}) and (W cl‚à©Cof cl,Fib cl)(W_{cl} \cap Cof_{cl}, Fib_{cl}) from def. 41 are weak factorization systems.

Proof

Since we have already seen the factorization property (lemma 20, lemma 21) and the lifting properties (lemma 22), it only remains to see that the given left/right classes exhaust the class of morphisms with the given lifting property.

For the classical fibrations this is by definition, for the the classical acyclic fibrations this is by lemma 19.

The remaining statement for Cof clCof_{cl} and W cl‚à©Cof clW_{cl}\cap Cof_{cl} follows from a general argument (here) for cofibrantly generated model categories (def. 89), which we spell out:

So let f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y be in (I TopInj)Proj(I_{Top} Inj) Proj, we need to show that then ff is a retract (remark 3) of a relative cell complex. To that end, apply the small object argument as in lemma 20 to factor ff as

f:X‚ü∂I TopCellY^‚ü∂‚ààI TopInjY. f \;\colon \; X \overset{I_{Top} Cell}{\longrightarrow} \hat Y \overset{\in I_{Top} Inj}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.

It follows that ff has the left lifting property against Y^‚ÜíY\hat Y \to Y, and hence by the retract argument (lemma 2) it is a retract of X‚ÜíICellY^X \overset{I Cell}{\to} \hat Y. This proves the claim for Cof clCof_{cl}.

The analogous argument for W cl‚à©Cof clW_{cl} \cap Cof_{cl}, using the small object argument for J TopJ_{Top}, shows that every f‚àà(J TopInj)Projf \in (J_{Top} Inj) Proj is a retract of a J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex. By lemma 17 and lemma 18 a J TopJ_{Top}-cell complex is both an I TopI_{Top}-cell complex and a weak homotopy equivalence. Retracts of the former are cofibrations by definition, and retracts of the latter are still weak homotopy equivalences by lemma 1. Hence such ff is an acyclic cofibration.

In conclusion, prop. 31 and prop. 32 say that:

Theorem

The classes of morphisms in Mor(Top)Mor(Top) of def. 41,

  • W cl=W_{cl} = weak homotopy equivalences,

  • Fib cl=Fib_{cl} = Serre fibrations

  • Cof cl=Cof_{cl} = retracts of relative cell complexes

define a model category structure (def. 1) Top QuillenTop_{Quillen}, the classical model structure on topological spaces or Serre-Quillen model structure .

In particular

  1. every object in Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} is fibrant;

  2. the cofibrant objects in Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} are the retracts of cell complexes.

Hence in particular the following classical statement is an immediate corollary:

Corollary

(Whitehead theorem)

Every weak homotopy equivalence (def. 32) between topological spaces that are homeomorphic to a retract of a cell complex, in particular to a CW-complex (def. 36), is a homotopy equivalence (def. 31).

Proof

This is the ‚ÄúWhitehead theorem in model categories‚Äù, lemma 5, specialized to Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} via theorem 2.

In proving theorem 2 we have in fact shown a bit more that stated. Looking back, all the structure of Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} is entirely induced by the set I TopI_{Top} (def. 35) of generating cofibrations and the set J TopJ_{Top} (def. 38) of generating acyclic cofibrations (whence the terminology). This situation is usefully summarized by the concept of cofibrantly generated model category (Def. 89).

This phenomenon will keep recurring and will keep being useful as we construct further model categories, such as the classical model structure on pointed topological spaces (def. 47), the projective model structure on topological functors (thm. 5), and finally various model structures on spectra which we turn to in the section on stable homotopy theory.

\,

The classical homotopy category

With the classical model structure on topological spaces in hand, we now have good control over the classical homotopy category:

Definition

The Serre-Quillen classical homotopy category is the homotopy category, def. 9, of the classical model structure on topological spaces Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} from theorem 2: we write

Ho(Top)‚âîHo(Top Quillen). Ho(Top) \coloneqq Ho(Top_{Quillen}) \,.
Remark

From just theorem 2, the definition 9 (def. 42) gives that

Ho(Top Quillen)‚âÉ(Top Retract(Cell))/ ‚àº Ho(Top_{Quillen}) \simeq (Top_{Retract(Cell)})/_\sim

is the category whose objects are retracts of cell complexes (def. 36) and whose morphisms are homotopy classes of continuous functions. But in fact more is true:

Theorem 2 in itself implies that every topological space is weakly equivalent to a retract of a cell complex, def. 36. But by the existence of CW approximations, this cell complex may even be taken to be a CW complex.

(Better yet, there is Quillen equivalence to the classical model structure on simplicial sets which implies a functorial CW approximation |SingX|‚ü∂‚ààW clX{\vert Sing X\vert} \overset{\in W_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} X given by forming the geometric realization of the singular simplicial complex of XX.)

Hence the Serre-Quillen classical homotopy category is also equivalently the category of just the CW-complexes whith homotopy classes of continuous functions between them

Ho(Top Quillen) ‚âÉ(Top Retract(Cell))/ ‚àº ‚âÉ(Top CW)/ ‚àº. \begin{aligned} Ho(Top_{Quillen}) & \simeq (Top_{Retract(Cell)})/_\sim \\ & \simeq (Top_{CW})/_{\sim} \end{aligned} \,.

It follows that the universal property of the homotopy category (theorem 1)

Ho(Top Quillen)‚âÉTop[W cl ‚àí1] Ho(Top_{Quillen}) \simeq Top[W_{cl}^{-1}]

implies that there is a bijection, up to natural isomorphism, between

  1. functors out of Top CWTop_{CW} which agree on homotopy-equivalent maps;

  2. functors out of all of TopTop which send weak homotopy equivalences to isomorphisms.

This statement in particular serves to show that two different axiomatizations of generalized (Eilenberg-Steenrod) cohomology theories are equivalent to each other. See at Introduction to Stable homotopy theory -- S the section generalized cohomology functors (this prop.)

Beware that, by remark 19, what is not equivalent to Ho(Top Quillen)Ho(Top_{Quillen}) is the category

hTop‚âîTop/ ‚àº hTop \coloneqq Top/_\sim

obtained from all topological spaces with morphisms the homotopy classes of continuous functions. This category is ‚Äútoo large‚Äù, the correct homotopy category is just the genuine full subcategory

Ho(Top Quillen)‚âÉ(Top Retract(Cell))/ ‚àº‚âÉTop/ ‚àº=‚Ü™hTop. Ho(Top_{Quillen}) \simeq (Top_{Retract(Cell)})/_\sim \simeq Top/_\sim = \hookrightarrow hTop \,.

Beware also the ambiguity of terminology: ‚Äúclassical homotopy category‚Äù some literature refers to hTophTop instead of Ho(Top Quillen)Ho(Top_{Quillen}). However, here we never have any use for hTophTop and will not mention it again.

Proposition

Let XX be a CW-complex, def. 36. Then the standard topological cylinder of def. 28

X‚äîX‚ü∂(i 0,i 1)X√óI‚ü∂X X \sqcup X \overset{(i_0,i_1)}{\longrightarrow} X\times I \longrightarrow X

(obtained by forming the product space with the standard topological interval I=[0,1]I = [0,1]) is indeed a cylinder object in the abstract sense of def. 7.

Proof

We describe the proof informally. It is immediate how to turn this into a formal proof, but the notation becomes tedious. (One place where it is spelled out completely is Ottina 14, prop. 2.9.)

So let X 0‚ÜíX 1‚ÜíX 2‚Üí‚ãØ‚ÜíXX_0 \to X_1 \to X_2\to \cdots \to X be a presentation of XX as a CW-complex. Proceed by induction on the cell dimension.

First observe that the cylinder X 0√óIX_0 \times I over X 0X_0 is a cell complex: First X 0X_0 itself is a disjoint union of points. Adding a second copy for every point (i.e. attaching along S ‚àí1‚ÜíD 0S^{-1}\to D^0) yields X 0‚äîX 0X_0 \sqcup X_0, then attaching an inteval between any two corresponding points (along S 0‚ÜíD 1S^0 \to D^1) yields X 0√óIX_0 \times I.

So assume that for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} it has been shown that X n√óIX_n \times I has the structure of a CW-complex of dimension (n+1)(n+1). Then for each cell of X n+1X_{n+1}, attach it twice to X n√óIX_n \times I, once at X n√ó{0}X_n \times \{0\}, and once at X n√ó{1}X_n \times \{1\}.

The result is X n+1X_{n+1} with a hollow cylinder erected over each of its (n+1)(n+1)-cells. Now fill these hollow cylinders (along S n+1‚ÜíD n+1S^{n+1} \to D^{n+1}) to obtain X n+1√óIX_{n+1}\times I.

This completes the induction, hence the proof of the CW-structure on X√óIX\times I.

The construction also manifestly exhibits the inclusion X‚äîX‚ü∂(i 0,i 1)X \sqcup X \overset{(i_0,i_1)}{\longrightarrow} as a relative cell complex.

Finally, it is clear (prop. 28) that X√óI‚ÜíXX \times I \to X is a weak homotopy equivalence.

Conversely:

Proposition

Let XX be any topological space. Then the standard topological path space object (def. 33)

X‚ü∂X I‚ü∂(X Œ¥ 0,X Œ¥ 1)X√óX X \longrightarrow X^I \overset{(X^{\delta_0}, X^{\delta_1})}{\longrightarrow} X \times X

(obtained by forming the mapping space, def. 27, with the standard topological interval I=[0,1]I = [0,1]) is indeed a path space object in the abstract sense of def. 7.

Proof

To see that const:X‚ÜíX Iconst \colon X\to X^I is a weak homotopy equivalence it is sufficient, by prop. 28, to exhibit a homotopy equivalence. Let the homotopy inverse be X Œ¥ 0:X I‚ÜíXX^{\delta_0} \colon X^I \to X. Then the composite

X‚ü∂constX I‚ü∂X Œ¥ 0X X \overset{const}{\longrightarrow} X^I \overset{X^{\delta_0}}{\longrightarrow} X

is already equal to the identity. The other we round, the rescaling of paths provides the required homotopy

I√óX I ‚ü∂(t,Œ≥)‚Ü¶Œ≥(t‚ãÖ(‚àí)) X I. \array{ I \times X^I &\overset{(t,\gamma)\mapsto \gamma(t\cdot(-))}{\longrightarrow}& X^I } \,.

To see that X I‚ÜíX√óXX^I \to X\times X is a fibration, we need to show that every commuting square of the form

D n ‚ü∂ X I i 0‚Üì ‚Üì D n√óI ‚ü∂ X√óX \array{ D^n &\longrightarrow& X^I \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_0}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{} \\ D^n \times I &\longrightarrow& X \times X }

has a lift.

Now first use the adjunction (I√ó(‚àí))‚ä£(‚àí) I(I \times (-))\dashv (-)^I from prop. 27 to rewrite this equivalently as the following commuting square:

D n‚äîD n ‚ü∂(i 0,i 0) (D n√óI)‚äî(D n√óI) (i 0,i 1)‚Üì ‚Üì D n√óI ‚ü∂ X. \array{ D^n \sqcup D^n &\overset{(i_0, i_0)}{\longrightarrow}& (D^n \times I) \sqcup (D^n \times I) \\ {}^{\mathllap{(i_0, i_1)}}\downarrow && \downarrow \\ D^n \times I &\longrightarrow& X } \,.

This square is equivalently (example 19) a morphism out of the pushout

D n√óI‚äîD n‚äîD n((D n√óI)‚äî(D n√óI))‚ü∂X. D^n \times I \underset{D^n \sqcup D^n }{\sqcup} \left((D^n \times I) \sqcup (D^n \times I)\right) \longrightarrow X \,.

By the same reasoning, a lift in the original diagram is now equivalently a lifting in

D n√óI‚äîD n‚äîD n((D n√óI)‚äî(D n√óI)) ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üì (D n√óI)√óI ‚ü∂ *. \array{ D^n \times I \underset{D^n \sqcup D^n }{\sqcup} \left((D^n \times I) \sqcup (D^n \times I)\right) &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ (D^n \times I)\times I &\longrightarrow& \ast } \,.

Inspection of the component maps shows that the left vertical morphism here is the inclusion into the square times D nD^n of three of its faces times D nD^n. This is homeomorphic to the inclusion D n+1‚ÜíD n+1√óID^{n+1} \to D^{n+1} \times I (as in remark 22). Therefore a lift in this square exsists, and hence a lift in the original square exists.

Model structure on pointed spaces

A pointed object (X,x)(X,x) is of course an object XX equipped with a point x:*‚ÜíXx \colon \ast \to X, and a morphism of pointed objects (X,x)‚ü∂(Y,y)(X,x) \longrightarrow (Y,y) is a morphism X‚ü∂YX \longrightarrow Y that takes xx to yy. Trivial as this is in itself, it is good to record some basic facts, which we do here.

Passing to pointed objects is also the first step in linearizing classical homotopy theory to stable homotopy theory. In particular, every category of pointed objects has a zero object, hence has zero morphisms. And crucially, if the original category had Cartesian products, then its pointed objects canonically inherit a non-cartesian tensor product: the smash product. These ingredients will be key below in the section on stable homotopy theory.

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a category and let X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} be an object.

The slice category ùíû /X\mathcal{C}_{/X} is the category whose

  • objects are morphisms A ‚Üì X\array{A \\ \downarrow \\ X} in ùíû\mathcal{C};

  • morphisms are commuting triangles A ‚ü∂ B ‚Üò ‚Üô X\array{ A && \longrightarrow && B \\ & {}_{}\searrow && \swarrow \\ && X} in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Dually, the coslice category ùíû X/\mathcal{C}^{X/} is the category whose

  • objects are morphisms X ‚Üì A\array{X \\ \downarrow \\ A} in ùíû\mathcal{C};

  • morphisms are commuting triangles X ‚Üô ‚Üò A ‚ü∂ B\array{ && X \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ A && \longrightarrow && B } in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

There are the canonical forgetful functors

U:ùíû /X,ùíû X/‚ü∂ùíû U \;\colon \; \mathcal{C}_{/X}, \mathcal{C}^{X/} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}

given by forgetting the morphisms to/from XX.

We here focus on this class of examples:

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a category with terminal object *\ast, the coslice category (def. 43) ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} is the corresponding category of pointed objects: its

  • objects are morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C} of the form *‚ÜíxX\ast \overset{x}{\to} X (hence an object XX equipped with a choice of point; i.e. a pointed object);

  • morphisms are commuting triangles of the form

    * x‚Üô ‚Üò y X ‚ü∂f Y \array{ && \ast \\ & {}^{\mathllap{x}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{y}} \\ X && \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} && Y }

    (hence morphisms in ùíû\mathcal{C} which preserve the chosen points).

Remark

In a category of pointed objects ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}, def. 44, the terminal object coincides with the initial object, both are given by *‚ààùíû\ast \in \mathcal{C} itself, pointed in the unique way.

In this situation one says that *\ast is a zero object and that ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} is a pointed category.

It follows that also all hom-sets Hom ùíû */(X,Y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}}(X,Y) of ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} are canonically pointed sets, pointed by the zero morphism

0:X‚ü∂‚àÉ!0‚ü∂‚àÉ!Y. 0 \;\colon\; X \overset{\exists !}{\longrightarrow} 0 \overset{\exists !}{\longrightarrow} Y \,.
Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a category with terminal object and finite colimits. Then the forgetful functor U:ùíû */‚ÜíùíûU \colon \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} \to \mathcal{C} from its category of pointed objects, def. 44, has a left adjoint

ùíû */‚ä•‚ü∂U‚üµ(‚àí) +ùíû \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} \underoverset {\underset{U}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{(-)_+}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C}

given by forming the disjoint union (coproduct) with a base point (‚Äúadjoining a base point‚Äù).

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a category with all limits and colimits. Then also the category of pointed objects ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}, def. 44, has all limits and colimits.

Moreover:

  1. the limits are the limits of the underlying diagrams in ùíû\mathcal{C}, with the base point of the limit induced by its universal property in ùíû\mathcal{C};

  2. the colimits are the limits in ùíû\mathcal{C} of the diagrams with the basepoint adjoined.

Proof

It is immediate to check the relevant universal property. For details see at slice category ‚Äì limits and colimits.

Example

Given two pointed objects (X,x)(X,x) and (Y,y)(Y,y), then:

  1. their product in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} is simply (X√óY,(x,y))(X\times Y, (x,y));

  2. their coproduct in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} has to be computed using the second clause in prop. 35: since the point *\ast has to be adjoined to the diagram, it is given not by the coproduct in ùíû\mathcal{C}, but by the pushout in ùíû\mathcal{C} of the form:

    * ‚ü∂x X y‚Üì (po) ‚Üì Y ‚ü∂ X‚à®Y. \array{ \ast &\overset{x}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{y}}\downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ Y &\longrightarrow& X \vee Y } \,.

    This is called the wedge sum operation on pointed objects.

Generally for a set {X i} i‚ààI\{X_i\}_{i \in I} in Top */Top^{\ast/}

  1. their product is formed in TopTop as in example 16, with the new basepoint canonically induced;

  2. their coproduct is formed by the colimit in TopTop over the diagram with a basepoint adjoined, and is called the wedge sum ‚à® i‚ààIX i\vee_{i \in I} X_i.

Example

For XX a CW-complex, def. 36 then for every n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} the quotient (example 20) of its nn-skeleton by its (n‚àí1)(n-1)-skeleton is the wedge sum, def. 28, of nn-spheres, one for each nn-cell of XX:

X n/X n‚àí1‚âÉ‚à®i‚ààI nS n. X^n / X^{n-1} \simeq \underset{i \in I_n}{\vee} S^n \,.
Definition

For ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} a category of pointed objects with finite limits and finite colimits, the smash product is the functor

(‚àí)‚àß(‚àí):ùíû */√óùíû */‚ü∂ùíû */ (-)\wedge(-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} \times \mathcal{C}^{\ast/} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\ast/}

given by

X‚àßY‚âî*‚äîX‚äîY(X√óY), X \wedge Y \;\coloneqq\; \ast \underset{X\sqcup Y}{\sqcup} (X \times Y) \,,

hence by the pushout in ùíû\mathcal{C}

X‚äîY ‚ü∂(id X,y),(x,id Y) X√óY ‚Üì ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ X‚àßY. \array{ X \sqcup Y &\overset{(id_X,y),(x,id_Y) }{\longrightarrow}& X \times Y \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& X \wedge Y } \,.

In terms of the wedge sum from def. 28, this may be written concisely as

X‚àßY=X√óYX‚à®Y. X \wedge Y = \frac{X\times Y}{X \vee Y} \,.
Remark

For a general category ùíû\mathcal{C} in def. 46, the smash product need not be associative, namely it fails to be associative if the functor (‚àí)√óZ(-)\times Z does not preserve the quotients involved in the definition.

In particular this may happen for ùíû=\mathcal{C} = Top.

A sufficient condition for (‚àí)√óZ(-) \times Z to preserve quotients is that it is a left adjoint functor. This is the case in the smaller subcategory of compactly generated topological spaces, we come to this in prop. 38 below.

These two operations are going to be ubiquituous in stable homotopy theory:

symbolnamecategory theory
X‚à®YX \vee Ywedge sumcoproduct in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}
X‚àßYX \wedge Ysmash producttensor product in ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}
Example

For X,Y‚ààTopX, Y \in Top, with X +,Y +‚ààTop */X_+,Y_+ \in Top^{\ast/}, def. 45, then

  • X +‚à®Y +‚âÉ(X‚äîY) +X_+ \vee Y_+ \simeq (X \sqcup Y)_+;

  • X +‚àßY +‚âÉ(X√óY) +X_+ \wedge Y_+ \simeq (X \times Y)_+.

Proof

By example 28, X +‚à®Y +X_+ \vee Y_+ is given by the colimit in TopTop over the diagram

* ‚Üô ‚Üò X * * Y. \array{ && && \ast \\ && & \swarrow && \searrow \\ X &\,\,& \ast && && \ast &\,\,& Y } \,.

This is clearly X‚äî*‚äîYX \sqcup \ast \sqcup Y. Then, by definition 46

X +‚àßY + ‚âÉ(X‚äî*)√ó(X‚äî*)(X‚äî*)‚à®(Y‚äî*) ‚âÉX√óY‚äîX‚äîY‚äî*X‚äîY‚äî* ‚âÉX√óY‚äî*. \begin{aligned} X_+ \wedge Y_+ & \simeq \frac{(X \sqcup \ast) \times (X \sqcup \ast)}{(X\sqcup \ast) \vee (Y \sqcup \ast)} \\ & \simeq \frac{X \times Y \sqcup X \sqcup Y \sqcup \ast}{X \sqcup Y \sqcup \ast} \\ & \simeq X \times Y \sqcup \ast \,. \end{aligned}
Example

Let ùíû */=Top */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} = Top^{\ast/} be pointed topological spaces. Then

I +‚ààTop */ I_+ \in Top^{\ast/}

denotes the standard interval object I=[0,1]I = [0,1] from def. 28, with a djoint basepoint adjoined, def. 45. Now for XX any pointed topological space, then

X‚àß(I +)=(X√óI)/({x 0}√óI) X \wedge (I_+) = (X \times I)/(\{x_0\} \times I)

is the reduced cylinder over XX: the result of forming the ordinary cyclinder over XX as in def. 28, and then identifying the interval over the basepoint of XX with the point.

(Generally, any construction in ùíû\mathcal{C} properly adapted to pointed objects ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} is called the ‚Äúreduced‚Äù version of the unpointed construction. Notably so for ‚Äúreduced suspension‚Äù which we come to below.)

Just like the ordinary cylinder X√óIX\times I receives a canonical injection from the coproduct X‚äîXX \sqcup X formed in TopTop, so the reduced cyclinder receives a canonical injection from the coproduct X‚äîXX \sqcup X formed in Top */Top^{\ast/}, which is the wedge sum from example 28:

X‚à®X‚ü∂X‚àß(I +). X \vee X \longrightarrow X \wedge (I_+) \,.
Example

For (X,x),(Y,y)(X,x),(Y,y) pointed topological spaces with YY a locally compact topological space, then the pointed mapping space is the topological subspace of the mapping space of def. 27

Maps((Y,y),(X,x)) *‚Ü™(X Y,const x) Maps((Y,y),(X,x))_\ast \hookrightarrow (X^Y, const_x)

on those maps which preserve the basepoints, and pointed by the map constant on the basepoint of XX.

In particular, the standard topological pointed path space object on some pointed XX (the pointed variant of def. 33) is the pointed mapping space Maps(I +,X) *Maps(I_+,X)_\ast.

The pointed consequence of prop. 27 then gives that there is a natural bijection

Hom Top */((Z,z)‚àß(Y,y),(X,x))‚âÉHom Top */((Z,z),Maps((Y,y),(X,x)) *) Hom_{Top^{\ast/}}((Z,z) \wedge (Y,y), (X,x)) \simeq Hom_{Top^{\ast/}}((Z,z), Maps((Y,y),(X,x))_\ast)

between basepoint-preserving continuous functions out of a smash product, def. 46, with pointed continuous functions of one variable into the pointed mapping space.

Example

Given a morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y in a category of pointed objects ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}, def. 44, with finite limits and colimits,

  1. its fiber or kernel is the pullback of the point inclusion

    fib(f) ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì (pb) ‚Üì f * ‚ü∂ Y \array{ fib(f) &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &(pb)& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& Y }

  2. its cofiber or cokernel is the pushout of the point projection

    X ‚ü∂f Y ‚Üì (po) ‚Üì * ‚ü∂ cofib(f). \array{ X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ \downarrow &(po)& \downarrow \\ \ast &\longrightarrow& cofib(f) } \,.
Remark

In the situation of example 33, both the pullback as well as the pushout are equivalently computed in ùíû\mathcal{C}. For the pullback this is the first clause of prop. 35. The second clause says that for computing the pushout in ùíû\mathcal{C}, first the point is to be adjoined to the diagram, and then the colimit over the larger diagram

* ‚Üò X ‚ü∂f Y ‚Üì * \array{ \ast \\ & \searrow \\ & & X &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ & & \downarrow && \\ & & \ast && }

be computed. But one readily checks that in this special case this does not affect the result. (The technical jargon is that the inclusion of the smaller diagram into the larger one in this case happens to be a final functor.)

Proposition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a model category and let X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} be an object. Then both the slice category ùíû /X\mathcal{C}_{/X} as well as the coslice category ùíû X/\mathcal{C}^{X/}, def. 43, carry model structures themselves ‚Äì the model structure on a (co-)slice category, where a morphism is a weak equivalence, fibration or cofibration iff its image under the forgetful functor UU is so in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

In particular the category ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} of pointed objects, def. 44, in a model category ùíû\mathcal{C} becomes itself a model category this way.

The corresponding homotopy category of a model category, def. 9, we call the pointed homotopy category Ho(ùíû */)Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}).

Proof

This is immediate:

By prop. 35 the (co-)slice category has all limits and colimits. By definition of the weak equivalences in the (co-)slice, they satisfy two-out-of-three, def. \ref{CategoryWithWeakEquivalences}, because the do in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Similarly, the factorization and lifting is all induced by ùíû\mathcal{C}: Consider the coslice category ùíû X/\mathcal{C}^{X/}, the case of the slice category is formally dual; then if

X ‚Üô ‚Üò A ‚ü∂f B \array{ && X \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ A && \underset{f}{\longrightarrow} && B }

commutes in ùíû\mathcal{C}, and a factorization of ff exists in ùíû\mathcal{C}, it uniquely makes this diagram commute

X ‚Üô ‚Üì ‚Üò A ‚ü∂ C ‚ü∂ B. \array{ && X \\ & \swarrow &\downarrow& \searrow \\ A &\longrightarrow& C & \longrightarrow& B } \,.

Similarly, if

A ‚ü∂ C ‚Üì ‚Üì B ‚ü∂ D \array{ A &\longrightarrow& C \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ B &\longrightarrow& D }

is a commuting diagram in ùíû X/\mathcal{C}^{X/}, hence a commuting diagram in ùíû\mathcal{C} as shown, with all objects equipped with compatible morphisms from XX, then inspection shows that any lift in the diagram necessarily respects the maps from XX, too.

Example

For ùíû\mathcal{C} any model category, with ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} its pointed model structure according to prop. 36, then the corresponding homotopy category (def. 9) is, by remark 24, canonically enriched in pointed sets, in that its hom-functor is of the form

[‚àí,‚àí] *:Ho(ùíû */) op√óHo(ùíû */)‚ü∂Set */. [-,-]_\ast \;\colon\; Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/})^\op \times Ho(\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}) \longrightarrow Set^{\ast/} \,.
Definition

Write Top Quillen */Top^{\ast/}_{Quillen} for the classical model structure on pointed topological spaces, obtained from the classical model structure on topological spaces Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} (theorem 2) via the induced coslice model structure of prop. 36.

Its homotopy category, def. 9,

Ho(Top */)‚âîHo(Top Quillen */) Ho(Top^{\ast/}) \coloneqq Ho(Top_{Quillen}^{\ast/})

we call the classical pointed homotopy category.

Remark

The fibrant objects in the pointed model structure ùíû */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/}, prop. 36, are those that are fibrant as objects of ùíû\mathcal{C}. But the cofibrant objects in ùíû *\mathcal{C}^{\ast} are now those for which the basepoint inclusion is a cofibration in XX.

For ùíû */=Top Quillen */\mathcal{C}^{\ast/} = Top^{\ast/}_{Quillen} from def. 47, then the corresponding cofibrant pointed topological spaces are tyically referred to as spaces with non-degenerate basepoints or . Notice that the point itself is cofibrant in Top QuillenTop_{Quillen}, so that cofibrant pointed topological spaces are in particular cofibrant topological spaces.

While the existence of the model structure on Top */Top^{\ast/} is immediate, via prop. 36, for the discussion of topologically enriched functors (below) it is useful to record that this, too, is a cofibrantly generated model category (def. 89), as follows:

Definition

Write

I Top */={S + n‚àí1‚ü∂(Œπ n) +D + n}‚äÇMor(Top */) I_{Top^{\ast/}} = \left\{ S^{n-1}_+ \overset{(\iota_n)_+}{\longrightarrow} D^n_+ \right\} \;\; \subset Mor(Top^{\ast/})

and

J Top */={D + n‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0) +(D n√óI) +}‚äÇMor(Top */), J_{Top^{\ast/}} = \left\{ D^n_+ \overset{(id, \delta_0)_+}{\longrightarrow} (D^n \times I)_+ \right\} \;\;\; \subset Mor(Top^{\ast/}) \,,

respectively, for the sets of morphisms obtained from the classical generating cofibrations, def. 35, and the classical generating acyclic cofibrations, def. 38, under adjoining of basepoints (def. 45).

Theorem

The sets I Top */I_{Top^{\ast/}} and J Top */J_{Top^{\ast/}} in def. 48 exhibit the classical model structure on pointed topological spaces Top Quillen */Top^{\ast/}_{Quillen} of def. 47 as a cofibrantly generated model category, def. 89.

(This is also a special case of a general statement about cofibrant generation of coslice model structures, see this proposition.)

Proof

Due to the fact that in J Top */J_{Top^{\ast/}} a basepoint is freely adjoined, lemma 19 goes through verbatim for the pointed case, with J TopJ_{Top} replaced by J Top */J_{Top^{\ast/}}, as do the other two lemmas above that depend on point-set topology, lemma 15 and lemma 18. With this, the rest of the proof follows by the same general abstract reasoning as above in the proof of theorem 2.

Model structure on compactly generated spaces

The category Top has the technical inconvenience that mapping spaces X YX^Y (def. 27) satisfying the exponential property (prop. 27) exist in general only for YY a locally compact topological space, but fail to exist more generally. In other words: Top is not cartesian closed. But cartesian closure is necessary for some purposes of homotopy theory, for instance it ensures that

  1. the smash product (def. 46) on pointed topological spaces is associative (prop. 38 below);

  2. there is a concept of topologically enriched functors with values in topological spaces, to which we turn below;

  3. geometric realization of simplicial sets preserves products.

The first two of these are crucial for the development of stable homotopy theory in the next section, the third is a great convenience in computations.

Now, since the homotopy theory of topological spaces only cares about the CW approximation to any topological space (remark 23), it is plausible to ask for a full subcategory of Top which still contains all CW-complexes, still has all limits and colimits, still supports a model category structure constructed in the same way as above, but which in addition is cartesian closed, and preferably such that the model structure interacts well with the cartesian closure.

Such a full subcategory exists, the category of compactly generated topological spaces. This we briefly describe now.

Literature (Strickland 09)

\,

Definition

Let XX be a topological space.

A subset A‚äÇXA \subset X is called compactly closed (or kk-closed) if for every continuous function f:K‚ü∂Xf \colon K \longrightarrow X out of a compact Hausdorff space KK, then the preimage f ‚àí1(A)f^{-1}(A) is a closed subset of KK.

The space XX is called compactly generated if its closed subsets exhaust (hence coincide with) the kk-closed subsets.

Write

Top cg‚Ü™Top Top_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top

for the full subcategory of Top on the compactly generated topological spaces.

Definition

Write

Top‚ü∂kTop cg‚Ü™Top Top \overset{k}{\longrightarrow} Top_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top

for the functor which sends any topological space X=(S,œÑ)X = (S,\tau) to the topological space (S,kœÑ)(S, k \tau) with the same underlying set SS, but with open subsets kœÑk \tau the collection of all kk-open subsets with respect to œÑ\tau.

Lemma

Let X‚ààTop cg‚Ü™TopX \in Top_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top and let Y‚ààTopY\in Top. Then continuous functions

X‚ü∂Y X \longrightarrow Y

are also continuous when regarded as functions

X‚ü∂k(Y) X \longrightarrow k(Y)

with kk from def. 50.

Proof

We need to show that for A‚äÇXA \subset X a kk-closed subset, then the preimage f ‚àí1(A)‚äÇXf^{-1}(A) \subset X is closed subset.

Let œï:K‚ü∂X\phi \colon K \longrightarrow X be any continuous function out of a compact Hausdorff space KK. Since AA is kk-closed by assumption, we have that (f‚àòœï) ‚àí1(A)=œï ‚àí1(f ‚àí1(A))‚äÇK(f \circ \phi)^{-1}(A) = \phi^{-1}(f^{-1}(A))\subset K is closed in KK. This means that f ‚àí1(A)f^{-1}(A) is kk-closed in XX. But by the assumption that XX is compactly generated, it follows that f ‚àí1(A)f^{-1}(A) is already closed.

Corollary

For X‚ààTop cgX \in Top_{cg} there is a natural bijection

Hom Top(X,Y)‚âÉHom Top cg(X,k(Y)). Hom_{Top}(X,Y) \simeq Hom_{Top_{cg}}(X, k(Y)) \,.

This means equivalently that the functor kk (def. 50) together with the inclusion from def. 88 forms an pair of adjoint functors

Top cg‚ä•‚üµk‚Ü™Top. Top_{cg} \underoverset {\underset{k}{\longleftarrow}} {\hookrightarrow} {\bot} Top \,.

This in turn means equivalently that Top cg‚Ü™TopTop_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top is a coreflective subcategory with coreflector kk. In particular kk is idemotent in that there are natural homeomorphisms

k(k(X))‚âÉk(X). k(k(X))\simeq k(X) \,.

Hence colimits in Top cgTop_{cg} exists and are computed as in Top. Also limits in Top cgTop_{cg} exists, these are obtained by computing the limit in Top and then applying the functor kk to the result.

The following is a slight variant of def. 27, appropriate for the context of Top cgTop_{cg}.

Definition

For X,Y‚ààTop cgX, Y \in Top_{cg} (def. 88) the compactly generated mapping space X Y‚ààTop cgX^Y \in Top_{cg} is the compactly generated topological space whose underlying set is the set C(Y,X)C(Y,X) of continuous functions f:Y‚ÜíXf \colon Y \to X, and for which a subbase for its topology has elements U œï(K)U^{\phi(K)}, for U‚äÇXU \subset X any open subset and œï:K‚ÜíY\phi \colon K \to Y a continuous function out of a compact Hausdorff space KK given by

U œï(Œ∫)‚âî{f‚ààC(Y,X)|f(œï(K))‚äÇU}. U^{\phi(\kappa)} \coloneqq \left\{ f\in C(Y,X) | f(\phi(K)) \subset U \right\} \,.
Remark

If YY is (compactly generated and) a Hausdorff space, then the topology on the compactly generated mapping space X YX^Y in def. 51 agrees with the compact-open topology of def. 27. Beware that it is common to say ‚Äúcompact-open topology‚Äù also for the topology of the compactly generated mapping space when YY is not Hausdorff. In that case, however, the two definitions in general disagree.

Proposition

The category Top cgTop_{cg} of def. 88 is cartesian closed:

for every X‚ààTop cgX \in Top_{cg} then the operation X√ó(‚àí)√ó(‚àí)√óXX\times (-) \times (-)\times X of forming the Cartesian product in Top cgTop_{cg} (which by cor. 4 is kk applied to the usual product topological space) together with the operation (‚àí) X(-)^X of forming the compactly generated mapping space (def. 51) forms a pair of adjoint functors

Top cg‚ä•‚ü∂(‚àí) X‚üµX√ó(‚àí)Top cg. Top_{cg} \underoverset {\underset{(-)^X}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{X \times (-)}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} Top_{cg} \,.

For proof see for instance (Strickland 09, prop. 2.12).

Corollary

For X,Y‚ààTop cg */X, Y \in Top_{cg}^{\ast/}, the operation of forming the pointed mapping space (example 32) inside the compactly generated mapping space of def. 51

Maps(Y,X) *‚âîfib(X Y‚ü∂ev yX,x) Maps(Y,X)_\ast \coloneqq fib\left( X^Y \overset{ev_y}{\longrightarrow} X \;, x \right)

is left adjoint to the smash product operation on pointed compactly generated topological spaces.

Top cg */‚ä•‚ü∂Maps(Y,‚àí) *‚üµY‚àß(‚àí)Top cg */. Top_{cg}^{\ast/} \underoverset {\underset{Maps(Y,-)_\ast}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{Y \wedge (-)}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} Top_{cg}^{\ast/} \,.
Corollary

For II a small category and X ‚Ä¢:I‚ÜíTop cg */X_\bullet \colon I \to Top^{\ast/}_{cg} a diagram, then the compactly generated mapping space construction from def. 51 preserves limits in its covariant argument and sends colimits in its contravariant argument to limits:

Maps(X,lim‚üµ iY i) *‚âÉlim‚üµ iMaps(X,Y i) * Maps(X,\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i Y_i)_\ast \;\simeq\; \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i Maps(X, Y_i)_\ast

and

Maps(lim‚ü∂ iX i,Y) *‚âÉlim‚üµ iMaps(X i,Y) *. Maps( \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i, \; Y )_\ast \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i Maps( X_i, Y )_\ast \,.
Proof

The first statement is an immediate implication of Maps(X,‚àí) *Maps(X,-)_\ast being a right adjoint, according to cor. 5.

For the second statement, we use that by def. 88 a compactly generated topological space is uniquely determined if one knows all continuous functions out of compact Hausdorff spaces into it. Hence it is sufficient to show that there is a natural isomorphism

Hom Top cg */(K,Maps(lim‚ü∂ iX i,Y) *)‚âÉHom Top cg */(K,lim‚üµ iMaps(X i,Y) *) Hom_{Top_{cg}^{\ast/}}\left( K,\; Maps( \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i, \; Y )_\ast \right) \simeq Hom_{Top^{\ast/}_{cg}}\left( K, \; \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i Maps( X_i, Y )_\ast \right)

for KK any compact Hausdorff space.

With this, the statement follows by cor. 5 and using that ordinary hom-sets take colimits in the first argument and limits in the second argument to limits:

Hom Top cg */(K,Maps(lim‚ü∂ iX i,Y) *) ‚âÉHom Top cg */(K‚àßlim‚ü∂ iX i,Y) ‚âÉHom Top cg */(lim‚ü∂ i(K‚àßX i),Y) ‚âÉlim‚üµ i(Hom Top cg */(K‚àßX i,Y)) ‚âÉlim‚üµ iHom Top cg */(K,Maps(X i,Y) *) ‚âÉHom Top cg */(K,lim‚üµ iMaps(X i,Y) *). \begin{aligned} Hom_{Top^{\ast/}_{cg}} \left( K, \; Maps(\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i,\; Y)_\ast \right) & \simeq Hom_{Top^{\ast/}_{cg}} \left( K \wedge \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i,\; Y \right) \\ & \simeq Hom_{Top^{\ast/}_{cg}} \left( \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i (K \wedge X_i) ,\; Y \right) \\ & \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( Hom_{Top^{\ast/}_{cg}} ( K \wedge X_i, \; Y ) \right) \\ & \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i Hom_{Top^{\ast/}_{cg}}( K, \; Maps(X_i,Y)_\ast ) \\ & \simeq Hom_{Top^{\ast/}_{cg}} \left( K,\; \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i Maps(X_i,Y)_\ast \right) \end{aligned} \,.

Moreover, compact generation fixes the associativity of the smash product (remark 25):

Proposition

On pointed (def. 44) compactly generated topological spaces (def. 88) the smash product (def. 46)

(‚àí)‚àß(‚àí):Top cg */√óTop cg */‚ü∂Top cg */ (-)\wedge (-) \;\colon\; Top_{cg}^{\ast/} \times Top_{cg}^{\ast/} \longrightarrow Top_{cg}^{\ast/}

is associative and the 0-sphere is a tensor unit for it.

Proof

Since (‚àí)√óX(-)\times X is a left adjoint by prop. 37, it presevers colimits and in particular quotient space projections. Therefore with X,Y,Z‚ààTop cg */X, Y, Z \in Top_{cg}^{\ast/} then

(X‚àßY)‚àßZ =X√óYX√ó{y}‚äî{x}√óY√óZ(X‚àßY)√ó{z}‚äî{[x]=[y]}√óZ ‚âÉX√óY√óZX√ó{y}√óZ‚äî{x}√óY√óZX√óY√ó{z} ‚âÉX√óY√óZX‚à®Y‚à®Z. \begin{aligned} (X \wedge Y) \wedge Z & = \frac{ \frac{X\times Y}{X \times\{y\} \sqcup \{x\}\times Y} \times Z }{ (X \wedge Y)\times \{z\} \sqcup \{[x] = [y]\} \times Z} \\ & \simeq \frac{\frac{X \times Y \times Z}{X \times \{y\}\times Z \sqcup \{x\}\times Y \times Z}}{ X \times Y \times \{z\} } \\ &\simeq \frac{X\times Y \times Z}{ X \vee Y \vee Z} \end{aligned} \,.

The analogous reasoning applies to yield also X‚àß(Y‚àßZ)‚âÉX√óY√óZX‚à®Y‚à®ZX \wedge (Y\wedge Z) \simeq \frac{X\times Y \times Z}{ X \vee Y \vee Z}.

The second statement follows directly with prop. 37.

Remark

Corollary 5 together with prop. 38 says that under the smash product the category of pointed compactly generated topological spaces is a closed symmetric monoidal category with tensor unit the 0-sphere.

(Top cg */,‚àß,S 0),. (Top_{cg}^{\ast/}, \wedge, S^0) ,.

Notice that by prop. 37 also unpointed compactly generated spaces under Cartesian product form a closed symmetric monoidal category, hence a cartesian closed category

(Top cg,√ó,*). (Top_{cg}, \times , \ast) \,.

The fact that Top cg */Top_{cg}^{\ast/} is still closed symmetric monoidal but no longer Cartesian exhibits Top cg */Top_{cg}^{\ast/} as being ‚Äúmore linear‚Äù than Top cgTop_{cg}. The ‚Äúfull linearization‚Äù of Top cgTop_{cg} is the closed symmteric monoidal category of structured spectra under smash product of spectra which we discuss in section 1.

Due to the idempotency k‚àòk‚âÉkk \circ k \simeq k (cor. 4) it is useful to know plenty of conditions under which a given topological space is already compactly generated, for then applying kk to it does not change it and one may continue working as in TopTop.

Example

Every CW-complex is compactly generated.

Proof

Since a CW-complex is a Hausdorff space, by prop. 40 and prop. 41 its kk-closed subsets are precisely those whose intersection with every compact subspace is closed.

Since a CW-complex XX is a colimit in Top over attachments of standard n-disks D n iD^{n_i} (its cells), by the characterization of colimits in TopTop (prop.) a subset of XX is open or closed precisely if its restriction to each cell is open or closed, respectively. Since the nn-disks are compact, this implies one direction: if a subset AA of XX intersected with all compact subsets is closed, then AA is closed.

For the converse direction, since a CW-complex is a Hausdorff space and since compact subspaces of Hausdorff spaces are closed, the intersection of a closed subset with a compact subset is closed.

For completeness we record further classes of examples:

Example

The category Top cgTop_{cg} of compactly generated topological spaces includes

  1. all locally compact topological spaces,

  2. all first-countable topological spaces,

    hence in particular

    1. all metrizable topological spaces,

    2. all discrete topological spaces,

    3. all codiscrete topological spaces.

(Lewis 78, p. 148)

Recall that by corollary 4, all colimits of compactly generated spaces are again compactly generated.

Example

The product topological space of a CW-complex with a compact CW-complex, and more generally with a locally compact CW-complex, is compactly generated.

(Hatcher ‚ÄúTopology of cell complexes‚Äù, theorem A.6)

More generally:

Proposition

For XX a compactly generated space and YY a locally compact Hausdorff space, then the product topological space X√óYX\times Y is compactly generated.

e.g. (Strickland 09, prop. 26)

Finally we check that the concept of homotopy and homotopy groups does not change under passing to compactly generated spaces:

Proposition

For every topological space XX, the canonical function k(X)‚ü∂Xk(X) \longrightarrow X (the adjunction unit) is a weak homotopy equivalence.

Proof

By example 35, example 37 and lemma 23, continuous functions S n‚Üík(X)S^n \to k(X) and their left homotopies S n√óI‚Üík(X)S^n \times I \to k(X) are in bijection with functions S n‚ÜíXS^n \to X and their homotopies S n√óI‚ÜíXS^n \times I \to X.

Theorem

The restriction of the model category structure on Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} from theorem 2 along the inclusion Top cg‚Ü™TopTop_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top of def. 88 is still a model category structure, which is cofibrantly generated by the same sets I TopI_{Top} (def. 35) and J TopJ_{Top} (def. 38) The coreflection of cor. 4 is a Quillen equivalence (def. 17)

(Top cg) Quillen‚ä•‚üµk‚Ü™Top Quillen. (Top_{cg})_{Quillen} \underoverset {\underset{k}{\longleftarrow}} {\hookrightarrow} {\bot} Top_{Quillen} \,.
Proof

By example 35, the sets I TopI_{Top} and J TopJ_{Top} are indeed in Mor(Top cg)Mor(Top_{cg}). By example 37 all arguments above about left homotopies between maps out of these basic cells go through verbatim in Top cgTop_{cg}. Hence the three technical lemmas above depending on actual point-set topology, topology, lemma 15, lemma 18 and lemma 19, go through verbatim as before. Accordingly, since the remainder of the proof of theorem 2 of Top QuillenTop_{Quillen} follows by general abstract arguments from these, it also still goes through verbatim for (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} (repeatedly use the small object argument and the retract argument to establish the two weak factorization systems).

Hence the (acyclic) cofibrations in (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} are identified with those in Top QuillenTop_{Quillen}, and so the inclusion is a part of a Quillen adjunction (def. 16). To see that this is a Quillen equivalence (def. 17), it is sufficient to check that for XX a compactly generated space then a continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y is a weak homotopy equivalence (def. 32) precisely if the adjunct fÀú:X‚Üík(Y)\tilde f \colon X \to k(Y) is a weak homotopy equivalence. But, by lemma 23, fÀú\tilde f is the same function as ff, just considered with different codomain. Hence the result follows with prop. 39.

\,

Compactly generated weakly Hausdorff topological spaces

While the inclusion Top cg‚Ü™TopTop_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top of def. 88 does satisfy the requirement that it gives a cartesian closed category with all limits and colimits and containing all CW-complexes, one may ask for yet smaller subcategories that still share all these properties but potentially exhibit further convenient properties still.

A popular choice introduced in (McCord 69) is to add the further restriction to topopological spaces which are not only compactly generated but also weakly Hausdorff. This was motivated from (Steenrod 67) where compactly generated Hausdorff spaces were used by the observation ((McCord 69, section 2)) that Hausdorffness is not preserved my many colimit operations, notably not by forming quotient spaces.

On the other hand, in above we wouldn‚Äôt have imposed Hausdorffness in the first place. More intrinsic advantages of Top cgwHTop_{cgwH} over Top cgTop_{cg} are the following:

  • every pushout of a morphism in Top cgwH‚Ü™TopTop_{cgwH} \hookrightarrow Top along a closed subspace inclusion in TopTop is again in Top cgwHTop_{cgwH}

  • in Top cgwHTop_{cgwH} quotient spaces are not only preserved by cartesian products (as is the case for all compactly generated spaces due to X√ó(‚àí)X\times (-) being a left adjoint, according to cor. 4) but by all pullbacks

  • in Top cgwHTop_{cgwH} the regular monomorphisms are the closed subspace inclusions

We will not need this here or in the following sections, but we briefly mention it for completenes:

Definition

A topological space XX is called weakly Hausdorff if for every continuous function

f:K‚ü∂X f \;\colon\; K \longrightarrow X

out of a compact Hausdorff space KK, its image f(K)‚äÇXf(K) \subset X is a closed subset of XX.

Proposition

Every Hausdorff space is a weakly Hausdorff space, def. 52.

Proof

Since compact subspaces of Hausdorff spaces are closed.

Proposition

For XX a weakly Hausdorff topological space, def. 52, then a subset A‚äÇXA \subset X is kk-closed, def. 88, precisely if for every subset K‚äÇXK \subset X that is compact Hausdorff with respect to the subspace topology, then the intersection K‚à©AK \cap A is a closed subset of XX.

e.g. (Strickland 09, lemma 1.4 (c))

Topological enrichment

So far the classical model structure on topological spaces which we established in theorem 2, as well as the projective model structures on topologically enriched functors induced from it in theorem 5, concern the hom-sets, but not the hom-spaces (def. 55), i.e. the model structure so far has not been related to the topology on hom-spaces. The following statements say that in fact the model structure and the enrichment by topology on the hom-spaces are compatible in a suitable sense: we have an ‚Äúenriched model category‚Äù. This implies in particular that the product/hom-adjunctions are Quillen adjunctions, which is crucial for a decent discusson of the derived functors of the suspension/looping adjunction below.

Definition

Let i 1:X 1‚ÜíY 1i_1 \colon X_1 \to Y_1 and i 2:X 2‚ÜíY 2i_2 \colon X_2 \to Y_2 be morphisms in Top cgTop_{cg}, def. 88. Their pushout product

i 1‚ñ°i 2‚âî((id,i 2),(i 1,id)) i_1\Box i_2 \coloneqq ((id, i_2), (i_1,id))

is the universal morphism in the following diagram

X 1√óX 2 (i 1,id)‚Üô ‚Üò (id,i 2) Y 1√óX 2 (po) X 1√óY 2 ‚Üò ‚Üô (Y 1√óX 2)‚äîX 1√óX 2(X 1√óY 2) ‚Üì ((id,i 2),(i 1,id)) Y 1√óY 2 \array{ && X_1 \times X_2 \\ & {}^{\mathllap{(i_1,id)}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{(id,i_2)}} \\ Y_1 \times X_2 && (po) && X_1 \times Y_2 \\ & {}_{\mathllap{}}\searrow && \swarrow \\ && (Y_1 \times X_2) \underset{X_1 \times X_2}{\sqcup} (X_1 \times Y_2) \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{((id, i_2), (i_1,id))}} \\ && Y_1 \times Y_2 }
Example

If i 1:X 1‚Ü™Y 1i_1 \colon X_1 \hookrightarrow Y_1 and i 2:X 2‚Ü™Y 2i_2 \colon X_2 \hookrightarrow Y_2 are inclusions, then their pushout product i 1‚ñ°i 2i_1 \Box i_2 from def. 53 is the inclusion

(X 1√óY 2‚à™Y 1√óX 2)‚Ü™Y 1√óY 2. \left( X_1 \times Y_2 \;\cup\; Y_1 \times X_2 \right) \hookrightarrow Y_1 \times Y_2 \,.

For instance

({0}‚Ü™I)‚ñ°({0}‚Ü™I) \left( \{0\} \hookrightarrow I \right) \Box \left( \{0\} \hookrightarrow I \right)

is the inclusion of two adjacent edges of a square into the square.

Example

The pushout product with an initial morphism is just the ordinary Cartesian product functor

(‚àÖ‚ÜíX)‚ñ°(‚àí)‚âÉX√ó(‚àí), (\emptyset \to X) \Box (-) \simeq X \times (-) \,,

i.e.

(‚àÖ‚ÜíX)‚ñ°(A‚ÜífB)‚âÉ(X√óA‚ü∂X√ófX√óB). (\emptyset \to X) \Box (A \overset{f}{\to} B) \simeq (X\times A \overset{X \times f}{\longrightarrow} X \times B ) \,.
Proof

The product topological space with the empty space is the empty space, hence the map ‚àÖ√óA‚ü∂(id,f)‚àÖ√óB\emptyset \times A \overset{(id,f)}{\longrightarrow} \emptyset \times B is an isomorphism, and so the pushout in the pushout product is X√óAX \times A. From this one reads off the universal map in question to be X√ófX \times f:

‚àÖ√óA ‚Üô ‚Üò ‚âÉ X√óA (po) ‚àÖ√óB ‚âÉ‚Üò ‚Üô X√óA ‚Üì ((id,f),‚àÉ!) X√óB. \array{ && \emptyset \times A \\ & {}^{\mathllap{}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}} \\ X \times A && (po) && \emptyset \times B \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\simeq}}\searrow && \swarrow \\ && X \times A \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{((id, f), \exists !)}} \\ && X \times B } \,.
Example

With

I Top:{S n‚àí1‚Ü™i nD n}andJ Top:{D n‚Ü™j nD n√óI} I_{Top} \colon \{ S^{n-1} \overset{i_n}{\hookrightarrow} D^n\} \;\;\; and \;\;\; J_{Top} \colon \{ D^n \overset{j_n}{\hookrightarrow} D^n \times I\}

the generating cofibrations (def. 35) and generating acyclic cofibrations (def. 38) of (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} (theorem 4), then their pushout-products (def. 53) are

i n 1‚ñ°i n 2 ‚âÉi n 1+n 2 i n 1‚ñ°j n 2 ‚âÉj n 1+n 2. \begin{aligned} i_{n_1} \Box i_{n_2} & \simeq i_{n_1 + n_2} \\ i_{n_1} \Box j_{n_2} & \simeq j_{n_1 + n_2} \end{aligned} \,.
Proof

To see this, it is profitable to model n-disks and n-spheres, up to homeomorphism, as nn-cubes D n‚âÉ[0,1] n‚äÇ‚Ñù nD^\n \simeq [0,1]^n \subset \mathbb{R}^n and their boundaries S n‚àí1‚âÉ‚àÇ[0,1] nS^{n-1} \simeq \partial [0,1]^n . For the idea of the proof, consider the situation in low dimensions, where one readily sees pictorially that

i 1‚ñ°i 1:(=‚à™||)‚Ü™‚ñ° i_1 \Box i_1 \;\colon\; \left(\;\; = \;\;\cup\;\; \vert\vert\;\;\right) \hookrightarrow \Box

and

i 1‚ñ°j 0:(=‚à™|)‚Ü™‚ñ°. i_1 \Box j_0 \;\colon\; \left(\;\; = \;\;\cup\;\; \vert \;\; \right) \hookrightarrow \Box \,.

Generally, D nD^n may be represented as the space of nn-tuples of elements in [0,1][0,1], and S nS^n as the suspace of tuples for which at least one of the coordinates is equal to 0 or to 1.

Accordingly, S n 1√óD n 2‚Ü™D n 1+n 2S^{n_1} \times D^{n_2} \hookrightarrow D^{n_1 + n_2} is the subspace of (n 1+n 2)(n_1+n_2)-tuples, such that at least one of the first n 1n_1 coordinates is equal to 0 or 1, while D n 1√óS n 2‚Ü™D n 1+n 2D^{n_1} \times S^{n_2} \hookrightarrow D^{n_1+ n_2} is the subspace of (n 1+n 2)(n_1 + n_2)-tuples such that east least one of the last n 2n_2 coordinates is equal to 0 or to 1. Therefore

S n 1√óD n 2‚à™D n 1√óS n 2‚âÉS n 1+n 2. S^{n_1} \times D^{n_2} \cup D^{n_1} \times S^{n_2} \simeq S^{n_1 + n_2} \,.

And of course it is clear that D n 1√óD n 2‚âÉD n 1+n 2D^{n_1} \times D^{n_2} \simeq D^{n_1 + n_2}. This shows the first case.

For the second, use that S n 1√óD n 2√óIS^{n_1} \times D^{n_2} \times I is contractible to S n 1√óD n 2S^{n_1} \times D^{n_2} in D n 1√óD n 2√óID^{n_1} \times D^{n_2} \times I, and that S n 1√óD n 2S^{n_1} \times D^{n_2} is a subspace of D n 1√óD n 2D^{n_1} \times D^{n_2}.

Definition

Let i:A‚ÜíBi \colon A \to B and p:X‚ÜíYp \colon X \to Y be two morphisms in Top cgTop_{cg}, def. 88. Their pullback powering is

p ‚ñ°i‚âî(p B,X i) p^{\Box i} \coloneqq (p^B, X^i)

being the universal morphism in

X B ‚Üì (p B,X i) Y B√óY AX A ‚Üô ‚Üò Y B (pb) X A Y i‚Üò ‚Üô p A Y A \array{ && X^B \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(p^B, X^i)}} \\ && Y^B \underset{Y^A}{\times} X^A \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ Y^B && (pb) && X^A \\ & {}_{\mathllap{Y^i}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{p^A}} \\ && Y^A }
Proposition

Let i 1,i 2,pi_1, i_2 , p be three morphisms in Top cgTop_{cg}, def. 88. Then for their pushout-products (def. 53) and pullback-powerings (def. 54) the following lifting properties are equivalent (‚ÄúJoyal-Tierney calculus‚Äù):

i 1‚ñ°i 2 has LLP against p ‚áî i 1 has LLP against p ‚ñ°i 2 ‚áî i 2 has LLP against p ‚ñ°i 1. \array{ & i_1 \Box i_2 & \text{has LLP against} & p \\ \Leftrightarrow & i_1 & \text{has LLP against} & p^{\Box i_2} \\ \Leftrightarrow & i_2 & \text{has LLP against} & p^{\Box i_1} } \,.
Proof

We claim that by the cartesian closure of Top cgTop_{cg}, and carefully collecting terms, one finds a natural bijection between commuting squares and their lifts as follows:

Q ‚ü∂f X B i 1‚Üì ‚Üì p ‚ñ°i 2 P ‚ü∂(g 1,g 2) Y B√óY AX A‚ÜîQ√óB‚äîQ√óAP√óA ‚ü∂(fÀú,gÀú 2) X i 1‚ñ°i 2‚Üì ‚Üì p P√óB ‚ü∂gÀú 1 Y, \array{ Q &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& X^B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p^{\Box i_2}}} \\ P &\underset{(g_1,g_2)}{\longrightarrow}& Y^B \underset{Y^A}{\times} X^A } \;\;\;\;\;\;\; \leftrightarrow \;\;\;\;\;\;\; \array{ Q \times B \underset{Q \times A}{\sqcup} P \times A &\overset{(\tilde f, \tilde g_2)}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1 \Box i_2}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ P \times B & \underset{\tilde g_1}{\longrightarrow} & Y } \,,

where the tilde denotes product/hom-adjuncts, for instance

P‚ü∂g 1Y BP√óB‚ü∂gÀú 1Y \frac{ P \overset{g_1}{\longrightarrow} Y^B }{ P \times B \overset{\tilde g_1}{\longrightarrow} Y }

etc.

To see this in more detail, observe that both squares above each represent two squares from the two components into the fiber product and out of the pushout, respectively, as well as one more square exhibiting the compatibility condition on these components:

Q ‚ü∂f X B i 1‚Üì ‚Üì p ‚ñ°i 2 P ‚ü∂(g 1,g 2) Y B√óY AX A ‚âÉ {Q ‚ü∂f X B i 1‚Üì ‚Üì p B P ‚ü∂g 1 Y B,Q ‚ü∂f X B i 1‚Üì ‚Üì X i 2 P ‚ü∂g 1 X A,P ‚ü∂g 2 X A g 1‚Üì ‚Üì p A Y B ‚ü∂Y i 2 Y A} ‚Üî {Q√óB ‚ü∂fÀú X (i 1,id)‚Üì ‚Üì p P√óB ‚ü∂gÀú 2 Y,Q√óA ‚ü∂(id,i 2) Q√óB (i 1,id)‚Üì ‚Üì fÀú P√óA ‚ü∂gÀú 2 X,P√óA ‚ü∂gÀú 2 X (id,i 2)‚Üì ‚Üì p P√óB ‚ü∂gÀú 1 Y} ‚âÉ Q√óB‚äîQ√óAP√óA ‚ü∂(fÀú,gÀú 2) X i 1‚ñ°i 2‚Üì ‚Üì p P√óB ‚ü∂gÀú 1 Y. \begin{aligned} & \;\;\;\; \array{ Q &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& X^B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p^{\Box i_2}}} \\ P &\underset{(g_1,g_2)}{\longrightarrow}& Y^B \underset{Y^A}{\times} X^A } \\ \simeq & \;\;\;\; \left\{ \;\;\;\; \array{ Q &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& X^B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p^B}} \\ P &\underset{g_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y^B } \;\;\;\;\; \,, \;\;\;\;\; \array{ Q &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& X^B \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{X^{i_2}}} \\ P &\underset{g_1}{\longrightarrow}& X^A } \;\;\;\;\; \,, \;\;\;\;\; \array{ P &\overset{g_2}{\longrightarrow}& X^A \\ {}^{\mathllap{g_1}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p^A}} \\ Y^B &\underset{Y^{i_2}}{\longrightarrow}& Y^A } \;\;\;\;\; \right\} \\ \leftrightarrow & \;\;\;\; \left\{ \;\;\;\;\; \array{ Q \times B &\overset{\tilde f}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(i_1,id)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ P \times B &\underset{\tilde g_2}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \;\;\;\;\; \,, \;\;\;\;\; \array{ Q \times A &\overset{(id,i_2)}{\longrightarrow}& Q \times B \\ {}^{\mathllap{(i_1,id)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\tilde f}} \\ P \times A &\underset{\tilde g_2}{\longrightarrow}& X } \;\;\;\;\; \,, \;\;\;\;\; \array{ P \times A &\overset{\tilde g_2}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id,i_2)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ P \times B &\underset{\tilde g_1}{\longrightarrow}& Y } \;\;\;\;\; \right\} \\ \simeq & \;\;\;\; \array{ Q \times B \underset{Q \times A}{\sqcup} P \times A &\overset{(\tilde f, \tilde g_2)}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ {}^{\mathllap{i_1 \Box i_2}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p}} \\ P \times B & \underset{\tilde g_1}{\longrightarrow} & Y } \end{aligned} \,.
Proposition

The pushout-product in Top cgTop_{cg} (def. 88) of two classical cofibrations is a classical cofibration:

Cof cl‚ñ°Cof cl‚äÇCof cl. Cof_{cl} \Box Cof_{cl} \subset Cof_{cl} \,.

If one of them is acyclic, then so is the pushout-product:

Cof cl‚ñ°(W cl‚à©Cof cl)‚äÇW cl‚à©Cof cl. Cof_{cl} \Box (W_{cl} \cap Cof_{cl}) \subset W_{cl}\cap Cof_{cl} \,.
Proof

Regarding the first point:

By example 41 we have

I Top‚ñ°I Top‚äÇI Top I_{Top} \Box I_{Top} \subset I_{Top}

Hence

I Top‚ñ°I Top has LLP against W cl‚à©Fib cl ‚áî I Top has LLP against (W cl‚à©Fib cl) ‚ñ°I Top ‚áí Cof cl has LLP against (W cl‚à©Fib cl) ‚ñ°I Top ‚áî I Top‚ñ°Cof cl has LLP against W cl‚à©Fib cl ‚áî I Top has LLP against (W cl‚à©Fib cl) Cof cl ‚áí Cof cl has LLP against (W cl‚à©Fib cl) Cof cl ‚áî Cof cl‚ñ°Cof cl has LLP against W cl‚à©Fib cl, \array{ & I_{Top} \Box I_{Top} & \text{has LLP against} & W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl} \\ \Leftrightarrow & I_{Top} & \text{has LLP against} & (W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl})^{\Box I_{Top}} \\ \Rightarrow & Cof_{cl} & \text{has LLP against} & (W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl})^{\Box I_{Top}} \\ \Leftrightarrow & I_{Top} \Box Cof_{cl} & \text{has LLP against} & W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl} \\ \Leftrightarrow & I_{Top} & \text{has LLP against} & (W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl})^{Cof_{cl}} \\ \Rightarrow & Cof_{cl} & \text{has LLP against} & (W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl})^{Cof_{cl}} \\ \Leftrightarrow & Cof_{cl} \Box \Cof_{cl} & \text{has LLP against} & W_{cl} \cap Fib_{cl} } \,,

where all logical equivalences used are those of prop. 42 and where all implications appearing are by the closure property of lifting problems, prop. 1.

Regarding the second point: By example 41 we moreover have

I Top‚ñ°J Top‚äÇJ Top I_{Top} \Box J_{Top} \subset J_{Top}

and the conclusion follows by the same kind of reasoning.

Remark

In model category theory the property in proposition 43 is referred to as saying that the model category (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} from theorem \ref{ModelStructureOnTopcg}

  1. is a monoidal model category with respect to the Cartesian product on Top cgTop_{cg};

  2. is an enriched model category, over itself.

A key point of what this entails is the following:

Proposition

For X‚àà(Top cg) QuillenX \in (Top_{cg})_{Quillen} cofibrant (a retract of a cell complex) then the product-hom-adjunction for YY (prop. 37) is a Quillen adjunction

(Top cg) Quillen‚ä•‚ü∂(‚àí) X‚üµX√ó(‚àí)(Top cg) Quillen. (Top_{cg})_{Quillen} \underoverset \underset{(-)^X}{\longrightarrow} \overset{X \times (-)}{\longleftarrow} {\bot} (Top_{cg})_{Quillen} \,.
Proof

By example 40 we have that the left adjoint functor is equivalently the pushout product functor with the initial morphism of XX:

X√ó(‚àí)‚âÉ(‚àÖ‚ÜíX)‚ñ°(‚àí). X \times (-) \simeq (\emptyset \to X) \Box (-) \,.

By assumption (‚àÖ‚ÜíX)(\emptyset \to X) is a cofibration, and hence prop. 43 says that this is a left Quillen functor.

The statement and proof of prop. 44 has a direct analogue in pointed topological spaces

Proposition

For X‚àà(Top cg */) QuillenX \in (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen} cofibrant with respect to the classical model structure on pointed compactly generated topological spaces (theorem 4, prop. 36) (hence a retract of a cell complex with non-degenerate basepoint, remark 27) then the pointed product-hom-adjunction from corollary 5 is a Quillen adjunction (def. 16):

(Top cg */) Quillen‚ä•‚ü∂Maps(X,‚àí) *‚üµX‚àß(‚àí)(Top cg */) Quillen. (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen} \underoverset \underset{Maps(X,-)_\ast}{\longrightarrow} \overset{X \wedge (-)}{\longleftarrow} {\bot} (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen} \,.
Proof

Let now ‚ñ° ‚àß\Box_\wedge denote the smash pushout product and (‚àí) ‚ñ°(‚àí)(-)^{\Box(-)} the smash pullback powering defined as in def. 53 and def. 54, but with Cartesian product replaced by smash product (def. 46) and compactly generated mapping space replaced by pointed mapping spaces (def. 32).

By theorem 3 (Top cg */) Quillen(Top_{cg}^{\ast/})_{Quillen} is cofibrantly generated by I Top */=(I Top) +I_{Top^{\ast/}} = (I_{Top})_+ and J Top */=(J Top) +J_{Top^{\ast/}}= (J_{Top})_+. Example 30 gives that for i n‚ààI Topi_n \in I_{Top} and j n‚ààJ Topj_n \in J_{Top} then

(i n 1) +‚ñ° ‚àß(i n 2) +‚âÉ(i n 1+n 2) + (i_{n_1})_+ \Box_\wedge (i_{n_2})_+ \simeq (i_{n_1 + n_2})_+

and

(i n 1) +‚àß ‚àß(i n 2) +‚âÉ(i n 1+n 2) +. (i_{n_1})_+ \wedge_\wedge (i_{n_2})_+ \simeq (i_{n_1 + n_2})_+ \,.

Hence the pointed analog of prop. 43 holds and therefore so does the pointed analog of the conclusion in prop. 44.

Model structure on topological functors

With classical topological homotopy theory in hand (theorem 2, theorem 4), it is straightforward now to generalize this to a homotopy theory of topological diagrams. This is going to be the basis for the stable homotopy theory of spectra, because spectra may be identified with certain topological diagrams (prop.).

Technically, ‚Äútopological diagram‚Äù here means ‚ÄúTop-enriched functor‚Äù. We now discuss what this means and then observe that as an immediate corollary of theorem 2 we obtain a model category structure on topological diagrams.

As a by-product, we obtain the model category theory of homotopy colimits in topological spaces, which will be useful.

In the following we say Top-enriched category and Top-enriched functor etc. for what often is referred to as ‚Äútopological category‚Äù and ‚Äútopological functor‚Äù etc. As discussed there, these latter terms are ambiguous.

Literature (Riehl, chapter 3) for basics of enriched category theory; (Piacenza 91) for the projective model structure on topological functors.

\,

Definition

A topologically enriched category ùíû\mathcal{C} is a Top cgTop_{cg}-enriched category, hence:

  1. a class Obj(ùíû)Obj(\mathcal{C}), called the class of objects;

  2. for each a,b‚ààObj(ùíû)a, b\in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a compactly generated topological space (def. 88)

    ùíû(a,b)‚ààTop cg, \mathcal{C}(a,b)\in Top_{cg} \,,

    called the space of morphisms or the hom-space between aa and bb;

  3. for each a,b,c‚ààObj(ùíû)a,b,c\in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a continuous function

    ‚àò a,b,c:ùíû(a,b)√óùíû(b,c)‚ü∂ùíû(a,c) \circ_{a,b,c} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(a,b)\times \mathcal{C}(b,c) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}(a,c)

    out of the cartesian product (by cor. 4: the image under kk of the product topological space), called the composition operation;

  4. for each a‚ààObj(ùíû)a \in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a point Id a‚ààùíû(a,a)Id_a\in \mathcal{C}(a,a), called the identity morphism on aa

such that the composition is associative and unital.

Similarly a pointed topologically enriched category is such a structure with Top cgTop_{cg} replaced by Top cg */Top^{\ast/}_{cg} (def. 44) and with the Cartesian product replaced by the smash product (def. 46) of pointed topological spaces.

Remark

Given a (pointed) topologically enriched category as in def. 55, then forgetting the topology on the hom-spaces (along the forgetful functor U:Top cg‚ÜíSetU \colon Top_{cg} \to Set) yields an ordinary locally small category with

Hom ùíû(a,b)=U(ùíû(a,b)). Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(a,b) = U(\mathcal{C}(a,b)) \,.

It is in this sense that ùíû\mathcal{C} is a category with extra structure, and hence ‚Äúenriched‚Äù.

The archetypical example is Top cgTop_{cg} itself:

Example

The category Top cgTop_{cg} (def. 88) canonically obtains the structure of a topologically enriched category, def. 55, with hom-spaces given by the compactly generated mapping spaces (def. 51)

Top cg(X,Y)‚âîY X Top_{cg}(X,Y) \coloneqq Y^X

and with composition

Y X√óZ Y‚ü∂Z X Y^X \times Z^Y \longrightarrow Z^X

given by the adjunct under the (product‚ä£\dashv mapping-space)-adjunction from prop. 37 of the evaluation morphisms

X√óY X√óZ Y‚ü∂(ev,id)Y√óZ Y‚ü∂evZ. X \times Y^X \times Z^Y \overset{(ev, id)}{\longrightarrow} Y \times Z^Y \overset{ev}{\longrightarrow} Z \,.

Similarly, pointed compactly generated topological spaces Top k */Top_k^{\ast/} form a pointed topologically enriched category, using the pointed mapping spaces from example 32:

Top cg */(X,Y)‚âîMaps(X,Y) *. Top^{\ast/}_{cg}(X,Y) \coloneqq Maps(X,Y)_\ast \,.
Definition

A topologically enriched functor between two topologically enriched categories

F:ùíû‚ü∂ùíü F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

is a Top cgTop_{cg}-enriched functor, hence:

  1. a function

    F 0:Obj(ùíû)‚ü∂Obj(ùíü) F_0 \;\colon\; Obj(\mathcal{C}) \longrightarrow Obj(\mathcal{D})

    of objects;

  2. for each a,b‚ààObj(ùíû)a,b \in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a continuous function

    F a,b:ùíû(a,b)‚ü∂ùíü(F 0(a),F 0(b)) F_{a,b} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(a,b) \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}(F_0(a), F_0(b))

    of hom-spaces,

such that this preserves composition and identity morphisms in the evident sense.

A homomorphism of topologically enriched functors

Œ∑:F‚áíG \eta \;\colon\; F \Rightarrow G

is a Top cgTop_{cg}-enriched natural transformation: for each c‚ààObj(ùíû)c \in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a choice of morphism Œ∑ c‚ààùíü(F(c),G(c))\eta_c \in \mathcal{D}(F(c),G(c)) such that for each pair of objects c,d‚ààùíûc,d \in \mathcal{C} the two continuous functions

Œ∑ d‚àòF(‚àí):ùíû(c,d)‚ü∂ùíü(F(c),G(d)) \eta_d \circ F(-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}(F(c), G(d))

and

G(‚àí)‚àòŒ∑ c:ùíû(c,d)‚ü∂ùíü(F(c),G(d)) G(-) \circ \eta_c \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}(F(c), G(d))

agree.

We write [ùíû,ùíü][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] for the resulting category of topologically enriched functors.

Remark

The condition on an enriched natural transformation in def. 56 is just that on an ordinary natural transformation on the underlying unenriched functors, saying that for every morphisms f:c‚Üídf \colon c \to d there is a commuting square

f‚Ü¶ùíû(c,c)√óX ‚ü∂Œ∑ c F(c) ùíû(c,f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(f) ùíû(c,d)√óX ‚ü∂Œ∑ d F(d). f \;\;\;\; \mapsto \;\;\;\; \array{ \mathcal{C}(c,c) \times X &\overset{\eta_c}{\longrightarrow}& F(c) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\mathcal{C}(c,f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(f)}} \\ \mathcal{C}(c,d) \times X &\underset{\eta_d}{\longrightarrow}& F(d) } \,.
Example

For ùíû\mathcal{C} any topologically enriched category, def. 55 then a topologically enriched functor (def. 56)

F:ùíû‚ü∂Top cg F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Top_{cg}

to the archetypical topologically enriched category from example 42 may be thought of as a topologically enriched copresheaf, at least if ùíû\mathcal{C} is small (in that its class of objects is a proper set).

Hence the category of topologically enriched functors

[ùíû,Top cg] [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}]

according to def. 56 may be thought of as the (co-)presheaf category over ùíû\mathcal{C} in the realm of topological enriched categories.

A functor F‚àà[ùíû,Top cg]F \in [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] is equivalently

  1. a compactly generated topological space F a‚ààTop cgF_a \in Top_{cg} for each object a‚ààObj(ùíû)a \in Obj(\mathcal{C});

  2. a continuous function

    F a√óùíû(a,b)‚ü∂F b F_a \times \mathcal{C}(a,b) \longrightarrow F_b

    for all pairs of objects a,b‚ààObj(ùíû)a,b \in Obj(\mathcal{C})

such that composition is respected, in the evident sense.

For every object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C}, there is a topologically enriched representable functor, denoted y(c)y(c) or ùíû(c,‚àí)\mathcal{C}(c,-) which sends objects to

y(c)(d)=ùíû(c,d)‚ààTop cg y(c)(d) = \mathcal{C}(c,d) \in Top_{cg}

and whose action on morphisms is, under the above identification, just the composition operation in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Proposition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} any small topologically enriched category, def. 55 then the enriched functor category [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] from example 43 has all limits and colimits, and they are computed objectwise:

if

F ‚Ä¢:I‚ü∂[ùíû,Top cg] F_\bullet \;\colon\; I \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}]

is a diagram of functors and c‚ààùíûc\in \mathcal{C} is any object, then

(lim‚üµ iF i)(c)‚âÉlim‚üµ i(F i(c))‚ààTop cg (\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i F_i)(c) \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i (F_i(c)) \;\;\in Top_{cg}

and

(lim‚ü∂ iF i)(c)‚âÉlim‚ü∂ i(F i(c))‚ààTop cg. (\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i F_i)(c) \simeq \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i (F_i(c)) \;\; \in Top_{cg} \,.
Proof

First consider the underlying diagram of functors F i ‚àòF_i^\circ where the topology on the hom-spaces of ùíû\mathcal{C} and of Top cgTop_{cg} has been forgotten. Then one finds

(lim‚üµ iF i ‚àò)(c)‚âÉlim‚üµ i(F i ‚àò(c))‚ààSet (\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i F^\circ_i)(c) \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i (F^\circ_i(c)) \;\;\in Set

and

(lim‚ü∂ iF i ‚àò)(c)‚âÉlim‚ü∂ i(F i ‚àò(c))‚ààSet (\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i F^\circ _i)(c) \simeq \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i (F^\circ_i(c)) \;\; \in Set

by the universal property of limits and colimits. (Given a morphism of diagrams then a unique compatible morphism between their limits or colimits, respectively, is induced as the universal factorization of the morphism of diagrams regarded as a cone or cocone, respectvely, over the codomain or domain diagram, respectively).

Hence it only remains to see that equipped with topology, these limits and colimits in SetSet become limits and colimits in Top cgTop_{cg}. That is just the statement of prop. 26 with corollary 4.

Definition

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a topologically enriched category, def. 55, with [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] its category of topologically enriched copresheaves from example 43.

  1. Define a functor

    (‚àí)‚ãÖ(‚àí):[ùíû,Top cg]√óTop cg‚ü∂[ùíû,Top cg] (-)\cdot(-) \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] \times Top_{cg} \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}]

    by forming objectwise cartesian products (hence kk of product topological spaces)

    F‚ãÖX:c‚Ü¶F(c)√óX. F \cdot X \;\colon\; c \mapsto F(c) \times X \,.

    This is called the tensoring of [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C},Top_{cg}] over Top cgTop_{cg}.

  2. Define a functor

    (‚àí) (‚àí):(Top cg) op√ó[ùíû,Top cg]‚ü∂[ùíû,Top cg] (-)^{(-)} \;\colon\; (Top_{cg})^{op} \times [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}]

    by forming objectwise compactly generated mapping spaces (def. 51)

    F X:c‚Ü¶F(c) X. F^X \;\colon\; c \mapsto F(c)^X \,.

    This is called the powering of [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] over Top cgTop_{cg}.

Analogously, for ùíû\mathcal{C} a pointed topologically enriched category, def. 55, with [ùíû,Top cg */][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}^{\ast/}] its category of pointed topologically enriched copresheaves from example 43, then:

  1. Define a functor

    (‚àí)‚àß(‚àí):[ùíû,Top cg */]√óTop cg */‚ü∂[ùíû,Top cg */] (-)\wedge(-) \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, Top^{\ast/}_{cg}] \times Top^{\ast/}_{cg} \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, Top^{\ast/}_{cg}]

    by forming objectwise smash products (def. 46)

    F‚àßX:c‚Ü¶F(c)‚àßX. F \wedge X \;\colon\; c \mapsto F(c) \wedge X \,.

    This is called the smash tensoring of [ùíû,Top cg */][\mathcal{C},Top^{\ast/}_{cg}] over Top cg */Top^{\ast/}_{cg}.

  2. Define a functor

    Maps(‚àí,‚àí) *:Top cg */√ó[ùíû,Top cg */]‚ü∂[ùíû,Top cg */] Maps(-,-)_\ast \;\colon\; Top^{\ast/}_{cg} \times [\mathcal{C}, Top^{\ast/}_{cg}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, Top^{\ast/}_{cg}]

    by forming objectwise pointed mapping spaces (example 32)

    F X:c‚Ü¶Maps(X,F(c)) *. F^X \;\colon\; c \mapsto Maps(X,F(c))_\ast \,.

    This is called the pointed powering of [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] over Top cgTop_{cg}.

There is a full blown Top cgTop_{cg}-enriched Yoneda lemma. The following records a slightly simplified version which is all that is needed here:

Proposition

(topologically enriched Yoneda-lemma)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a topologically enriched category, def. 55, write [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] for its category of topologically enriched (co-)presheaves, and for c‚ààObj(ùíû)c\in Obj(\mathcal{C}) write y(c)=ùíû(c,‚àí)‚àà[ùíû,Top k]y(c) = \mathcal{C}(c,-) \in [\mathcal{C}, Top_k] for the topologically enriched functor that it represents, all according to example 43. Recall the tensoring operation (F,X)‚Ü¶F‚ãÖX(F,X) \mapsto F \cdot X from def. 57.

For c‚ààObj(ùíû)c\in Obj(\mathcal{C}), X‚ààTop cgX \in Top_{cg} and F‚àà[ùíû,Top cg]F \in [\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}], there is a natural bijection between

  1. morphisms y(c)‚ãÖX‚ü∂Fy(c) \cdot X \longrightarrow F in [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}];

  2. morphisms X‚ü∂F(c)X \longrightarrow F(c) in Top cgTop_{cg}.

In short:

y(c)‚ãÖX‚ü∂FX‚ü∂F(c) \frac{ y(c)\cdot X \longrightarrow F }{ X \longrightarrow F(c) }
Proof

Given a morphism Œ∑:y(c)‚ãÖX‚ü∂F\eta \colon y(c) \cdot X \longrightarrow F consider its component

Œ∑ c:ùíû(c,c)√óX‚ü∂F(c) \eta_c \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,c)\times X \longrightarrow F(c)

and restrict that to the identity morphism id c‚ààùíû(c,c)id_c \in \mathcal{C}(c,c) in the first argument

Œ∑ c(id c,‚àí):X‚ü∂F(c). \eta_c(id_c,-) \;\colon\; X \longrightarrow F(c) \,.

We claim that just this Œ∑ c(id c,‚àí)\eta_c(id_c,-) already uniquely determines all components

Œ∑ d:ùíû(c,d)√óX‚ü∂F(d) \eta_d \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d)\times X \longrightarrow F(d)

of Œ∑\eta, for all d‚ààObj(ùíû)d \in Obj(\mathcal{C}): By definition of the transformation Œ∑\eta (def. 56), the two functions

F(‚àí)‚àòŒ∑ c:ùíû(c,d)‚ü∂F(d) ùíû(c,c)√óX F(-) \circ \eta_c \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \longrightarrow F(d)^{\mathcal{C}(c,c) \times X}

and

Œ∑ d‚àòùíû(c,‚àí)√óX:ùíû(c,d)‚ü∂F(d) ùíû(c,c)√óX \eta_d \circ \mathcal{C}(c,-) \times X \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \longrightarrow F(d)^{\mathcal{C}(c,c) \times X}

agree. This means (remark 32) that they may be thought of jointly as a function with values in commuting squares in Top cgTop_{cg} of this form:

f‚Ü¶ùíû(c,c)√óX ‚ü∂Œ∑ c F(c) ùíû(c,f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(f) ùíû(c,d)√óX ‚ü∂Œ∑ d F(d) f \;\;\;\; \mapsto \;\;\;\; \array{ \mathcal{C}(c,c) \times X &\overset{\eta_c}{\longrightarrow}& F(c) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\mathcal{C}(c,f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(f)}} \\ \mathcal{C}(c,d) \times X &\underset{\eta_d}{\longrightarrow}& F(d) }

For any f‚ààùíû(c,d)f \in \mathcal{C}(c,d), consider the restriction of

Œ∑ d‚àòùíû(c,f)‚ààF(d) ùíû(c,c)√óX \eta_d \circ \mathcal{C}(c,f) \in F(d)^{\mathcal{C}(c,c) \times X}

to id c‚ààùíû(c,c)id_c \in \mathcal{C}(c,c), hence restricting the above commuting squares to

f‚Ü¶{id c}√óX ‚ü∂Œ∑ c F(c) ùíû(c,f)‚Üì ‚Üì F(f) {f}√óX ‚ü∂Œ∑ d F(d) f \;\;\;\; \mapsto \;\;\;\; \array{ \{id_c\} \times X &\overset{\eta_c}{\longrightarrow}& F(c) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\mathcal{C}(c,f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{F(f)}} \\ \{f\} \times X &\underset{\eta_d}{\longrightarrow}& F(d) }

This shows that Œ∑ d\eta_d is fixed to be the function

Œ∑ d(f,x)=F(f)‚àòŒ∑ c(id c,x) \eta_d(f,x) = F(f)\circ \eta_c(id_c,x)

and this is a continuous function since all the operations it is built from are continuous.

Conversely, given a continuous function Œ±:X‚ü∂F(c)\alpha \colon X \longrightarrow F(c), define for each dd the function

Œ∑ d:(f,x)‚Ü¶F(f)‚àòŒ±. \eta_d \colon (f,x) \mapsto F(f) \circ \alpha \,.

Running the above analysis backwards shows that this determines a transformation Œ∑:y(c)√óX‚ÜíF\eta \colon y(c)\times X \to F.

Definition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a small topologically enriched category, def. 55, write

I Top ùíû‚âî{y(c)‚ãÖ(S n‚àí1‚ü∂Œπ nD n)} n‚àà‚Ñï,c‚ààObj(ùíû) I_{Top}^{\mathcal{C}} \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ y(c)\cdot (S^{n-1} \overset{\iota_n}{\longrightarrow} D^n) \right\}_{{n \in \mathbb{N},} \atop {c \in Obj(\mathcal{C})}}

and

J Top ùíû‚âî{y(c)‚ãÖ(D n‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0)D n√óI)} n‚àà‚Ñï,c‚ààObj(ùíû) J_{Top}^{\mathcal{C}} \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ y(c)\cdot (D^n \overset{(id, \delta_0)}{\longrightarrow} D^n \times I) \right\}_{{n \in \mathbb{N},} \atop {c \in Obj(\mathcal{C})}}

for the sets of morphisms given by tensoring (def. 57) the representable functors (example 43) with the generating cofibrations (def.35) and acyclic generating cofibrations (def. 38), respectively, of (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} (theorem 4).

These are going to be called the generating cofibrations and acyclic generating cofibrations for the projective model structure on topologically enriched functors over ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Analgously, for ùíû\mathcal{C} a pointed topologically enriched category, write

I Top */ ùíû‚âî{y(c)‚àß(S + n‚àí1‚ü∂(Œπ n) +D + n)} n‚àà‚Ñï,c‚ààObj(ùíû) I_{Top^{\ast/}}^{\mathcal{C}} \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ y(c) \wedge (S^{n-1}_+ \overset{(\iota_n)_+}{\longrightarrow} D^n_+) \right\}_{{n \in \mathbb{N},} \atop {c \in Obj(\mathcal{C})}}

and

J Top */ ùíû‚âî{y(c)‚àß(D + n‚ü∂(id,Œ¥ 0) +(D n√óI) +)} n‚àà‚Ñï,c‚ààObj(ùíû) J_{Top^{\ast/}}^{\mathcal{C}} \;\coloneqq\; \left\{ y(c) \wedge (D^n_+ \overset{(id, \delta_0)_+}{\longrightarrow} (D^n \times I)_+) \right\}_{{n \in \mathbb{N},} \atop {c \in Obj(\mathcal{C})}}

for the analogous construction applied to the pointed generating (acyclic) cofibrations of def. 48.

Definition

Given a small (pointed) topologically enriched category ùíû\mathcal{C}, def. 55, say that a morphism in the category of (pointed) topologically enriched copresheaves [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] ([ùíû,Top cg */][\mathcal{C},Top_{cg}^{\ast/}]), example 43, hence a natural transformation between topologically enriched functors, Œ∑:F‚ÜíG\eta \colon F \to G is

  • a projective weak equivalence, if for all c‚ààObj(ùíû)c\in Obj(\mathcal{C}) the component Œ∑ c:F(c)‚ÜíG(c)\eta_c \colon F(c) \to G(c) is a weak homotopy equivalence (def. 32);

  • a projective fibration if for all c‚ààObj(ùíû)c\in Obj(\mathcal{C}) the component Œ∑ c:F(c)‚ÜíG(c)\eta_c \colon F(c) \to G(c) is a Serre fibration (def. 76);

  • a projective cofibration if it is a retract (rmk. 3) of an I Top ùíûI_{Top}^{\mathcal{C}}-relative cell complex (def. 37, def. 58).

Write

[ùíû,(Top cg) Quillen] proj [\mathcal{C}, (Top_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj}

and

[ùíû,(Top cg */) Quillen] proj [\mathcal{C}, (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj}

for the categories of topologically enriched functors equipped with these classes of morphisms.

Theorem

The classes of morphisms in def. 59 constitute a model category structure on [ùíû,Top cg][\mathcal{C}, Top_{cg}] and [ùíû,Top cg */][\mathcal{C}, Top^{\ast/}_{cg}], called the projective model structure on enriched functors

[ùíû,(Top cg) Quillen] proj [\mathcal{C}, (Top_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj}

and

[ùíû,(Top cg */) Quillen] proj [\mathcal{C}, (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj}

These are cofibrantly generated model category, def. 89, with set of generating (acyclic) cofibrations the sets I Top ùíûI_{Top}^{\mathcal{C}}, J Top ùíûJ_{Top}^{\mathcal{C}} and I Top */ ùíûI_{Top^{\ast/}}^{\mathcal{C}}, J Top */ ùíûJ_{Top^{\ast/}}^{\mathcal{C}} from def. 58, respectively.

(Piacenza 91, theorem 5.4)

Proof

By prop. 46 the category has all limits and colimits, hence it remains to check the model structure

But via the enriched Yoneda lemma (prop. 47) it follows that proving the model structure reduces objectwise to the proof of theorem 2, theorem 4. In particular, the technical lemmas 15, 18 and 19 generalize immediately to the present situation, with the evident small change of wording:
