For instance, the fact that a morphism of topologically enriched functors Œ∑:F‚ÜíG\eta \colon F \to G that has the right lifting property against the elements of I Top ùíûI_{Top}^{\mathcal{C}} is a projective weak equivalence, follows by noticing that for fixed Œ∑:F‚ÜíG\eta \colon F \to G the enriched Yoneda lemma prop. 47 gives a natural bijection of commuting diagrams (and their fillers) of the form

(y(c)‚ãÖS n‚àí1 ‚ü∂ F (id‚ãÖŒπ n)‚Üì ‚Üì Œ∑ y(c)‚ãÖD n ‚ü∂ G)‚Üî(S n‚àí1 ‚ü∂ F(c) ‚Üì ‚Üì Œ∑ c D n ‚ü∂ G(c)), \left( \array{ y(c) \cdot S^{n-1} &\longrightarrow& F \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id\cdot \iota_n)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}} \\ y(c) \cdot D^n &\longrightarrow& G } \right) \;\;\;\leftrightarrow\;\;\; \left( \array{ S^{n-1} &\longrightarrow& F(c) \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta_c}} \\ D^n &\longrightarrow& G(c) } \right) \,,

and hence the statement follows with part A) of the proof of lemma 19.

With these three lemmas in hand, the remaining formal part of the proof goes through verbatim as above: repeatedly use the small object argument (prop. 4) and the retract argument (prop. 2) to establish the two weak factorization systems. (While again the structure of a category with weak equivalences is evident.)

Example

Given examples 42 and 43, the next evident example of a pointed topologically enriched category besides Top cg */Top^{\ast/}_{cg} itself is the functor category

[Top cg */,Top cg */]. [Top_{cg}^{\ast/}, Top_{cg}^{\ast/}] \,.

The only technical problem with this is that Top cg */Top^{\ast/}_{cg} is not a small category (it has a proper class of objects), which means that the existence of all limits and colimits via prop. 46 may (and does) fail.

But so we just restrict to a small topologically enriched subcategory. A good choice is the full subcategory

Top cg,fin */‚Ü™Top cg */ Top^{\ast/}_{cg,fin} \hookrightarrow Top^{\ast/}_{cg}

of topological spaces homoemorphic to finite CW-complexes. The resulting projective model category (via theorem 5)

[Top cg,fin */,(Top cg */) Quillen] proj [Top_{cg,fin}^{\ast/}\;,\; (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj}

is also also known as the strict model structure for excisive functors. (This terminology is the special case for n=1n = 1 of the terminology ‚Äún-excisive functors‚Äù as used in ‚ÄúGoodwillie calculus‚Äù, a homotopy-theoretic analog of differential calculus.) After enlarging its class of weak equivalences while keeping the cofibrations fixed, this will become Quillen equivalent to a model structure for spectra. This we discuss in part 1.2, in the section on pre-excisive functors.

One consequence of theorem 5 is the model category theoretic incarnation of the theory of homotopy colimits.

Observe that ordinary limits and colimits (def. 23) are equivalently characterized in terms of adjoint functors:

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be any category and let II be a small category. Write [I,ùíû][I,\mathcal{C}] for the corresponding functor category. We may think of its objects as II-shaped diagrams in ùíû\mathcal{C}, and of its morphisms as homomorphisms of these diagrams. There is a canonical functor

const I:ùíû‚ü∂[I,ùíû] const_I \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \overset{}{\longrightarrow} [I,\mathcal{C}]

which sends each object of ùíû\mathcal{C} to the diagram that is constant on this object. Inspection of the definition of the universal properties of limits and colimits on one hand, and of left adjoint and right adjoint functors on the other hand, shows that

  1. precisely when ùíû\mathcal{C} has all colimits of shape II, then the functor const Iconst_I has a left adjoint functor, which is the operation of forming these colimits:

    [I,ùíû]‚ä•‚üµconst I‚ü∂lim‚ü∂ Iùíû [I,\mathcal{C}] \underoverset {\underset{const_I}{\longleftarrow}} {\overset{\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_I}{\longrightarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C}

  2. precisely when ùíû\mathcal{C} has all limits of shape II, then the functor const Iconst_I has a right adjoint functor, which is the operation of forming these limits.

    [I,ùíû]‚ä•‚ü∂lim‚üµ I‚üµconst Iùíû [I,\mathcal{C}] \underoverset {\underset{\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_I}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{const_I}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C}
Proposition

Let II be a small topologically enriched category (def. 55). Then the (lim‚ü∂ I‚ä£const I)(\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_I \dashv const_I)-adjunction

[I,(Top cg) Quillen] proj‚ä•‚üµconst I‚ü∂lim‚ü∂ I(Top cg) Quillen [I,(Top_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj} \underoverset {\underset{const_I}{\longleftarrow}} {\overset{\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_I}{\longrightarrow}} {\bot} (Top_{cg})_{Quillen}

is a Quillen adjunction (def. 16) between the projective model structure on topological functors on II, from theorem 5, and the classical model structure on topological spaces from theorem 4.

Similarly, if II is enriched in pointed topological spaces, then for the classical model structure on pointed topological spaces (prop. 36, theorem 3) the adjunction

[I,(Top cg */) Quillen] proj‚ä•‚üµconst‚ü∂lim‚ü∂(Top cg */) Quillen [I,(Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj} \underoverset {\underset{const}{\longleftarrow}} {\overset{\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}}{\longrightarrow}} {\bot} (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}

is a Quillen adjunction.

Proof

Since the fibrations and weak equivalences in the projective model structure (def. 59) on the functor category are objectwise those of (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} and of (Top cg */) Quillen(Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}, respectively, it is immediate that the functor const Iconst_I preserves these. In particular it preserves fibrations and acyclic fibrations and so the claim follows (prop. 9).

Definition

In the situation of prop. 48 we say that the left derived functor (def. 15) of the colimit functor is the homotopy colimit

hocolim I‚âîùïÉlim‚ü∂ I:Ho([I,Top])‚ü∂Ho(Top) hocolim_I \coloneqq \mathbb{L}\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_I \;\colon\; Ho([I,Top]) \longrightarrow Ho(Top)

and

hocolim I‚âîùïÉlim‚ü∂ I:Ho([I,Top */])‚ü∂Ho(Top */). hocolim_I \coloneqq \mathbb{L}\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_I \;\colon\; Ho([I,Top^{\ast/}]) \longrightarrow Ho(Top^{\ast/}) \,.
Remark

Since every object in (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} and in (Top cg */) Quillen(Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen} is fibrant, the homotopy colimit of any diagram X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet, according to def. 60, is (up to weak homotopy equivalence) the result of forming the ordinary colimit of any projectively cofibrant replacement X^ ‚Ä¢‚Üí‚ààW projX ‚Ä¢\hat X_\bullet \overset{\in W_{proj}}{\to} X_\bullet.

Example

Write ‚Ñï ‚â§\mathbb{N}^{\leq} for the poset (def. 25) of natural numbers, hence for the small category (with at most one morphism from any given object to any other given object) that looks like

‚Ñï ‚â§={0‚Üí1‚Üí2‚Üí3‚Üí‚ãØ}. \mathbb{N}^{\leq} = \left\{ 0 \to 1 \to 2 \to 3 \to \cdots \right\} \,.

Regard this as a topologically enriched category with the, necessarily, discrete topology on its hom-sets.

Then a topologically enriched functor

X ‚Ä¢:‚Ñï ‚â§‚ü∂Top cg X_\bullet \;\colon\; \mathbb{N}^{\leq} \longrightarrow Top_{cg}

is just a plain functor and is equivalently a sequence of continuous functions (morphisms in Top cgTop_{cg}) of the form (also called a cotower)

X 0‚ü∂f 0X 1‚ü∂f 1X 2‚ü∂f 2X 3‚ü∂‚ãØ. X_0 \overset{f_0}{\longrightarrow} X_1 \overset{f_1}{\longrightarrow} X_2 \overset{f_2}{\longrightarrow} X_3 \longrightarrow \cdots \,.

It is immediate to check that those sequences X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet which are cofibrant in the projective model structure (theorem 5) are precisely those for which

  1. all component morphisms f if_i are cofibrations in (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} or (Top cg */) Quillen(Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}, respectively, hence retracts (remark 3) of relative cell complex inclusions (def. 36);

  2. the object X 0X_0, and hence all other objects, are cofibrant, hence are retracts of cell complexes (def. 36).

By example 45 it is immediate that the operation of forming colimits sends projective (acyclic) cofibrations between sequences of topological spaces to (acyclic) cofibrations in the classical model structure on pointed topological spaces. On those projectively cofibrant sequences where every map is not just a retract of a relative cell complex inclusion, but a plain relative cell complex inclusion, more is true:

Proposition

In the projective model structures on cotowers in topological spaces, [‚Ñï ‚â§,(Top cg) Quillen] proj[\mathbb{N}^{\leq}, (Top_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj} and [‚Ñï ‚â§,(Top cg */) Quillen] proj[\mathbb{N}^{\leq}, (Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen}]_{proj} from def. 45, the following holds:

  1. The colimit functor preserves fibrations between sequences of relative cell complex inclusions;

  2. Let II be a finite category, let D ‚Ä¢(‚àí):I‚Üí[‚Ñï ‚â§,Top cg]D_\bullet(-) \colon I \to [\mathbb{N}^{\leq}, Top_{cg}] be a finite diagram of sequences of relative cell complexes. Then there is a weak homotopy equivalence

    lim‚ü∂ n(lim‚üµ iD n(i))‚ü∂‚ààW cllim‚üµ i(lim‚ü∂ nD n(i)) \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{n} \left( \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i D_n(i) \right) \overset{\in W_{cl}}{\longrightarrow} \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{n} D_n(i) \right)

    from the colimit over the limit sequnce to the limit of the colimits of sequences.

Proof

Regarding the first statement:

Use that both (Top cg) Quillen(Top_{cg})_{Quillen} and (Top cg */) Quillen(Top^{\ast/}_{cg})_{Quillen} are cofibrantly generated model categories (theorem 3) whose generating acyclic cofibrations have compact topological spaces as domains and codomains. The colimit over a sequence of relative cell complexes (being a transfinite composition) yields another relative cell complex, and hence lemma 15 says that every morphism out of the domain or codomain of a generating acyclic cofibration into this colimit factors through a finite stage inclusion. Since a projective fibration is a degreewise fibration, we have the lifting property at that finite stage, and hence also the lifting property against the morphisms of colimits.

Regarding the second statement:

This is a model category theoretic version of a standard fact of plain category theory, which says that in the category Set of sets, filtered colimits commute with finite limits in that there is an isomorphism of sets of the form which we have to prove is a weak homotopy equivalence of topological spaces. But now using that weak homotopy equivalences are detected by forming homotopy groups (def. 30), hence hom-sets out of n-spheres, and since nn-spheres are compact topological spaces, lemma 15 says that homming out of nn-spheres commutes over the colimits in question. Moreover, generally homming out of anything commutes over limits, in particular finite limits (every hom functor is left exact functor in the second variable). Therefore we find isomorphisms of the form

Hom(S q,lim‚ü∂ n(lim‚üµ iD n(i)))‚âÉlim‚ü∂ n(lim‚üµ iHom(S q,D n(i)))‚ü∂‚àºlim‚üµ i(lim‚ü∂ nHom(S qD n(i)))‚âÉHom(S q,lim‚üµ i(lim‚ü∂ nD n(i))) Hom\left( S^q, \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{n} \left( \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i D_n(i) \right) \right) \simeq \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{n} \left( \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i Hom\left(S^q, D_n(i)\right) \right) \overset{\sim}{\longrightarrow} \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{n} Hom\left(S^q D_n(i)\right) \right) \simeq Hom\left( S^q, \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_{n} D_n(i) \right) \right)

and similarly for the left homotopies Hom(S q√óI,‚àí)Hom(S^q \times I,-) (and similarly for the pointed case). This implies the claimed isomorphism on homotopy groups.

\,

‚àû\infty-Groupoids II): Simplicial homotopy theory

With groupoids and chain complexes we have seen two kinds of objects which support concepts of homotopy theory, such as a concept of homotopy equivalence between them (equivalence of groupoids on the one hand, and quasi-isomorphism on the other). In some sense these two cases are opposite extremes in the more general context of homotopy theory:

  • chain complexes have homotopical structure (e.g. chain homology) in arbitrary high degree, i.e. they may be homotopy n-types for arbitrary nn, but they are fully abelian in that there is never any nonabelian group structure in a chain complex, not is there any non-trivial action of the homology groups of a chain complex on each other;

  • groupoids have more general non-abelian structure, for every (nonabelian) group there is a groupoid which has this as its fundamental group, but this fundamental group (in degree 1) is already the highest homotopical structure they carry, groupoids are necessarily homotopy 1-types.

On the other hand, both groupoids and chain complexes naturally have incarnations in the joint context of simplicial sets. We now discuss how their common joint generalization is given by those simplicial sets whose simplices have a sensible notion of composition and inverses, the Kan complexes.

topologicalspaces ‚Üì higherpathgroupoid groupoids ‚ü∂Grothendiecknerve Kancomplexes‚âÉ‚àû‚àígroupoids ‚üµDold‚àíKancorrespondence chaincomplexes ‚Üì includedin simplicialsets \array{ && {topological \atop spaces} \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{{higher \atop path}\atop groupoid}} & \\ groupoids &\stackrel{{Grothendieck \atop nerve}}{\longrightarrow}& { {\mathbf{Kan}\;\mathbf{complexes}} \atop {\simeq \infty-groupoids} } &\stackrel{{Dold-Kan \atop correspondence}}{\longleftarrow}& {chain \atop complexes} \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{included \atop in}} \\ && {simplicial \atop sets} }

Kan complexes serve as a standard powerful model on which the complete formulation of homotopy theory (without geometry) may be formulated.

Simplicial sets

The concept of simplicial sets is secretly well familiar already in basic algebraic topology: it reflects just the abstract structure carried by the singular simplicial complexes of topological spaces, as in the definition of singular homology and singular cohomology.

Conversely, every simplicial set may be geometrically realized as a topological space. These two adjoint operations turn out to exhibit the homotopy theory of simplicial sets as being equivalent (Quillen equivalent) to the homotopy theory of topological spaces. For some purposes, working in simplicial homotopy theory is preferable over working with topological homotopy theory.

Definition

(topological simplex)

For n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, the topological n-simplex is, up to homeomorphism, the topological space whose underlying set is the subset

Œî n‚âî{x‚Üí‚àà‚Ñù n+1|‚àë i=0 nx i=1and‚àÄi.x i‚â•0}‚äÇ‚Ñù n+1 \Delta^n \coloneqq \{ \vec x \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1} | \sum_{i = 0 }^n x_i = 1 \; and \; \forall i . x_i \geq 0 \} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}

of the Cartesian space ‚Ñù n+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}, and whose topology is the subspace topology induces from the canonical topology in ‚Ñù n+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}.

Example

For n=0n = 0 this is the point, Œî 0=*\Delta^0 = *.

For n=1n = 1 this is the standard interval object Œî 1=[0,1]\Delta^1 = [0,1].

For n=2n = 2 this is the filled triangle.

For n=3n = 3 this is the filled tetrahedron.

Definition

For n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, n‚â•1\n \geq 1 and 0‚â§k‚â§n0 \leq k \leq n, the kkth (n‚àí1)(n-1)-face (inclusion) of the topological nn-simplex, def. 61, is the subspace inclusion

Œ¥ k:Œî n‚àí1‚Ü™Œî n \delta_k : \Delta^{n-1} \hookrightarrow \Delta^n

induced under the coordinate presentation of def. 61, by the inclusion

‚Ñù n‚Ü™‚Ñù n+1 \mathbb{R}^n \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n+1}

which ‚Äúomits‚Äù the kkth canonical coordinate:

(x 0,‚ãØ,x n‚àí1)‚Ü¶(x 0,‚ãØ,x k‚àí1,0,x k,‚ãØ,x n). (x_0, \cdots , x_{n-1}) \mapsto (x_0, \cdots, x_{k-1} , 0 , x_{k}, \cdots, x_n) \,.
Example

The inclusion

Œ¥ 0:Œî 0‚ÜíŒî 1 \delta_0 : \Delta^0 \to \Delta^1

is the inclusion

{1}‚Ü™[0,1] \{1\} \hookrightarrow [0,1]

of the ‚Äúright‚Äù end of the standard interval. The other inclusion

Œ¥ 1:Œî 0‚ÜíŒî 1 \delta_1 : \Delta^0 \to \Delta^1

is that of the ‚Äúleft‚Äù end {0}‚Ü™[0,1]\{0\} \hookrightarrow [0,1].

(graphics taken from Friedman 08)

Definition

For n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} and 0‚â§k<n0 \leq k \lt n the kkth degenerate (n)(n)-simplex (projection) is the surjective map

œÉ k:Œî n‚ÜíŒî n‚àí1 \sigma_k : \Delta^{n} \to \Delta^{n-1}

induced under the barycentric coordinates of def. 61 under the surjection

‚Ñù n+1‚Üí‚Ñù n \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \to \mathbb{R}^n

which sends

(x 0,‚ãØ,x n)‚Ü¶(x 0,‚ãØ,x k+x k+1,‚ãØ,x n). (x_0, \cdots, x_n) \mapsto (x_0, \cdots, x_{k} + x_{k+1}, \cdots, x_n) \,.
Definition

(singular simplex)

For X‚ààX \in Top and n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, a singular nn-simplex in XX is a continuous map

œÉ:Œî n‚ÜíX \sigma : \Delta^n \to X

from the topological nn-simplex, def. 61, to XX.

Write

(SingX) n‚âîHom Top(Œî n,X) (Sing X)_n \coloneqq Hom_{Top}(\Delta^n , X)

for the set of singular nn-simplices of XX.

(graphics taken from Friedman 08)

The sets (SingX) ‚Ä¢(Sing X)_\bullet here are closely related by an interlocking system of maps that make them form what is called a simplicial set, and as such the collection of these sets of singular simplices is called the singular simplicial complex of XX. We discuss the definition of simplicial sets now and then come back to this below in def. 67.

Since the topological nn-simplices Œî n\Delta^n from def. 61 sit inside each other by the face inclusions of def. 62

Œ¥ k:Œî n‚àí1‚ÜíŒî n \delta_k : \Delta^{n-1} \to \Delta^{n}

and project onto each other by the degeneracy maps, def. 63

œÉ k:Œî n+1‚ÜíŒî n \sigma_k : \Delta^{n+1} \to \Delta^n

we dually have functions

d k‚âîHom Top(Œ¥ k,X):(SingX) n‚Üí(SingX) n‚àí1 d_k \coloneqq Hom_{Top}(\delta_k, X) : (Sing X)_n \to (Sing X)_{n-1}

that send each singular nn-simplex to its kk-face and functions

s k‚âîHom Top(œÉ k,X):(SingX) n‚Üí(SingX) n+1 s_k \coloneqq Hom_{Top}(\sigma_k,X) : (Sing X)_{n} \to (Sing X)_{n+1}

that regard an nn-simplex as beign a degenerate (‚Äúthin‚Äù) (n+1)(n+1)-simplex. All these sets of simplices and face and degeneracy maps between them form the following structure.

Definition

(simplicial sets)

A simplicial set SS is

  • for each n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} a set S n‚ààSetS_n \in Set ‚Äì the set of nn-simplices;

  • for each injective map Œ¥ i:n‚àí1¬Ø‚Üín¬Ø\delta_i : \overline{n-1} \to \overline{n} of totally ordered sets n¬Ø‚âî{0<1<‚ãØ<n}\bar n \coloneqq \{ 0 \lt 1 \lt \cdots \lt n \}

    a function d i:S n‚ÜíS n‚àí1d_i : S_{n} \to S_{n-1} ‚Äì the iith face map on nn-simplices;

  • for each surjective map œÉ i:n+1¬Ø‚Üín¬Ø\sigma_i : \overline{n+1} \to \bar n of totally ordered sets

    a function œÉ i:S n‚ÜíS n+1\sigma_i : S_{n} \to S_{n+1} ‚Äì the iith degeneracy map on nn-simplices;

such that these functions satisfy the following identities, called the_simplicial identities_:

  1. d i‚àòd j=d j‚àí1‚àòd i d_i \circ d_j = d_{j-1} \circ d_i if i<ji \lt j,

  2. s i‚àòs j=s j‚àòs i‚àí1s_i \circ s_j = s_j \circ s_{i-1} if i>ji \gt j.

  3. d i‚àòs j={s j‚àí1‚àòd i ifi<j id ifi=jori=j+1 s j‚àòd i‚àí1 ifi>j+1d_i \circ s_j = \left\{ \array{ s_{j-1} \circ d_i & if \; i \lt j \\ id & if \; i = j \; or \; i = j+1 \\ s_j \circ d_{i-1} & if i \gt j+1 } \right.

For S,TS, T two simplicial sets, a morphism of simplicial sets S‚ü∂fTS \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} T is for each n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} a function S N‚ü∂f nT nS_N \overset{f_n}{\longrightarrow} T_n between sets of nn-simplices, such that these functions are compatible with all the face and degeneracy maps.

This defines a category (Def. \ref{Categories}) sSet of simplicial sets.

It is straightforward to check by explicit inspection that the evident injection and restriction maps between the sets of singular simplices make (SingX) ‚Ä¢(Sing X)_\bullet into a simplicial set. However for working with this, it is good to streamline a little:

Definition

(simplex category)

The simplex category Œî\Delta is the full subcategory of Cat on the free categories of the form

[0] ‚âî{0} [1] ‚âî{0‚Üí1} [2] ‚âî{0‚Üí1‚Üí2} ‚ãÆ. \begin{aligned} [0] & \coloneqq \{0\} \\ [1] & \coloneqq \{0 \to 1\} \\ [2] & \coloneqq \{0 \to 1 \to 2\} \\ \vdots \end{aligned} \,.
Remark

This is called the ‚Äúsimplex category‚Äù because we are to think of the object [n][n] as being the ‚Äúspine‚Äù of the nn-simplex. For instance for n=2n = 2 we think of 0‚Üí1‚Üí20 \to 1 \to 2 as the ‚Äúspine‚Äù of the triangle. This becomes clear if we don‚Äôt just draw the morphisms that generate the category [n][n], but draw also all their composites. For instance for n=2n = 2 we have_

[2]={ 1 ‚Üó ‚Üò 0 ‚Üí 2}. [2] = \left\{ \array{ && 1 \\ & \nearrow && \searrow \\ 0 &&\to&& 2 } \right\} \,.
Proposition

(simplicial sets are presheaves on the simplex category)

A functor

S:Œî op‚ÜíSet S \;\colon\; \Delta^{op} \to Set

from the opposite category (Example \ref{OppositeCategory}) of the simplex category (Def. 66) to the category of sets, hence a presheaf on Œî\Delta (Example \ref{CategoryOfPresheaves}), is canonically identified with a simplicial set, def. \ref{SimplicialSet}.

Via this identification, the category sSet of simplicial sets (Def. 65) is equivalent to the category of presheaves on the simplex category

sSet=[Œî op,Set]. sSet \;=\; [\Delta^{op}, Set] \,.

In particular this means that sSet is a cosmos for enriched category theory (Example \ref{ExamplesOfCosmoi}), by Prop. \ref{PropertiesOfSheafToposes}.

Proof

One checks by inspection that the simplicial identities characterize precisely the behaviour of the morphisms in Œî op([n],[n+1])\Delta^{op}([n],[n+1]) and Œî op([n],[n‚àí1])\Delta^{op}([n],[n-1]).

This makes the following evident:

Example

The topological simplices from def. 61 arrange into a cosimplicial object in Top, namely a functor

Œî ‚Ä¢:Œî‚ÜíTop. \Delta^\bullet : \Delta \to Top \,.

With this now the structure of a simplicial set on (SingX) ‚Ä¢(Sing X)_\bullet, def. 64, is manifest: it is just the nerve of XX with respect to Œî ‚Ä¢\Delta^\bullet, namely:

Definition

For XX a topological space its simplicial set of singular simplicies (often called the singular simplicial complex)

(SingX) ‚Ä¢:Œî op‚ÜíSet (Sing X)_\bullet : \Delta^{op} \to Set

is given by composition of the functor from example 48 with the hom functor of Top:

(SingX):[n]‚Ü¶Hom Top(Œî n,X). (Sing X) : [n] \mapsto Hom_{Top}( \Delta^n , X ) \,.
Remark

It turns out ‚Äì this is the content of the homotopy hypothesis-theorem (Quillen 67) ‚Äì that homotopy type of the topological space XX is entirely captured by its singular simplicial complex SingXSing X. Moreover, the geometric realization of SingXSing X is a model for the same homotopy type as that of XX, but with the special property that it is canonically a cell complex ‚Äì a CW-complex. Better yet, SingXSing X is itself already good cell complex, namely a Kan complex. We come to this below.

Simplicial homotopy

The concept of homotopy of morphisms between simplicial sets proceeds in direct analogy with that in topological spaces.

Definition

For XX a simplicial set, def. \ref{SimplicialSet}, its simplicial cylinder object is the Cartesian product X√óŒî[1]X\times \Delta[1] (formed in the category sSet, Prop. \ref{SimplicialSetsAsPresheavesOnTheSimplexCategory }).

A left homotopy

Œ∑:f‚áíg \eta \;\colon\; f \Rightarrow g

between two morphisms

f,g:X‚ü∂Y f,g\;\colon\; X \longrightarrow Y

of simplicial sets is a morphism

Œ∑:X√óŒî[1]‚ü∂Y \eta \;\colon\; X \times \Delta[1] \longrightarrow Y

such that the following diagram commutes

X (id X,d 1)‚Üì ‚Üò f X√óŒî 1 ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y (id x,d 0)‚Üë ‚Üó g X. \array{ X \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id_X,d_1)}}\downarrow & \searrow^{\mathllap{f}} \\ X \times \Delta^1 &\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y \\ {}^{\mathllap{(id_x, d_0)}}\uparrow & \nearrow_{\mathllap{g}} \\ X } \,.

For YY a Kan complex, def. \ref{SimplicialSet}, its simplicial path space object is the function complex X Œî[1]X^{\Delta[1]} (formed in the category sSet, Prop. 50).

A right homotopy

Œ∑:f‚áíg \eta \;\colon\; f \Rightarrow g

between two morphisms

f,g:X‚ü∂Y f,g\;\colon\; X \longrightarrow Y

of simplicial sets is a morphism

Œ∑:X‚ü∂Y Œî[1] \eta \colon X \longrightarrow Y^{\Delta[1]}

such that the following diagram commutes

Y f‚Üó ‚Üë Y d 1 X ‚ü∂Œ∑ Y Œî[1] g‚Üò ‚Üì Y d 0 Y. \array{ && Y \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f}}\nearrow & \uparrow^{\mathrlap{Y^{d_1}}} \\ X &\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& Y^{\Delta[1]} \\ & {}_{\mathllap{g}}\searrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{Y^{d_0}}} \\ && Y } \,.
Proposition

For YY a Kan complex, def. \ref{KanComplexes}, and XX any simplicial set, then left homotopy, def. 68, regarded as a relation

(f‚àºg)‚áî(f‚áí‚àÉg) (f\sim g) \Leftrightarrow (f \stackrel{\exists}{\Rightarrow} g)

on the hom set Hom sSet(X,Y)Hom_{sSet}(X,Y), is an equivalence relation.

Definition

(homotopy equivalence in simplicial sets)

A morphism f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y of simplicial sets is a left/right homotopy equivalence if there exists a morphisms X‚üµY:gX \longleftarrow Y \colon g and left/right homotopies (def. 68)

g‚àòf‚áíid X,f‚àòg‚áíid Y g \circ f \Rightarrow id_X\,,\;\;\;\; f\circ g \Rightarrow id_Y

The the basic invariants of simplicial sets/Kan complexes in simplicial homotopy theory are their simplicial homotopy groups, to which we turn now.

Given that a Kan complex is a special simplicial set that behaves like a combinatorial model for a topological space, the simplicial homotopy groups of a Kan complex are accordingly the combinatorial analog of the homotopy groups of topological spaces: instead of being maps from topological spheres modulo maps from topological disks, they are maps from the boundary of a simplex modulo those from the simplex itself.

Accordingly, the definition of the discussion of simplicial homotopy groups is essentially literally the same as that of homotopy groups of topological spaces. One technical difference is for instance that the definition of the group structure is slightly more non-immediate for simplicial homotopy groups than for topological homotopy groups (see below).

Definition

For XX a Kan complex, then its 0th simplicial homotopy group (or set of connected components) is the set of equivalence classes of vertices modulo the equivalence relation X 1‚ü∂(d 1,d 0)X 0√óX 0X_1 \stackrel{(d_1,d_0)}{\longrightarrow} X_0 \times X_0

œÄ 0(X):X 0/X 1. \pi_0(X) \colon X_0/X_1 \,.

For x‚ààX 0x \in X_0 a vertex and for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, n‚â•1n \geq 1, then the underlying set of the nnth simplicial homotopy group of XX at xx ‚Äì denoted œÄ n(X,x)\pi_n(X,x) ‚Äì is, the set of equivalence classes [Œ±][\alpha] of morphisms

Œ±:Œî n‚ÜíX \alpha \colon \Delta^n \to X

from the simplicial nn-simplex Œî n\Delta^n to XX, such that these take the boundary of the simplex to xx, i.e. such that they fit into a commuting diagram in sSet of the form

‚àÇŒî[n] ‚ü∂ Œî[0] ‚Üì ‚Üì x Œî[n] ‚ü∂Œ± X, \array{ \partial \Delta[n] & \longrightarrow & \Delta[0] \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{x}} \\ \Delta[n] &\stackrel{\alpha}{\longrightarrow}& X } \,,

where two such maps Œ±,Œ±‚Ä≤\alpha, \alpha' are taken to be equivalent is they are related by a simplicial homotopy Œ∑\eta

Œî[n] ‚Üì i 0 ‚Üò Œ± Œî[n]√óŒî[1] ‚ü∂Œ∑ X ‚Üë i 1 ‚Üó Œ±‚Ä≤ Œî[n] \array{ \Delta[n] \\ \downarrow^{i_0} & \searrow^{\alpha} \\ \Delta[n] \times \Delta[1] &\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& X \\ \uparrow^{i_1} & \nearrow_{\alpha'} \\ \Delta[n] }

that fixes the boundary in that it fits into a commuting diagram in sSet of the form

‚àÇŒî[n]√óŒî[1] ‚ü∂ Œî[0] ‚Üì ‚Üì x Œî[n]√óŒî[1] ‚ü∂Œ∑ X. \array{ \partial \Delta[n] \times \Delta[1] & \longrightarrow & \Delta[0] \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{x}} \\ \Delta[n] \times \Delta[1] &\stackrel{\eta}{\longrightarrow}& X } \,.

These sets are taken to be equipped with the following group structure.

Definition

For XX a Kan complex, for x‚ààX 0x\in X_0, for n‚â•1n \geq 1 and for f,g:Œî[n]‚ÜíXf,g \colon \Delta[n] \to X two representatives of œÄ n(X,x)\pi_n(X,x) as in def. 70, consider the following nn-simplices in X nX_n:

v i‚âî{s 0‚àòs 0‚àò‚ãØ‚àòs 0(x) for0‚â§i‚â§n‚àí2 f fori=n‚àí1 g fori=n+1 v_i \coloneqq \left\{ \array{ s_0 \circ s_0 \circ \cdots \circ s_0 (x) & for \; 0 \leq i \leq n-2 \\ f & for \; i = n-1 \\ g & for \; i = n+1 } \right.

This corresponds to a morphism Œõ n+1[n]‚ÜíX\Lambda^{n+1}[n] \to X from a horn of the (n+1)(n+1)-simplex into XX. By the Kan complex property of XX this morphism has an extension Œ∏\theta through the (n+1)(n+1)-simplex Œî[n]\Delta[n]

Œõ n+1[n] ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üó Œ∏ Œî[n+1] \array{ \Lambda^{n+1}[n] & \longrightarrow & X \\ \downarrow & \nearrow_{\mathrlap{\theta}} \\ \Delta[n+1] }

From the simplicial identities one finds that the boundary of the nn-simplex arising as the nnth boundary piece d nŒ∏d_n \theta of Œ∏\theta is constant on xx

d id nŒ∏=d n‚àí1d iŒ∏=x d_i d_{n} \theta = d_{n-1} d_i \theta = x

So d nŒ∏d_n \theta represents an element in œÄ n(X,x)\pi_n(X,x) and we define a product operation on œÄ n(X,x)\pi_n(X,x) by

[f]‚ãÖ[g]‚âî[d nŒ∏]. [f]\cdot [g] \coloneqq [d_n \theta] \,.

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 99, p. 26)

Remark

All the degenerate nn-simplices v 0‚â§i‚â§n‚àí2v_{0 \leq i \leq n-2} in def. 71 are just there so that the gluing of the two nn-cells ff and gg to each other can be regarded as forming the boundary of an (n+1)(n+1)-simplex except for one face. By the Kan extension property that missing face exists, namely d nŒ∏d_n \theta. This is a choice of gluing composite of ff with gg.

Lemma

The product on homotopy group elements in def. 71 is well defined, in that it is independent of the choice of representatives ff, gg and of the extension Œ∏\theta.

e.g. (Goerss-Jardine 99, lemma 7.1)

Lemma

The product operation in def. 71 yields a group structure on œÄ n(X,x)\pi_n(X,x), which is abelian for n‚â•2n \geq 2.

e.g. (Goerss-Jardine 99, theorem 7.2)

Remark

The first homotopy group, œÄ 1(X,x)\pi_1(X,x), is also called the fundamental group of XX.

Definition

(weak homotopy equivalence of simplicial sets)

For X,Y‚ààKanCplx‚Ü™sSetX,Y \in KanCplx \hookrightarrow sSet two Kan complexes, then a morphism

f:X‚ü∂Y f \colon X \longrightarrow Y

is called a weak homotopy equivalence if it induces isomorphisms on all simplicial homotopy groups, i.e. if

  1. œÄ 0(f):œÄ 0(X)‚ü∂œÄ 0(Y)\pi_0(f) \colon \pi_0(X) \longrightarrow \pi_0(Y) is a bijection of sets;

  2. œÄ n(f,x):œÄ n(X,x)lonrightarrowœÄ n(Y,f(x))\pi_n(f,x) \colon \pi_n(X,x) \lonrightarrow \pi_n(Y,f(x)) is an isomorphism of groups for all x‚ààX 0x\in X_0 and all n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}; n‚â•1n \geq 1.

Kan complexes

Recall the definition of simplicial sets from above. Let

Œî[n]=Œî(‚àí,[n])‚ààSimpSet \Delta[n] = \mathbf{\Delta}( -, [n]) \in Simp Set

be the standard simplicial nn-simplex in SimpSet.

Definition

For each ii, 0‚â§i‚â§n0 \leq i \leq n, the (n,i)(n,i)-horn or (n,i)(n,i)-box is the subsimplicial set

Œõ i[n]‚Ü™Œî[n] \Lambda^i[n] \hookrightarrow \Delta[n]

which is the union of all faces except the i thi^{th} one.

This is called an outer horn if k=0k = 0 or k=nk = n. Otherwise it is an inner horn.

Remark

Since sSet is a presheaf topos, unions of subobjects make sense and they are calculated objectwise, thus in this case dimensionwise. This way it becomes clear what the structure of a horn as a functor Œõ k[n]:Œî op‚ÜíSet\Lambda^k[n]: \Delta^{op} \to Set must therefore be: it takes [m][m] to the collection of ordinal maps f:[m]‚Üí[n]f: [m] \to [n] which do not have the element kk in the image.

Example

The inner horn, def. 73 of the 2-simplex

Œî 2={ 1 ‚Üó ‚áì ‚Üò 0 ‚Üí 2} \Delta^2 = \left\{ \array{ && 1 \\ & \nearrow &\Downarrow& \searrow \\ 0 &&\to&& 2 } \right\}

with boundary

‚àÇŒî 2={ 1 ‚Üó ‚Üò 0 ‚Üí 2}\partial \Delta^2 = \left\{ \array{ && 1 \\ & \nearrow && \searrow \\ 0 &&\to&& 2 } \right\}

looks like

Œõ 1 2={ 1 ‚Üó ‚Üò 0 2}. \Lambda^2_1 = \left\{ \array{ && 1 \\ & \nearrow && \searrow \\ 0 &&&& 2 } \right\} \,.

The two outer horns look like

Œõ 0 2={ 1 ‚Üó 0 ‚Üí 2}\Lambda^2_0 = \left\{ \array{ && 1 \\ & \nearrow && \\ 0 &&\to&& 2 } \right\}

and

Œõ 2 2={ 1 ‚Üò 0 ‚Üí 2}\Lambda^2_2 = \left\{ \array{ && 1 \\ & && \searrow \\ 0 &&\to&& 2 } \right\}

respectively.

(graphics taken from Friedman 08)

Definition

(Kan complex)

A Kan complex is a simplicial set SS that satisfies the Kan condition,

  • which says that all horns of the simplicial set have fillers/extend to simplices;

  • which means equivalently that the unique homomorphism S‚ÜíptS \to pt from SS to the point (the terminal simplicial set) is a Kan fibration;

  • which means equivalently that for all diagrams in sSet of the form

    Œõ i[n] ‚Üí S ‚Üì ‚Üì Œî[n] ‚Üí pt‚ÜîŒõ i[n] ‚Üí S ‚Üì Œî[n] \array{ \Lambda^i[n] &\to& S \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ \Delta[n] &\to& pt } \;\;\; \leftrightarrow \;\;\; \array{ \Lambda^i[n] &\to& S \\ \downarrow && \\ \Delta[n] }

    there exists a diagonal morphism

    Œõ i[n] ‚Üí S ‚Üì ‚Üó ‚Üì Œî[n] ‚Üí pt‚ÜîŒõ i[n] ‚Üí S ‚Üì ‚Üó Œî[n] \array{ \Lambda^i[n] &\to& S \\ \downarrow &\nearrow& \downarrow \\ \Delta[n] &\to& pt } \;\;\; \leftrightarrow \;\;\; \array{ \Lambda^i[n] &\to& S \\ \downarrow &\nearrow& \\ \Delta[n] }

    completing this to a commuting diagram;

  • which in turn means equivalently that the map from nn-simplices to (n,i)(n,i)-horns is an epimorphism

    [Œî[n],S]‚Ü†[Œõ i[n],S]. [\Delta[n], S]\, \twoheadrightarrow \,[\Lambda^i[n],S] \,.
Proposition

For XX a topological space, its singular simplicial complex Sing(X)Sing(X), def. 67, is a Kan complex, def. \ref{KanComplexes}.

Proof

The inclusions Œõ n Top k‚Ü™Œî Top n{{\Lambda^n}_{Top}}_k \hookrightarrow \Delta^n_{Top} of topological horns into topological simplices are retracts, in that there are continuous maps Œî Top n‚ÜíŒõ n Top k\Delta^n_{Top} \to {{\Lambda^n}_{Top}}_k given by ‚Äúsquashing‚Äù a topological nn-simplex onto parts of its boundary, such that

(Œõ n Top k‚ÜíŒî Top n‚ÜíŒõ n Top k)=Id. ({{\Lambda^n}_{Top}}_k \to \Delta^n_{Top} \to {{\Lambda^n}_{Top}}_k) = Id \,.

Therefore the map [Œî n,Œ†(X)]‚Üí[Œõ k n,Œ†(X)][\Delta^n, \Pi(X)] \to [\Lambda^n_k,\Pi(X)] is an epimorphism, since it is equal to to Top(Œî n,X)‚ÜíTop(Œõ k n,X)Top(\Delta^n, X) \to Top(\Lambda^n_k, X) which has a right inverse Top(Œõ k n,X)‚ÜíTop(Œî n,X)Top(\Lambda^n_k, X) \to Top(\Delta^n, X).

More generally:

Definition

(Kan fibration)

A morphism œï:S‚ü∂T\phi \colon S \longrightarrow T in sSet is called a Kan fibration if it has the right lifting property again all horn inclusions, def. \ref{Horn}, hence if for every commuting diagram of the form

Œõ i[n] ‚ü∂ S ‚Üì ‚Üì œï Œî[n] ‚ü∂ T \array{ \Lambda^i[n] &\longrightarrow& S \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\phi}} \\ \Delta[n] &\longrightarrow& T }

there exists a lift

Œõ i[n] ‚ü∂ S ‚Üì ‚Üó ‚Üì œï Œî[n] ‚ü∂ T. \array{ \Lambda^i[n] &\longrightarrow& S \\ \downarrow &\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\phi}} \\ \Delta[n] &\longrightarrow& T } \,.

This is the simplicial incarnation of the concept of Serre fibrations of topological spaces:

Definition

A continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y between topological spaces is a Serre fibration if for all CW-complexes CC and for every commuting diagram in Top of the form

C ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üì f C√óI ‚ü∂ Y \array{ C &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ C \times I &\longrightarrow& Y }

there exists a lift

C ‚ü∂ X ‚Üì ‚Üó ‚Üì f C√óI ‚ü∂ Y. \array{ C &\longrightarrow& X \\ \downarrow &\nearrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ C \times I &\longrightarrow& Y } \,.
Proposition

A continuous function f:X‚ü∂Yf \colon X \longrightarrow Y is a Serre fibration, def. 76, precisely if Sing(f):Sing(X)‚ü∂Sing(Y)Sing(f) \colon Sing(X) \longrightarrow Sing(Y) (def. 67) is a Kan fibration, def. 75.

The proof uses the basic tool of nerve and realization-adjunction to which we get to below in prop. 63.

Proof

First observe that the left lifting property against all C‚Ü™C√óIC \hookrightarrow C \times I for CC a CW-complex is equivalent to left lifting against geometric realization |Œõ i[n]|‚Ü™|Œî[n]|{\vert \Lambda^i[n]\vert} \hookrightarrow {\vert \Delta[n]\vert} of horn inclusions. Then apply the natural isomorphism Top(|‚àí|,‚àí)‚âÉsSet(‚àí,Sing(‚àí))Top({\vert-\vert},-) \simeq sSet(-,Sing(-)), given by the adjunction of prop. 63 and example 65, to the lifting diagrams.

Lemma

Let p:X‚ü∂Yp \colon X \longrightarrow Y be a Kan fibration, def. 75, and let f 1,f 2:A‚ü∂Xf_1,f_2 \colon A \longrightarrow X be two morphisms. If there is a left homotopy (def. 68) f 1‚áíf 2f_1 \Rightarrow f_2 between these maps, then there is a fiberwise homotopy equivalence, def. 31, between the pullback fibrations f 1 *X‚âÉf 2 *Xf_1^\ast X \simeq f_2^\ast X.

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, lemma 10.6)

While simplicial sets have the advantage of being purely combinatorial structures, the singular simplicial complex of any given topological space, def. 67 is in general a huge simplicial set which does not lend itself to detailed inspection. The following is about small models.

Definition

A Kan fibration œï:S‚ü∂T\phi \colon S \longrightarrow T, def. 75, is called a minimal Kan fibration if for any two cells in the same fiber with the same boundary if they are homotopic relative their boundary, then they are already equal.

More formally, œï\phi is minimal precisely if for every commuting diagram of the form

(‚àÇŒî[n])√óŒî[1] ‚ü∂p 1 ‚àÇŒî[n] ‚Üì ‚Üì Œî[n]√óŒî[1] ‚ü∂h S ‚Üì p 1 ‚Üì œï Œî[n] ‚ü∂ T \array{ (\partial \Delta[n]) \times \Delta[1] &\stackrel{p_1}{\longrightarrow}& \partial \Delta[n] \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ \Delta[n] \times \Delta[1] &\stackrel{h}{\longrightarrow}& S \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{p_1}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\phi}} \\ \Delta[n] &\longrightarrow& T }

then the two composites

Œî[n]‚ü∂d 1‚ü∂d 0Œî[n]√óŒî[1]‚ü∂hS \Delta[n] \stackrel{\overset{d_0}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{d_1}{\longrightarrow}} \Delta[n] \times \Delta[1] \stackrel{h}{\longrightarrow} S

are equal.

Proposition

The pullback (in sSet) of a minimal Kan fibration, def. 76, along any morphism is again a mimimal Kan fibration.

‚Ä¶ anodyne extensions‚Ä¶

(Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, section 4, Joyal-Tierney 05, section 31)

Proposition

For every Kan fibration, def. 75, there exists a fiberwise strong deformation retract to a minimal Kan fibration, def. 76.

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, prop. 10.3, Joyal-Tierney 05, theorem 3.3.1, theorem 3.3.3).

Proof idea

Choose representatives by induction, use that in the induction step one needs lifts of anodyne extensions against a Kan fibration, which exist.

Lemma

A morphism between minimal Kan fibrations, def. 76, which is fiberwise a homotopy equivalence, def. 69, is already an isomorphism.

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, lemma 10.4)

Proof idea

Show the statement degreewise. In the induction one needs to lift anodyne extensions agains a Kan fibration.

Lemma

Every minimal Kan fibration, def. 76, over a connected base is a simplicial fiber bundle, locally trivial over every simplex of the base.

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, corollary 10.8)

Proof

By assumption of the base being connected, the classifying maps for the fibers over any two vertices are connected by a zig-zag of homotopies, hence by lemma 26 the fibers are connected by homotopy equivalences and then by prop. 54 and lemma 27 they are already isomorphic. Write FF for this typical fiber.

Moreover, for all nn the morphisms Œî[n]‚ÜíŒî[0]‚ÜíŒî[n]\Delta[n] \to \Delta[0] \to \Delta[n] are left homotopic to Œî[n]‚ÜíidŒî[n]\Delta[n] \stackrel{id}{\to} \Delta[n] and so applying lemma 26 and prop. 27 once more yields that the fiber over each Œî[n]\Delta[n] is isomorphic to Œî[n]√óF\Delta[n]\times F.

Groupoids as Kan complexes

Definition

A (small) groupoid ùí¢ ‚Ä¢\mathcal{G}_\bullet is

  • a pair of sets ùí¢ 0‚ààSet\mathcal{G}_0 \in Set (the set of objects) and ùí¢ 1‚ààSet\mathcal{G}_1 \in Set (the set of morphisms)

  • equipped with functions

    ùí¢ 1√ó ùí¢ 0ùí¢ 1 ‚ü∂‚àò ùí¢ 1 ‚ü∂s‚Üêi‚ü∂t ùí¢ 0, \array{ \mathcal{G}_1 \times_{\mathcal{G}_0} \mathcal{G}_1 &\stackrel{\circ}{\longrightarrow}& \mathcal{G}_1 & \stackrel{\overset{t}{\longrightarrow}}{\stackrel{\overset{i}{\leftarrow}}{\underset{s}{\longrightarrow}}}& \mathcal{G}_0 }\,,

    where the fiber product on the left is that over ùí¢ 1‚Üítùí¢ 0‚Üêsùí¢ 1\mathcal{G}_1 \stackrel{t}{\to} \mathcal{G}_0 \stackrel{s}{\leftarrow} \mathcal{G}_1,

such that

  • ii takes values in endomorphisms;

    t‚àòi=s‚àòi=id ùí¢ 0, t \circ i = s \circ i = id_{\mathcal{G}_0}, \;\;\;

  • ‚àò\circ defines a partial composition operation which is associative and unital for i(ùí¢ 0)i(\mathcal{G}_0) the identities; in particular

    s(g‚àòf)=s(f)s (g \circ f) = s(f) and t(g‚àòf)=t(g)t (g \circ f) = t(g);

  • every morphism has an inverse under this composition.

Remark

This data is visualized as follows. The set of morphisms is

ùí¢ 1={œï 0‚Üíkœï 1} \mathcal{G}_1 = \left\{ \phi_0 \stackrel{k}{\to} \phi_1 \right\}

and the set of pairs of composable morphisms is

ùí¢ 2‚âîùí¢ 1√óùí¢ 0ùí¢ 1={ œï 1 k 1‚Üó ‚Üò k 2 œï 0 ‚Üík 2‚àòk 1 œï 2}. \mathcal{G}_2 \coloneqq \mathcal{G}_1 \underset{\mathcal{G}_0}{\times} \mathcal{G}_1 = \left\{ \array{ && \phi_1 \\ & {}^{\mathllap{k_1}}\nearrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{k_2}} \\ \phi_0 && \stackrel{k_2 \circ k_1}{\to} && \phi_2 } \right\} \,.

The functions p 1,p 2,‚àò:ùí¢ 2‚Üíùí¢ 1p_1, p_2, \circ \colon \mathcal{G}_2 \to \mathcal{G}_1 are those which send, respectively, these triangular diagrams to the left morphism, or the right morphism, or the bottom morphism.

Example

For XX a set, it becomes a groupoid by taking XX to be the set of objects and adding only precisely the identity morphism from each object to itself

(X‚üµid‚ü∂id‚ü∂idX). \left( X \underoverset {\underset{id}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{id}{\longrightarrow}} { \overset{id}{\longleftarrow} } X \right) \,.
Example

For GG a group, its delooping groupoid (BG) ‚Ä¢(\mathbf{B}G)_\bullet has

  • (BG) 0=*(\mathbf{B}G)_0 = \ast;

  • (BG) 1=G(\mathbf{B}G)_1 = G.

For GG and KK two groups, group homomorphisms f:G‚ÜíKf \colon G \to K are in natural bijection with groupoid homomorphisms

(Bf) ‚Ä¢:(BG) ‚Ä¢‚Üí(BK) ‚Ä¢. (\mathbf{B}f)_\bullet \;\colon\; (\mathbf{B}G)_\bullet \to (\mathbf{B}K)_\bullet \,.

In particular a group character c:G‚ÜíU(1)c \colon G \to U(1) is equivalently a groupoid homomorphism

(Bc) ‚Ä¢:(BG) ‚Ä¢‚Üí(BU(1)) ‚Ä¢. (\mathbf{B}c)_\bullet \;\colon\; (\mathbf{B}G)_\bullet \to (\mathbf{B}U(1))_\bullet \,.

Here, for the time being, all groups are discrete groups. Since the circle group U(1)U(1) also has a standard structure of a Lie group, and since later for the discussion of Chern-Simons type theories this will be relevant, we will write from now on

‚ô≠U(1)‚ààGrp \flat U(1) \in Grp

to mean explicitly the discrete group underlying the circle group. (Here ‚Äú‚ô≠\flat‚Äù denotes the ‚Äúflat modality‚Äù.)

Example

For XX a set, GG a discrete group and œÅ:X√óG‚ÜíX\rho \colon X \times G \to X an action of GG on XX (a permutation representation), the action groupoid or homotopy quotient of XX by GG is the groupoid

X// œÅG=(X√óG‚ü∂p 1‚ü∂œÅX) X//_\rho G = \left( X \times G \stackrel{\overset{\rho}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{p_1}{\longrightarrow}} X \right)

with composition induced by the product in GG. Hence this is the groupoid whose objects are the elements of XX, and where morphisms are of the form

x 1‚Üígx 2=œÅ(x 1)(g) x_1 \stackrel{g}{\to} x_2 = \rho(x_1)(g)

for x 1,x 2‚ààXx_1, x_2 \in X, g‚ààGg \in G.

As an important special case we have:

Example

For GG a discrete group and œÅ\rho the trivial action of GG on the point *\ast (the singleton set), the corresponding action groupoid according to def. 52 is the delooping groupoid of GG according to def. 51:

(*//G) ‚Ä¢=(BG) ‚Ä¢. (\ast //G)_\bullet = (\mathbf{B}G)_\bullet \,.

Another canonical action is the action of GG on itself by right multiplication. The corresponding action groupoid we write

(EG) ‚Ä¢‚âîG//G. (\mathbf{E}G)_\bullet \coloneqq G//G \,.

The constant map G‚Üí*G \to \ast induces a canonical morphism

G//G ‚âÉ EG ‚Üì ‚Üì *//G ‚âÉ BG. \array{ G//G & \simeq & \mathbf{E}G \\ \downarrow && \downarrow \\ \ast //G & \simeq & \mathbf{B}G } \,.

This is known as the GG-universal principal bundle. See below in 59 for more on this.

Example

The interval II is the groupoid with

  • I 0={a,b}I_0 = \{a,b\};
  • I 1={id a,id b,a‚Üíb}I_1 = \{\mathrm{id}_a, \mathrm{id}_b, a \to b \}.
Example

For Œ£\Sigma a topological space, its fundamental groupoid Œ† 1(Œ£)\Pi_1(\Sigma) is

  • Œ† 1(Œ£) 0=\Pi_1(\Sigma)_0 = points in XX;
  • Œ† 1(Œ£) 1=\Pi_1(\Sigma)_1 = continuous paths in XX modulo homotopy that leaves the endpoints fixed.
Example

For ùí¢ ‚Ä¢\mathcal{G}_\bullet any groupoid, there is the path space groupoid ùí¢ ‚Ä¢ I\mathcal{G}^I_\bullet with

  • ùí¢ 0 I=ùí¢ 1={œï 0 ‚Üì k œï 1}\mathcal{G}^I_0 = \mathcal{G}_1 = \left\{ \array{ \phi_0 \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{k}} \\ \phi_1 } \right\};

  • ùí¢ 1 I=\mathcal{G}^I_1 = commuting squares in ùí¢ ‚Ä¢\mathcal{G}_\bullet = {œï 0 ‚Üíh 0 œïÀú 0 k‚Üì ‚Üì kÀú œï 1 ‚Üíh 1 œïÀú 1}. \left\{ \array{ \phi_0 &\stackrel{h_0}{\to}& \tilde \phi_0 \\ {}^{\mathllap{k}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\tilde k}} \\ \phi_1 &\stackrel{h_1}{\to}& \tilde \phi_1 } \right\} \,.

This comes with two canonical homomorphisms

ùí¢ ‚Ä¢ I‚ü∂ev 0‚ü∂ev 1ùí¢ ‚Ä¢ \mathcal{G}^I_\bullet \stackrel{\overset{ev_1}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{ev_0}{\longrightarrow}} \mathcal{G}_\bullet

which are given by endpoint evaluation, hence which send such a commuting square to either its top or its bottom hirizontal component.

Definition

For f ‚Ä¢,g ‚Ä¢:ùí¢ ‚Ä¢‚Üíùí¶ ‚Ä¢f_\bullet, g_\bullet : \mathcal{G}_\bullet \to \mathcal{K}_\bullet two morphisms between groupoids, a homotopy f‚áígf \Rightarrow g (a natural transformation) is a homomorphism of the form Œ∑ ‚Ä¢:ùí¢ ‚Ä¢‚Üíùí¶ ‚Ä¢ I\eta_\bullet : \mathcal{G}_\bullet \to \mathcal{K}^I_\bullet (with codomain the path space object of ùí¶ ‚Ä¢\mathcal{K}_\bullet as in example 56) such that it fits into the diagram as depicted here on the right:

‚Üó‚Üò f ‚Ä¢ ùí¢ ‚áì Œ∑ ùí¶ ‚Üò‚Üó g ‚Ä¢‚âî ùí¶ ‚Ä¢ f ‚Ä¢‚Üó ‚Üë (ev 1) ‚Ä¢ ùí¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚ÜíŒ∑ ‚Ä¢ ùí¶ ‚Ä¢ I g ‚Ä¢‚Üò ‚Üì (ev 0) ‚Ä¢ ùí¶. \array{ & \nearrow \searrow^{\mathrlap{f_\bullet}} \\ \mathcal{G} &\Downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta}}& \mathcal{K} \\ & \searrow \nearrow_{\mathrlap{g_\bullet}} } \;\;\;\; \coloneqq \;\;\;\; \array{ && \mathcal{K}_\bullet \\ & {}^{\mathllap{f_\bullet}}\nearrow & \uparrow^{\mathrlap{(ev_1)_\bullet}} \\ \mathcal{G}_\bullet &\stackrel{\eta_\bullet}{\to}& \mathcal{K}^I_\bullet \\ & {}_{\mathllap{g_\bullet}}\searrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(ev_0)_\bullet}} \\ && \mathcal{K} } \,.
Definition (Notation)

Here and in the following, the convention is that we write

  • ùí¢ ‚Ä¢\mathcal{G}_\bullet (with the subscript decoration) when we regard groupoids with just homomorphisms (functors) between them,

  • ùí¢\mathcal{G} (without the subscript decoration) when we regard groupoids with homomorphisms (functors) between them and homotopies (natural transformations) between these

    ‚Üó‚Üò f X ‚áì Y ‚Üò‚Üó g. \array{ & \nearrow \searrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ X &\Downarrow& Y \\ & \searrow \nearrow_{g} } \,.

The unbulleted version of groupoids are also called homotopy 1-types (or often just their homotopy-equivalence classes are called this way.) Below we generalize this to arbitrary homotopy types (def. \ref{KanComplexesAsHomotopyTypes}).

Example

For X,YX,Y two groupoids, the mapping groupoid [X,Y][X,Y] or Y XY^X is

  • [X,Y] 0=[X,Y]_0 = homomorphisms X‚ÜíYX \to Y;
  • [X,Y] 1=[X,Y]_1 = homotopies between such.
Definition

A (homotopy-) equivalence of groupoids is a morphism ùí¢‚Üíùí¶\mathcal{G} \to \mathcal{K} which has a left and right inverse up to homotopy.

Example

The map

B‚Ñ§‚ÜíŒ†(S 1) \mathbf{B}\mathbb{Z} \stackrel{}{\to} \Pi(S^1)

which picks any point and sends n‚àà‚Ñ§n \in \mathbb{Z} to the loop based at that point which winds around nn times, is an equivalence of groupoids.

Proposition

Assuming the axiom of choice in the ambient set theory, every groupoid is equivalent to a disjoint union of delooping groupoids, example 51 ‚Äì a skeleton.

Remark

The statement of prop. 56 becomes false as when we pass to groupoids that are equipped with geometric structure. This is the reason why for discrete geometry all Chern-Simons-type field theories (namely Dijkgraaf-Witten theory-type theories) fundamentally involve just groups (and higher groups), while for nontrivial geometry there are genuine groupoid theories, for instance the AKSZ sigma-models. But even so, Dijkgraaf-Witten theory is usefully discussed in terms of groupoid technology, in particular since the choice of equivalence in prop. 56 is not canonical.

Definition

Given two morphisms of groupoids X‚ÜífB‚ÜêgYX \stackrel{f}{\rightarrow} B \stackrel{g}{\leftarrow} Y their homotopy fiber product

X√óBY ‚Üí X ‚Üì ‚áô ‚Üì f Y ‚Üíg B \array{ X \underset{B}{\times} Y &\stackrel{}{\to}& X \\ \downarrow &\swArrow& \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ Y &\underset{g}{\to}& B }

is the limit cone

X ‚Ä¢√óB ‚Ä¢B ‚Ä¢ I√óB ‚Ä¢Y ‚Ä¢ ‚Üí ‚Üí X ‚Ä¢ ‚Üì ‚Üì f ‚Ä¢ B ‚Ä¢ I ‚Üí(ev 0) ‚Ä¢ B ‚Ä¢ ‚Üì ‚Üì (ev 1) ‚Ä¢ Y ‚Ä¢ ‚Üíg ‚Ä¢ B ‚Ä¢, \array{ X_\bullet \underset{B_\bullet}{\times} B^I_\bullet \underset{B_\bullet}{\times} Y_\bullet &\to& &\to& X_\bullet \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{f_\bullet}} \\ && B^I_\bullet &\underset{(ev_0)_\bullet}{\to}& B_\bullet \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(ev_1)_\bullet}} \\ Y_\bullet &\underset{g_\bullet}{\to}& B_\bullet } \,,

hence the ordinary iterated fiber product over the path space groupoid, as indicated.

Remark

An ordinary fiber product X ‚Ä¢√óB ‚Ä¢Y ‚Ä¢X_\bullet \underset{B_\bullet}{\times}Y_\bullet of groupoids is given simply by the fiber product of the underlying sets of objects and morphisms:

(X ‚Ä¢√óB ‚Ä¢Y ‚Ä¢) i=X i√óB iY i. (X_\bullet \underset{B_\bullet}{\times}Y_\bullet)_i = X_i \underset{B_i}{\times} Y_i \,.
Example

For XX a groupoid, GG a group and X‚ÜíBGX \to \mathbf{B}G a map into its delooping, the pullback P‚ÜíXP \to X of the GG-universal principal bundle of example 53 is equivalently the homotopy fiber product of XX with the point over BG\mathbf{B}G:

P‚âÉX√óBG*. P \simeq X \underset{\mathbf{B}G}{\times} \ast \,.

Namely both squares in the following diagram are pullback squares

P ‚Üí EG ‚Üí * ‚Ä¢ ‚Üì ‚Üì (BG) ‚Ä¢ I ‚Üí(ev 0) ‚Ä¢ (BG) ‚Ä¢ ‚Üì ‚Üì (ev 1) ‚Ä¢ X ‚Ä¢ ‚Üí (BG) ‚Ä¢. \array{ P &\to& \mathbf{E}G &\to& \ast_\bullet \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ && (\mathbf{B}G)^I_\bullet &\underset{(ev_0)_\bullet}{\to}& (\mathbf{B}G)_\bullet \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(ev_1)_\bullet}} \\ X_\bullet &\underset{}{\to}& (\mathbf{B}G)_\bullet } \,.

(This is the first example of the more general phenomenon of universal principal infinity-bundles.)

Example

For XX a groupoid and *‚ÜíX\ast \to X a point in it, we call

Œ©X‚âî*√óX* \Omega X \coloneqq \ast \underset{X}{\times} \ast

the loop space groupoid of XX.

For GG a group and BG\mathbf{B}G its delooping groupoid from example 51, we have

G‚âÉŒ©BG=*√óBG*. G \simeq \Omega \mathbf{B}G = \ast \underset{\mathbf{B}G}{\times} \ast \,.

Hence GG is the loop space object of its own delooping, as it should be.

Proof

We are to compute the ordinary limiting cone *√óBG ‚Ä¢(BG I) ‚Ä¢√óBG ‚Ä¢*\ast \underset{\mathbf{B}G_\bullet}{\times} (\mathbf{B}G^I)_\bullet \underset{\mathbf{B}G_\bullet}{\times} \ast in

‚Üí ‚Üí * ‚Üì ‚Üì (BG) ‚Ä¢ I ‚Üí(ev 0) ‚Ä¢ BG ‚Ä¢ ‚Üì ‚Üì (ev 1) ‚Ä¢ * ‚Üí BG ‚Ä¢, \array{ &\to& &\to& \ast \\ \downarrow && && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{}} \\ && (\mathbf{B}G)^I_\bullet &\underset{(ev_0)_\bullet}{\to}& \mathbf{B}G_\bullet \\ \downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(ev_1)_\bullet}} \\ \ast &\underset{}{\to}& \mathbf{B}G_\bullet } \,,

In the middle we have the groupoid (BG) ‚Ä¢ I(\mathbf{B}G)^I_\bullet whose objects are elements of GG and whose morphisms starting at some element are labeled by pairs of elements h 1,h 2‚ààGh_1, h_2 \in G and end at h 1‚ãÖg‚ãÖh 2h_1 \cdot g \cdot h_2. Using remark 41 the limiting cone is seen to precisely pick those morphisms in (BG ‚Ä¢) ‚Ä¢ I(\mathbf{B}G_\bullet)^I_\bullet such that these two elements are constant on the neutral element h 1=h 2=e=id *h_1 = h_2 = e = id_{\ast}, hence it produces just the elements of GG regarded as a groupoid with only identity morphisms, as in example 50.

Proposition

The free loop space object is

[Œ†(S 1),X]‚âÉX√ó[Œ†(S 0),X]X [\Pi(S^1), X] \simeq X \underset{[\Pi(S^0), X]}{\times}X
Proof

Notice that Œ† 1(S 0)‚âÉ*‚àê*\Pi_1(S^0) \simeq \ast \coprod \ast. Therefore the path space object [Œ†(S 0),X ‚Ä¢] ‚Ä¢ I[\Pi(S^0), X_\bullet]^I_\bullet has

  • objects are pairs of morphisms in X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet;

  • morphisms are commuting squares of such.

Now the fiber product in def. 81 picks in there those pairs of morphisms for which both start at the same object, and both end at the same object. Therefore X ‚Ä¢√ó[Œ†(S 0),X ‚Ä¢] ‚Ä¢[Œ†(S 0),X ‚Ä¢] ‚Ä¢ I√ó[Œ†(S 0),X ‚Ä¢] ‚Ä¢XX_\bullet \underset{[\Pi(S^0), X_\bullet]_\bullet}{\times} [\Pi(S^0), X_\bullet]^I_\bullet \underset{[\Pi(S^0), X_\bullet]_\bullet}{\times} X is the groupoid whose

  • objects are diagrams in X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet of the form

    ‚Üó‚Üò x 0 x 1 ‚Üò‚Üó \array{ & \nearrow \searrow \\ x_0 && x_1 \\ & \searrow \nearrow }

  • morphism are cylinder-diagrams over these.

One finds along the lines of example 58 that this is equivalent to maps from Œ† 1(S 1)\Pi_1(S^1) into X ‚Ä¢X_\bullet and homotopies between these.

Remark

Even though all these models of the circle Œ† 1(S 1)\Pi_1(S^1) are equivalent, below the special appearance of the circle in the proof of prop. 57 as the combination of two semi-circles will be important for the following proofs. As we see in a moment, this is the natural way in which the circle appears as the composition of an evaluation map with a coevaluation map.

Example

For GG a discrete group, the free loop space object of its delooping BG\mathbf{B}G is G// adGG//_{ad} G, the action groupoid, def. 52, of the adjoint action of GG on itself:

[Œ†(S 1),BG]‚âÉG// adG. [\Pi(S^1), \mathbf{B}G] \simeq G//_{ad} G \,.
Example

For an abelian group such as ‚ô≠U(1)\flat U(1) we have

[Œ†(S 1),B‚ô≠U(1)]‚âÉ‚ô≠U(1)// ad‚ô≠U(1)‚âÉ(‚ô≠U(1))√ó(B‚ô≠U(1)). [\Pi(S^1), \mathbf{B}\flat U(1)] \simeq \flat U(1)//_{ad} \flat U(1) \simeq (\flat U(1)) \times (\mathbf{B}\flat U(1)) \,.
Example

Let c:G‚Üí‚ô≠U(1)c \colon G \to \flat U(1) be a group homomorphism, hence a group character. By example 51 this has a delooping to a groupoid homomorphism

Bc:BG‚ÜíB‚ô≠U(1). \mathbf{B}c \;\colon\; \mathbf{B}G \to \mathbf{B}\flat U(1) \,.

Under the free loop space object construction this becomes

[Œ†(S 1),Bc]:[Œ†(S 1),BG]‚Üí[Œ†(S 1),B‚ô≠U(1)] [\Pi(S^1), \mathbf{B}c] \;\colon\; [\Pi(S^1), \mathbf{B}G] \to [\Pi(S^1), \mathbf{B}\flat U(1)]

hence

[Œ†(S 1),Bc]:G// adG‚Üí‚ô≠U(1)√óBU(1). [\Pi(S^1), \mathbf{B}c] \;\colon\; G//_{ad}G \to \flat U(1) \times \mathbf{B}U(1) \,.

So by postcomposing with the projection on the first factor we recover from the general homotopy theory of groupoids the statement that a group character is a class function on conjugacy classes:

[Œ†(S 1),Bc]:G// adG‚ÜíU(1). [\Pi(S^1), \mathbf{B}c] \;\colon\; G//_{ad}G \to U(1) \,.

\,

Definition

For ùí¢ ‚Ä¢\mathcal{G}_\bullet a groupoid, def. 77, its simplicial nerve N(ùí¢ ‚Ä¢) ‚Ä¢N(\mathcal{G}_\bullet)_\bullet is the simplicial set with

N(ùí¢ ‚Ä¢) n‚âîùí¢ 1 √ó ùí¢ 0 n N(\mathcal{G}_\bullet)_n \coloneqq \mathcal{G}_1^{\times_{\mathcal{G}_0}^n}

the set of sequences of composable morphisms of length nn, for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N};

with face maps

d k:N(ùí¢ ‚Ä¢) n+1‚ÜíN(ùí¢ ‚Ä¢) n d_k \colon N(\mathcal{G}_\bullet)_{n+1} \to N(\mathcal{G}_\bullet)_{n}

being,

  • for n=0n = 0 the functions that remembers the kkth object;

  • for n‚â•1n \geq 1

    • the two outer face maps d 0d_0 and d nd_n are given by forgetting the first and the last morphism in such a sequence, respectively;

    • the n‚àí1n-1 inner face maps d 0<k<nd_{0 \lt k \lt n} are given by composing the kkth morphism with the k+1k+1st in the sequence.

The degeneracy maps

s k:N(ùí¢ ‚Ä¢)n‚ÜíN(ùí¢ ‚Ä¢) n+1. s_k \colon N(\mathcal{G}_\bullet)n \to N(\mathcal{G}_\bullet)_{n+1} \,.

are given by inserting an identity morphism on x kx_k.

Remark

Spelling this out in more detail: write

ùí¢ n={x 0‚Üíf 0,1x 1‚Üíf 1,2x 2‚Üíf 2,3‚ãØ‚Üíf n‚àí1,nx n} \mathcal{G}_n = \left\{ x_0 \stackrel{f_{0,1}}{\to} x_1 \stackrel{f_{1,2}}{\to} x_2 \stackrel{f_{2,3}}{\to} \cdots \stackrel{f_{n-1,n}}{\to} x_n \right\}

for the set of sequences of nn composable morphisms. Given any element of this set and 0<k<n0 \lt k \lt n , write

f i‚àí1,i+1‚âîf i,i+1‚àòf i‚àí1,i f_{i-1,i+1} \coloneqq f_{i,i+1} \circ f_{i-1,i}

for the comosition of the two morphism that share the iith vertex.

With this, face map d kd_k acts simply by ‚Äúremoving the index kk‚Äù:

d 0:(x 0‚Üíf 0,1x 1‚Üíf 1,2x 2‚ãØ‚Üíf n‚àí1,nx n)‚Ü¶(x 1‚Üíf 1,2x 2‚ãØ‚Üíf n‚àí1,nx n) d_0 \colon (x_0 \stackrel{f_{0,1}}{\to} x_1 \stackrel{f_{1,2}}{\to} x_{2} \cdots \stackrel{f_{n-1,n}}{\to} x_n ) \mapsto (x_1 \stackrel{f_{1,2}}{\to} x_{2} \cdots \stackrel{f_{n-1,n}}{\to} x_n )
d 0<k<n:(x 0‚ãØ‚Üíx k‚àí1‚Üíf k‚àí1,kx k‚Üíf k,k+1x k+1‚Üí‚ãØx n)‚Ü¶(x 0‚ãØ‚Üíx k‚àí1‚Üíf k‚àí1,k+1x k+1‚Üí‚ãØx n) d_{0\lt k \lt n} \colon ( x_0 \cdots \stackrel{}{\to} x_{k-1} \stackrel{f_{k-1,k}}{\to} x_k \stackrel{f_{k,k+1}}{\to} x_{k+1} \stackrel{}{\to} \cdots x_n ) \mapsto ( x_0 \cdots \stackrel{}{\to} x_{k-1} \stackrel{f_{k-1,k+1}}{\to} x_{k+1} \stackrel{}{\to} \cdots x_n )
d n:(x 0‚Üíf 0,1‚ãØ‚Üíf n‚àí2,n‚àí1x n‚àí1‚Üíf n‚àí1,nx n)‚Ü¶(x 0‚Üíf 0,1‚ãØ‚Üíf n‚àí2,n‚àí1x n‚àí1). d_n \colon ( x_0 \stackrel{f_{0,1}}{\to} \cdots \stackrel{f_{n-2,n-1}}{\to} x_{n-1} \stackrel{f_{n-1,n}}{\to} x_n ) \mapsto ( x_0 \stackrel{f_{0,1}}{\to} \cdots \stackrel{f_{n-2,n-1}}{\to} x_{n-1} ) \,.

Similarly, writing

f k,k‚âîid x k f_{k,k} \coloneqq id_{x_k}

for the identity morphism on the object x kx_k, then the degenarcy map acts by ‚Äúrepeating the kkth index‚Äù

s k:(x 0‚Üí‚ãØ‚Üíx k‚Üíf k,k+1x k+1‚Üí‚ãØ)‚Ü¶(x 0‚Üí‚ãØ‚Üíx k‚Üíf k,kx k‚Üíf k,k+1x k+1‚Üí‚ãØ). s_k \colon ( x_0 \stackrel{}{\to} \cdots \to x_k \stackrel{f_{k,k+1}}{\to} x_{k+1} \to \cdots ) \mapsto ( x_0 \stackrel{}{\to} \cdots \to x_k \stackrel{f_{k,k}}{\to} x_k \stackrel{f_{k,k+1}}{\to} x_{k+1} \to \cdots ) \,.

This makes it manifest that these functions organise into a simplicial set.

Proposition

These collections of maps in def. 82 satisfy the simplicial identities, hence make the nerve ùí¢ ‚Ä¢\mathcal{G}_\bullet into a simplicial set. Moreover, this simplicial set is a Kan complex, where each horn has a unique filler (extension to a simplex).

(A 2-coskeletal Kan complex.)

Proposition

The nerve operation constitutes a full and faithful functor

N:Grpd‚ÜíKanCplx‚Ü™sSet. N \colon Grpd \to KanCplx \hookrightarrow sSet \,.

Chain complexes as Kan complexes

In the familiar construction of singular homology recalled above one constructs the alternating face map chain complex of the simplicial abelian group of singular simplices, def. \ref{ComplexOfChainsOnASimplicialSet}. This construction is natural and straightforward, but the result chain complex tends to be very ‚Äúlarge‚Äù even if its chain homology groups end up being very ‚Äúsmall‚Äù. But in the context of homotopy theory one is to consider all objects notup to isomorphism, but of to weak equivalence, which for chain complexes means up to quasi-isomorphisms. Hence one should look for the natural construction of ‚Äúsmaller‚Äù chain complexes that are still quasi-isomorphic to these alternating face map complexes. This is accomplished by the normalized chain complex construction:

Definition

For AA a simplicial abelian group its alternating face map complex (CA) ‚Ä¢(C A)_\bullet of AA is the chain complex which

  • in degree nn is given by the group A nA_n itself

    (CA) n:=A n (C A)_n := A_n

  • with differential given by the alternating sum of face maps (using the abelian group structure on AA)

    ‚àÇ n‚âî‚àë i=0 n(‚àí1) id i:(CA) n‚Üí(CA) n‚àí1. \partial_n \coloneqq \sum_{i = 0}^n (-1)^i d_i \;\colon\; (C A)_n \to (C A)_{n-1} \,.
Lemma

The differential in def. 83 is well-defined in that it indeed squares to 0.

Proof

Using the simplicial identity, prop. \ref{SimplicialIdentities}, d i‚àòd j=d j‚àí1‚àòd id_i \circ d_j = d_{j-1} \circ d_i for i<ji \lt j one finds:

‚àÇ n‚àÇ n+1 =‚àë i,j(‚àí1) i+jd i‚àòd j =‚àë i‚â•j(‚àí1) i+jd i‚àòd j+‚àë i<j(‚àí1) i+jd i‚àòd j =‚àë i‚â•j(‚àí1) i+jd i‚àòd j+‚àë i<j(‚àí1) i+jd j‚àí1‚àòd i =‚àë i‚â•j(‚àí1) i+jd i‚àòd j‚àí‚àë i‚â§k(‚àí1) i+kd k‚àòd i =0. \begin{aligned} \partial_n \partial_{n+1} & = \sum_{i, j} (-1)^{i+j} d_i \circ d_{j} \\ &= \sum_{i \geq j} (-1)^{i+j} d_i \circ d_j + \sum_{i \lt j} (-1)^{i+j} d_i \circ d_j \\ &= \sum_{i \geq j} (-1)^{i+j} d_i \circ d_j + \sum_{i \lt j} (-1)^{i+j} d_{j-1} \circ d_i \\ &= \sum_{i \geq j} (-1)^{i+j} d_i \circ d_j - \sum_{i \leq k} (-1)^{i+k} d_{k} \circ d_i \\ &= 0 \end{aligned} \,.
Definition

Given a simplicial abelian group AA, its normalized chain complex or Moore complex is the ‚Ñï\mathbb{N}-graded chain complex ((NA) ‚Ä¢,‚àÇ)((N A)_\bullet,\partial ) which

  • is in degree nn the joint kernel

    (NA) n=‚ãÇ i=1 nkerd i n (N A)_n=\bigcap_{i=1}^{n}ker\,d_i^n

    of all face maps except the 0-face;

  • with differential given by the remaining 0-face map

    ‚àÇ n:=d 0 n| (NA) n:(NA) n‚Üí(NA) n‚àí1. \partial_n := d_0^n|_{(N A)_n} : (N A)_n \rightarrow (N A)_{n-1} \,.
Remark

We may think of the elements of the complex NAN A, def. 84, in degree kk as being kk-dimensional disks in AA all whose boundary is captured by a single face:

  • an element g‚ààNG 1g \in N G_1 in degree 1 is a 1-disk

    1‚Üíg‚àÇg, 1 \stackrel{g}{\to} \partial g \,,

  • an element h‚ààNG 2h \in N G_2 is a 2-disk

    1 1‚Üó ‚áì h ‚Üò ‚àÇh 1 ‚Üí1 1, \array{ && 1 \\ & {}^1\nearrow &\Downarrow^h& \searrow^{\partial h} \\ 1 &&\stackrel{1}{\to}&& 1 } \,,

  • a degree 2 element in the kernel of the boundary map is such a 2-disk that is closed to a 2-sphere

    1 1‚Üó ‚áì h ‚Üò ‚àÇh=1 1 ‚Üí1 1, \array{ && 1 \\ & {}^1\nearrow &\Downarrow^h& \searrow^{\partial h = 1} \\ 1 &&\stackrel{1}{\to}&& 1 } \,,

etc.

Definition

Given a simplicial group AA (or in fact any simplicial set), then an element a‚ààA n+1a \in A_{n+1} is called degenerate (or thin) if it is in the image of one of the simplicial degeneracy maps s i:A n‚ÜíA n+1s_i \colon A_n \to A_{n+1}. All elements of A 0A_0 are regarded a non-degenerate. Write

D(A n+1)‚âî‚ü®‚à™ is i(A n)‚ü©‚Ü™A n+1 D (A_{n+1}) \coloneqq \langle \cup_i s_i(A_{n}) \rangle \hookrightarrow A_{n+1}

for the subgroup of A n+1A_{n+1} which is generated by the degenerate elements (i.e. the smallest subgroup containing all the degenerate elements).

Definition

For AA a simplicial abelian group its alternating face maps chain complex modulo degeneracies, (CA)/(DA)(C A)/(D A) is the chain complex

  • which in degree 0 equals is just ((CA)/D(A)) 0‚âîA 0((C A)/D(A))_0 \coloneqq A_0;

  • which in degree n+1n+1 is the quotient group obtained by dividing out the group of degenerate elements, def. 85:

    ((CA)/D(A)) n+1:=A n+1/D(A n+1) ((C A)/D(A))_{n+1} := A_{n+1} / D(A_{n+1})

  • whose differential is the induced action of the alternating sum of faces on the quotient (which is well-defined by lemma 30).

Lemma

Def. 86 is indeed well defined in that the alternating face map differential respects the degenerate subcomplex.

Proof

Using the mixed simplicial identities we find that for s j(a)‚ààA ns_j(a) \in A_n a degenerate element, its boundary is

‚àë i(‚àí1) id is j(a) =‚àë i<j(‚àí1) is j‚àí1d i(a)+‚àë i=j,j+1(‚àí1) ia+‚àë i>j+1(‚àí1) is jd i‚àí1(a) =‚àë i<j(‚àí1) is j‚àí1d i(a)+‚àë i>j+1(‚àí1) is jd i‚àí1(a) \begin{aligned} \sum_i (-1)^i d_i s_j(a) &= \sum_{i \lt j} (-1)^i s_{j-1} d_i(a) + \sum_{i = j, j+1} (-1)^i a + \sum_{i \gt j+1} (-1)^i s_j d_{i-1}(a) \\ &= \sum_{i \lt j} (-1)^i s_{j-1} d_i(a) + \sum_{i \gt j+1} (-1)^i s_j d_{i-1}(a) \end{aligned}

which is again a combination of elements in the image of the degeneracy maps.

Proposition

Given a simplicial abelian group AA, the evident composite of natural morphisms

NA‚Ü™iA‚Üíp(CA)/(DA) N A \stackrel{i}{\hookrightarrow} A \stackrel{p}{\to} (C A)/(D A)

from the normalized chain complex, def. 84, into the alternating face map complex modulo degeneracies, def. 86, (inclusion followed by projection to the quotient) is a natural isomorphism of chain complexes.

e.g. (Goerss-Jardine, theorem III 2.1).

Corollary

For AA a simplicial abelian group, there is a splitting

C ‚Ä¢(A)‚âÉN ‚Ä¢(A)‚äïD ‚Ä¢(A) C_\bullet(A) \simeq N_\bullet(A) \oplus D_\bullet(A)

of the alternating face map complex, def. 83 as a direct sum, where the first direct summand is naturally isomorphic to the normalized chain complex of def. 84 and the second is the degenerate cells from def. 86.

Proof

By prop. 60 there is an inverse to the diagonal composite in

CA ‚ü∂p (CA)/(DA) i‚Üë ‚Üó NA. \array{ C A &\stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow}& (C A)/(D A) \\ {}^{\mathllap{i}}\uparrow & \nearrow \\ N A } \,.

This hence exhibits a splitting of the short exact sequence given by the quotient by DAD A.

0 ‚Üí DA ‚Ü™ CA ‚ü∂p (CA)/(DA) ‚Üí 0 i‚Üë ‚Üô ‚âÉ iso NA. \array{ 0 &\to& D A &\hookrightarrow & C A &\stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow}& (C A)/(D A) &\to & 0 \\ && && {}^{\mathllap{i}}\uparrow & \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\simeq}_{iso}} \\ && && N A } \,.
Theorem (Eilenberg-MacLane)

Given a simplicial abelian group AA, then the inclusion

NA‚Ü™CA N A \hookrightarrow C A

of the normalized chain complex, def. 84 into the full alternating face map complex, def. 83, is a natural quasi-isomorphism and in fact a natural chain homotopy equivalence, i.e. the complex D ‚Ä¢(X)D_\bullet(X) is null-homotopic.

(Goerss-Jardine, theorem III 2.4)

Corollary

Given a simplicial abelian group AA, then the projection chain map

(CA)‚ü∂(CA)/(DA) (C A) \longrightarrow (C A)/(D A)

from its alternating face maps complex, def. 83, to the alternating face map complex modulo degeneracies, def. 86, is a quasi-isomorphism.

Proof

Consider the pre-composition of the map with the inclusion of the normalized chain complex, def. 84.

CA ‚ü∂p (CA)/(DA) i‚Üë ‚Üó NA \array{ C A &\stackrel{p}{\longrightarrow}& (C A)/(D A) \\ {}^{\mathllap{i}}\uparrow & \nearrow \\ N A }

By theorem 6 the vertical map is a quasi-isomorphism and by prop. 60 the composite diagonal map is an isomorphism, hence in particular also a quasi-isomorphism. Since quasi-isomorphisms satisfy the two-out-of-three property, it follows that also the map in question is a quasi-isomorphism.

Example

Consider the 1-simplex Œî[1]\Delta[1] regarded as a simplicial set, and write ‚Ñ§[Œî[1]]\mathbb{Z}[\Delta[1]] for the simplicial abelian group which in each degree is the free abelian group on the simplices in Œî[1]\Delta[1].

This simplicial abelian group starts out as

‚Ñ§[Œî[1]]=(‚ãØ‚ü∂‚ü∂‚ü∂‚ü∂‚Ñ§ 4‚ü∂‚ü∂‚ü∂‚Ñ§ 3‚ü∂‚àÇ 1‚ü∂‚àÇ 0‚Ñ§ 2) \mathbb{Z}[\Delta[1]] = \left( \cdots \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow}}} \mathbb{Z}^4 \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\stackrel{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow}} \mathbb{Z}^3 \stackrel{\overset{\partial_0}{\longrightarrow}}{\underset{\partial_1}{\longrightarrow}} \mathbb{Z}^2 \right)

(where we are indicating only the face maps for notational simplicity).

Here the first ‚Ñ§ 2=‚Ñ§‚äï‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}^2 = \mathbb{Z}\oplus \mathbb{Z}, the direct sum of two copies of the integers, is the group of 0-chains generated from the two endpoints (0)(0) and (1)(1) of Œî[1]\Delta[1], i.e. the abelian group of formal linear combinations of the form

‚Ñ§ 2‚âÉ{a‚ãÖ(0)+b‚ãÖ(1)|a,b‚àà‚Ñ§}. \mathbb{Z}^2 \simeq \left\{ a \cdot (0) + b \cdot (1) | a,b \in \mathbb{Z}\right\} \,.

The second ‚Ñ§ 3‚âÉ‚Ñ§‚äï‚Ñ§‚äï‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}^3 \simeq \mathbb{Z}\oplus \mathbb{Z}\oplus \mathbb{Z} is the abelian group generated from the three (!) 1-simplicies in Œî[1]\Delta[1], namely the non-degenerate edge (0‚Üí1)(0\to 1) and the two degenerate cells (0‚Üí0)(0 \to 0) and (1‚Üí1)(1 \to 1), hence the abelian group of formal linear combinations of the form

‚Ñ§ 3‚âÉ{a‚ãÖ(0‚Üí0)+b‚ãÖ(0‚Üí1)+c‚ãÖ(1‚Üí1)|a,b,c‚àà‚Ñ§}. \mathbb{Z}^3 \simeq \left\{ a \cdot (0\to 0) + b \cdot (0 \to 1) + c \cdot (1 \to 1) | a,b,c \in \mathbb{Z}\right\} \,.

The two face maps act on the basis 1-cells as

‚àÇ 1:(i‚Üíj)‚Ü¶(i) \partial_1 \colon (i \to j) \mapsto (i)
‚àÇ 0:(i‚Üíj)‚Ü¶(j). \partial_0 \colon (i \to j) \mapsto (j) \,.

Now of course most of the (infinitely!) many simplices inside Œî[1]\Delta[1] are degenerate. In fact the only non-degenerate simplices are the two 0-cells (0)(0) and (1)(1) and the 1-cell (0‚Üí1)(0 \to 1). Hence the alternating face maps complex modulo degeneracies, def. 86, of ‚Ñ§[Œî[1]]\mathbb{Z}[\Delta[1]] is simply this:

(C(‚Ñ§[Œî[1]]))/D(‚Ñ§[Œî[1]]))=(‚ãØ‚Üí0‚Üí0‚Üí‚Ñ§‚ü∂(1‚àí1)‚Ñ§ 2). (C (\mathbb{Z}[\Delta[1]])) / D (\mathbb{Z}[\Delta[1]])) = \left( \cdots \to 0 \to 0 \to \mathbb{Z} \stackrel{\left(1 \atop -1\right)}{\longrightarrow} \mathbb{Z}^2 \right) \,.

Notice that alternatively we could consider the topological 1-simplex Œî 1=[0,1]\Delta^1 = [0,1] and its singular simplicial complex Sing(Œî 1)Sing(\Delta^1) in place of the smaller Œî[1]\Delta[1], then the free simplicial abelian group ‚Ñ§(Sing(Œî 1))\mathbb{Z}(Sing(\Delta^1)) of that. The corresponding alternating face map chain complex C(‚Ñ§(Sing(Œî 1)))C(\mathbb{Z}(Sing(\Delta^1))) is ‚Äúhuge‚Äù in that in each positive degree it has a free abelian group on uncountably many generators. Quotienting out the degenerate cells still leaves uncountably many generators in each positive degree (while every singular nn-simplex in [0,1][0,1] is ‚Äúthin‚Äù, only those whose parameterization is as induced by a degeneracy map are actually regarded as degenerate cells here). Hence even after normalization the singular simplicial chain complex is ‚Äúhuge‚Äù. Nevertheless it is quasi-isomorphic to the tiny chain complex found above.

The statement of the Dold-Kan correspondence now is the following.

Theorem

For AA an abelian category there is an equivalence of categories

N:A Œî op‚Üí‚ÜêCh ‚Ä¢ +(A):Œì N \;\colon\; A^{\Delta^{op}} \stackrel{\leftarrow}{\to} Ch_\bullet^+(A) \;\colon\; \Gamma

between

  • the category of simplicial objects in AA;

  • the category of connective chain complexes in AA;

where

  • NN is the normalized chains complex/normalized Moore complex functor.

(Dold 58, Kan 58, Dold-Puppe 61).

Theorem (Kan)

For the case that AA is the category Ab of abelian groups, the functors NN and Œì\Gamma are nerve and realization with respect to the cosimplicial chain complex

‚Ñ§[‚àí]:Œî‚ÜíCh +(Ab) \mathbb{Z}[-]: \Delta \to Ch_+(Ab)

that sends the standard nn-simplex to the normalized Moore complex of the free simplicial abelian group F ‚Ñ§(Œî n)F_{\mathbb{Z}}(\Delta^n) on the simplicial set Œî n\Delta^n, i.e.

Œì(V):[k]‚Ü¶Hom Ch ‚Ä¢ +(Ab)(N(‚Ñ§(Œî[k])),V). \Gamma(V) : [k] \mapsto Hom_{Ch_\bullet^+(Ab)}(N(\mathbb{Z}(\Delta[k])), V) \,.

This is due to (Kan 58).

More explicitly we have the following

Proposition

  • For V‚ààCh ‚Ä¢ +V \in Ch_\bullet^+ the simplicial abelian group Œì(V)\Gamma(V) is in degree nn given by

    Œì(V) n=‚®Å [n]‚Üísurj[k]V k \Gamma(V)_n = \bigoplus_{[n] \underset{surj}{\to} [k]} V_k

    and for Œ∏:[m]‚Üí[n]\theta : [m] \to [n] a morphism in Œî\Delta the corresponding map Œì(V) n‚ÜíŒì(V) m\Gamma(V)_n \to \Gamma(V)_m

    Œ∏ *:‚®Å [n]‚Üísurj[k]V k‚Üí‚®Å [m]‚Üísurj[r]V r \theta^* : \bigoplus_{[n] \underset{surj}{\to} [k]} V_k \to \bigoplus_{[m] \underset{surj}{\to} [r]} V_r

    is given on the summand indexed by some œÉ:[n]‚Üí[k]\sigma : [n] \to [k] by the composite

    V k‚Üíd *V s‚Ü™‚®Å [m]‚Üísurj[r]V r V_k \stackrel{d^*}{\to} V_s \hookrightarrow \bigoplus_{[m] \underset{surj}{\to} [r]} V_r

    where

    [m]‚Üít[s]‚Üíd[k] [m] \stackrel{t}{\to} [s] \stackrel{d}{\to} [k]

    is the epi-mono factorization of the composite [m]‚ÜíŒ∏[n]‚ÜíœÉ[k][m] \stackrel{\theta}{\to} [n] \stackrel{\sigma}{\to} [k].

  • The natural isomorphism ŒìN‚ÜíId\Gamma N \to Id is given on A‚ààsAb Œî opA \in sAb^{\Delta^{op}} by the map

    ‚®Å [n]‚Üísurj[k](NA) k‚ÜíA n \bigoplus_{[n] \underset{surj}{\to} [k]} (N A)_k \to A_n

    which on the direct summand indexed by œÉ:[n]‚Üí[k]\sigma : [n] \to [k] is the composite

    NA k‚Ü™A k‚ÜíœÉ *A n. N A_k \hookrightarrow A_k \stackrel{\sigma^*}{\to} A_n \,.

  • The natural isomorphism Id‚ÜíNŒìId \to N \Gamma is on a chain complex VV given by the composite of the projection

    V‚ÜíC(Œì(V))‚ÜíC(Œì(C))/D(Œì(V)) V \to C(\Gamma(V)) \to C(\Gamma(C))/D(\Gamma(V))

    with the inverse

    C(Œì(V))/D(Œì(V))‚ÜíNŒì(V) C(\Gamma(V))/D(\Gamma(V)) \to N \Gamma(V)

    of

    NŒì(V)‚Ü™C(Œì(V))‚ÜíC(Œì(V))/D(Œì(V)) N \Gamma(V) \hookrightarrow C(\Gamma(V)) \to C(\Gamma(V))/D(\Gamma(V))

    (which is indeed an isomorphism, as discussed at Moore complex).

This is spelled out in (Goerss-Jardine, prop. 2.2 in section III.2).

Proposition

With the explicit choice for ŒìN‚Üí‚âÉId\Gamma N \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} Id as above we have that Œì\Gamma and NN form an adjoint equivalence (Œì‚ä£N)(\Gamma \dashv N)

This is for instance (Weibel, exercise 8.4.2).

Remark

It follows that with the inverse structure maps, we also have an adjunction the other way round: (N‚ä£Œì)(N \dashv \Gamma).

Hence in conclusion the Dold-Kan correspondence allows us to regard chain complexes (in non-negative degree) as, in particular, special simplicial sets. In fact as simplicial sets they are Kan complexes and hence infinity-groupoids:

Theorem (J. C. Moore)

The simplicial set underlying any simplicial group (by forgetting the group structure) is a Kan complex.

This is due to (Moore, 1954)

In fact, not only are the horn fillers guaranteed to exist, but there is an algorithm that provides explicit fillers. This implies that constructions on a simplicial group that use fillers of horns can often be adjusted to be functorial by using the algorithmically defined fillers. An argument that just uses ‚Äòexistence‚Äô of fillers can be refined to give something more ‚Äòcoherent‚Äô.

Proof

Let GG be a simplicial group.

Here is the explicit algorithm that computes the horn fillers:

Let (y 0,‚Ä¶,y k‚àí1,‚àí,y k+1,‚Ä¶,y n)(y_0,\ldots, y_{k-1}, -,y_{k+1}, \ldots, y_n) give a horn in G n‚àí1G_{n-1}, so the y iy_is are (n‚àí1)(n-1) simplices that fit together as if they were all but one, the k thk^{th} one, of the faces of an nn-simplex. There are three cases:

  1. if k=0k = 0:

    • Let w n=s n‚àí1y nw_n = s_{n-1}y_n and then w i=w i+1(s i‚àí1d iw i+1) ‚àí1s i‚àí1y iw_i = w_{i+1}(s_{i-1}d_i w_{i+1})^{-1}s_{i-1}y_i for i=n,‚Ä¶,1i = n, \ldots, 1, then w 1w_1 satisfies d iw 1=y id_i w_1 = y_i, i‚â†0i\neq 0;

  2. if 0<k<n0\lt k \lt n:

    • Let w 0=s 0y 0w_0 = s_0 y_0 and w i=w i‚àí1(s id iw i‚àí1) ‚àí1s iy iw_i = w_{i-1}(s_i d_i w_{i-1})^{-1}s_i y_i for i=0,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1i = 0, \ldots, k-1, then take w n=w k‚àí1(s n‚àí1d nwk‚àí1) ‚àí1s n‚àí1y nw_n = w_{k-1}(s_{n-1}d_nw_{k-1})^{-1}s_{n-1}y_n, and finally a downwards induction given by w i=w i+1(s i‚àí1d iw i+1) ‚àí1s i‚àí1y iw_i = w_{i+1}(s_{i-1}d_{i}w_{i+1})^{-1}s_{i-1}y_i, for i=n,‚Ä¶,k+1i = n, \ldots, k+1, then w k+1w_{k+1} gives d iw k+1=y id_{i}w_{k+1} = y_i for i‚â†ki \neq k;

  3. if k=nk=n:

    • use w 0=s 0y 0w_0 = s_0 y_0 and w i=w i‚àí1(s id iw i‚àí1) ‚àí1s iy iw_i = w_{i-1}(s_i d_i w_{i-1})^{-1}s_i y_i for i=0,‚Ä¶,n‚àí1i = 0, \ldots, n-1, then w n‚àí1w_{n-1} satisfies d iw n‚àí1=y id_i w_{n-1} = y_i, i‚â†ni\neq n.

Geometric realization

So far we we have considered passing from topological spaces to simplicial sets by applying the singular simplicial complex functor of def. 67. Now we discuss a left adjoint of this functor, called geometric realization, which turns a simplicial set into a topological space by identifying each of its abstract n-simplices with the standard topological nn-simplex.

This is an example of a general abstract phenomenon:

Proposition

Let

Œ¥:D‚ü∂ùíû \delta \;\colon\; D \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}

be a functor from a small category DD to a locally small category ùíû\mathcal{C} with all colimits. Then the nerve-functor

N:ùíû‚ü∂[D op,Set] N \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow [D^{op}, Set]
N(X)‚âîùíû(Œ¥(‚àí),X) N(X) \coloneqq \mathcal{C}(\delta(-),X)

has a left adjoint functor |‚àí|{\vert-\vert}, called geometric realization,

(|‚àí|‚ä£N):ùíû‚ü∂N‚üµ|‚àí|[D op,Set] ({\vert-\vert} \dashv N) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \stackrel{\overset{{\vert-\vert}}{\longleftarrow}}{\underset{N}{\longrightarrow}} [D^{op}, Set]

given by the coend

|S|=‚à´ d‚ààDŒ¥(d)‚ãÖS(d). {\vert S\vert} = \int^{d \in D} \delta(d) \cdot S(d) \,.

(Kan 58)

Proof

By basic propeties of ends and coends:

[D op,Set](S,N(X)) =‚à´ d‚ààDSet(S(d),N(X)(d)) =‚à´ d‚ààDSet(S(d),ùíû(Œ¥(d),X)) ‚âÉ‚à´ d‚ààDùíû(Œ¥(d)‚ãÖS(d),X) ‚âÉùíû(‚à´ d‚ààDŒ¥(d)‚ãÖS(d),X) =ùíû(|S|,X). \begin{aligned} [D^{op}, Set](S,N(X)) & = \int_{d \in D} Set(S(d), N(X)(d)) \\ & = \int_{d\in D} Set(S(d), \mathcal{C}(\delta(d),X)) \\ & \simeq \int_{d \in D} \mathcal{C}(\delta(d) \cdot S(d), X) \\ & \simeq \mathcal{C}(\int^{d \in D} \delta(d) \cdot S(d), X) \\ & = \mathcal{C}({\vert S\vert}, X) \,. \end{aligned}
Example

The singular simplicial complex functor SingSing of def. 67 has a left adjoint geometric realization functor

|‚àí|:sSet‚ü∂Top {\vert-\vert} \colon sSet \longrightarrow Top

given by the coend

|S|=‚à´ [n]‚ààŒîŒî n‚ãÖS n. {\vert S \vert} = \int^{[n]\in \Delta} \Delta^n \cdot S_n \,.

Topological geometric realization takes values in particularly nice topological spaces.

Proposition

The topological geometric realization of simplicial sets in example 65 takes values in CW-complexes.

(e.g. Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, prop. 2.3)

Thus for a topological space XX the adjunction counit œµ X:|SingX|‚ü∂X\epsilon_X \colon {\vert Sing X\vert} \longrightarrow X of the nerve and realization-adjunction is a candidate for a replacement of XX by a CW-complex. For this, œµ X\epsilon_X should be at least a weak homotopy equivalence, i.e. induce isomorphisms on all homotopy groups. Since homotopy groups are built from maps into XX out of compact topological spaces it is plausible that this works if the topology of XX is entirely detected by maps out of compact topological spaces into XX. Topological spaces with this property are called compactly generated.

We take compact topological space to imply Hausdorff topological space.

Definition

A subspace U‚äÇXU \subset X of a topological space XX is called compactly open or compactly closed, respectively, if for every continuous function f:K‚ü∂Xf \colon K \longrightarrow X out of a compact topological space the preimage f ‚àí1(U)‚äÇKf^{-1}(U) \subset K is open or closed, respectively.

A topological space XX is a compactly generated topological space if each of its compactly closed subspaces is already closed.

Write

Top cg‚Ü™Top Top_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top

for the full subcategory of Top on the compactly generated topological spaces.

Often the condition is added that a compactly closed topological space be also a weakly Hausdorff topological space.

Example

Examples of compactly generated topological spaces, def. 88, include

  • every compact space;

  • every locally compact space;

  • every topological manifold;

  • every CW-complex;

  • every first countable space

Corollary

The topological geometric realization functor of simplicial sets in example 65 takes values in compactly generated topological spaces
