|‚àí|:sSet‚ü∂Top cg {\vert - \vert} \;\colon\; sSet \longrightarrow Top_{cg}
Proof

By example 66 and prop. 87.

Proposition

The subcategory Top cg‚Ü™TopTop_{cg} \hookrightarrow Top of def. 88 has the following properties

  1. It is a coreflective subcategory

    Top cg‚üµk‚Ü™Top. Top_{cg} \stackrel{\hookrightarrow}{\underset{k}{\longleftarrow}} Top \,.

    The coreflection k(X)k(X) of a topological space is given by adding to the open subsets of XX all compactly open subsets, def. 88.

  2. It has all small limits and colimits.

    The colimits are computed in TopTop, the limits are the image under kk of the limits as computed in TopTop.

  3. It is a cartesian closed category.

    The cartesian product in Top cgTop_{cg} is the image under kk of the Cartesian product formed in TopTop.

This is due to (Steenrod 67), expanded on in (Lewis 78, appendix A). One says that prop. 64 with example 66 makes Top cgTop_{cg} a ‚Äúconvenient category of topological spaces‚Äù.

Proposition

Regarded, via corollary 9 as a functor |‚àí|:sSet‚ÜíTop cg{\vert - \vert} \colon sSet \to Top_{cg}, geometric realization preserves finite limits.

See at Geometric realization is left exact.

Proof idea

The key step in the proof is to use the cartesian closure of Top cgTop_{cg} (prop. 64). This gives that the Cartesian product is a left adjoint and hence preserves colimits in each variable, so that the coend in the definition of the geometric realization may be taken out of Cartesian products.

Lemma

The geometric realization, example 65, of a minimal Kan fibration, def. 76 is a Serre fibration, def. 76.

This is due to (Gabriel-Zisman 67). See for instance (Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, corollary 10.8, theorem 10.9).

Proof idea

By prop. 28 minimal Kan fibrations are simplicial fiber bundles, locally trivial over each simplex in the base. By prop. 65 this property translates to their geometric realization also being a locally trivial fiber bundle of topological spaces, hence in particular a Serre fibration.

Proposition

The geometric realization, example 65, of any Kan fibration, def. 75 is a Serre fibration, def. 76.

This is due to (Quillen 68). See for instance (Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, theorem 10.10).

Proposition

For SS a Kan complex, then the unit of the nerve and realization-adjunction (prop. 63, example 65)

S‚ü∂Sing|S| S \longrightarrow Sing {\vert S \vert}

is a weak homotopy equivalence, def. 72.

For XX any topological space, then the adjunction counit

|SingX|‚ü∂X {\vert Sing X\vert} \longrightarrow X

is a weak homotopy equivalence

e.g. (Goerss-Jardine 99, chapter I, prop. 11.1 and p. 63).

Proof idea

Use prop. 53 and prop. 66 applied to the path fibration to proceed by induction.

\,

The classical model structure on simplicial sets

Definition

(classical model structure on simplicial sets)

The classical model structure on simplicial sets, sSet QuillensSet_{Quillen}, has the following distinguished classes of morphisms:

  • The classical weak equivalences WW are the morphisms whose geometric realization, example 65, is a weak homotopy equivalence of topological spaces;

  • The classical fibrations FF are the Kan fibrations, def. 75;

  • The classical cofibrations CC are the monomorphisms of simplicial sets, i.e. the degreewise injections.

Proposition

In model structure sSet QuillensSet_{Quillen}, def. 88, the following holds.

  • The fibrant objects are precisely the Kan complexes.

  • A morphism f:X‚ÜíYf : X \to Y of fibrant simplicial sets / Kan complexes is a weak equivalence precisely if it induces an isomorphism on all simplicial homotopy groups, def. 70.

  • All simplicial sets are cofibrant with respect to this model structure.

Proposition

The acyclic fibrations in sSet QuillensSet_{Quillen}(i.e. the maps that are both fibrations as well as weak equivalences) between Kan complexes are precisely the morphisms f:X‚ÜíYf : X \to Y that have the right lifting property with respect to all inclusions ‚àÇŒî[n]‚Ü™Œî[n]\partial \Delta[n] \hookrightarrow \Delta[n] of boundaries of nn-simplices into their nn-simplices

‚àÇŒî[n] ‚Üí X ‚Üì ‚àÉ‚Üó ‚Üì f Œî[n] ‚Üí Y. \array{ \partial \Delta[n] &\to& X \\ \downarrow &{}^\exists\nearrow& \downarrow^f \\ \Delta[n] &\to& Y } \,.

This appears spelled out for instance as (Goerss-Jardine 99, theorem 11.2).

In fact:

Proposition

sSet QuillensSet_{Quillen} is a cofibrantly generated model category with

  • generating cofibrations the boundary inclusions ‚àÇŒî[n]‚ÜíŒî[n]\partial \Delta[n] \to \Delta[n];

  • generating acyclic cofibrations the horn inclusions Œõ i[n]‚ÜíŒî[n]\Lambda^i[n] \to \Delta[n].

Theorem

Let WW be the smallest class of morphisms in sSetsSet satisfying the following conditions:

  1. The class of monomorphisms that are in WW is closed under pushout, transfinite composition, and retracts.
  2. WW has the two-out-of-three property in sSetsSet and contains all the isomorphisms.
  3. For all natural numbers nn, the unique morphism Œî[n]‚ÜíŒî[0]\Delta [n] \to \Delta [0] is in WW.

Then WW is the class of weak homotopy equivalences.

Proof
  • First, notice that the horn inclusions Œõ 0[1]‚Ü™Œî[1]\Lambda^0 [1] \hookrightarrow \Delta [1] and Œõ 1[1]‚Ü™Œî[1]\Lambda^1 [1] \hookrightarrow \Delta [1] are in WW.
  • Suppose that the horn inclusion Œõ k[m]‚Ü™Œî[m]\Lambda^k [m] \hookrightarrow \Delta [m] is in WW for all m<nm \lt n and all 0‚â§k‚â§m0 \le k \le m. Then for 0‚â§l‚â§n0 \le l \le n, the horn inclusion Œõ l[n]‚Ü™Œî[n]\Lambda^l [n] \hookrightarrow \Delta [n] is also in WW.
  • Quillen‚Äôs small object argument then implies all the trivial cofibrations are in WW.
  • If p:X‚ÜíYp : X \to Y is a trivial Kan fibration, then its right lifting property implies there is a morphism s:Y‚ÜíXs : Y \to X such that p‚àòs=id Yp \circ s = id_Y, and the two-out-of-three property implies s:Y‚ÜíXs : Y \to X is a trivial cofibration. Thus every trivial Kan fibration is also in WW.
  • Every weak homotopy equivalence factors as p‚àòip \circ i where pp is a trivial Kan fibration and ii is a trivial cofibration, so every weak homotopy equivalence is indeed in WW.
  • Finally, noting that the class of weak homotopy equivalences satisfies the conditions in the theorem, we deduce that it is the smallest such class.

As a corollary, we deduce that the classical model structure on sSetsSet is the smallest (in terms of weak equivalences) model structure for which the cofibrations are the monomorphisms and the weak equivalences include the (combinatorial) homotopy equivalences.

Proposition

Let œÄ 0:sSet‚ÜíSet\pi_0 : sSet \to Set be the connected components functor, i.e. the left adjoint of the constant functor cst:Set‚ÜísSetcst : Set \to sSet. A morphism f:Z‚ÜíWf : Z \to W in sSetsSet is a weak homotopy equivalence if and only if the induced map

œÄ 0K f:œÄ 0K W‚ÜíœÄ 0K Z\pi_0 K^f : \pi_0 K^W \to \pi_0 K^Z

is a bijection for all Kan complexes KK.

Proof

One direction is easy: if KK is a Kan complex, then axiomS FOR simplicial model categories (Def. 93) implies the functor K (‚àí):sSet op‚ÜísSetK^{(-)} : sSet^{op} \to sSet is a right Quillen functor, so Ken Brown's lemma (Prop. 8) implies that it preserves all weak homotopy equivalences; in particular, œÄ 0K (‚àí):sSet op‚ÜíSet\pi_0 K^{(-)} : sSet^{op} \to Set sends weak homotopy equivalences to bijections.

Conversely, when KK is a Kan complex, there is a natural bijection between œÄ 0K X\pi_0 K^X and the hom-set Ho(sSet)(X,K)Ho (sSet) (X, K), and thus by the Yoneda lemma, a morphism f:Z‚ÜíWf : Z \to W such that the induced morphism œÄ 0K W‚ÜíœÄ 0K Z\pi_0 K^W \to \pi_0 K^Z is a bijection for all Kan complexes KK is precisely a morphism that becomes an isomorphism in Ho(sSet)Ho (sSet), i.e. a weak homotopy equivalence.

Theorem

The singular simplicial complex/geometric realization-adjunction of example 65 constitutes a Quillen equivalence between the classical model structure on simplicial sets sSet QuillensSet_{Quillen} of def. 88 and the classical model structure on topological spaces:

(|‚àí|‚ä£Sing):Top Quillen Q‚âÉ Q‚ü∂Sing‚üµ|‚àí|sSet Quillen ({\vert -\vert}\dashv Sing) \;\colon\; Top_{Quillen} \underoverset {\underset{Sing}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{{\vert -\vert}}{\longleftarrow}} {\phantom{{}_{Q}}\simeq_{Q}} sSet_{Quillen}
Proof

First of all, the adjunction is indeed a Quillen adjunction: prop. 53 says in particular that Sing(‚àí)Sing(-) takes Serre fibrations to Kan fibrations and prop. 87 gives that |‚àí|{\vert-\vert} sends monomorphisms of simplicial sets to relative cell complexes.

Now prop. 67 says that the derived adjunction unit and counit are weak equivalences, and hence the Quillen adjunction is a Quillen equivalence.

\,

Basic notions of higher topos theory

Locally presentable (‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-Categories

The analog of the notion of locally presentable categories (Def. \ref{LocallyPresentableCategory}) for model categories are combinatorial model categories (Def. 90) below. In addition to the ordinary condition of presentability of the underlying category, these are required to be cofibrant generation (Def. 89 below) in that all cofibrations are retracts of relative cell complex-inclusions.

That this is indeed the correct model category-analog of locally presentable categories is the statement of Dugger's theorem (Def. 76 below).

Hence as we pass to the localization of the very large category of combinatorial model categories at the Quillen equivalences, we obtain a homotopy-theoretic refinement of the very large category PrCat of locally presentable categories: Ho(CombModCat) (Def. 92). An object in Ho(CombModCat) we also refer to as a locally presentable (‚àû,1)-category, and a morphism in Ho(CombModCat) we also refer to as the equivalence class of an (‚àû,1)-colimit-preserving (‚àû,1)-functor.

\,

Definition

(cofibrantly generated model category)

A model category ùíû\mathcal{C} (def. 1) is called cofibrantly generated if there exists two small subsets

I,J‚äÇMor(ùíû) I, J \subset Mor(\mathcal{C})

of its class of morphisms, such that

  1. II and JJ have small domains according to def. 6,

  2. the (acyclic) cofibrations of ùíû\mathcal{C} are precisely the retracts, of II-relative cell complexes (JJ-relative cell complexes), def. 37.

Proposition

For ùíû\mathcal{C} a cofibrantly generated model category, def. 89, with generating (acylic) cofibrations II (JJ), then its classes W,Fib,CofW, Fib, Cof of weak equivalences, fibrations and cofibrations are equivalently expressed as injective or projective morphisms (def. 2) this way:

  1. Cof=(IInj)ProjCof = (I Inj) Proj

  2. W‚à©Fib=IInjW \cap Fib = I Inj;

  3. W‚à©Cof=(JInj)ProjW \cap Cof = (J Inj) Proj;

  4. Fib=JInjFib = J Inj;

Proof

It is clear from the definition that I‚äÇ(IInj)ProjI \subset (I Inj) Proj, so that the closure property of prop. 1 gives an inclusion

Cof‚äÇ(IInj)Proj. Cof \subset (I Inj) Proj \,.

For the converse inclusion, let f‚àà(IInj)Projf \in (I Inj) Proj. By the small object argument, prop. 4, there is a factorization f:‚ü∂‚ààICell‚ü∂IInjf\colon \overset{\in I Cell}{\longrightarrow}\overset{I Inj}{\longrightarrow}. Hence by assumption and by the retract argument lemma 2, ff is a retract of an II-relative cell complex, hence is in CofCof.

This proves the first statement. Together with the closure properties of prop. 1, this implies the second claim.

The proof of the third and fourth item is directly analogous, just with JJ replaced for II.

Definition

(combinatorial model category)

A combinatorial model category is a model category (Def. 1) which is

  1. locally presentable (Def. \ref{LocallyPresentableCategory})

  2. cofibrantly generated model category (Def. 89)

Example

(classical model structure on simplicial sets is combinatorial model category)

The classical model structure on simplicial sets (Def. 88) sSet QusSet_{Qu} is a combinatorial model category (Def. 90).

Example

(category of simplicial presheaves)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a small (Def. \ref{SmallCategory}) sSet-enriched category (Def. 55 with Example \ref{ExamplesOfCosmoi}) and consider the enriched presheaf category (Example \ref{EnrichedPresheaf})

sPSh(ùíû)‚âî[ùíû op,sSet] sPSh(\mathcal{C}) \;\coloneqq\; [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet]

This is called the category of simplicial presheaves on ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Proposition

(model categories of simplicial presheaves)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a small (Def. \ref{SmallCategory}) sSet-enriched category (Def. 55 with Example \ref{ExamplesOfCosmoi}). Then the category of simplicial presheaves [ùíû op,sSet][\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet] (Example 67) carries the following two structures of a model category (Def. 1)

  1. the projective model structure on simplicial presheaves

    [ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj}

    has as weak equivalences and fibrations those natural transformations Œ∑\eta whose component on every object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C} is a weak equivalences or fibration, respectively, in the classical model structure on simplicial sets (Def. 88);

  2. the injective model structure on simplicial presheaves

    [ùíû op,sSet Qu] inj [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{inj}

    has as weak equivalences and cofibrations those natural transformations Œ∑\eta whose component on every object c‚ààùíûc \in \mathcal{C} is a weak equivalences or cofibration, respectively, in the classical model structure on simplicial sets (Def. 88);

Example

(homotopy limit of simplicial sets)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. \ref{SmallCategory}) and consider the limit/colimit adjoint functors (Def. \ref{Limits}) with values in simplicial sets (Def. 65). These are Quillen adjunctions (Def. 16) for the injective/projective model structure on simplicial presheaves (Prop. 74), respectively:

[ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj‚ä• Qy‚üµAAconstAA‚ü∂lim‚ü∂sSet QuAAAA[ùíû op,sSet Qu] inj‚ä• Qy‚ü∂lim‚üµ‚üµAAconstAAsSet Qu. [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj} \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AA}const\phantom{AA}}{\longleftarrow}} {\overset{ \underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim} }{\longrightarrow}} {\bot_{Qy}} sSet_{Qu} \phantom{AAAA} [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{inj} \underoverset {\underset{ \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} }{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\phantom{AA}const\phantom{AA}}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot_{Qy}} sSet_{Qu} \,.

(Since constconst evidently preserves weak equivalences in any case, and preserves fibrations for the projective model structure and cofibrations for the injective model structure.)

The corresponding derived functors (Def. 15) are called

  • the homotopy limit functor

    ‚Ñùlim‚üµ:Ho([ùíû op,sSet Qu])‚ü∂Ho(sSet) \mathbb{R}\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim} \;\colon\; Ho([\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]) \longrightarrow Ho(sSet)

  • the homotopy colimit functor

    ‚Ñùlim‚ü∂:Ho([ùíû op,sSet Qu])‚ü∂Ho(sSet) \mathbb{R}\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim} \;\colon\; Ho([\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]) \longrightarrow Ho(sSet)

The following concept of left Bousfield localization is the analog for model categories of the concept of reflection onto local objects (Def. \ref{LocalizationAtACollectionOfMorphisms}):

Definition

(left Bousfield localization)

A left Bousfield localization ùíû loc\mathcal{C}_{loc} of a model category ùíû\mathcal{C} (Def. 1) is another model category structure on the same underlying category with the same cofibrations,

Cof loc=Cof Cof_{loc} = Cof

but more weak equivalences

W loc‚äÉW. W_{loc} \supset W \,.

We say that this is localization at W locW_{loc}.

Notice that:

Proposition

Given a left Bousfield localization ùíû loc\mathcal{C}_{loc} of ùíû\mathcal{C} as in def. 91, then

  1. Fib loc‚äÇFibFib_{loc} \subset Fib;

  2. W loc‚à©Fib loc=W‚à©FibW_{loc} \cap Fib_{loc} = W \cap Fib;

  3. the identity functors constitute a Quillen adjunction

    ùíû loc‚ä•‚ü∂id‚üµidùíû. \mathcal{C}_{loc} \underoverset {\underset{id}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{id}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C} \,.

  4. the induced adjunction of derived functors (Prop. 10) exhibits a reflective subcategory inclusion of homotopy categories (Def. 9)

    Ho(ùíû loc)‚ä•‚ü∂‚Ñùid‚üµùïÉidHo(ùíû). Ho(\mathcal{C}_{loc}) \underoverset {\underset{\mathbb{R} id}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\mathbb{L}id}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} Ho(\mathcal{C}) \,.
Proof

Regarding the first two items:

Using the properties of the weak factorization systems (def.) of (acyclic cofibrations, fibrations) and (cofibrations, acyclic fibrations) for both model structures we get

Fib loc =(Cof loc‚à©W loc)Inj ‚äÇ(Cof loc‚à©W)Inj =Fib \begin{aligned} Fib_{loc} &= (Cof_{loc} \cap W_{loc})Inj \\ &\subset (Cof_{loc} \cap W)Inj \\ & = Fib \end{aligned}

and

Fib loc‚à©W loc =Cof locInj =CofInj =Fib‚à©W. \begin{aligned} Fib_{loc} \cap W_{loc} & = Cof_{loc} Inj \\ & = Cof \, Inj \\ & = Fib \cap W \end{aligned} \,.

Regarding the third point:

By construction, id:ùíû‚Üíùíû locid \colon \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}_{loc} preserves cofibrations and acyclic cofibrations, hence is a left Quillen functor.

Regarding the fourth point:

Since Cof loc=CofCof_{loc} = Cof the notion of left homotopy in ùíû loc\mathcal{C}_{loc} is the same as that in ùíû\mathcal{C}, and hence the inclusion of the subcategory of local cofibrant-fibrant objects into the homotopy category of the original cofibrant-fibrant objects is clearly a full inclusion. Since Fib loc‚äÇFibFib_{loc} \subset Fib by the first statement, on these cofibrant-fibrant objects the right derived functor of the identity is just the identity and hence does exhibit this inclusion. The left adjoint to this inclusion is given by ùïÉid\mathbb{L}id, by the general properties of Quillen adjunctions (prop).

The following proposition says that Definition 90 of combinatorial model categories is indeed the suitable analog of Def. \ref{LocallyPresentableCategory} of locally presentable categories:

Proposition

(Dugger's theorem)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a combinatorial model category (Def. 90). Then there exists

  1. a small category ùíÆ\mathcal{S};

  2. a small set S‚äÇMor [ùíÆ op,sSet]S \subset Mor_{[\mathcal{S}^{op}, sSet]} in its category of simplicial presheaves (Example 67);

1 a Quillen equivalence (Def. 17)

[ùíÆ op,sSet Qu] proj,S Qu‚âÉ Qu‚ü∂AAAA‚üµùíû [\mathcal{S}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj,S} \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{}{\longleftarrow}} {\phantom{{}_{Qu}}\simeq_{Qu}} \mathcal{C}

between ùíû\mathcal{C} and the left Bousfield localization (Def. 91) of the projective model structure on simplicial presheaves over ùíû\mathcal{C} (Prop. 74) at the set SS.

Definition

(homotopy category of presentable (‚àû,1)-categories)

Write CombModCatCombModCat for the very large category whose objects are combinatorial model categories (Def. 90) and whose morphisms are left Quillen functors between them (Def. 16).

We write

Ho(CombModCat) ‚âîCombModCat[QuillenEquivs ‚àí1]\coloneqq CombModCat\big[ QuillenEquivs^{-1}\big]

for its localization (Def. \ref{LocalizationOfACategory}) at the Quillen equivalences (Def. 17).

We say:

  • an object in Ho(CombModCat) is a locally presentable (‚àû,1)-category,

  • a morphism in Ho(CombModCat) is the equivalence class of an(‚àû,1)-colimit-preserving (‚àû,1)-functor_;

  • an isomorphism in Ho(CombModCat) is an equivalence of (‚àû,1)-categories.

The following example is the genralization of the category of sets (Def. \ref{CategoryOfSets}) as we pass to homotopy theory:

Example

(‚àûGrpd)

The image of the classical model structure on simplicial sets sSet QusSet_{Qu} (Def. 88), which is combinatorial model category by example 73, under the localization to Ho(CombModCat) (Def. 92), we call the presentable (‚àû,1)-category of ‚àû-groupoids:

CombModCat ‚ü∂AAŒ≥AA Ho(CombModCat) sSet Qu ‚Ü¶ ‚àûGrpd \array{ CombModCat &\overset{\phantom{AA}\gamma\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}& Ho(CombModCat) \\ sSet_{Qu} &\mapsto& \infty Grpd }

In order to get good control over left Bousfield localization (Def. 91) and hence over presentable (‚àû,1)-categories (Def. 92) we need the analog of Prop. \ref{ReflectiveLocalizationGivenByLocalObjects}, saying that reflective localization are reflections onto their full subcategories of local objects. For this, in turn, we need a good handle on the hom-infinity-groupoids:

Definition

(simplicial model category)

An sSet Quillen{}_{Quillen}-enriched model category or simplicial model category, for short is a category ùíû\mathcal{C} (Def. \ref{Categories}) equipped with

  1. the structure of an sSet-enriched category (Def. 55 via Example 31), with sSet (Def. 65), equipped with its canonical structure of a cosmos from Prop. \ref{PropertiesOfSheafToposes}, Example \ref{ExamplesOfCosmoi}, and with compatible powering and copowering over sSet;

  2. the structure of a model category (Def. 1)

such that these two structures are compatible in the following way:

  • for every cofibration X‚ÜíYX \to Y and every fibration A‚ÜíBA \to B in ùíû\mathcal{C}, the induced pullback powering-morphism of hom-simplicial sets

    ùíû(Y,A)‚ü∂ùíû(X,A)√óùíû(X,B)ùíû(Y,B) \mathcal{C}(Y,A) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}(X,A) \underset{\mathcal{C}(X,B)}{\times} \mathcal{C}(Y,B)

    is a Kan fibration (Def. 75), and is a weak homotopy equivalence (Def. 72) as soon as one of the two morphisms is a weak equivalence in ùíû\mathcal{C}.

Proposition

(model structure on simplicial presheaves is left proper combinatorial simplicial model category)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a small (Def. \ref{SmallCategory}) sSet-enriched category (Def. 55 with Example \ref{ExamplesOfCosmoi}). Then the injective and projective model structure on simplicial presheaves over ùíû\mathcal{C} (Prop. 74)

[ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj,A[ùíû op,sSet Qu] inj‚ààCombModCat [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj} \;, \phantom{A} [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{inj} \;\;\; \in CombModCat

are

  1. proper model categories (Def. 21),

  2. simplicial model categories (Def. 93),

  3. combinatorial model categories (Def. 90).

Definition

(derived hom-functor)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a simplicial model category (Def. 93). Then the right derived functor (Def. 15) of the enriched hom-functor is called the derived hom-functor

‚ÑùHom:Ho(ùíû op√óùíû)‚ü∂Ho(sSet Quillen) \mathbb{R}Hom \;\colon\; Ho(\mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C}) \longrightarrow Ho(sSet_{Quillen})

In the presence of functorial cofibrant resolution QQ and fibrant resolution PP (Def. 10) this is given by the ordinary enriched hom-functor ùíû(‚àí,‚àí)\mathcal{C}(-,-) as

‚ÑùHom(X,Y)‚âÉùíû(QX,PY). \mathbb{R}Hom(X,Y) \;\simeq\; \mathcal{C}(Q X, P Y) \,.

The following is the model category-analog of the concept of local objects from Def. \ref{LocalObjects}:

Definition

(local objects and local morphisms in a model category)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a simplicial model category (Def. 93) and let S‚äÇMor ùíûS \subset Mor_{\mathcal{C}} be a sub-class of its class of morphisms. Then

  1. an object A‚ààùíûA \in \mathcal{C} is called a (derived-)local object if for every X‚ÜísY‚ààSX \overset{s}{\to} Y \; \in S the value of the derived hom-functor (Def. 94) out of ss into XX is a weak equivalence (i.e. an isomorphism in the classical homotopy category Ho(sSet)Ho(sSet))

    ‚ÑùHom(s,A):‚ÑùHom(Y,A)‚ü∂‚âÉ‚ÑùHom(X,A) \mathbb{R}Hom(s,A) \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}Hom(Y,A) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \mathbb{R}Hom(X,A)

  2. a morphism X‚ÜífYX \overset{f}{\to} Y in ùíû\mathcal{C} is called a (derived-)local morphism if for every local object AA we have

    ‚ÑùHom(f,A):‚ÑùHom(Y,A)‚ü∂‚âÉ‚ÑùHom(X,A) \mathbb{R}Hom(f,A) \;\colon\; \mathbb{R}Hom(Y,A) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \mathbb{R}Hom(X,A)

The following is the model category-analog of the characterization from Prop. \ref{ReflectiveLocalizationGivenByLocalObjects} of reflective localizations as reflections onto local objects:

Proposition

(existence of left Bousfield localization for left proper simplicial combinatorial model categories)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a combinatorial model category (Def. 90) which is left proper (Def. 21) and simplicial (Def. 93), and let S‚äÇMor ùíûS \subset Mor_{\mathcal{C}} be a small set of its morphisms.

Then the left Bousfield localization (Def. 91) of ùíû\mathcal{C} at SS, namely at the class of SS-local morphisms (Def. 1) exist, to be denoted L SùíûL_S \mathcal{C}, and it has the following properties:

  1. L SùíûL_S \mathcal{C} is itself a left proper simplicial combinatorial model category;

  2. the fibrant objects of L SmathcaCL_S \mathca{C} are precisely those fibrant objects of ùíû\mathcal{C} which in addition are SS-local objects (Def. 1).

Example

(homotopy localization of combinatorial model categories)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a combinatorial model category which, by Dugger's theorem (Prop. 76) is Quillen equivalent to a left Bousfield localization of a model category of simplicial presheaves over some small simplicial category ùíÆ\mathcal{S}.

Let moreover ùíú\mathcal{A} be any object. Then the homotopy localization of ùíû\mathcal{C} at ùî∏\mathbb{A} is the further left Bousfield localization at the morphisms of the form

X√óùî∏‚ü∂p 1X X \times \mathbb{A} \overset{p_1}{\longrightarrow} X

for all X‚ààùíÆX \in \mathcal{S}.

Proposition

(recognition of simplicial Quillen adjunctions)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} and ùíü\mathcal{D} be two simplicial model categories (Def. 93) such that ùíü\mathcal{D} is also a left proper model category (Def. 21). Then for an sSet-enriched adjunction (Def. \ref{EnrichedAdjunction}) of the form

ùíû‚ä•‚ü∂R‚üµAALAAùíü \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\phantom{AA}L\phantom{AA}}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

to be Quillen adjunction (Def. 16, hence a simplicial Quillen adjunction) it is sufficient that the following two conditions hold:

  1. LL preserves cofibrations,

  2. RR preserves fibrant objects

(i.e. this already implies that RR preserves all fibrations).

(Lurie HTT, cor. A.3.7.2)

(‚Ä¶)

\,

(‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-Toposes

The characterization of sheaf toposes as the left exact reflective localizations of presheaf toposes (Prop. \ref{SheafToposViaLexReflection}) now has an immediate generalization from the realm of locally presentable categories to that of combinatorial model categories and their corresponding locally presentable (‚àû,1)-categories (Def. 92): This yields concept of model toposes and (‚àû,1)-toposes (Def. 95 below).

\,

Definition

(model topos and (‚àû,1)-topos)

A combinatorial model category (Def. 90) is a model topos if it has a presentation via Dugger's theorem (Prop. 76)

(2)[ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj,S‚ä• Qu‚ü∂AAidAA‚üµid[ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj‚ààCombModCat [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj,S} \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AA}id\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{id}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot_{Qu}} [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj} \;\; \in CombModCat

such that the left derived functor ùïÉid\mathbb{L}id preserves finite homotopy limits.

We denote the image of such a combinatorial model category under the localization functor Œ≥\gamma in Ho(CombModCat) (Def. 92) by

Sh ‚àû(ùíû)‚âîŒ≥([ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj,S)‚ààHo(CombModCat) Sh_\infty(\mathcal{C}) \;\coloneqq\; \gamma([\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj,S}) \;\in\; Ho(CombModCat)

and call this an (‚àû,1)-topos over a site ùíû\mathcal{C}. Moreover, we denote the image of the defining Quillen adjunction (2) in Ho(CombModCat) by

Sh ‚àû(ùíû)‚ä•‚Ü™AAAA‚üµlexPSh ‚àû(ùíû)‚ààHo(CombModCat). Sh_\infty(\mathcal{C}) \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{lex}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} PSh_\infty(\mathcal{C}) \;\; \in Ho(CombModCat) \,.

The following construction generalizes the Cech groupoid (Example \ref{CechGroupoid}) as groupoids are generalized to Kan complexes (Def. 74):

Example

(Cech nerve)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a site (Def. \ref{Coverage}). Then for every object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} and every covering {U i‚ÜíŒπ iX}\{U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to}X\} there is a simplicial presheaf (Example 67)

C({U i})‚àà[ùíû op,sSet] C(\{U_i\}) \;\in\; [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet]

which in degree kk is given by the disjoint union of the kk-fold fiber products of presheaves over y(X)y(X) of the patches y(U i)‚àà[ùíû op,Set]y(U_i) \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] of the cover, regarded as presheaves under the Yoneda embedding (Prop. \ref{YonedaEmbedding})

C({U i}) k‚âî‚àêi 1,‚ãØ,i ky(U i 1)√ó y(X)y(U i 2)√ó y(X)‚ãØ√ó y(X)y(U i k). C(\{U_i\})_k \;\coloneqq\; \underset{i_1, \cdots, i_k}{\coprod} y(U_{i_1}) \times_{y(X)} y(U_{i_2}) \times_{y(X)} \cdots \times_{y(X)} y(U_{i_k}) \,.

The face maps are the evident projection morphisms, and the degeneracy maps the evident diagonal morphisms.

This is called the Cech nerve of the given cover.

By the definition of fiber products there is a canonical morphism of simplicial presheaves from the Cech nerve to y(X)y(X)

(3)C({U i})‚ü∂p {U i}y(X) C(\{U_i\}) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}}}{\longrightarrow} y(X)

The following is the generalization of Prop. \ref{CechGroupoidCoRepresents}, saying that Cech nerves are codescent-objects for (‚àû,1)-sheaves:

Proposition

(topological localization)

Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a site (Def. \ref{Coverage}) and let

S‚âî{C({U i})‚ü∂p {U i}y(X)|{U i‚ÜíŒπ iX} icovering}‚äÇMor [ùíû op,sSet] S \;\coloneqq\; \big\{ C(\{U_i\}) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}}}{\longrightarrow} y(X) \;\vert\; \{U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X\}_i \; \text{covering} \big\} \subset Mor_{[\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet]}

be the set of projections (3) out of the Cech nerves (Example \ref{example}) for coverings of all objects in the site, as a subset of the class of morphisms of simplicial presheaves over ùíû\mathcal{C} (Example 67)

Then the left Bousfield localization (Def. 78) of the projective model structure on simplicial presheaves (Prop. 74), to be denoted

[ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj,loc‚ä• Qu‚ü∂AAidAA‚üµid[ùíû op,sSet Qu] proj [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj, loc} \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AA}id\phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{id}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot_{Qu}} [\mathcal{C}^{op}, sSet_{Qu}]_{proj}

is left exact, in that it exhibits a model topos according to Def. 95, hence in that its image in Ho(CombModCat) is an (‚àû,1)-topos

Sh ‚àû(ùíû)‚ä•‚Ü™AAŒπAA‚üµlexPSh ‚àû(ùíû). Sh_\infty(\mathcal{C}) \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AA}\iota\phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{lex}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} PSh_\infty(\mathcal{C}) \,.

(‚Ä¶)
